webTitle: National Trust upholds stag hunting ban

fields.headline: National Trust upholds stag hunting ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: The ban on stag hunting will continue on National Trust lands, the organisation's ruling council has decided after considering the Burns report on hunting.
fields.body:
The ban on stag hunting will continue on National Trust lands, the organisation's ruling council has decided after considering the Burns report on hunting.

The decision ends the last hope of the deer hunts in the West Country to overturn the trust's ban, introduced in 1997 after an earlier report had condemned the sport as cruel.

Since then the hunters have taken on the trust in a protracted high court battle and commissioned their own study to try to show that the science in the original Bateson report on cruelty was flawed.

Each time the trust has remained unmoved, but its council said in January that it would keep an open mind on new evidence and would consider the government-commissioned Burns report.

This report looked at the social, economic, conservation and animal welfare aspects of a ban on hunting with hounds, but the trust decided yesterday that the report did not alter the basis on which it had developed its field sports policy.

Stag hunting remains banned but other field sports including fox hunting, shooting and fishing can continue, unless the government bans them.

In the statement the council said: "The National Trust is very much aware of the importance of countryside traditions.

"It allows field sports to take place on its property where traditionally practised, providing they are within the law and are compatible with the trust's purposes, which include public access and the protection of rare animals and birds and fragile habitats.

"The trust is a charitable body, and as such cannot take a political position either for or against field sports."

Relations with the stag hunting fraternity have continued to deteriorate since the ban, with allegations that the hunters have been trespassing on trust land.

Ten days ago the master of the Quantock staghounds, Paddy Groves, was forced to apologise to the trust and give a written undertaking that the Quantock staghounds would not trespass in future.

The apology followed a trespass at Shervage wood in Somerset on September 4, when the International Fund for Animal Welfare videoed the hunt and provided evidence that the Quantock staghounds had broken the ban.

The trust consulted its lawyers and would have taken the hunt to court seeking an injunction to prevent another trespass if it had not received an apology and an undertaking it would not happen again.

The trust said at the time: "We have taken this firm and decisive action to protect the welfare of the red deer on our land."

Yesterday a spokesman in London said the trust hoped that the battle over hunting was now entirely a matter for the government.

fields.headline: Police inquiry into hospital 'mercy killings'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A hospital consultant is being investigated by police over allegations of up to 10 cases of mercy killing, following an internal inquiry at the hospital where she works.
fields.body:
A hospital consultant is being investigated by police over allegations of up to 10 cases of mercy killing, following an internal inquiry at the hospital where she works.

The doctor, who has not been named, has been suspended from the Basildon hospital in Essex.

The allegations relate to the overprescription of drugs. Up to 10 patients are thought to have been given lethal doses of pain killers. All the patients are thought to have been elderly and terminally ill. None was a child.

Essex police said they "are investigating allegations made against a doctor from the Basildon and Thurrock general hospitals NHS trust concerning inappropriate use of medicines on seriously ill patients.

"The police were called in by the trust following concerns raised by an internal investigation. The doctor is currently suspended."

The hospital carried out an internal inquiry after a colleague raised concerns about the amount of painkillers the doctor had been prescribing.

The case is likely to highlight again the difficult and emotive issues involved in treating people who are terminally ill and may be in severe pain.

The British Medical Association has drawn up guidelines which bar doctors from euthanasia or from helping patients to end their lives, but there have been heated debates every time the issues have arisen.

Two years ago, the BMA conference demanded that its leadership hold a major consultation exercise within the profession. Some doctors wanted to reserve the right to help their patients kill themselves, but the consensus was that it was neither safe nor consistent with a doctor's duty to heal and save life.

The guidelines for doctors now state: "The BMA recognises that some doctors, having exhausted all other possibilities for ensuring a patient's comfort, may see the deliberate termination of life as the only solution in an individual case.

"Nevertheless, the BMA maintains that in such circumstances, the doctor should be accountable to the law and to the General Medical Council and be obliged to defend such an action."

Many doctors will admit privately that they have helped a patient who is in pain to die. Sometimes it may happen inadvertently. Giving a very high dose of painkillers to a terminally ill patient will block the pain, but may shorten the patient's life.

One GP, David Moor, was acquitted of carrying out a mercy killing in May last year. He admitted giving an 85-year- old cancer patient, George Liddell, a large dose of diamorphine, but successfully argued that his intention had been to stop the pain, not to kill.

He said after his acquittal: "Given a situation like George Liddell I would take exactly the same decision, manage the whole harrowing experience in the same way, and walk out of the house with a clear conscience."

The case became something of a cause celebre after Dr Moor was reported to have said he had helped 300 of his patients to die. He later denied the claim in court. In the end, the issue of euthanasia was not put on trial as some had hoped because of Dr Moor's insistence that death was coincidental.

"Doctors who treat dying patients to relieve their pain and suffering walk a tightrope to achieve this," the GP said.

webTitle: EU says it will keep pledge to rebuild in Serbia

fields.headline: EU says it will keep pledge to rebuild
fields.standfirst:
Embargoes soon to fall, but flow of aid could be slower
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The European Union is ready to plough millions of pounds worth of aid into Serbia to shore up its new democratic government.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
The European Union is ready to plough millions of pounds worth of aid into Serbia to shore up its new democratic government.

Most of the EU sanctions imposed against the country are to be lifted on Monday. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said yesterday that it was time to be generous. A Foreign Office official said there had been discussion in Brussels yesterday about investment, adding: "We need to crack on."

But the EU record on investment is poor: on average, projects wait three years from the time money is committed. The average time rises to nine years when the projects involve Mediterranean states.

Kosovo province in Serbia is still awaiting the restoration of its power station, in spite of promises by the UN to pour money in to rebuild its infrastructure damaged in last year's war.

Mr Cook, euphoric over this week's ousting of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, said that while European spending ministers were re luctant to part with cash, substantial amounts had already been budgeted within the EU for helping Serbia, which with Montenegro makes up Yugoslavia.

He said: "It is important that we get some visible projects to demonstrate to the people of Serbia that things are now different."

Top of his list was opening up the Danube for navigation. He also suggested rebuilding the bridges bombed by Nato last year and the provision of food and other relief supplies over the winter.

Foreign ministers meeting in Luxembourg on Monday are expected to lift the oil embargo against Serbia, and end the ban on commercial flights to and from Yugoslavia.

But diplomats were worried that the Milosevic family and regime cronies might manage to get round a freeze on their assets. "We don't want a situation where some of the worst elements of the regime can get the money they've salted away and take it out of Serbia," the EU's external affairs commissioner, Chris Patten, said.

The UN-imposed arms embargo can be ended only by a UN security council resolution.

Monday's Luxembourg meeting is also expected to consider freeing up 2.3bn euros (currently £1.3bn) in economic aid which the EU had earmarked for Serbia in the next seven years if Mr Milosevic was thrown out.

The fear in Serbia's secessionist province of Kosovo is that western attention and cash will switch to Serbia proper, but Mr Patten said: "There cannot be any question of us trying to pay for what will be needed in Serbia out of what is being done for the Balkans as a whole."

Bernard Kouchner, the United Nations administrator in Kosovo, urged the international community not to be "diverted from the tasks at hand here in Kosovo".

The new Belgrade government and the west want Kosovo and Montenegro to remain part of Yugoslavia.

But ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, in which Serbs form only a small minority since last year's war, will press for independence. Montenegro might also think that the time is perfect to push for independence.

In a sign of the speed with which the EU wants to embrace the new government, the French president, Jacques Chirac, extended an invitation yesterday to the president-elect, Vojislav Kostunica, to attend a European Union summit in Biarritz next week. France holds the EU presidency. The union's 15 heads of government are expected to attend, including Tony Blair.

"I invited [Mr Kostunica] to study with him the aid that the European Union should provide to help a democratic Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to emerge," Mr Chirac said. "I confirmed to him that the Union will lift the sanctions imposed on his country."

But the EU record on investment is poor: on average, projects wait three years from the time money is committed. The average time rises to nine years when the projects involve Mediterranean states. Kosovo province in Serbia is still awaiting the restoration of its power station, in spite of promises by the UN to pour money in to rebuild its infrastructure damaged in last year's war. Mr Cook, euphoric over this week's ousting of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, said that while European spending ministers were re luctant to part with cash, substantial amounts had already been budgeted within the EU for helping Serbia, which with Montenegro makes up Yugoslavia. He said: "It is important that we get some visible projects to demonstrate to the people of Serbia that things are now different." Top of his list was opening up the Danube for navigation. He also suggested rebuilding the bridges bombed by Nato last year and the provision of food and other relief supplies over the winter. Foreign ministers meeting in Luxembourg on Monday are expected to lift the oil embargo against Serbia, and end the ban on commercial flights to and from Yugoslavia. But diplomats were worried that the Milosevic family and regime cronies might manage to get round a freeze on their assets. "We don't want a situation where some of the worst elements of the regime can get the money they've salted away and take it out of Serbia," the EU's external affairs commissioner, Chris Patten, said. The UN-imposed arms embargo can be ended only by a UN security council resolution. Monday's Luxembourg meeting is also expected to consider freeing up 2.3bn euros (currently £1.3bn) in economic aid which the EU had earmarked for Serbia in the next seven years if Mr Milosevic was thrown out. The fear in Serbia's secessionist province of Kosovo is that western attention and cash will switch to Serbia proper, but Mr Patten said: "There cannot be any question of us trying to pay for what will be needed in Serbia out of what is being done for the Balkans as a whole." Bernard Kouchner, the United Nations administrator in Kosovo, urged the international community not to be "diverted from the tasks at hand here in Kosovo". The new Belgrade government and the west want Kosovo and Montenegro to remain part of Yugoslavia. But ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, in which Serbs form only a small minority since last year's war, will press for independence. Montenegro might also think that the time is perfect to push for independence. In a sign of the speed with which the EU wants to embrace the new government, the French president, Jacques Chirac, extended an invitation yesterday to the president-elect, Vojislav Kostunica, to attend a European Union summit in Biarritz next week. France holds the EU presidency. The union's 15 heads of government are expected to attend, including Tony Blair. "I invited [Mr Kostunica] to study with him the aid that the European Union should provide to help a democratic Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to emerge," Mr Chirac said. "I confirmed to him that the Union will lift the sanctions imposed on his country."

webTitle: Cab driver held after striking gold

fields.headline: Cab driver held after striking gold
fields.trailText: A black-cab driver initially hailed as a hero was arrested yesterday after Matthew Pinsent's Olympic rowing gold medal was stolen.
fields.body:
A black-cab driver initially hailed as a hero was arrested yesterday after Matthew Pinsent's Olympic rowing gold medal was stolen.

Terry Sandford, 41, of Bexleyheath, Kent, was believed to be in custody at Heathrow last night after coming forward with the missing medal.

Earlier he had spoken to reporters from a layby on the M25, proudly telling them how he had had a stolen Olympic medal in his taxi and had reunited it with its owner.

He claimed that two people had thrust a moleskin bag containing the medal into his cab at traffic lights outside Heathrow and asked him to hand it to police. He said he had not realised its significance: "I just saw there was a letter on top of it addressed to Matthew Pinsent, and I didn't even know who he was."

He phoned Pinsent's agent, whose number appeared on the letter, and was asked urgently if the bag contained the medal. "I looked in a bluish box and, blow me, there it was," Mr Sandford said.

In a jibe at black cabs' rivals, he added: "I hope it shows people that their property is safe in black cabs as opposed to mini-cabs. Black-cab drivers always hand stuff in."

Before news of Mr Sandford's arrest came to light, Pinsent said: "I am enormously relieved and grateful to the taxi driver for returning the medal. I can't express in words what this morning has been like. I'm just pleased it is all over and it ended on a high note."

Pinsent, 29, had had a briefcase with the medal in it by his side at Heathrow yesterday morning when he met his girlfriend, Demetra Koutsoukos, 26, arriving from Canada. They had stopped for coffee when they noticed the briefcase was missing. "It was horrible," Pinsent said. "I was at the crying stage."

The rower, who was nearly left behind at Sydney airport on Sunday after losing his passport, added: "I was very angry with myself. We all know that out in public with a briefcase you have got to keep your wits about you.

"I didn't cry when I got the medal, but I've had more than a few cries in the last couple of hours."

webTitle: Festival criticised for inviting Ceausescu poet

fields.headline: Festival criticised for inviting Ceausescu poet
fields.trailText: A storm has arisen over an invitation to a Romanian apologist for communism to recite his works at a poetry festival in St Andrews today.
fields.body:
A storm has arisen over an invitation to a Romanian apologist for communism to recite his works at a poetry festival in St Andrews today.

Adrian Paunescu, a friend of Nicolae Ceausescu, will read poems praising the tyrant who was executed in the 1989 revolution that ended communist rule in Romania.

Organisers of the StAnza event, which also features readings from the Scottish poets Douglas Gunn and Robert Crawford, defended their decision to invite Paunescu.

In one poem, Paunescu wrote: "It is Ceausescu himself that introduced honour within the Communist party and the country/He rediscovered our history unadulterated to make us reach for the future in our dreams."

A StAnza organiser, Brian Johnstone, said Paunescu would play a small part in the four-day event. "This is a poetry festival; people are here because they are interested in his poems and not in his political leanings."

Others view Paunescu's inclusion as an affront. Since 1989 he has been a journalist, a children's author and a politician known for his nationalist and anti-western views.

"Paunescu wrote sycophantic odes about Ceausescu and organised mass rallies at which young people were dragooned into praising the dictator," said Tom Gallagher, author of Romania After Ceausescu. "Paunescu was a cultural commissar for the regime and he did very well out of it."

Amnesty International said it had no evidence, however, that the poet was involved in human rights violations.

Another StAnza organiser, Gavin Bowd, said: "Paunescu had an ambivalent relationship with the regime, but so did most intellectuals and this is now 10 years ago."

webTitle: New setback for catamaran as trial is scrapped

fields.headline: New setback for catamaran as trial is scrapped
fields.trailText: Pete Goss, the yachtsman who three years ago carried out one of the most legendary ocean rescues in the history of navigation, was humbled by the sea yesterday.
fields.body:
Pete Goss, the yachtsman who three years ago carried out one of the most legendary ocean rescues in the history of navigation, was humbled by the sea yesterday.

His £4m racing catamaran Team Philips lasted only 18 hours on a transatlantic trial voyage to New York. Then it had to limp back to Dartmouth, Devon, after a swaying movement in one of its masts aroused concern.

It was a second setback for Goss, who with a four-man crew is testing the vessel to compete in The Race, a non-stop round-the-world dash which starts from Barcelona on December 31. The race crosses some of the world's most battering waters in the south Atlantic.

If it is to compete, the catamaran has to be in Monaco by December to take part in a prologue to the event.

The embarrassment follows an earlier near-disaster on March 29 off the Isles of Scilly, when 40ft of the craft's port bow snapped off during initial sea trials, crippling the vessel.

The latest trial was planned to give the hi-tech Team Philips its toughest outing since then. Before setting off for New York, Goss called his departure "judgment day".

The 38-year-old ex-Royal Marine said before casting off: "I do not feel I am going out to see whether the bow will stay on or not. I am going out to see how much I can get out of a good boat.

"One has to be happy the boat has the integrity to take on the southern ocean - and to do that we need to put it through its paces."

But the new problem struck in the base of one mast at a speed of 20 knots. Announcing the disappointment, a team spokeswoman said: "Pete Goss decided to immediately stabilise the situation and thoroughly inspect the mast. The situation is not like last time. It is a bit of a blip."

The project's managing director, Mark Orr, said: "It is a teething problem. It is not like formula one where people can do all their testing behind closed doors. Team Philips is at the cutting edge of technology and design. We are out at sea for everyone to see."

The catamaran is due to be sailed up the river Dart to Totnes for engineers to examine the mast today. A chastened Goss said: "I think we will probably dump [the trial to] New York and use that time for the repairs. Once we find out the problem, we will know how long it will take to resolve it."

Goss's last return to shore in a round-the-world yacht was as a hero. During the 1997 single-handed Vendee Globe race, he turned his boat around in a southern ocean hurricane and navigated 160 miles with a recently ruptured elbow to rescue a wrecked French sailor, Raphael Dinelli, who was clinging to a liferaft.

At les Sables d'Olonne on the Bay of Biscay, 150,000 French men and women lined the harbour to salute him for his bravery in carrying out one of the epic maritime rescues. President Chirac awarded him the Legion d'Honneur and the Queen made him an MBE.

webTitle: Both Lieberman and Cheney keep it clean

fields.headline: Both Lieberman and Cheney keep it clean
fields.standfirst:
Civil TV debate between would-be vice-presidents declared 'best ever'

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Taylor called Danville, Kentucky, a "sleepy little town" when she made the film Raintree County there with Montgomery Clift in 1956. But on Thursday night the good citizens of Danville were treated to what was described by the CBS commentator Dan Rather as the best vice-presidential debate ever to have taken place.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Taylor called Danville, Kentucky, a "sleepy little town" when she made the film Raintree County there with Montgomery Clift in 1956. But on Thursday night the good citizens of Danville were treated to what was described by the CBS commentator Dan Rather as the best vice-presidential debate ever to have taken place.

While this may seem to be damning with faint praise, the debate between Joe Lieberman and Dick Cheney at the Centre College was certainly livelier and better humoured than that of their presidential counterparts two days earlier.

Again, no knock-out blow was delivered, but Mr Cheney gave the more self-confident and assured performance and even managed to lighten his image with some jokes. Commentators generally felt that the Republican candidate had managed to humanise himself and catch up with Mr Lieberman in the personal popularity stakes without necessarily swinging many votes.

Mr Lieberman started and ended by invoking his parents.

He said that his 85-year-old mother had told him before the debate: "Sweetheart, be positive and remember that I will love you no matter what your opponent says about you." He closed with a tearful reference to his late father, who had once worked night shifts on a bakery truck, and had taught that "in America, if you have faith and work hard and play by the rules there is nothing you cannot achieve".

Mr Cheney won some laughs in response to a tease from Mr Lieberman about how much better off he was after eight years of the Democrats - a reference to the millions Mr Cheney has made in the private sector.

"I can tell you, Joe, that the government had absolutely nothing to do with it," he said.

Mr Lieberman said that he could see his wife in the audience and thought she must be wishing that he, too, would go into the private sector. "I'm going to try and help you do that, Joe," Mr Cheney said.

They were asked by the moderator, Bernard Shaw, an African-American, to imagine themselves as black and to say what they would feel about being stopped by the police purely because of their colour.

Mr Lieberman said it made him want to "hit the wall... we can't tolerate it any more". Mr Cheney, who quoted Martin Luther King, said it "would make me extraordinarily angry", but said he would find it hard, as someone who had always been part of the majority, to understand properly what the experience was of a minority.

On the issue of gay rights and gay marriages, Mr Lieberman said that gay people were "as much children of the same awesome God as any of the rest of us", and he had an open mind on the issue of gay unions because he had friends in gay or lesbian partnerships who had pointed out "elements of unfairness".

Mr Cheney said: "We live in a free society and freedom means freedom for everybody... it's really no one else's business." He added, "I try to be open-minded about it as much as I can," and said he felt it was up to each state to decide how relationships were recognised.

Both eschewed personal attacks until the end of the 90-minute debate, when Mr Cheney took a sideswipe at Mr Lieberman for attending a Hollywood fundraiser at which a comedian made a joke about George W Bush's religion.

Mr Lieberman, who made frequent references to God - almost as frequent as his 18 references to "Al Gore and I" - deplored the joke but refrained from making any cracks about Mr Cheney.

Each referred to the other by his first name throughout and they paid fulsome compliments to one another.

While Mr Rather said that it was perhaps not a debate to listen to if you were operating heavy machinery, the general response was that it had been civilised, that it had shown Mr Cheney to be less of a conservative hardliner than his image, and had emphasised Mr Lieberman's tendency to make jokes to defuse a situation.

The Washington Post described it as "sober, detailed, polite", the Los Angeles Times as "smooth and low key" and the New York Times as like an "academic seminar". What Elizabeth Taylor would have made of it is another matter.

fields.headline: Fewer trains run on time
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The 25 train companies and Railtrack were yesterday told to stop a "substantial and severe slide" in punctuality, after figures revealed an alarming decline in performance.
fields.body:
The 25 train companies and Railtrack were yesterday told to stop a "substantial and severe slide" in punctuality, after figures revealed an alarming decline in performance.

Stewart Francis, chairman of the rail passengers' council, said the companies had to draw a line under the figures, which showed that the percentage of trains running on time fell on 21 of the 25 passsenger franchises.

Mr Francis expressed dismay that the decline had occurred over the three month summer period when fewer trains were running and said he was extremely concerned at what would happen this autumn.

"What actions are individual train operators taking to alleviate these problems?" he asked.

Railtrack's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, has already hinted that punctuality will suffer because of unusually heavy falls of leaves on the line.

The council is to ask the shadow strategic rail authority for a breakdown of the figures so it can identify where the problems are occurring. It said the authority should impose tougher controls over companies if their track record failed to meet its standards.

The worst performer was Great North Eastern Railways, whose punctuality fell by 9%. Only 77% of its trains ran to time.

fields.headline: The running mates' bottom line
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The role of second banana in the presidential race is a tricky one. While an imaginative choice of running mate may add bounce to a campaign, there is always the danger of a skeleton lurking in the closet.
fields.body:
The role of second banana in the presidential race is a tricky one. While an imaginative choice of running mate may add bounce to a campaign, there is always the danger of a skeleton lurking in the closet.

The two vice-presidential candidates squared up on Thursday night with Joe Lieberman ahead of Dick Cheney in the battle for votes.

Such had been the lacklustre performance of Mr Cheney up to then that a mischievous "urban myth" email had been suggesting that there were plans for him to withdraw from the race on health grounds and be replaced by Colin Powell or John McCain.

When Mr Lieberman was chosen, the focus was on the fact that he had been the most prominent Democrat in attacking the conduct of President Clinton in the Lewinsky affair.

He was also known as a critic of violence and sex in entertainment and as someone who spoke often of his Jewish faith.

The Gore team, in wooing the African-American vote, was also relieved to discover that as a 21-year-old student at Yale in 1963 Mr Lieberman had travelled to Mississippi to campaign for the rights of black voters.

He has proved a major plus for the Gore team and, so far, he has passed the financial test which so many of his predecessors failed. His personal accounts show that his and his wife's income last year was $336,201 and that he paid 23.5% income tax. Around 3% of their income goes to charity.

But Mr Lieberman has come under fire for continuing to stand for his Senate seat which, if elected vice-president, he would not be able to take up.

In contrast, although Mr Cheney's roles as White House chief of staff and defence secretary during 25 years in Washington gave the Bush ticket the bottom it had been lacking, this initial advantage appeared to wear off swiftly.

It emerged that he had often not bothered to vote in Texas elections; he received flak for praising Opec for driving up the price of oil in his role as chief executive of an energy services company, Halliburton; and his income of $4,423,289 last year was rather more difficult for the average American to digest.

Even more spectacularly, Mr Cheney went on to cash in his stake in Halliburton and make a $20.6m profit.

webTitle: Delay in disclosing dental HIV risk defended

fields.headline: Delay in disclosing dental HIV risk defended
fields.standfirst: Special report: NHS
fields.trailText: Essex health authorities waited more than six months before telling 5,000 patients by letter yesterday of a small risk that they might have been infected with HIV during treatment at dental surgeries in three of the county's main towns.
fields.body:
Essex health authorities waited more than six months before telling 5,000 patients by letter yesterday of a small risk that they might have been infected with HIV during treatment at dental surgeries in three of the county's main towns.

Public health officials said they had decided against making an earlier announcement because they wanted first to mount "a major look-back exercise" to identify all the patients who had come into contact with the infected health worker over the previous 12 years.

Paul Watson, director of public health for north Essex, said the operation to check rigorously through the relevant dental practice records was the biggest of its kind undertaken in Britain.

The north Essex and south Essex authorities were told in March that a healthcare worker looking after patients at surgeries in Colchester, Clacton and Southend had tested positive for HIV.

"We are expecting thousands of people to call our helpline, afraid that they might have been affected. Had we made an announcement in March that number could have run into millions and caused a lot of unnecessary panic."

"I would expect the authority to inform patients at the surgeries that they may be at risk immediately. By waiting this long, they are only going to cause more panic and concern," he said.

A non-official source at north Essex health authority said: "We have been overwhelmed by the number of calls. People are naturally very concerned."

Dr Watson said the chances of patients being infected with HIV while they received treatment were "minuscule, but we do feel that people should be informed and offered a confidential test if they want it".

In north Essex about 5,000 patients were notified by letters posted on Thursday. Helplines were set up offering counselling and the opportunity to take a simple saliva test for HIV.

In south Essex nearly 100 people were notified and offered the same facilities.

webTitle: Past is not enough for modern Poland

fields.headline: Past is not enough for modern Poland
fields.standfirst: Lech Walesa won the fight against communism in the 80s, but is failing to win over voters in 2000
fields.trailText: "I'd prefer to go fishing, pick mushrooms, or have fun with my wife, rather than this," Lech Walesa maintains. He is sitting in an armchair in a pair of blue quilted slippers, answering questions on an internet chatline in his office in Warsaw.
fields.body:
"I'd prefer to go fishing, pick mushrooms, or have fun with my wife, rather than this," Lech Walesa maintains. He is sitting in an armchair in a pair of blue quilted slippers, answering questions on an internet chatline in his office in Warsaw.

An assistant fastens his tie. Now and then a woman comes in with more herbal tea. Then the chatline coordinator announces that the site has only received 400 hits.

"That's not good," Mr Walesa says, shaking his head. "Am I wasting my time?"

It is the last day of campaigning in the Polish presidential election and - despite having secured a hero's place in European history as the leader of the Solidarity movement, which took Poland out of communism and into democracy - Mr Walesa is not satisfied enough to sit back, whatever he may say about fishing.

Rather, he hopes the election will restore his past glories by making him president for the second time.

But the former Gdansk shipyard electrician is almost certain to go down to a humiliating defeat.

Standing under the slogan "Black is black and white is white" (black symbolising the ex-communists in power), Mr Walesa, 57, says he is driven by the stubborn belief that he can reshape Polish life.

"I owe a lot to the nation," he says.

"When the country is in trouble, as it is now, I must put myself at the people's disposal. Maybe not now, but tomorrow they will come knocking at my door. I will be there and they will not be able to say I have forsaken them.

"If they reject me that's OK, they can do that. But I can't reject them."

It is the tone of the parental martyr implicitly chastising neglectful children. And there are other characters in the Walesa political repertoire - such as the revolutionary who cannot give up the cause even though it has been won.

"I will continue the fight against communism until they hammer the last nail into my coffin - the grain has to die in order for something new to be reborn," he says, banging his fist on the table and adding that if he does not succeed he will stand a third time for the largely a ceremonial post.

Having chased away communist rule, Mr Walesa became president in 1990. At the election five years later he lost by just 3.5% to Aleksander Kwasniewski, 46, a younger, slicker figure who was sports minister when the Communist party ruled.

Now the narrow vote gap between them has deepened to a chasm. Support for President Kwasniewski - under whom Poland has become central Europe's economic powerhouse and looks likely to join the EU within four years - stands at between 52% and 55%.

Mr Walesa sees himself as "blamed for the pain of transition": opinion surveys give him a popularity rating of just 2%. He has scarcely been mentioned in the election campaign.

He is standing as an independent, having been rejected even by the ruling Solidarity bloc. It, too, faces a humiliating defeat.

The campaign has been lacklustre. But it has been peppered with western-style dirty tricks, mainly thanks to Marian Krzaklewski, 50, the candidate from the Solidarity-AWS alliance of trade unions and Catholic parties who is widely considered to be the brains behind the government.

Despite Mr Walesa's claim that he is "still my friend", Mr Krzaklewski is one of the politicians responsible for squeezing Mr Walesa out of the Solidarity bloc.

In August there was brief excitement when they had to defend themselves in a Warsaw court after rivals accused them of having collaborated with the communist secret police. Both were cleared.

Last month Mr Kwasniewski suffered a blow which some believed might fell him, when his campaign broadcast showed his national security adviser, Marek Siwiec, parodying the Pope by kissing the soil as he left a helicopter during a 1997 presidential trip.

It upset much of the electorate in the predominantly Roman Catholic country and, as Mr Siwiec's boss Mr Kwasniewski suffered a drop of 5-10 percentage points in his popular support.

Despite such setbacks, the only unknown in tomorrow's vote is how big tMr Kwasniewski's victory will be over the 11 rightwing and centrist candidates.

Much of the success of the communist-turned-social democrat - described by Mr Walesa as a "well dressed scarecrow who uses Goebbels-style techniques" - is put down to his ability to epitomise modern Poland.

In 1995 image makers from Poland and France were recruited to dress him in designer suits, polish up his communication skills and turn him into one of central Europe's first US-style politicians.

Post-communist Poland likes style and aspires to success.

"Kwasniewski is slick, funny and speaks foreign languages, as opposed to Walesa, who wears scuffed shoes and speaks awful Polish," says Malgorzata Jatkowska, 30, a film school student at Lodz in central Poland.

Respect still attaches to Mr Walesa's past role, but today he is seen as too dogmatic and haphazard.

"Churchill was a good wartime leader, but proved hopeless in peace time, and it's the same with Walesa," said a bookseller in Warsaw.

But Mr Walesa says he has not yet had a chance to prove what he can do.

"I always expected I'd be elected for a second term," he says. "So I've only realised half my plan and there is still a lot of evil to get rid of."

fields.headline: Woman wins £345,000 for 'cancer' hell
fields.trailText: A former nurse who underwent a series of devastating operations after being wrongly diagnosed with breast cancer was awarded £345,222 in damages yesterday at the high court in London.
fields.body:
A former nurse who underwent a series of devastating operations after being wrongly diagnosed with breast cancer was awarded £345,222 in damages yesterday at the high court in London.

East London and the City health authority admitted liability for the misdiagnosis at the Royal London hospital that led Jennifer Cormack, 63, to undergo a series of operations that left her feeling "mutilated".

Mrs Cormack, from Kenninghall, Norwich, was diagnosed in 1985 but was not told of the error until 1994, by which time she had had a double mastectomy, a hysterectomy, and numerous other operations.

Outside the court, she said: "I am very very relieved the ordeal is over and I sincerely hope the hospital disciplinary procedures will duly take place." She had felt "disbelief and anger" when told of the misdiagnosis. "I suffered nine years of hell."

Mrs Cormack is considering lodging a complaint with the General Medical Council.

The payout comes after the health authority admitted liability and the extent of the injuries earlier this week. Initially it had claimed the diagnosis was correct, then that the double mastectomy was justified as a prophylactic measure.

These arguments were abandoned and on the second day of the hearing a "derisory" settlement offer was rejected by Mrs Cormack's lawyers.

Giving his ruling yesterday, Mr Justice Buckley agreed Mrs Cormack should receive payment for loss of earnings, loss of pension rights, the cost of care, and the pain and suffering she endured.

He quoted from the hospital's internal report into the misdiagnosis which said: "A serious and indefensible diagnosis has been made.

"It is no exaggeration to state that the standard of reporting indicates a level of competence insufficient for a candidate to pass a preliminary examination for membership of the Royal College of Pathologists."

Mr Justice Buckley said: "No further comment is needed from me."

Professor Sir Colin Berry, the doctor at the centre of the misdiagnosis, no longer works with breast cancer patients. He is a fellow of the Royal College of Physicians and a member and former treasurer of the Royal College of Pathology.

The health authority, which must also bear Mrs Cormack's court costs, thought to exceed £100,000, apologised for the mistake. A statement from the hospital trust said: "Since this case a triple assessment system for all pre- and post-operative cases has been introduced. Every case is reviewed by several experts before any decisions are made."

Mrs Cormack's ordeal began in 1985 when Sir Colin carried out a biopsy on a lump in her right breast. He diagnosed an invasive carcinoma and Mrs Cormack was told there was a 50% chance it would spread to her other breast.

As a result of the biopsy she had a double mastectomy, a hysterectomy, a partial thyroidectomy and seven reconstructive breast operations. Muscle taken from her groin for use in these operations led her to require two hernia operations for which she is still being treated and may need further surgery.

The stream of operations and treatment has left her unable to continue working as a child health manager and impaired her ability to do housework and gardening. It also shattered her confidence. "It was devastating. I'm reminded of it every time I get dressed and see my scarred and mutilated body in the mirror," she said.

Mrs Cormack's case came to light only after the Royal London held an internal review of biopsies carried out by Sir Colin, prompted by the case of Lesley Morpurgo. She was diagnosed with breast cancer by Sir Colin in 1986 and also had a double mastectomy. A checkup in 1994 revealed she did not have the disease.

Mrs Cormack's sister was diagnosed with breast cancer in the same month as she received her erroneous biopsy results. For three years Mrs Cormack, who is married with two children, tended to her sister. "All the time I was looking after her and watching her slip away I was thinking, 'This is me next.'"

Mrs Cormack is now a counsellor with a breast cancer charity. "I had a great determination not to let this thing warp me. Working as a volunteer has helped," she said.

"My family and friends have all learned that life is a one-stop, it's not a rehearsal. You have to take your chances while you can. And always get a second opinion."

fields.headline: Scottish exam authority 'riddled with ineptitude'
fields.trailText: An initial report into the body responsible for Scotland's exam results fiasco has uncovered a damning catalogue of failure and incompetence across the organisation.
fields.body:
An initial report into the body responsible for Scotland's exam results fiasco has uncovered a damning catalogue of failure and incompetence across the organisation.

The report by the interim chief executive of the Scottish qualifications authority found that some SQA staff were not trained and there were allegations of bullying.

The SQA was responsible for collating and distributing results for the 147,000 pupils who took exams in Scotland this year. But thousands of youngsters were sent incomplete or inaccurate grades and the validity of all results for the class of 2000 has been thrown into doubt.

In written evidence to an inquiry set up by the Scottish parliament's education committee, Bill Morton, who was appointed as acting SQA chief executive after the scandal broke, said management of the authority was poor. There was little accountability or communication, some staff had not been properly trained , others did not know how to respond to customer needs, and there was evidence of concern about bullying.

He said his internal inquiry into the problems also found poor administration of marking - although the quality assurance of the marking was said to be "robust" - and inadequate planning, preparation and project management.

There was, said Mr Morton, little evidence of checks to prevent errors and omissions, with ad hoc solutions being attempted as successive problems appeared, and there was a clear lack of communication within the body.

Mr Morton said staff concerns about difficulties were not acted upon effectively or on time and he found evidence of a fear of bullying among workers.

He told MSPs that he had been forced to make key changes because of the seriousness and scale of the problem, and further fundamental changes were in the pipeline.

The Scottish National party's education spokesman, Mike Russell, said the report put further pressure on the Scottish exective and the education minister, Sam Galbraith, to explain their role in the fiasco.

Mr Galbraith has insisted that he was not aware of the extent of problems in the SQA despite repeated requests for information.

"Mr Morton has found an organsation in deep trouble and it is unlikely that this situation arose overnight," he said. "Why was an organisation that was supposed to be the gold standard for Scottish education allowed to get into such a state?

"Was the education minister informed? And if he didn't know, why not?

Earlier this week, the enterprise minister, Henry McLeish, told the education committee inquiry that Mr Morton was conducting a rigorous investigation.

Mr Galbraith, meanwhile, has also acknowledged this week that there was a possibility that the entire board of the SQA might not be in place by the end of the year.

The authority's original chief executive, Ron Tuck, resigned his post within days of the crisis breaking.

Mr Morton's investigation is one of three different probes into the cause of the exam chaos. As well as the education committee inquiry, an independent inquiry has been commissioned by the Scottish executive.

webTitle: How the Tories' spending plans add up

fields.headline: How the Tories' spending plans add up
fields.standfirst:
Attack on Portillo's sums signals return to old ideological divide as battleground for election
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: After an interval of eight years, the great ideological divide between Labour and the Tories returned with a vengeance this week - taxation and spending.
fields.body:
After an interval of eight years, the great ideological divide between Labour and the Tories returned with a vengeance this week - taxation and spending.

The election in 1992 was all about Labour's £1,100 tax bombshell; this time it will be about the Conservatives' £600 a head spending cut.

Eight months before the earliest expected date for polling day, skirmishes between Millbank and Conservative central office have broken out. The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, told his party's conference in Bournemouth this week that "Conservatives will tax less, spend better, and deliver more".

The government says this cannot be done. It challenges Mr Portillo to come clean "on the hospitals they would close, the schools they would shut, and the transport projects they would cancel" to make his sums add up. So what is the true state of affairs?

Labour calculates there is a £16bn hole in the Tory spending plans, equivalent to £600 for every taxpayer in Britain. Gordon Brown intends to increase public spending by 3.25% a year between 2001-02 and 2003-04, spending over the period a total of £439.6bn. By contrast, Labour says Mr Portillo is on record as saying that he would restrict increases in spending to below the trend rate of growth in the economy - which, the government says, would result in £423.9bn having been spent at the end of this three-year period. Ergo, says Labour, the Tories would "cut" £16bn.

But Labour makes certain assumptions. The first is the trend rate of growth (an assessment of the average increase in gross domestic product over many decades) the Conservatives would use as their benchmark. Based on remarks made in the summer, Labour assumes the Conservatives believe the trend rate is just over 2%, but neither Mr Portillo nor William Hague has been specific.

The government itself is in two minds about the trend rate. While using 2.5% for its economic forecasts, the Treasury uses 2.25% to project the public finances, to avoid expensive mistakes about what it can afford to spend.

These separate figures - 2%, 2.25% and 2.5% - give three different results for the size of the spending gap.

Using 2.5% for Mr Portillo's spending proposals (not unreasonable, given that Kenneth Clarke assumed 2.5% was the trend rate when chancellor) gives a different outlook for the public finances.

Also vital to the calculation is timing. The government is assuming Mr Portillo starts to cut from the moment he walks in to the Treasury, but this would be difficult given that the 2001-02 financial year will have begun next April. It would cause havoc to government departments to announce spending cuts when money was already budgeted for, and Mr Portillo would almost certainly wait until 2002-03 before wielding the axe.

So, assuming the Conservatives spend at the same rate as Labour in the first year and then increase spending by 2.5% a year rather than 2%, what would be the difference between the two programmes? By 2003-04, the final year of Mr Brown's three-year plan, the Tories would be spending £433.2bn as opposed to the government's £439.6bn - a difference of £6.4bn rather than £16bn. If he increased spending at 2.25% the shortfall would be £8.5bn.

In the context of the public finances, both of these figures represent small change. The gap is so small, and the projected size of the government's surplus (set to be £15bn this year) is so big, that Mr Portillo might not need to make any cuts at all, unless he wanted to. In fact, the Tories, given their pronouncements on the desirability of lower taxes, would probably have to spend less than Labour overall.

Mr Portillo has agreed to match Labour's spending on the NHS and on pensions - two of the government's biggest items of expenditure. Labour also says the Conservatives have been "spraying around" spending commitments for 8,000 soldiers, 18,000 more in the territorial army, abolition of the early release scheme for prisoners, new housing grants, new right-to-buy discounts for council houses, new link roads, more trains on Sundays, endowments for universities, extra police, the restoration of the assisted places scheme, and boosting annuities for pensioners. Whether these are additional to, or substitutes for, existing programmes has yet to be made clear.

But the Conservative approach is far less disciplined than the regime Mr Brown imposed on Labour before the 1997 election. Millbank intends to spend the next weeks and months meticulously costing every pledge.

Mr Portillo has only a limited range of options for reducing spending to make room for extra commitments. He is unlikely to want to cut the politically sensitive education budget or defence. That leaves transport infrastructure, social security other than pensions, and eliminating bureaucracy and fraud, as candidates for saving serious amounts of money.

Some of the money saved will also be earmarked for the tax cuts promised this week by Mr Portillo. In his speech he said he would cut taxes on business, restore the married couples allowance, cut the duty on fuel, help pensioners and hard working families, encourage savings, and reform taxes on entrepreneurs and inward investment.

Of these, only fuel duty has been fleshed out, with the 3p a litre cut pledged by Mr Hague likely to cost £1.1bn in the first year. But restoration of the married couples allowance at its level before Mr Brown abolished it this year would cost a further £2bn. If Mr Portillo wanted a 1p cut in the basic income tax, that would cost a further £3bn.

The more Mr Portillo spends on tax cuts, the more he will have to save elsewhere. That is not to say there will not be room for any tax cuts - as Mr Brown will almost certainly demonstrate next March, the health of the public finances is such that it is possible to maintain spending and make modest tax cuts.

But cutting taxes and increasing spending may come at the cost of higher interest rates. The Bank of England will be watching very closely indeed.

fields.headline: Anti-social order made against barrister
fields.trailText: As a barrister with 20 years' experience Veena Madnani would have become used to being told to pipe down by a judge. When she took to repeatedly banging on her ceiling, apparently in response to noise from above, it led to a far more serious rebuke.
fields.body:
As a barrister with 20 years' experience Veena Madnani would have become used to being told to pipe down by a judge. When she took to repeatedly banging on her ceiling, apparently in response to noise from above, it led to a far more serious rebuke.

Madnani has become the first homeowner to be issued with an anti-social behaviour order after her neighbours in smart Fitzrovia, London, complained about the tattoo the barrister was beating on their floor. She bashed the ceiling so hard it was dotted with indentations; her neighbours complained regularly but eventually moved.

Camden council last week obtained an anti-social behaviour order against Madnani after a six-day hearing at Highbury Corner magistrates court. The order prohibits her from harassment, intimidation, abuse or causing a nuisance or annoyance by repeated noise abuse. She faces a fine or imprisonment if she breaches the order, which was made for five years.

A spokesman for the council said he believed it was the first time such an order had been made against a leaseholder rather than a council tenant.

"We were able to carry this through because those living above Madnani were council tenants and needed our help. The complaints have been going on for a number of years," he said.

Madnani, who was unavailable for comment, had told the court that she was a victim of racial harassment and entrapment by council staff. District judge JV Perkins dismissed her claims and said she was not a witness upon whose evidence he could rely.

webTitle: Sinatra was 'go-between for Mafia and JFK'

fields.headline: Sinatra was 'go-between for Mafia and JFK'
fields.standfirst: The singer's daughter reveals how Ol' Blue Eyes worked for the Kennedy clan, the mob and the CIA
fields.trailText: Frank Sinatra's youngest daughter presents the United States tomorrow with a snapshot of an era in which presidential election campaigns took a more relaxed view about where their funds came from than the Gore and Bush teams of today.
fields.body:
Frank Sinatra's youngest daughter presents the United States tomorrow with a snapshot of an era in which presidential election campaigns took a more relaxed view about where their funds came from than the Gore and Bush teams of today.

Tina Sinatra says that her father, one of the most reliable targets each time the world goes looking for a tarnished hero, acted as a facilitator when John F Kennedy's election machine realised it could use a little help from the Mafia 40 years ago.

The singer, whose job as a go-between was set up by the Kennedy family patriarch Joseph, asked the Chicago crime overlord Sam Giancana to use the mob's muscle to deliver union votes.

It was thought to be "in Jack Kennedy's best interest if his father did not make the contact directly", Ms Sinatra, 52, told the CBS current affairs programme 60 Minutes. "Dad was on an errand."

Sinatra, who died two years ago at the age of 82, received the call when JFK, then a member of the Senate, was fighting Hubert Humphrey for the Democratic nomination to run as president in 1960. His father believed that Giancana's influence could make the difference in the West Virginia primary.

Sinatra was chosen for the task "because Kennedy knew dad had access to Sam Giancana", his daughter said. The Mafia boss agreed to help, indicating that it was all in a day's work for him.

"It's a couple of calls," he said.

But Giancana felt betrayed after Kennedy won the primary and then the the White House, and his brother Robert, the attorney general, turned against organised crime.

Ms Sinatra said: "Sam was saying 'That's not right. You know he owes me' - he meaning Joe Kennedy. And dad, I think, said 'No, I owe you. I asked for the favour'."

Her father repaid his debt to Giancana by agreeing to play the mobster's Chicago club, the Villa Venice, and made the apology more fulsome by bringing along Sammy Davis Jr and Dean Martin for an eight-night engagement.

Subsequently, the president, the performer and the persistent criminal were linked through the late Judith Exner, who had affairs with all three. Sinatra said that contact with underworld elements was all a part of the entertainment industry.

"In theatrical work, in night club work, in concerts," he told an interviewer.

"In restaurants you meet all kinds of people, so that there's really not much to be said about that. And I think the less the better."

Ms Sinatra said her father talked also of acting as a courier for the CIA. "Because he controlled his own air travel, [the CIA] would ask him and many others with that capacity to courier a body - a living person, you know, not a corpse, but a diplomat - or papers." But he never divulged any names.

The family begged Sinatra to stop performing in his old age but he could not resist making comebacks because he was convinced that he had to keep on making money, says his daughter, who publishes her autobiography next week.

"The older he got, the more sickly he became, the less he enjoyed his life. None of us thought he would become that frail. It's funny how you delude yourself."

fields.headline: Killings shock Cornish hamlet
fields.standfirst: Villagers struggle to comprehend tragedy
fields.trailText: Frances Prowse shuddered, her eyes moistening slowly, as the local radio confirmed that two bodies had been recovered from a field a few miles from her tiny hilltop bungalow.
fields.body:
Frances Prowse shuddered, her eyes moistening slowly, as the local radio confirmed that two bodies had been recovered from a field a few miles from her tiny hilltop bungalow.

Only the day before three bodies had been removed from a woodshed in the back garden of a property two doors away from the home she has shared with her husband Jack for almost 20 years. Like others in the west Cornwall hamlet of Carnkie, she was barely able to comprehend what was taking place around her.

Now in her 70s, she has no grandchildren of her own. Had she been blessed with any, she would have liked them to be like the "nice kids" from the nearby property who used to say hello to her and Jack when they went outside. Now, she is having to come to terms with radio reports of their deaths.

"It has not sunk in yet but we are all feeling very bad," she said yesterday as police forensic experts clothed in white boilersuits began to wind up their search of the pre-fabricated bungalow where Lesley Ford lived with her four teenage children and the two younger children from her second marriage.

On the verge outside the rented property to which the Fords moved two years ago, a bunch of freshly picked sunflowers and two bouquets wrapped in cellophane provided the first outward sign of the community's despair at what has happened.

Carnkie, a rural hamlet of some 70 houses a few miles from Helston, has little in the way of public amenities to call its own. But in the bar of the Wendron cricket and football club, the mood was subdued yesterday.

Club stewardess Julie Kirk, who moved to the area only a couple of months ago, said people in the village were "absolutely devastated" about what they had heard.

The pain has been particularly hard to bear at Helston school, Cornwall's largest, where three of Mrs Ford's children - Craig, 13, Steven, 14, and Anne-Marie, 16, were pupils - and where 17-year-old Sarah-Jane spent a term before leaving school and starting a job in a nearby McDonald's restaurant.

Headteacher Dennis Johnson said staff and students had been profoundly shocked by news of the tragedy and were being offered counselling by the local authority.

Paul Pullen, a local priest, said the clergy stood ready to offer any pastoral care local people wanted: "The community is in shock and it will take some time for people to come to terms with this."

Mrs Ford and the four children disappeared from their home in Carnkie more than a month ago but were not reported missing until last week when Mrs Ford's brother, who lives in Hampshire, raised the alarm. Three bodies were discovered on Wednesday in a shed in the garden of their home. Two more were recovered yesterday after a police search of a field at Treluswell, about six miles away.

Lesley Ford's parents, who live in Newquay, Cornwall, said they were devastated by what had happened. "We are reeling, we can't understand it," her father, Leslie Wyatt, said last night.

In Shropshire, where Mrs Ford's two youngest children are being looked after by relatives, her distraught former husband, Michael Tranter, was being comforted by family and friends at his Telford home.

The Liberal Democrat MP for St Ives, Andrew George, said he knew how close-knit the community was in that area. "It will take years for the wider community to come to terms with the fact that something so shocking and unbelievable could happen in their midst."

A 33-year-old man appeared in court at Truro yesterday charged with the murders of his wife and his four stepchildren.

Lee Ford, of Carnkie, was charged with murdering Lesley Ford, 36, Sarah-Jane Tranter, 17, Ann-Marie Tranter, 16, Steven Tranter, 14, and Craig Tranter, 13, between August 26 and October 5. He was remanded in custody for a week.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Spain is the worst place for accidents on holiday while America is the worst for murder, the annual Foreign Office report on the British abroad has revealed. Some 2,400 Britons died overseas last year, most from natural causes, but dozens were killed in road crashes, swimming tragedies and other accidents.
fields.body:
Spain worst for accidents

Spain is the worst place for accidents on holiday while America is the worst for murder, the annual Foreign Office report on the British abroad has revealed. Some 2,400 Britons died overseas last year, most from natural causes, but dozens were killed in road crashes, swimming tragedies and other accidents.

Driver fined for drinking water

Car driver Linda Smart, 27, was yesterday fined £40 and ordered to pay £50 costs by Chippenham magistrates, in Wiltshire, for drinking from a bottle of water while driving. The police claimed she did not have a full view of the road.

Police sue radio station

Hampshire police have issued a high court libel writ against IW Radio on the Isle of Wight, claiming up to £100,000 damages after a caller made controversial comments about four officers.

Dome warning to revellers

Revellers have been warned not to climb up the Millennium Dome after police rescued two teenagers marooned on the London attraction late at night.

Sex fair setback

The Xsensual 2000 fair, featuring strippers and bondage gear, due to take place at Cardiff International Arena later this month, yesterday had its request for a sex shop licence refused by Cardiff council's licensing committee, following more than 450 complaints.

Wimpy gets the beer in

Britain's oldest burger chain, Wimpy, is to sell beer and wine in a £3m fightback against high street pubs and coffee shops.

webTitle: Japan escapes lightly from huge earthquake

fields.headline: Japan escapes lightly from huge earthquake
fields.standfirst: Buildings and bridges sway, roads buckle, but no one dies as 7.3 convulsion rolls across the country
fields.trailText: Japan cautiously celebrated a narrow escape yesterday after one of its biggest earthquakes in decades tore up buildings and roads but amazingly did not take a single life.
fields.body:
Japan cautiously celebrated a narrow escape yesterday after one of its biggest earthquakes in decades tore up buildings and roads but amazingly did not take a single life.

The tremor, which struck Tottori prefecture in western Japan, registered 7.3 on the Richter scale, making it more powerful than the 7.2 Kobe quake which killed more than 6,000 people in 1995.

Thirty-six people were injured as the tremor rippled half the length of Japan, sending skyscrapers swaying in Tokyo, more than 370 miles to the north-east.

The worst hit places were rural communities in and around Minato, the town nearest to the epicentre.

More than 190 homes were destroyed, forcing more than 430 refugees to bed down last night in schools and community centres.

"I've never experienced such a terrifying earthquake in my life," a local shopowner said in a television interview.

"I grabbed a customer and held on to her as we cowered on the floor."

The quake triggered about a dozen landslides, halted train services and blocked roads. In some parts of this mountainous region huge boulders tumbled down on to the roads - fortunately when there was no traffic.

Elsewhere there was a catalogue of near misses. Road surfaces cracked and buckled, but no accidents were reported, and bridges swayed: in Okayama one was reported to have collapsed and been swept away.

In Saihaku village the heavy tiled roof of a shrine collapsed but the two people inside escaped with injuries.

At a construction site in Shimane prefecture two people buried in a landslide were rescued alive. Power cuts, gas leaks and burst gas pipes were also dealt with before anyone was hurt.

The biggest escape, however, may have been at two nuclear reactors, just 12 miles from the epicentre, which happened to be shut down for routine checks when the quake hit.

Part of the credit for the low number of casualties must go to the authorities, who responded rapidly, in sharp contrast to the blundering delays which worsened the death toll in Kobe five years ago.

Within an hour the cabinet had established a crisis-management taskforce and the defence forces had sent planes to make an aerial examination. No emergency action was required, however, prompting a collective sigh of relief from the government.

"We must be thankful that there have been no reports of fatalities," the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, said.

"When you consider the immense size of the earthquake, the damage so far has been small."

Seismologists were still analysing the data last night to determine why Tottori had been able to escape so lightly.

The fact that the quake hit a sparsely populated region in the afternoon was cited as a key factor.

This was in contrast to the Kobe quake, which struck early in the morning, killing many people in their beds.

It was also speculated that the movement of the quake was mostly horizontal, which sets buildings swaying, rather than the lethal vertical shaking that jolted Kobe.

The authorities warned, however, that is was too early to declare an all clear.

Aftershocks were still rocking Tottori and the surrounding areas yesterday and the meteorological agency warned that there was a 40% chance of another powerful quake in the next 24 hours.

The Japanese need little reminding of the dangers. The country, which sits on the juncture of three tectonic plates, is one of the most seismically active in the world.

This year the archipelago has been shaken by an unusual number of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, prompting the fear that a major movement of the plates in the Earth's crust is taking place.

The quake triggered about a dozen landslides, halted train services and blocked roads. In some parts of this mountainous region huge boulders tumbled down on to the roads - fortunately when there was no traffic. Elsewhere there was a catalogue of near misses. Road surfaces cracked and buckled, but no accidents were reported, and bridges swayed: in Okayama one was reported to have collapsed and been swept away. In Saihaku village the heavy tiled roof of a shrine collapsed but the two people inside escaped with injuries. At a construction site in Shimane prefecture two people buried in a landslide were rescued alive. Power cuts, gas leaks and burst gas pipes were also dealt with before anyone was hurt. The biggest escape, however, may have been at two nuclear reactors, just 12 miles from the epicentre, which happened to be shut down for routine checks when the quake hit. Part of the credit for the low number of casualties must go to the authorities, who responded rapidly, in sharp contrast to the blundering delays which worsened the death toll in Kobe five years ago. Within an hour the cabinet had established a crisis-management taskforce and the defence forces had sent planes to make an aerial examination. No emergency action was required, however, prompting a collective sigh of relief from the government. "We must be thankful that there have been no reports of fatalities," the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, said. "When you consider the immense size of the earthquake, the damage so far has been small." Seismologists were still analysing the data last night to determine why Tottori had been able to escape so lightly. The fact that the quake hit a sparsely populated region in the afternoon was cited as a key factor. This was in contrast to the Kobe quake, which struck early in the morning, killing many people in their beds. It was also speculated that the movement of the quake was mostly horizontal, which sets buildings swaying, rather than the lethal vertical shaking that jolted Kobe. The authorities warned, however, that is was too early to declare an all clear. Aftershocks were still rocking Tottori and the surrounding areas yesterday and the meteorological agency warned that there was a 40% chance of another powerful quake in the next 24 hours. The Japanese need little reminding of the dangers. The country, which sits on the juncture of three tectonic plates, is one of the most seismically active in the world. This year the archipelago has been shaken by an unusual number of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, prompting the fear that a major movement of the plates in the Earth's crust is taking place.

fields.headline: Luxembourg crowns new grand duke
fields.trailText: This morning, to the strains of a trumpet blast from Luxembourg's national anthem, one of Europe's smallest monarchies will change hands.
fields.body:
This morning, to the strains of a trumpet blast from Luxembourg's national anthem, one of Europe's smallest monarchies will change hands.

Grand Duke Jean, 79, head of state for the past 36 years, hands over to his eldest son, Prince Henri, 45. The grand duke, educated at Ampleforth and a former colonel in the Irish Guards, is following family tradition by abdicating, an event he decided was suitable for the millennium.

But today's ceremony - an oath-taking, a thanksgiving service, and a "meeting with the population" - will be a low key event, because the prince's younger brother, Guillaume, was seriously injured in a car crash last month and is still in hospital.

The family, descended from the medieval kings of France, is related to half the royal families of Europe and presides over the smallest and wealthiest of the 15 EU states

Luxembourg's 400,000 inhabitants are, indeed, among the richest in the world, thanks to their secretive and accommodating banks, so convenient for the neighbouring Germans, French, Belgians and Dutch to squirrel away their savings safe from their own countries' tax authorities.

Grand Duke Jean appointed Henri, a Sandhurst-trained member of the Parachute regiment, as his lieutenant-representant two years ago.

"The people benefit from a period in which they can become accustomed to the idea of the change which is to come," a government statement said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Violence flares in Irian Jaya
fields.body:
Violence flares in Irian Jaya

Eleven hours of fighting between Indonesian security forces and independence supporters in Irian Jaya yesterday left seven people dead and at least 38 injured.

The clashes broke out in Wamena after the authorities lowered the independence flag in the market and chopped down the flagpole. John Aglionby, Jakarta

Bombs shake Russian cities

A series of bomb blasts in two southern Russian cities yesterday killed at least two people and injured dozens, officials said.

A woman died when two bombs exploded on a railway platform in Pyatigorsk. Later, two blasts rocked Nevinnomyssk 60 miles away. Reuters, Moscow

webTitle: Rosbif to run French food bible

fields.headline: Rosbif to run French food bible
fields.trailText: The Michelin Red Guide, the eagerly awaited and widely debated French foodies' bible, is to be run by a Brit.
fields.body:
The Michelin Red Guide, the eagerly awaited and widely debated French foodies' bible, is to be run by a Brit.

Announcing a change which is bound to provoke uproar in Gallic culinary circles, the tyre company said yesterday that Derek Brown, who is currently in charge of its travel business in Asia, will take over as director of the century-old French guide on January 1 next year.

Given the prevailing French perceptionof British food - "If it's cold it's soup, if it's warm it's beer" is one unflattering adage - Michelin was understandably defensive.

Its spokesman Jean-Frédéric Douroux said: "Derek Brown was chosen because he is the best man for the job... Nowadays nationality is of no importance in top-class cuisine."

Mr Brown will replace Bernard Naegellen, a discreet if portly and all-powerful figure in the elevated world of French gastronomy.

The appointment, which carries with it the clout to make or break some of the world's most exclusive and expensive restaurants, comes as the Red Guide and its star system are coming under increasingly heavy fire.

Critics, even in France, argue that it has failed to move with the times and rewards culinary tradition rather than innovation.

Some top chefs have also broken rank, turning down stars on the grounds that the practice of rating comfort as highly as cuisine means they are bankrupting themselves on fripperies rather than food.

fields.headline: Don't thank the bombers
fields.standfirst:
The west should not be allowed to take the credit for the fall of Milosevic
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Whatever happens in the next days and weeks, one would have to be a granite-hearted Stalinist not to be uplifted watching the people of Belgrade dance in the streets. Even people for whom those same Yugoslav civilians represented legitimate targets a few short months ago will have enjoyed the pictures.
fields.body:
Whatever happens in the next days and weeks, one would have to be a granite-hearted Stalinist not to be uplifted watching the people of Belgrade dance in the streets. Even people for whom those same Yugoslav civilians represented legitimate targets a few short months ago will have enjoyed the pictures.

Those who cheered as Nato offloaded its various hardware - some of which continues to explode, killing and maiming hundreds of people in Kosovo since the end of hostilities - will doubtless claim credit for the fall of Milosevic. I haven't yet heard comment from Mark Laity. Incidentally, it is high time he paid back all the public money he received as BBC defence correspondent. I'm sorry, but when a person who is accused of being a Nato spokesman is then hired to be the Nato spokesman, the accusation sticks like a prime minister to his shirt. For years, we paid for the shirts on Laity's back, including his pyjama tops, which, I am reliably informed, bear a pattern of Tornado jets. Whether he tucks the shirt into the bottoms, I don't know. Let's just say it seems certain.

In any event, it will be said that defeat by Nato effected Milosevic's fall. It will probably even be claimed that freeing the Serbs from Milosevic was always the aim of the war, and Nato knew it would happen; which is like saying Hitler annexed Austria because he knew The Third Man would be a great film and was determined that it should be made. Both sides in the debate about the war against Yugoslavia made predictions, and predictions on both sides were inaccurate. For example, the war precipitated the thing it was ostensibly intended to prevent.

On the anti-war side, we also made inaccurate predictions. That doesn't mean we were wrong to oppose the war, but it means we didn't always put our case very well. That was partly because we were an uneasy alliance. I marched alongside people who were unabashed Milosevic fans and others who supported the KLA, arguing that, although they didn't support Nato, "we should arm the Kosovans". Since we had no guns, I didn't really understand the rationale, but it seemed to mean that we should campaign for Nato to become a non-profit-making arms dealer.

But most of us, I think, saw nationalism as the curse of the Balkans. And we were all united in a belief that world politics should not be shaped to the designs of the United States. We were right, although not all of our predictions were. We had no way of knowing how the war would go. Some people said that Yugoslavia would never submit to bombing. This struck me as an unwise prediction. Despite the breath-taking Nato lies about its successes against the Yugoslav army, the Yugoslav people were a much softer target, and there's only so much any country can take.

It was also argued that the war would confirm Milosevic in power. In the short term that was clearly true. Voices of dissent, which had bravely challenged the regime for years with no recognition in the west, were immediately silenced. Had the destruction of Yugoslavia carried on for many months, it is hard to know what shape the opposition movement would have been in. I was surprised by the quickness of his capitulation, but Milosevic must have realised that Nato had no interest in unseating him and so cut a deal.

None the less he had brought humiliation, death and disaster to his people. Moreover, market capitalism has brought increasing deprivation and dislocation to eastern Europe and few rulers can now look to industrial workers for support. There is only so long that rulers can use the racism and nationalism that breeds under capitalism to distract people from the fact that they are not paid enough to live on.

This is not to say that the new regime in Yugoslavia will reject capitalism. It will extend it. One of the great crimes of the old command economies is that they associated planning with tyranny. Small wonder that capitalism's propagandists get away with linking the market to freedom. I'm sure some of those dancing in the streets of Belgrade are part of the grow ing worldwide anti-capitalist movement. But one can't expect them to have a huge domestic audience just yet.

Some might say it's easy to be anti-capitalist when you can afford to be, which is another way of saying that ideas are a product of material circumstances. In fact, it's much easier to be anti- capitalist if you work in a Far East sweat-shop making clothes for American youth. It is to the very great credit of American youth that so many of them are protesting about the conditions in which their clothes are produced. You might say their protests are a luxury. I say fair play to them; they could just go to the mall.

The Yugoslav revolution reminds us that people have in themselves the power to change the world. Robin Cook, Madeleine Albright, Nato and Nike may be rubbing their hands now, but they shouldn't feel too comfortable.
