fields.headline: Can Catholics be gay?
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Late one night, many years ago, a bunch of undergraduates were staggering out of a Scottish university students' union after having had too much to drink. We passed a fellow student who fitted the archetype of the "queer", standing by himself.
fields.body:
Late one night, many years ago, a bunch of undergraduates were staggering out of a Scottish university students' union after having had too much to drink. We passed a fellow student who fitted the archetype of the "queer", standing by himself. My pal Harry made noisy kissing sounds in his direction and shouted, "Coming out with me tonight, sister?" We rolled on down the hill laughing. A few days later I noticed this same man, alone at a table close to ours in the union bar. Suddenly one of our group turned to look directly at him and said, "I hate fucking perverts, don't you?"

I felt horrified and sick with apprehension - as I suspect this man did, for he got up at once and left the bar. It hit me at once that the gap between this outburst and Harry's drunken remark was small. I was 19 and began to ponder seriously who is and is not my neighbour.

That was in the 1950s, when homosexuals had not yet acquired the self-description of gay. The dictionary connotations of the word queer are odd, singular, quaint, open to suspicion, counterfeit, slightly mad, and sickly. This queerness has obviously proved unnerving for many heterosexuals who tend to be afraid of gay people, seen as strangers in our midst. Hence the persecution and, I suppose, the negative biblical references to homosexuality. What am I to make of this as a committed Catholic who just happens to be heterosexual?

There is no New Testament record of Jesus mentioning homosexuality. We do know that the scorned and outcast were the kinds of people he particularly cared about and wanted to be with. To me that implies something warmer than mere tolerance.

The tone of Vatican teaching is at best reluctantly tolerant. Cardinal Ratzinger's October 1986 Letter to the Bishops of the Catholic Church on the Pastoral Care of Homosexual Persons said that "although the particular inclination of the homosexual person is not a sin, it is a more or less strong tendency ordered toward an intrinsic moral evil; and thus the inclination itself must be seen as an objective disorder." Homosexual actions are "in no case to be approved of." Since my homosexual friends are on the whole living decent, loving and even admirably religious lives with their partners, I know I could not look them in the eye and repeat this instruction.

The Pontifical Council's 1996 document, The Truth and Meaning of Human Sexuality: Guidelines for Education Within the Family, is made of still sterner stuff. At a time when we have no certainty about the causes of homosexuality, it considers subjecting young people to therapy to change their sexual orientation.

One of my students has catalogued the suggestions therapists have made about appropriate methodologies. They include "exercise to exhaustion; sleeping with prostitutes; electric shock aversion; chemical aversion through nausea inducing drugs; covert sensitisation through reshaping masturbatory fantasies; psychoanalysis." I wonder which of these the Pontifical Council has in mind?

Martin Pendergast, a member of the Roman Catholic caucus in the Lesbian and Gay Christian movement since 1976, told me how homosexual Catholics often have the literal experience of being treated like strangers in their own church. They feel that there is "a dogged rejection of real dialogue with lesbian, gay and bisexual people, their parents and families, over the honourable integration of diverse sexual orientations, and their expression, with Christian faith."

They even feel that this carelessness amounts to a tacit acceptance of the daily bullying, persecution and in recent times even bombing, that gay people suffer. How can it be otherwise when Catholic clergy of goodwill - and there are many- struggle with the tension between the alienating language of Vatican statements and the realities they meet every day?

I did learn something from the oppression I once colluded in. It is to do with the mercy of God. Religious people can choose to ignore that and rest inertly upon cultural norms that are so long-standing that they appear to be self-evident. This leads to a forgetfulness of the humanity and goodness of people who find themselves unable to abide by those norms. Sheer lack of awareness leads to a passive and undiscriminating emphasis on the norms while sanctioning blindness to the needs of our neighbours.

Passing by on the other side won't do: not on the streets of Scotland, any more than on the road to Jericho.

 Dr David Hay is a former reader in spiritual education at Nottingham University

fields.headline: The remaking of Serbia
fields.standfirst:
Kostunica faces an enormous task

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: After the revolution, the real work begins. Having bombed and blasted Serbia during the Kosovo war, impoverished it with economic sanctions and isolated and divided it by all available means, western governments now bear a heavy responsibility in helping its people put their country back together again. Having succoured and shielded Slobodan Milosevic during Yugoslavia's years of fear, Russia, too, has a moral obligation to repair the damage. Institutions like the Council of Europe and the OSCE can also play a role in rebuilding a democratic, free and open civil society, in persuading Serbs that their future lies securely within the European community.
fields.body:
After the revolution, the real work begins. Having bombed and blasted Serbia during the Kosovo war, impoverished it with economic sanctions and isolated and divided it by all available means, western governments now bear a heavy responsibility in helping its people put their country back together again. Having succoured and shielded Slobodan Milosevic during Yugoslavia's years of fear, Russia, too, has a moral obligation to repair the damage. Institutions like the Council of Europe and the OSCE can also play a role in rebuilding a democratic, free and open civil society, in persuading Serbs that their future lies securely within the European community.

Foreign secretary Robin Cook was quick yesterday to offer reconstruction aid. The EU as a whole and the US have a duty to be generous in this respect. Most sanctions will be rescinded in the next few days; and Milosevic's successor, Vojislav Kostunica, has been invited to next week's EU summit in Biarritz. He should receive not merely the congratulations of Europe's leaders but funds and, for example, practical assistance in clearing the Danube and rebuilding bombed bridges. Mr Kostunica and the federal parliament will of course be the judges of what is right and proper in the way of aid. But if he asks for western help, he must be sure to get it. There should be no repeat of the Kosovo shambles last winter after the west failed to deliver swiftly on its Sarajevo summit promises. This week the Serbs finally found the courage to change. The rewards for that brave act of popular will must be immediate, tangible and persuasive.

For just as the joy this week has at times been unconfined, the perils ahead are limitless. In deposing the hated Milosevic, the opposition lost the single issue that united it. Maintaining this inherently unstable alliance, retaining popular support and creating a consensus for much-needed, thorough institutional reform are challenges that may yet prove to be beyond Mr Kostunica's power.

He has to contend with the old guard of Milosevic cronies and placemen and the tainted, undemocratic structures controlled by Milosevic's Socialist party. He faces, in parliament and beyond, the rump forces of a destructive ultra-nationalism that his own strong, patriotic credentials may not be enough to neutralise. He must win the backing, not merely the acquiescence of the vast security apparatus. And he must deal with the unavoidable questions of retribution and reconciliation in a society where justice and the law were debauched. Much baring of souls and past sins can be expected as the media casts off its chains and free speech returns. A South African-style truth commission might be a good start. For Serbia's self-inflicted wounds, let alone those inflicted on its neighbours, will not be easily healed, nor the thirst for revenge easily quenched.

For a watching world, one key test of Serbia's rehabilitation will be its treatment of indicted war criminals like Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic. Above all, Milosevic, the man who created and harboured them, must be made to answer for his crimes. In all such cases, there should be no deals, no amnesties. Another test will be future policy towards independence-minded Kosovo and Montenegro. Mr Kostunica opposes a further Yugoslav fragmentation; the west opposes the creation of yet more Balkan mini-states. But reintegration is deeply problematic. This is all part of the larger conundrum - how to make the nation whole again. Having reclaimed his country, Mr Kostunica must now find the means to resurrect it.

In deposing the hated Milosevic, the opposition lost the single issue that united it. Maintaining this inherently unstable alliance, retaining popular support and creating a consensus for much-needed, thorough institutional reform are challenges that may yet prove to be beyond Mr Kostunica's power. He has to contend with the old guard of Milosevic cronies and placemen and the tainted, undemocratic structures controlled by Milosevic's Socialist party. He faces, in parliament and beyond, the rump forces of a destructive ultra-nationalism that his own strong, patriotic credentials may not be enough to neutralise. He must win the backing, not merely the acquiescence of the vast security apparatus. And he must deal with the unavoidable questions of retribution and reconciliation in a society where justice and the law were debauched. Much baring of souls and past sins can be expected as the media casts off its chains and free speech returns. A South African-style truth commission might be a good start. For Serbia's self-inflicted wounds, let alone those inflicted on its neighbours, will not be easily healed, nor the thirst for revenge easily quenched. For a watching world, one key test of Serbia's rehabilitation will be its treatment of indicted war criminals like Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic. Above all, Milosevic, the man who created and harboured them, must be made to answer for his crimes. In all such cases, there should be no deals, no amnesties. Another test will be future policy towards independence-minded Kosovo and Montenegro. Mr Kostunica opposes a further Yugoslav fragmentation; the west opposes the creation of yet more Balkan mini-states. But reintegration is deeply problematic. This is all part of the larger conundrum - how to make the nation whole again. Having reclaimed his country, Mr Kostunica must now find the means to resurrect it.

fields.headline: A proven lawyer
fields.standfirst: Thomas More: a saint, but no choirboy
fields.trailText: The Pope's decision that Sir Thomas More should be named this November 5 (of all days) as the patron saint of politicians does not have to be voted on, which is just as well, since if it did, there would surely be opposition. Some say that the saint's reputation should not be sullied by such tawdry associations. But others declare that the choice is apt for reasons which may not have entered the Pope's calculations. Yes, More was a saint; but he was also speaker, lord president of the council and ultimately lord chancellor, and you do not acquire a CV like that through unremitting saintliness.
fields.body:
The Pope's decision that Sir Thomas More should be named this November 5 (of all days) as the patron saint of politicians does not have to be voted on, which is just as well, since if it did, there would surely be opposition. Some say that the saint's reputation should not be sullied by such tawdry associations. But others declare that the choice is apt for reasons which may not have entered the Pope's calculations. Yes, More was a saint; but he was also speaker, lord president of the council and ultimately lord chancellor, and you do not acquire a CV like that through unremitting saintliness.

As one of his biographers, Professor John Guy, wrote this week, More as Lord Chancellor invented what in the Nixon era came to be known as covert operations. And indeed, the harder you look at his story, the more it seems to have in common with the rougher realities of political life. More was a lawyer, as are so many (too many) politicians today. His habit of scourging himself foreshadows Gladstone, while his knack of surviving on four hours' sleep prefigures Thatcher. He found himself a mentor (Wolsey) and took his job when Wolsey got sacked. Like many political managers he was ruthless in his treatment of heresy; he even, in a clear anticipation of later parliamentary practice, had such dissentients whipped. Those who refused to recant were sometimes put on the rack, which goes further than anything Tony Blair has tried to do to Ken Livingstone. He was full of jests, some of them vulgar, and in dealing with his opponents frequently resorted to personal abuse. And his troubles really began only when he attached himself to a preacher of coming doom known as the Holy Maid of Kent: a clear warning to today's young Tory MPs not to get too close to Ann Widdecombe. True, he died for his principles: but that too is encouraging, since it suggests that today's MPs have the potential to do the same. The arguments will continue. But we think the "ayes" have it.

fields.headline: Palaces of art
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones paints a misleading picture of public access to the Royal Collection (It's one of the greatest collections in the world. So why can't we see it? G2, October 5). He would apparently strip the royal palaces of their contents, which are intimately linked to the history of those buildings, leaving, one can only assume, empty rooms.
fields.body:
Jonathan Jones paints a misleading picture of public access to the Royal Collection (It's one of the greatest collections in the world. So why can't we see it? G2, October 5). He would apparently strip the royal palaces of their contents, which are intimately linked to the history of those buildings, leaving, one can only assume, empty rooms. He fails to acknowledge that some 5.5m people a year visit the palaces to enjoy the pictures and surroundings in situ, and that more than 3,000 works from the Royal Collection, including major paintings, are already on long-term loan to museums and galleries, such as the British Museum, National Gallery, Victoria and Albert Museum and the National Gallery of Scotland. A number of important paintings from the collection will form part of the new displays at Tate Britain next year.

Mr Jones makes no reference to the Royal Collection's long-standing programme of touring exhibitions, nor the hundreds of major items loaned annually to exhibitions organised by other institutions, where works from the collection may be seen in interesting and sometimes challenging new contexts (such as the Hayward's forthcoming Spectacular Bodies). The Royal Collection shows a larger proportion of its holdings to the public than many national collections. It receives no government funding and the current expansion of exhibition space at both Buckingham Palace and Holyrood House in Edinburgh is entirely self-financed.

Mr Jones takes issue with the fact that the Royal Collection is held "in trust", seemingly unaware that all our major national collections are also held in trust.
Hugh Roberts
The Royal Collection Trust

 What is more galling is that for members of the National Art Collections Fund who might enjoy going to see just the paintings on a fairly regular basis, Hampton Court has now withdrawn its free entrance concession, offering only a 20% discount. Even at the reduced rate of £8.40 to see inadequately presented displays, it might be considered as a bit of a "rip-off".
TC Mayhew
Thames Ditton, Surrey

 The purported property of the royal family consists of the fruits of over 900 years of organised crime, principally extortion (of land under the feudal system) and embezzlement (of taxes for private use), along with revenues arising from the stolen property. No one else can legally inherit ownership of stolen property. Why not immediately appropriate everything they have for the public good?
Adam Funk
Sheffield

fields.headline: Wesker bounces back
fields.trailText: Every so often a silly little academic (I accuse, October 4) bounces out of obscurity to announce the death of the novel, of melody, of figurative painting, of theatre.
fields.body:
Every so often a silly little academic (I accuse, October 4) bounces out of obscurity to announce the death of the novel, of melody, of figurative painting, of theatre.

"And make no mistake, theatre has failed," cries young John Freeman - he must be young else he'd be aware that he belongs to a type of cultural demagogue who wearisomely and regularly reappears and contributes nothing coherent to the fraught confusions that separate the arts from its potential public.

"Who really wants to see a Wesker play?" he asks, as though my plays appeared every year, or even ran for more than a few weeks. Why me? I've been on the fringe all my career for having written just what he calls for: the marginal, the subversive - the absence of compromise. I don't really care what he says about me. What depresses is the thought of the poisonous nonsense he's pouring into the ears of vulnerable students. He writes: "Mainstream theatres should be dismantled brick by brick ... We need to weed out the actors, writers and directors who deal in this dross."

It's familiar. A quarter century ago, playwright David Mercer, known for his Marxist position, was once invited to lecture in Essex university. Stink bombs and abuse were hurled at him. Later a student approached, and said: "We must burn all the books, burn them all." "What?" asked Mercer gently, "Marx and Engels as well?" "All of them!" cried the student. "Excuse me," said Mercer, "but that worries me a little, for the last time people said that was in the days of the Reichstag." "The what?" asked the student.
Arnold Wesker
Hay on Wye wesker@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Film soc
fields.trailText: I was fascinated to read that Stephen Lucas (Letters, October 6) has reached no 86 of Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest films of the century without having heard of a single one of them. I found Malcolm'schoices horribly reminiscent of the programme at my university film society 30 years ago. It would have been more intriguing if Malcolm had named 100 films which he'd enjoyed but would admit were no masterpieces.

fields.headline: Freedom in the Balkans
fields.trailText: Before western triumphalism takes over completely, a word of caution. The freeing of central and eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union has, over the past decade, led to an appalling economic meltdown. The former communist economies are now suffering from decreased life expectancy, increased morbidity, poorer educational quality and personal security and, above all, a massive increase in poverty and inequality.
fields.body:
Before western triumphalism takes over completely, a word of caution. The freeing of central and eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union has, over the past decade, led to an appalling economic meltdown. The former communist economies are now suffering from decreased life expectancy, increased morbidity, poorer educational quality and personal security and, above all, a massive increase in poverty and inequality. These are all the direct result of the blind establishment of a market economy, one of Martin Woollacott's prescribed solutions for Yugoslavia (Serbia keeps its date with revolution, a decade late, October 6).

The miners at Kolubara may be making "the comparison between their lives 10 years ago, when they made a good living in a country at peace, and their parlous situation now", but at least they still have jobs. Miners in Ukraine's Donbass, where the industry is now virtually non-existent, would tell a different story.

The rush to a market economy is not enough: all that will bring is the destruction of the old system. What is needed is the intelligent application of the lessons that even the World Bank and the IMF are now beginning learn: that foreign development aid has to help build new structures to replace the old; that these cannot be imposed from the outside, but must be built up from within, with the cooperation and commitment of the people. Civil society as we know it in the west was virtually non-existent in the eastern bloc when communism fell and it is only by helping to build it up that another disaster can be avoided in Yugoslavia.
Dr Richard Carter
European Children's Trust

 Once more, the benevolence of the west rockets forth toward the Balkan states, like a cruise missile of democratic love. No doubt the IMF will have a hand; our own provisos for democracy will be pushed upon the Serbs; and they will be colonised by multinational giants within a year.

It would be an act of patent folly to merely clear up Nato's mess and leave Serbia to design its own future. It might even be socialist, and we couldn't have that - bridges and communities might be built before billboards.
Tom James
Sheffield

 What a mercy that Mr Kostunica ignored your advice last week (Leader, September 28) to accept the deceitful offer of a second round of elections. Otherwise Milosevic would almost certainly be still in power.
John Ashwin
Chichester, W Sussex

 I am happy if the Serbs are free, but sad that their world view seems as limited as ever. The only Serb you quote said Serbs would try Milosevic "for everything he has done to make Serbs refugees from Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo", rather than for everything he has done in their name to non-Serb Croatians, Bosnians and Kosovans. Kostunica was silent on this issue as a candidate. He must confront it very soon as president.
John Heawood
York

 The release of the two British policemen is a good sign. Another, larger-scale release would be even more significant. There are still many Kosovar Albanians rounded up at the start of the Nato bombing and held in prisons throughout Serbia; and more the Red Cross has been unable to trace. The freeing of men and women held for no legitimate reason, and information on the fate of the disappeared, are both essential steps towards some kind of coexistence.
Ruth Valentine
London

 Revolution in the Balkans knocking Hague off the front page who said the Labour spin-machine was dead?
Felix Riley
Claygate, Surrey

fields.headline: Net sales
fields.trailText: The Arts Council's report on poetry-sales (No poetic justice in bestseller lists, October 5) baffled me a bit. I read it in a London primary school while selling books in support of a visit by Michael Rosen - about 250 paperbacks in all. Apparently, Michael's sales in one school alone exceeded those of Fleur Adcock for the whole of 1998-99.
fields.body:
The Arts Council's report on poetry-sales (No poetic justice in bestseller lists, October 5) baffled me a bit. I read it in a London primary school while selling books in support of a visit by Michael Rosen - about 250 paperbacks in all. Apparently, Michael's sales in one school alone exceeded those of Fleur Adcock for the whole of 1998-99.

So how come he didn't get a mention? If the Arts Council would like me to supply the names of other children's poets who routinely outsell several of the "big" names on their list, I'd be happy to oblige.
Jan Powling
Speaking of Books jan@speakingofbooks.co.uk

 It seems slightly contradictory to report that bookshops stock (and sell) very little poetry, and then produce sales figures based on bookshop sales. Like most small independent presses, the majority of our sales are now via mail order, author's readings and the internet. Stride has published many poetry books during the years considered by the Arts Council report that have sold more than the 200 assigned to Fleur Adcock.

As for booksellers requiring point-of-sale material -for three or four copies, at the most, on your shelves? Don't be silly. And while poetry books may not sell in their millions, it seems clear - with the growth of internet poetry magazines, newsgroups, websites and communities - that poetry is read and valued by thousands of people throughout the world.
Rupert Loydell
Stride Publications, Devon RML@madbear.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: We are cannabis cowards
fields.trailText:
Far from demonstrating that we are a nation of dope-smokers, your feature (Where there's smoke, G2, October 6) suggests instead that we are country of cannabis cowards, too frightened to admit that we have transgressed the law. Until the writers, lawyers, government ministers, journalists and doctors whom I have seen smoke dope hold up their hands and say "yes Mr Plod, I use cannabis, what are you going to do about it?", we will continue to have a ridiculous law which makes no moral, social or economic sense and which makes criminals of 40% of our teenagers.
Christian Wolmar
London

 Being almost a septuagenarian, my partner rolled our celebratory joints shortly after Ann Widdecombe's clarion call for zero tolerance on drugs. This old Labour codger is deeply indebted to the charismatic representative of the self-styled party of law and order for making this quite idiotic pronouncement. The prospect of this very respectable retired public servant (and former magistrate) being fined and criminalised for smoking cannabis in privacy, having been belatedly introduced to this very pleasurable pursuit for the first time earlier this year, is mind-boggling.

 A survey of readers of Disability Now in 1997 found that nearly 70% of the 200 people who responded used cannabis to help control pain. Would Ann Widdecombe fine disabled people for trying to cope with their pain?
Mary Wilkinson
Editor, Disability Now

webTitle: Oftel to look at internet access pricing

fields.headline: Oftel to look at internet access pricing
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The cost of accessing the internet is to come under scrutiny in an inquiry by telecommunications regulator Oftel. The investigation, which will lead to a consultation paper in December, will establish whether the watchdog needs to intervene further to bring down the price of web access.
fields.body:
The cost of accessing the internet is to come under scrutiny in an inquiry by telecommunications regulator Oftel. The investigation, which will lead to a consultation paper in December, will establish whether the watchdog needs to intervene further to bring down the price of web access.

The inquiry will also examine the impact on prices of other web access engines, for example mobile phones and digital television.

"The UK already has some of the cheapest deals in Europe for dial-up internet access," said Oftel director general David Edmonds. "This review will investigate how competition has developed and if it is now delivering the best deal for consumers." A final statement on any action by Oftel will be made in May next year.

The investigation is part of a series of reviews by Oftel to gauge the level of regulation needed. It will focus on dial-up, narrowband access.

In May Oftel issued a directive forcing British Telecom to make an unmetered wholesale internet access product available to enable other operators to offer their own unmetered services to customers.

The regulator estimates that 1.5m customers already subscribe to unmetered access packages, representing about a quarter of all dial-up access in the UK, but expects that figure to rise sharply.

A number of unmetered access packages have, however, been withdrawn. Heavy users have been stopped from using their services because they have proven uneconomical.

A report from Oftel published in May said Britain has some of the lowest internet access charges in Europe or the US.

UK residential internet access prices surveyed were the lowest on offer for off-peak access. Sweden, the next cheapest, had prices that were 28% higher.

Internet access charges for businesses, however, were higher than average.

A report from Oftel published in May said Britain has some of the lowest internet access charges in Europe or the US. UK residential internet access prices surveyed were the lowest on offer for off-peak access. Sweden, the next cheapest, had prices that were 28% higher. Internet access charges for businesses, however, were higher than average.

fields.headline: Michael Akintaro
fields.standfirst: Fearless seaman who stood up to gangsters and racists in London's wartime West End
fields.trailText: Michael Akintaro, who has died aged 86, was one of the last remaining members of a pioneering generation of African seamen who helped lay the groundwork for the establishment of London's postwar black community.
fields.body:
Michael Akintaro, who has died aged 86, was one of the last remaining members of a pioneering generation of African seamen who helped lay the groundwork for the establishment of London's postwar black community. A Nigerian who settled in Britain in the 1930s, he was a prominent fighter in the little known racial conflict that developed with the arrival of the segregated American army during the second world war. His refusal to capitulate under racist attack made him a legend throughout the West End.

Born into a Yoruba farming family at Odeomu, near Ibadan, Akintaro grew up in Lagos. He attended grammar school but went to sea in 1932 following the death of his mother. He travelled to Newfoundland, Belgium and Holland before making Liverpool his base. In the Texas port of Galveston, he first encountered the brutality of segregation.

In 1937 he moved to London's East End where Africans scraped a living among the Jewish community, but soon broke away from the area's poverty and headed for the West End. There he worked as a nightclub caretaker and boilerman, supplementing his earnings with occasional crowd work in films. At the legendary Jig's Club where he rubbed shoulders with Jewish gamblers, he met visiting American entertainers including his hero, pianist Fats Waller.

Akintaro was a small man but had a fearsome reputation for argument. His bravery was famously employed when other black entrepreneurs were bullied by the predecessors of the Richardsons and the Krays.

A family man, renowned for his devotion to his wife, he married Stella Bronstein, the daughter of a Whitechapel tailor from Odessa whose family claimed kinship to Leon Trotsky. Along with their two children they became part of Camden Town's important West African community.

With the outbreak of the second world war he rejoined the merchant fleet. He was bound for Philadelphia when his ship broke into two after an air raid. Rescued from a lifeboat wearing only a singlet, he spent two weeks in an Aberdeen hospital before returning to sea. However further injury ended his seagoing and he finished war service in a munitions factory.

By 1943 the West End streets were thronged with American troops. They provided entrepreneurial locals with a new source of income and Akintaro's Soho credentials stood him in good stead when he befriended black servicemen out on the town. For a while he ran a modest operation in a small airless cellar off Denmark Street. With a radiogram for dancing and the unsuspecting American P/X stores as his source of liquor, he discovered black GIs cared little for decor provided they could dance with their chosen partner. Such social freedom was important because many white Americans responded with violence to the sight of inter-racial couples socialising.

Akintaro experienced his own share of bigotry and always retaliated in kind, whatever the odds. Insulted and pushed off the pavement on one occasion, his response led to his imprisonment, but this only enhanced his reputation within the growing black movement.

Following the war, Guyanese revolutionary George Padmore employed Akintaro as a foot-soldier in the fight against colonial rule. He helped distribute radical literature and met other anti-colonialists, including Padmore's financier, the redoubtable Nancy Cunard, and future Ghanaian president Kwame Nkrumah.

In 1953 he abandoned the nightlife. He joined the ministry of works as a hot water fitter, a job that took him from the air ministry to Buckingham Palace, and on retirement he was awarded the Imperial Service Medal.

Akintaro maintained the important Yoruba cultural practice of visiting friends. He claimed to prefer the company of traditional "age-group" associates, but was generous to younger ones, too. Blessed with impressive recall and an unusual capacity for historical analysis, he brought the past alive for his listeners, enlightening them to the struggle and sacrifices of his generation, even when the memory was sometimes painful.

He is survived by a son and daughter, three grandchildren and one great-granddaughter.

 Michael Olatunji Akintaro, activist, born June 2 1914; died September 15 2000

webTitle: Eidos takes a hit on bid failure speculation

fields.headline: Eidos takes a hit on bid failure speculation
fields.trailText: Shares in beleagured computer games company Eidos suffered a further battering yesterday following the resignation of its finance chief and increased speculation that a takeover bid for the company is on the verge of collapse.
fields.body:
Shares in beleagured computer games company Eidos suffered a further battering yesterday following the resignation of its finance chief and increased speculation that a takeover bid for the company is on the verge of collapse.

The unexpected announcement that chief financial officer Jeremy Lewis had quit with immediate effect to "pursue other interests" has intensified a feeling among analysts that long-running takeover talks with Infogrames of France may end in deadlock.

Shares in Eidos slumped 15% in early trading and later closed down 12.75p at 294.5p, around one-fifth of the year high of £12.90p.

Eidos and Infogrames have been arguing about the terms of a deal since June 20, when the French firm first indicated that it was interested in making an offer for Eidos.

Mr Lewis' sudden departure and chief operating officer Mike McGarvey's admission that Eidos would now look for a finance chief with operational experience to help it through the slump in its busi ness led some analysts to suggest the deal was off, and that Eidos was preparing for life as an independent entity.

Eidos sources insisted that former corporate financier Mr Lewis was not leaving because of anything "sinister" inside the company.

"The straightforward truth is that Jeremy has a deal-making background and came into the company when we were making acquisitions and our growth cycle was at a different stage," Mr McGarvey said. "We will look for a more operationally focused finance director and focus inwards on controls, systems and overheads."

Sources close to Eidos admitted that losing Mr Lewis in the middle of takeover talks was far from ideal and would add to negative sentiment over the company in the City.

Eidos has been hit by successive profit warnings this year following falling sales of its Tombraider franchise and slowing demand for games as consumers waited for the introduction of new consoles.

Its shares fell sharply again last month when Sony admitted to a shortfall in supply of its PlayStation 2.

fields.headline: BT soars as executive quits
fields.standfirst: Shareholders hail finance chief's sudden departure
fields.trailText: BT finance director Robert Brace announced his resignation yesterday, sparking an ignominious 8% rise in the company's share price to 740p.
fields.body:
BT finance director Robert Brace announced his resignation yesterday, sparking an ignominious 8% rise in the company's share price to 740p.

The company strenuously denied Mr Brace's departure had been forced by shareholders who have become increasingly dissatisfied with BT's performance. His departure added £4bn to the former monopoly's market capitalisation.

The troubles swamping BT have led to widespread speculation of management changes that reached extraordinary heights last weekend when two separate reports suggesting that chairman Sir Iain Vallance was on the verge of quitting. BT issued a statement denying the stories.

Mr Brace, who was with the company for 11 years, will leave in December - allowing for one month's overlap with his successor, Philip Hampton, who joins from BG.

Mr Brace, 50, was paid £355,000 and was on a one year contract. He will receive £300,000 in compensation.

A spokeswoman said the timing was "unfortunate", given the speculation about Sir Iain, but added that Mr Brace had discussed his intention to leave with chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield some time ago.

Mr Brace is planning to live and work in north America, although he has not yet landed a new job.

"He agreed to stay until a successor had been found and until the end of the strategic review we have been having," the spokeswoman said. "He has been group finance director for seven years and that is a long time. His children have grown up and he is looking for a life change."

Sir Peter said Mr Brace had offered tremendous support and left with his "best wishes".

Investors, however, clearly welcomed his departure. "He has been deeply unpopular for some time but the company has been very loyal to him," said one large shareholder. "There is a sense now that they may have turned the corner."

Another commented: "It's great news. We wanted them to break up, like British Gas, and then they hire the man from British Gas. He can get on it with it now."

BT has come under severe pressure to take radical action to breathe life back into its ailing share price - which has fallen from a peak of £15.13 at the start of the year.

In its most recent results BT reported a 27% slump in first-quarter pre-tax profits from £772m to £561m.

In April, BT announced it had restructured the company into four main divisions and is expected to float some of them to raise cash.

It is also understood to be in talks with US group AT&T likely to involve the merger of the groups' business services.

Mr Brace said: "I have been group finance director of BT through some of the most exciting and challenging times in the history of the company.

"However, I would like a change, and am planning to live and work in north America," he added.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The number of people without work in the Irish Republic last month fell to a near-20-year low of 145,100. At 3.8% of the workforce, the percentage of jobless was one of the smallest on record. The figure stood at 16% in 1993.
fields.body:
More Irish in work

The number of people without work in the Irish Republic last month fell to a near-20-year low of 145,100. At 3.8% of the workforce, the percentage of jobless was one of the smallest on record. The figure stood at 16% in 1993.

The monthly drop of more than 6,000, after adjustment for seasonal factors such as the reopening of schools after summer holidays, was regarded as a further sign of Ireland's continuing economic boom.

Deputy premier and Enterprise, Trade and Employment Minister Mary Harney said of the figures, the lowest since 1981: "A new milestone has been reached, and this is one of the clearest indicators that the Irish economy is going from strength to strength.

"These positive achievements help underpin our strategic goal of a full employment economy."

BASF to invest in GM research

German chemicals group BASF will spend €700m (£420m) over 10 years on research into genetic modification of plants, Anja Klatt, spokeswoman for the firm's agriculture department, told Reuters.

The company has opened a new research facility in a biotechnology park in Berlin for its metanomics unit, which will have 70 staff, and will initially spend three years on a metabolic profiling project.

MobileFuture looks to float

MobileFuture, a wireless technology firm that claims to connect mobile phone users to the internet quicker than any other provider, plans to raise £4.7m through an Aim flotation.

Stockbroker Beeson Gregory is targeting a £15m-20m valuation for the Hertfordshire firm. In the 49 weeks to June 30 it recorded a turnover of £46,000 and a pre-tax loss of £663,000.

MobileFuture executives believe that users are frustrated by how slow most mobile devices connect to the internet and believes it can target a lucrative niche market by selling its technology to large network operators.

From Britannic to Post Office

Britannic said its finance director, Marisa Cassoni, would leave the insurance company at the beginning of next year to take up an appointment as group finance director at the Post Office.

Unilever to offload Arden

Unilever, the consumer products corporation, is in talks to sell its Elizabeth Arden cosmetics unit to US FFI Fragrances after management upheavals and patchy new product success.

The British-Dutch group has struggled to revive the Elizabeth Arden brand through the 1990s. With profits bouncing back recently, this is an ideal time to sell, according to the company.

Talks are centred on a price of $300m(£207m), but some analysts believe it could be as high as $350m depending on how many of Elizabeth Arden brands, such as Cerruti and Valentino, Unilever ends up keeping.

Owners fight burger boycott

Burger King's chief executive, Colin Storm, has asked American black activists to back away from a threatened boycott in support of La-Van Hawkins, a Detroit entrepreneur who operates dozens of Burger King restaurants, and who is in a $1.9bn (£1.3bn) court battle with the burger chain over his contract. Burger King is counter-suing for $8m.

webTitle: ISPs lose after day in traders' radar

fields.headline: ISPs lose after day in traders' radar
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Shares in the European internet sector took a hit yesterday despite rising expectations of further consolidation within the industry.
fields.body:
Shares in the European internet sector took a hit yesterday despite rising expectations of further consolidation within the industry.

Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, saw its stock fall, and the company - which rode the net wave to hit a peak of 978p in early March - ended the day down 11.75p, or 5.16%, at 216p. Italian ISP Tiscali lost more than 4% while France Telecom's net arm, Wanadoo, fell 7%.

Freenet was also on the trader's radar after Wanadoo said it was in talks with the German group, a 77%-owned subsidiary of telecommunications company Mobilcom.

Freenet responded coolly to Wanadoo chief executive Nicolas Dufourcq's revelation of negotiations. However Mobilcom - where France Telecom has a 28.5% stake - acknowledged that it was in talks with Wanadoo and others about the future of Freenet.

"We are looking at whether it makes sense for Freenet to join an international association", said Mobilcom spokesman Torsten Kollande. "We are examining which companies come into question and in what way that could happen."

fields.headline: M&S told to shut stores
fields.trailText: The gloom at Marks & Spencer was unabated yesterday with a new City warning that the shares are still overvalued.
fields.body:
The gloom at Marks & Spencer was unabated yesterday with a new City warning that the shares are still overvalued.

In a particularly downbeat assessment of M&S's prospects, analysts at brokers WestLB Panmure set a new target price for the shares of just 180p - and urged M&S to embark on a radical programme of store closures.

The WestLB conclusions came after a bad week for M&S investors. On Thursday the shares closed at less than 200p for the first time since the depths of the 1990 recession and yesterday they headed further down, finishing 3p lower at 196p. Analyst Emily Shamma at WestLB believes that M&S, under chairman Luc Vandevelde, is now making positive changes - but that they are too little and too slow, and that following the wholesale boardroom clearout Ms Shamma reckons M&S is still short of top talent.

She rates Roger Holmes, the group's new retail director, as "a competent individual", but is concerned that M&S has still not managed to fix a date for his arrival from Kingfisher and that he could find himself short of competent support.

"Holmes may be a good conductor, but we have concerns about the orchestra", she said. "In particular we are concerned that those responsible for recent disappointing seasons are those that will provide the merchant skills for the clothing-inexperienced Holmes."

WestLB, which is forecasting another dip in profits this year, expects M&S to announce cuts in trading space with its half-year results next month - but believes its plans will not go far enough.

Ms Shamma said M&S was frightened of the bad publicity that would accompany store closures but believes "an agressive downsize is a necessary evil" for long term recovery.

M&S meanwhile, is concentrating on the roll-out of its new concept stores, with improved store layouts.

fields.headline: Hewden price goes rampant
fields.trailText: After three profits warnings in a year from plant hire group Hewden-Stuart, the end could be in sight for long-suffering shareholders.
fields.body:
After three profits warnings in a year from plant hire group Hewden-Stuart , the end could be in sight for long-suffering shareholders.

They have watched the value of their investments fall 42% in 12 months but could soon be cheering the arrival of a 110p per share bid - if the market gossips are to believed.

There would be some logic in a takeover approach. Even after yesterday's strong gains - Hewden ended 4.5p, or 7.14%, higher at 67.5p - its shares are still trading at a discount to their net asset value of 82p.

Moreover, with few barriers to entry, the fragmented British market offers rich pickings for a big North American or German plant equipment supplier.

According to the gossips, the predator decided to make its move after seeing Hewden's interim figures last Thursday. Then, Hewden announced a 23% drop in pre-tax profits to £16m in the six months to July 31 and warned that it would struggle to match that performance in the second half of the year.

A spokesman for Hewden insisted the company was unaware of any approach, leaving observers to concluded that the bid was either hostile (unlikely) or (likely) that the tale was a Friday afternoon ramp. Given the fact that Hewden's chairman, Sir John Robb, was said to be at home suffering from toothache and was not, as was claimed, in the boardroom, most traders were settling on the latter.

Blue chips, meanwhile, closed higher after jumping 40 points in the controversial closing auction period.

Going into the auction the FTSE 100 had been trading lower, unsettled by some unfriendly economic data from the US. It came out the other end sporting a rise of 9.2 points to 6,391.2 - very mysterious. Dealers predicted a lower start on Monday.

Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 fell 9.8 points to 6,669.4 and the Techmark eased 1.35 to 3,728.67.

Neil Blackley, Merrill Lynch's top rated media analyst, was indulging in what seems to be his favourite pastime - bashing Granada Media . For the second time in 10 days Mr Blackley cut his profit forecasts for the group.

Although Mr Blackley's new downgrades were small, investors were taking no chances. After all, the last time Mr Blackley adjusted his forecasts Granada Media issued a warning on broadcasting revenues the next day.

Granada Media shares ended down 37.5p at 407p - the worst performer in the FTSE 100. The move also hurt its sister company (and 80% shareholder) Granada Compass , which was off 23p at 660p.

There was sibling rivalry of a different sort over at what used to be National Power. International Power , which now houses National Power's international operations, fell 9.5p to 315, after Deutsche Bank kicked the stock off of its influential European Focus List, replacing it with software group Misys , up 23p to 715p.

Meanwhile Innogy , the other half of the old National Power, rose 5p to 190p after Deutsche advised its clients to sell International Power and use the proceeds to buy Innogy.

Baltimore , the internet security company, dropped 15p to 660p after bearish comments from Nomura. fields.headline: Mayflower's rocky path
fields.trailText: John Harvey, the mysterious Barbados-based investor, has been at it again. He has acquired another 2.5m shares in Mayflower, the underperforming bus and truck maker - taking his holding to just over 5%.
fields.body:
John Harvey, the mysterious Barbados-based investor, has been at it again. He has acquired another 2.5m shares in Mayflower, the underperforming bus and truck maker - taking his holding to just over 5%.

Since he first revealed his interest in Mayflower last week its shares have risen steadily, but yesterday they closed 1p lower at 92.5p.

The problem seems to be that nobody has a clear idea of Mr Harvey's intentions. Although there has been speculation of a bid it is said that Mr Harvey's real intention is to increase his stake to 6%. This would make himthe firm's biggest investor and in the perfect position to agitate for change.

But while City professionals insist Mr Harvey has a history of taking stakes in undervalued companies ahead of corporate action, nobody has been able so far to come up with a concrete example.

fields.headline: New economy boost to manufacturing
fields.trailText: Record-breaking demand for mobile phones and high speed net access lifted manufacturing out of the doldrums in August, according to government figures which yesterday revealed a growing divide between the fortunes of new and old economy firms.
fields.body:
Record-breaking demand for mobile phones and high speed net access lifted manufacturing out of the doldrums in August, according to government figures which yesterday revealed a growing divide between the fortunes of new and old economy firms.

Manufacturing output rose by 0.8% in August, data from the Office for National Statistics showed, led by a 20% rise in mobile phone production - the largest since records began in 1979. But car production showed a sharp fall of 8.3% during the month.

"The disparities across manufacturing could hardly be more pronounced," said Geoffrey Dicks, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland.

"The 'new' sectors - IT, electrical and optical engineering plus defence, plus anyone selling into the US at a competitive $1.45, are doing well and earning good profits - and keeping quiet about it.

"Contrast the 'old' sectors selling into euroland at a very uncompetitive exchange rate, who are struggling and complaining," Mr Dicks said.

Industry representatives pointed out that without the contribution of hi-tech manufacturing, output would have been almost flat over the month. Stripping out electrical and optical equipment, manufacturing output expanded by just 0.1% in August, according to the ONS.

Firms in the so-called old economy sectors - basic metals, textiles and transport - are being priced out of highly competitive markets by the strength of sterling.

The motor industry contracted by 3.8% over the month, with the biggest fall coming in car making, which has been hit by expectations by consumers of lower prices.

"There is a two-speed economy within manufacturing, let alone a two-speed economy in manufacturing and services," said Sudhir Junankar of the CBI. "Those sectors that are more dependent on commodity products are still under tremendous pressure."

Yesterday's figures were encouraging for economists, who believe Britain could be on the verge of enjoying an American-style new economy boom.

The US economy has been expanding for more than nine years with few signs of inflation - partly as a result of ris ing hi-tech productivity.

"This has been a good day for those of us sympathetic to the notion that the 'new economy' effects are crossing the Atlantic," said Ciaran Barr, UK economist at Deutsche Bank.

The ONS said it had revised upwards its estimates of annual trend growth in manufacturing to 1.5% - and analysts said that despite gloomy headlines there were signs that the sector was returning to health after the last year's mini-recession.

"I think the story throughout this year is that the underlying picture on manufacturing has been better than a lot of the press stories would suggest," said Ian Stewart, an economist with the investment bank, Merrill Lynch.

"If you look at the more forward looking indicators from the CBI and the PMI, [Purchasing Managers Index] the order books have weakened, but they certainly have not collapsed and the general picture is one of sluggish but still positive output growth."

 Mobile phone operator Orange plans to create 1,500 jobs with the opening of a second customer services centre in north Tyneside. The £15m centre is due to open next August.

fields.headline: Seal snag
fields.standfirst: Dyson of washing machines delayed
fields.trailText: Dyson of washing machines delayed
fields.body:
The launch of Monotub Industries' revolutionary new washing machine has been delayed until February, because the company has had trouble getting hold of seals to prevent water leaking out writes Andrew Clark .

The widely hyped Titan washing machine has been tipped to be as influential in Britain's households as the Dyson bagless vacuum cleaner. It takes 40% more clothes than traditional models and uses 75% less water. Invented by Monotub's chairman Martin Myerscough, the machine was due to be launched this autumn. Yesterday's hold-up sent the company's shares down 55p to 450p. Mr Myerscough said: "The problem with start-ups is that you do encounter unexpected problems and delays." He said a supplier had been late in delivering special seals for the machines. This pushed the launch into the pre-Christmas period.

Retail chain Curry's, which has an exclusive deal to stock the machines for a four-month period, wanted to avoid a December launch because its shops are full of televisions and hi-fi systems for Christmas. So Mr Myerscough said the company had made a "grown-up decision" to wait until February. Mr Myerscough said Monotub had stepped up talks with continental retailers. "We're in discussions with people in Holland and France about an accelerated launch over there." Titan machines have a unique tilted drum, which makes access easier and allows the cycle to be stopped at any point without water spilling out.

Mr Myerscough, 57, whose full-time job is as finance director of the biotech firm KS Biomedix, has a 37% stake in Monotub. The value of his shares fell by £3m to £20m. The delay could cost Monotub several hundred thousand pounds, but the company has more than £3m cash in the bank.

webTitle: Guardian survey names worst endowment performers

fields.headline: Guardian survey names worst endowment performers
fields.trailText: A Guardian survey published today reveals that Pearl and Lloyds TSB have among the worst problems with failing mortgage endowments, with up to 40% of policies in serious shortfall compared to an industry average of 12%.
fields.body:
A Guardian survey published today reveals that Pearl and Lloyds TSB have among the worst problems with failing mortgage endowments, with up to 40% of policies in serious shortfall compared to an industry average of 12%.

Pearl says that 40% of its 140,000 policies have fallen into the "red" category of endowments, which are those most in danger of failing to pay off mortgage loans.

Lloyds TSB says that 31% of its 300,000 policies are in the "red" zone, with another 58% in the "amber" category.

Only one in 10 of its policies do not require a top-up, it says, with the average shortfall estimated at £4,000.

The figures are the first indication of which insurers face the biggest problems with failing policies. The Financial Services Authority confirmed earlier this week that 6.4m policies, 57% of the total, are "red" or "amber", where policyholders are recommended to pay in extra cash to ensure they meet their repayment targets.

But the FSA refused to name which companies are in the worst position, to the consternation of the Consumers' Association.

CA researcher Mick McAteer said: "The Guardian's figures confirm what we have feared - that there are big pockets of problem policies at particular insurers. We see no reason why the FSA should not force insurers to disclose the figures.

"Policyholders will be in a much stronger position to argue for compensation if they know that there are a large number of customers at their company in the same boat."

But Pearl and Lloyds TSB may not be the industry's worst. Many insurers, including some big providers, refused to cooperate in the survey.

A spokesman for Legal & General, which has 1.1m policies, said: "We are not publicising the split because there is a danger it will be misunderstood." Abbey National, which has 300,000 policies, described the figures as "com mercially sensitive". One high street bank is understood to have only 6% of policies in the all clear "green" category.

The survey reveals that two companies, Cooperative Insurance and Royal London, have a near-clean slate with regard to endowments. Royal London has just two of its 72,484 policies in the "red" category while Coop, with 187,114 policies, has none at all.

About half of the 1,500 complaints reviewed by the Financial Services Ombudsman have resulted in endowment holders receiving compensation. A further 3,500 are in the process of being investigated, the ombudsman said.

The FSA this week ruled out a comprehensive review of endowment policies but did say that it would "name and shame" a small group of insurers later this year where enforcement visits had identified serious shortcomings in endowment sales.

"Red" policies are defined by the FSA as needing more than 8% growth a year to meet their mortgage repayment target, while "amber" policies need 6-8% growth. The FSA says 6% growth a year is the prudent projection level for endowments in a period of low interest rates and low inflation.

webTitle: When losing a director is a rejoicing matter

fields.headline: When losing a director is a rejoicing matter
fields.standfirst: Board changes at BT and Eidos
fields.trailText: It was a tale of two finance directors in the City yesterday as Robert Brace from BT and Eidos' Jeremy Lewis quite their posts to "pursue fresh challenges". Investor reaction could hardly have been more different.
fields.body:
It was a tale of two finance directors in the City yesterday as Robert Brace from BT and Eidos' Jeremy Lewis quite their posts to "pursue fresh challenges". Investor reaction could hardly have been more different. At embattled Eidos, the company which gave the world Lara Croft, the share price tumbled 10%. The City was understandably nervous about the departure of a finance director in the middle of a takeover battle with not a word of explanation from the remaining board members.

But at BT news of Mr Brace's decision to cut the connection after 11 years was greeted with a £4bn surge in the company's value. Nothing, the City seemed to be saying, quite became Mr Brace's career at BT as the leaving.

It is true BT has problems. It is £30bn in debt and has come up with little to address the issue. It did promise a four way split, designed to reveal the underlying value of the business and boost the stock market value, but progress has been glacier-like.

But there is more to BT's travails than its debt mountain. Over the past five years it has frittered away huge advantages. In sectors like mobile telephony, the internet and business telecoms it has seen new, nimbler, more focused rivals steal its business or create whole new markets.

In recent months, as the share price has wilted from more than £15 to less than £7, investors have grown increasingly restless. They have demanded ac tion or scalps. Mr Brace has never been the City's favourite finance director but until now the board had stood squarely behind him. Interesting then, that his departure comes just as attention was beginning to focus higher up the executive ladder, first on chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and latterly on chairman Sir Iain Vallance.

Only this week BT pushed out a formal denial that Sir Iain was planning to step down early.

Driven crazy

Motorists must feel they live in a world of smoke and mirrors. Putting aside uncertainty about fuel prices on the forecourts, they now face a bewildering array of prices in car showrooms. As last month's figures showed, with an 8.7% fall in September sales, they are still waiting for even heftier cuts.

Yesterday MG Rover followed Monday's move by Ford and cut list prices in an effort to bring "clarity and stability" to the market. Some hopes. It will require very close scrutiny to find out whether the new list prices for different models are above, below or at the level of prices previously available under incentive packages.

What the manufacturers are doing is to bring list prices more closely in line with actual transaction prices following the government's August orders to force them to realign prices with those on the continent. But, by raising expectations, ministers, notably Stephen Byers at the DTI, must bear some responsibility for the resulting confusion and uncertainty.

The price war on the forecourt, moreover, has its own downside. Car makers live uncomfortably with margins touching a mere 2% and will seek to retain even these by squeezing dealers - and buying in even more components from abroad. Cheaper cars maybe but not made in the UK, not even in Nissan's Sunderland, Europe's most productive - and barely profitable - car plant.

Euro boost

If Britain in Europe had commissioned an academic to produce an economic model suggesting Britain's trade with the EU would triple if we swapped the pound for the euro, it would be easy to dismiss his findings as crude propaganda. But when a professor of economics from the University of California, Berkeley, one of the world's leading experts on international trade, produces such a model the results are worth a second look.

Andrew Rose's findings are based on an investigation involving 186 countries and nearly 34,000 bilateral trade observations. He finds that those nations which share the same currency trade three times as much with each other as they do with countries which have different currencies. In Britain's case, he reckons joining EMU could boost GDP by 20%.

A figure of that magnitude - enough to increase national income by roughly £200bn - certainly takes some swallowing, but even if Prof Rose's calculations are out by a wide margin, the gain would still be significant.

Of course, he offers no time scale for the predicted improvement in living standards and concedes that there are obstacles that could get in the way, such as the potential for more trade disputes and pressure for more labour market security resulting from bigger trade flows.

The big snag is that, however robust his model, the results are such that even enthusiasts for Britain accepting the euro might feel they are too good to be true.

fields.headline: At this price?  Computacenter
fields.trailText: Computacenter yesterday said it was no longer interested in making an offer for rival computer reseller Compel Group.
fields.body:
Computacenter yesterday said it was no longer interested in making an offer for rival computer reseller Compel Group.

On June 1 Computacenter indicated that it was prepared to pay around 275p per share in cash - an offer of around £85m that Compel insisted was opportunistic and too low. A Computacenter profits warning less than two weeks later seemed to scupper any deal anyway.

The only surprise is that it has taken the company so long to say it was no longer pursuing the bid. Analysts believe confirmation is further evidence of the fragility of the computer market and a sign that Computacenter has trading issues of its own to resolve before taking on anyone else's.

Computacenter has already said that margin pressure will continue into 2001. Compel itself said last month that the market for reselling remains weak and expenditure on IT in general remains depressed.

Low margins and revenue growth in the reselling industry make consolidation likely in the long run and Computacenter may play a leading part in this. For now though it should concentrate on its core business.

Investors appear to have two options. Those prepared to gamble on a potential spin off of Biomi, Computacenter's e-procurement business, securing a rumoured £600m valuation could find the remainder of the business valued very cheaply. Merrill Lynch says it would leave the core business trading on just 7.6 times 2000 earnings. In that event the stock could be a trading buy.

For the more risk-averse the more sensible route is to hold. This is a market that will recover slowly and could still generate further disappointment. Windows 2000 sales are not likely to affect hardware revenues until next year. Computacenter lacks scale in Europe and is still loss making.

The shares closed up 8.5p at 332.5p yesterday. The longer term future could be brighter though for those prepared to wait.

Merrill Lynch says it would leave the core business trading on just 7.6 times 2000 earnings. In that event the stock could be a trading buy. For the more risk-averse the more sensible route is to hold. This is a market that will recover slowly and could still generate further disappointment. Windows 2000 sales are not likely to affect hardware revenues until next year. Computacenter lacks scale in Europe and is still loss making. The shares closed up 8.5p at 332.5p yesterday. The longer term future could be brighter though for those prepared to wait.

fields.headline: Man's baser instincts at play
fields.standfirst: Quick returns are the name of the game
fields.trailText: Your risk appetite at any one moment will also depend on non-financial factors, such as which side of bed you got out of, whether the sun's shining or who you dined with last night. We've all experienced a rush of financial blood to the head that has puzzled or embarrassed us after the event. Even if it was to our advantage at the time.
fields.body:
Fancy a bet? You, me and this coin. I'll toss it, you call heads or tails. If I win, you pay me £100. And then that's the end of it. It's just a one-off. Interested? Possibly? Well, you tell me how much you want me to cough up if you win. £100? More? Less? It's not a trick question. There is no right or wrong answer. It's all a matter of your risk appetite. One would expect a sequence of 50:50 flutters to even out over a period. But a one-off is something altogether different. Just how much do you need to shoot for to compensate for the gut-wrenching feeling on losing £100?

Of course, your personal financial circumstances will be a key determinant of your answer. But this is not a simple, direct function of wealth. After all, the poorest people in the UK are often the heaviest players of the National Lottery, regardless of its outlandishly long odds. (Indeed, it is precisely because of its long odds that it lures the hard up.) However, on a straight toss of a coin, higher wealth will typically spell a greater willingness to embrace risk.

Your risk appetite at any one moment will also depend on non-financial factors, such as which side of bed you got out of, whether the sun's shining or who you dined with last night. We've all experienced a rush of financial blood to the head that has puzzled or embarrassed us after the event. Even if it was to our advantage at the time.

One of my colleagues, seeking further insight into the valuation mysteries of equity markets, this week posed this coin tossing question to 50 of our team at Old Mutual Securities. The answers ranged from £50 to £10,000, with £200 the most frequent reply. Apparently this is a typical result, which goes to show that stockbrokers have some regard for money.

In the interest of fairness, I'll have to try and forget what I've learnt about our staff before the time comes to dish out their pay and rations at the end of the year. After all, I now know that one member of the team values £100 200 times more highly than another. I think I'll fish a coin from my pocket and seek out those prepared to take me on for less than £101 - my personal answer to the survey. The unwillingness of most people to take on a perfectly balanced bet goes some way to explaining why over time equities tend to produce higher investment returns than both bonds and cash. Investors need to compensate for the downside risk inherent in equities. By contrast, cash is as safe as the bank it is deposited in. Bonds are as secure as their central bank or government guarantee.

Slough of despair

Over the course of the twentieth century US equities produced an annual return of 10.3%. Government bonds returned 4.7%. This is spookily consistent with the average desire to see a possible £200 win in return for a £100 risk on the toss of a coin.

This year, unless investor sentiment changes dramatically in the coming weeks, equity returns will fail to match those from bonds. So far in 2001, equity returns in both the US and UK lag 9% behind bonds. Globally, the shortfall is 2%.

The expectations of investors are typically formed by their most recent experiences. The future is assumed to be an extrapolation of the past , although different investors take different views of the time period over which the past should be measured. It is easy to see, then, how markets can work themselves into frenzies of excitement or sloughs of despair.

In the first quarter of 2000 frenzy, not slough, was the order of the day. Now, the reverse is true. It is very clear which side of the bed investors, collectively, are getting out of day after day after day.

Equity prices have fallen with no major change in the perception of background investment fundamentals. In these conditions, the expectation of future gains should have increased. However, investor appetite for risk has diminished, pushing up the level of returns demanded from equities by investors before they consider buying. In terms of our hypothetical toss of the coin, investors are now demanding a greater potential win before they'll risk their £100 stake.

Surefire winners

This change in the psychology of the markets is borne out by my everyday contact with investment institutions. One top performing unit trust manager confessed this week that he had to find some certain winners because a number of the flotations he backed at the start of the year are now holed below the waterline.

This desperation makes him less rather than more likely to back today's new issues because he dare not compound his problem. Actually, his best bet might be to increase his fund's commitment to flotations. The recent decline of equities has led to an exaggerated reduction in the valuation of companies coming to market. But then again, this is the real world.

The surreal investment world embraces a multiplicity of oddballs and oddball schemes. The latest to catch my eye is a planned day trading centre between the City and the West End, equipped with gym and wine bar to de-stress those held in thrall of their trading screens.

Call me old fashioned, if you like. Scorn me as a risk averse man who needs a £101 potential return before he will endanger £100. I just think day trading is a mug's game, appealing only to the financially desperate or those for whom risk is the drug of choice. There's little point in being hoity-toity about stock markets. Yes, they often resemble casinos. Yes, they encourage man's baser instincts. But for the sake of their long term health and reputation, the authorities must promote toindividuals the merits of informed investment over outright gambling.

The current correction in share prices will, in time, bring with it the seeds of eventual recovery. Perceptions of risk will adjust. By then, though, a slew of punters willing to risk £100 to gain £50 might find themselves bereft of coins to toss.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

fields.headline: SmithKline to swallow Sensodyne
fields.standfirst: Aquafresh maker lines up $1.2bn bid for privately owned toothpaste company Block Drug
fields.trailText: SmithKline Beecham, the owner of Aquafresh toothpaste, looks set to take a big bite out of the dental care market by snapping up Block Drug, the US manufacturer of Sensodyne.
fields.body:
SmithKline Beecham, the owner of Aquafresh toothpaste, looks set to take a big bite out of the dental care market by snapping up Block Drug, the US manufacturer of Sensodyne.

The pharmaceuticals company, which is in the middle of merging with rival Glaxo Wellcome, is lining up a bid for the up-for-sale business reported to be worth about $1.2bn (£800m).

Neither SmithKline nor Block would comment but an alysts said the combination made sense. Bill Blair of Nomura said: "Sensodyne is a very good brand and it would fit in a different market sector to Aquafresh."

Sensdodyne is targeted at people with particularly sensitive teeth, and does not compete directly with Aquafresh - a lower priced, high volume brand.

In addition to making Sensodyne, Block Drug manufactures cleansers and adhesives for false teeth, mouthwash, laxatives and ointment for nappy rash.

A family controlled business, Block Drug was established in 1907 by a Lithuanian pharmacist, Alexander Block, who opened a drugstore in Brooklyn, New York. The company, which joined the New York stock market in 1971, is chaired by Mr Block's grandson, James.

Members of the Block family have been frustrated by the company's poor share price performance, however.

They indicated their wish to sell up four months ago by appointing the investment bank Goldman Sachs to advise on "strategic options".

An auction has been gathering pace, with other possible bidders including the household products group Unilever and Colgate, the world's biggest toothpaste maker. SmithKline is thought to be among the leading contenders, but the outcome is by no means a foregone conclusion.

There was some surprise at SmithKline's interest because the drugs company is expected to concentrate on medicines after its merger with Glaxo. There has been speculation that the group's toothpaste business could be sold, along with its drinks operation - which owns Lucozade, Ribena and Horlicks.

One analyst said: "They've made noises about spinning these bits off. But by buying a business, integrating it and producing cost savings, they could make it more attractive for a future sale."

Earlier this year, there were suggestions that SmithKline was selling its consumer businesses to the Swiss healthcare group Novartis. However, this never materialised.

Block Drug has profit margins of about 20% - well above those of many other consumer healthcare companies. The company's sales last year rose 10% to $884m (£590m).

SmithKline's dental care products - which include Aquafresh, Macleans, Dr Best and German toothpaste Odol, notched up total sales of £585m last year.

SmithKline's former chief executive, Jan Leschly, who retired earlier this year, was keen on expanding the group's consumer healthcare business. He argued that by becoming an all-round supplier of goods to chemists, the company could keep control of older medicines which moved off prescription to become over-the-counter products.

However, Glaxo has taken a different view, preferring to specialise almost entirely on developing new prescription medicines.

The two companies are still awaiting clearance from the federal trade commission to complete their merger, which was originally due to be finalised in the summer.

fields.headline: Marconi goes for Nasdaq listing
fields.trailText: Marconi, the hi-tech communications group, yesterday announced it would expand its US base through a Nasdaq listing this month. The company aims to become a global rival in the telecoms market to US giants such as Cisco and Lucent.
fields.body:
Marconi, the hi-tech communications group, yesterday announced it would expand its US base through a Nasdaq listing this month. The company aims to become a global rival in the telecoms market to US giants such as Cisco and Lucent.

The group, which hopes to be a European version of Nortel, the US broadband equipment maker, said it would list its shares on Nasdaq in the week from October 16, paving the way for a further spate of North American acquisitions.

But Marconi sources denied that this was a prelude to moving the group, once Britain's premier engineering company as GEC, to the US where its communications division has its headquarters in Pittsburgh. "We are increasing the potential market to buy our shares and creating an acquisitions currency in the form of US paper. This has no implications for redomiciling the group," said the company.

Marconi, whose shares powered ahead 10p in London to close at 930p, plans rapidly to increase its North American shareholders from the current 10% and reduce its UK base which now accounts for 80% of equity.

fields.headline: Swell  seeker
fields.standfirst: Trimaran warship starts sea trials
fields.trailText: The world's first trimaran warship, Triton, embarked on 18 months of extensive trials yesterday from Portsmouth.
fields.body:
The world's first trimaran warship, Triton, embarked on 18 months of extensive trials yesterday from Portsmouth.

The largest steel trimaran in the world, Triton was built at the Vosper Thornycroft shipyard in Southampton, where workers face the threat of redundancy through lack of contracts. It displaces 1,100 tonnes, cost £13m to build and has a top speed of 20 knots.

The design will be adopted for the new generation of Royal Navy frigates and destroyers if tests for the Defence Evaluation and Research Agency (Dera) are successful. Triton will be sailing in search of heavy seas to prove the advantage of the triple hull design.
