fields.headline: House price rises still slowing
fields.trailText: The Halifax yesterday signalled a sharp slowdown in house price inflation next year that will result in average price rises of around 4%.
fields.body:
The Halifax yesterday signalled a sharp slowdown in house price inflation next year that will result in average price rises of around 4%.

The bank said the slump in the growth of house prices this year would continue into 2001 following a marked decline in the London and south east property prices during the third quarter compared to last year.

In the last quarter, the Halifax survey shows that house price inflation measured on a year-on-year basis in London was running at 13.2%, well below the 29.5% peak attained in the first quarter of this year.

But the bank's figures were in contrast to the Nationwide building society survey published earlier this week which predicted a softer landing for the property market. The Nationwide survey pointed to a 5-7% rise in house prices next year, saying that prices would recover next spring.

The average house price rose 1.1% in the third quarter to £85,332. However, the annual rise of 8.1% was down from the annual rate of 11.3% posted in the second quarter.

Earlier in the week the bank said a price rise in September of 1.6% was a blip.

Martin Ellis, Halifax chief economist, said: "We expect annual house price growth to ease further in the coming quarters, led by a continuing slowdown in the south."

Its regional breakdown of house prices for the third quarter showed there is still a sharp divide in prices between north and south.

The Halifax found prices in the south of England, where prices have boomed over the last 18 months, remained much higher than those in the rest of the UK.

The average price of a semi-detached house varied between £209,950 in Greater London to £42,850 in Dyfed, Wales, the bank said.

Prices in the north, which covers the north-east, have fallen by 1.3% over the past year while other areas such as Yorkshire and Humberside, the north-west and Wales experienced modest rises.

Wales and the north-west could join the north-east in registering an annual price drop if the cuts in prices during the last quarter of 2.1% and 0.3% respectively continue into next year as the Halifax predicts.

webTitle: Airtours man can join rival - in 2002

fields.headline: Airtours man can join rival - in 2002
fields.trailText: Airtours, Britain's biggest package tour operator, was last night attempting to thwart Thomson Travel's move to poach a senior executive by keeping him to two years' notice.
fields.body:
Airtours, Britain's biggest package tour operator, was last night attempting to thwart Thomson Travel's move to poach a senior executive by keeping him to two years' notice.

The resignation of Peter Rothwell, head of UK operations, was announced yesterday morning. The 41-year-old had agreed to become Thomson's chief operating officer, responsible for UK and international tours, distribution and aviation planning.

Airtours is understood to be keen on holding Mr Rothwell, who was privy to commercially sensitive information, to his two-year notice.

Industry observers said it was usual for a company to stipulate a period of "gardening leave" when an employee left to join a competitor.

Last night sources close to the companies expected the intervention of senior management or lawyers would be needed to resolve the dispute.

Analysts believe the news will be viewed negatively as market sentiment has swung against Airtours recently. Its shares tumbled earlier this week after a profits warning for its loss-making German unit Frosch Touristic.

The stock, which slipped another 1p to 215p yesterday, has underperformed the leisure sector by 32% so far this year.

A Thomson spokesman said: "We are sure this will be worked out in a sensible way."

Airtours declined to discuss the defection.

fields.headline: The last word on   Parents
fields.standfirst: The fundamental defect of parents is that they want their children to be a credit to them -   Bertrand Russell
fields.trailText: The fundamental defect of parents is that they want their children to be a credit to them - Bertrand Russell
fields.body:
This week saw the Human Rights Act take effect, a significant and largely beneficial change in the British constitution. But one matter it gives no guidance upon is the increasingly thorny question lying at the heart of current problems about parental rights, dramatised in recent days by several difficult cases: the Scottish parents of four boys who want to use in vitro techniques to replace their lost daughter, the American couple who had a genetically selected son to match their fatally-ill daughter's needs for donor tissue, and the Siamese twins dilemma settled by the appeal Court last week.

What is the extent of parents' rights in deciding what their offspring should be, and how they should be raised and treated? Few now think parents have absolute right over their children, but no one knows where the limits of parental autonomy lie. The two extremes in views about parental autonomy are marked by traditional China and Plato's Republic.

In old China parents, and especially fathers, had unrestricted rights over their children, whom they could put to death if displeased enough, and eat in times of famine (although as Lin Yutang fastidiously puts it, "we did not consume them raw, as the English do their beef"). In Plato's proto-fascistic Republic, children are brought up entirely by the state after being eugenically bred from the most handsome, clever and spirited youths and maidens available.

Nowadays we are pulled somewhat in the Platonic direction by our reason, and in the Chinese direction by our emotions. Reason tells us that it is right for the state to intervene when children are being harmed. But emotion makes us jealous of our right to decide how to raise our children, and - especially when the major part of that emotion is love - we vehemently oppose outside interference in our family life.

Predictably and familiarly, reason and emotion often conflict. When religious beliefs lead some parents to refuse life-saving blood transfusions for their children, should the state be empowered to overrule them? If so, where should the state's powers stop? Should it seek to protect children from being raised by devoutly religious people altogether, on the grounds that it is a form of abuse to brainwash children into false superstitions which might affect them throughout their lives? If that is a reasonable idea, what about the fact that few parents hesitate to encourage their children to share their political, moral and aesthetic tastes, with results that can be unhappy and even disastrous - should parents be left with a free hand here?

To find the right balance one has to begin by noting that biological and social parenthood are not the same thing, and skill at the latter does not automatically follow from the former. Parenthood in the social sense is sometimes better done by people other than biological parents, because what determines its adequacy is whether it provides the love, kindness and consistency needed by children, along with a good level of material and educational provision.

It therefore does not matter how many parents a child has, what sexes they are, or even whether they are genetically related, as long as love and resources are available. And also, therefore, society has to intervene when parents cannot themselves take decisions or provide care.

It can sometimes benefit parents as well as children when responsibility is transferred to less emotionally involved agents. As this suggests, society has an interest in children which occasionally, when it conflicts with parents' interests, can justifiably take precedence.

But this last point invites a serious caution. There can be few general principles in this domain other than those about children's welfare and the requirements of justice. Questions about who has the right to determine a child's welfare have to be individually answered, with the onus on justifying an abrogation of parental rights. That is a safeguard against Plato's Republic creeping nearer - but not as effective as the wisdom and generosity of parents themselves in being good at their task.
fields.bodyText: This week saw the Human Rights Act take effect, a significant and largely beneficial change in the British constitution. But one matter it gives no guidance upon is the increasingly thorny question lying at the heart of current problems about parental rights, dramatised in recent days by several difficult cases: the Scottish parents of four boys who want to use in vitro techniques to replace their lost daughter, the American couple who had a genetically selected son to match their fatally-ill daughter's needs for donor tissue, and the Siamese twins dilemma settled by the appeal Court last week. What is the extent of parents' rights in deciding what their offspring should be, and how they should be raised and treated? Few now think parents have absolute right over their children, but no one knows where the limits of parental autonomy lie. The two extremes in views about parental autonomy are marked by traditional China and Plato's Republic. In old China parents, and especially fathers, had unrestricted rights over their children, whom they could put to death if displeased enough, and eat in times of famine (although as Lin Yutang fastidiously puts it, "we did not consume them raw, as the English do their beef"). In Plato's proto-fascistic Republic, children are brought up entirely by the state after being eugenically bred from the most handsome, clever and spirited youths and maidens available. Nowadays we are pulled somewhat in the Platonic direction by our reason, and in the Chinese direction by our emotions. Reason tells us that it is right for the state to intervene when children are being harmed. But emotion makes us jealous of our right to decide how to raise our children, and - especially when the major part of that emotion is love - we vehemently oppose outside interference in our family life. Predictably and familiarly, reason and emotion often conflict. When religious beliefs lead some parents to refuse life-saving blood transfusions for their children, should the state be empowered to overrule them? If so, where should the state's powers stop? Should it seek to protect children from being raised by devoutly religious people altogether, on the grounds that it is a form of abuse to brainwash children into false superstitions which might affect them throughout their lives? If that is a reasonable idea, what about the fact that few parents hesitate to encourage their children to share their political, moral and aesthetic tastes, with results that can be unhappy and even disastrous - should parents be left with a free hand here? To find the right balance one has to begin by noting that biological and social parenthood are not the same thing, and skill at the latter does not automatically follow from the former. Parenthood in the social sense is sometimes better done by people other than biological parents, because what determines its adequacy is whether it provides the love, kindness and consistency needed by children, along with a good level of material and educational provision. It therefore does not matter how many parents a child has, what sexes they are, or even whether they are genetically related, as long as love and resources are available. And also, therefore, society has to intervene when parents cannot themselves take decisions or provide care. It can sometimes benefit parents as well as children when responsibility is transferred to less emotionally involved agents. As this suggests, society has an interest in children which occasionally, when it conflicts with parents' interests, can justifiably take precedence. But this last point invites a serious caution. There can be few general principles in this domain other than those about children's welfare and the requirements of justice. Questions about who has the right to determine a child's welfare have to be individually answered, with the onus on justifying an abrogation of parental rights. That is a safeguard against Plato's Republic creeping nearer - but not as effective as the wisdom and generosity of parents themselves in being good at their task.

webTitle: Let's face it: winning the quiz really does matter

fields.headline: Let's face it: winning the quiz really does matter
fields.trailText: We went to quiz night at our daughter's school a week ago. It was packed, of course. There's something about quizzes which fascinates the British middle classes. It matters. Our table came eighth, or something like that, and I don't mind admitting that it hurt. (Our worst round was one where you had to say which piece of music was used to advertise which car on TV, but I suspect it was everyone's worst round. We can remember the ads - Claudia Schiffer stripping off, all those gorgeous young couples having sex - but no one can ever recall which marques are being promoted.)

Our table came eighth, or something like that, and I don't mind admitting that it hurt. (Our worst round was one where you had to say which piece of music was used to advertise which car on TV, but I suspect it was everyone's worst round. We can remember the ads - Claudia Schiffer stripping off, all those gorgeous young couples having sex - but no one can ever recall which marques are being promoted.)

Every year we spend a weekend with friends in Thorpeness, Suffolk, and we always go to the regular Sunday night family quiz. And every year the town seems to be racked with terrible rumours about people cheating. It was alleged darkly that one family, not knowing the patron saint of doctors, actually sent a child out to the tennis courts to ask a GP who was playing there.

Another time the local MP, John Gummer, was accused of having three adults on his table instead of the maximum permitted two. I had reason to take him to lunch soon afterwards and began by saying that there was something important I had to ask him, and that if we cleared it out of the way we could relax and enjoy the lunch. He looked deeply worried, but when I told him of the charge he erupted in a fury.

"I did not cheat!" he said. "My poor wife Penny was not taking part in the quiz but she had to go and sit in the bar, on her own, because people kept talking loudly about how we were only allowed two adults, and I'm sick of it!" But that's quizzes for you; they arouse huge passions and mighty resentments.

Last year we took part in a junior school quiz. Next day a woman neighbour, who I know as a pleasant person, asked: "Aren't you going to congratulate us on our success last night?" I said I thought she'd only come fourth. "But we beat you, and that's all that counts!" she finished.

 It was kind of so many of you to write, but I wish now I hadn't asked for help on the "he is taller than me/I" question. Along with quizzes, British people seem obsessed by grammar. I've had innumerable letters and emails, mostly good-humoured but in some cases surprisingly bitter, angry and prescriptive. And long. Heavens, you wouldn't believe how much people can write about two words, one of which is only one letter long.

I'd say there was a narrow majority for the accusative case. Quite a lot of you think that "he is taller than I" sounds pretentious and clunky, even if it is technically correct. Others dispute even that, claiming that "than I", with an implied "am" at the end, is a grammarians' invention, dating from the time when they wanted to force the English language into Latin formulations. Another exam ple is the pointless banning of the split infinitive (though the most famous example of that, Star Trek's "to boldly go", sounds very peculiar to me.

Several point out that our language owes as much to Norman French as to Latin, and the French would always use the strong accusative, "toi" and "moi". But either way, I shall continue using "me" and the correspondence is closed.

 At a whisky reception the other day, I met a man with the splendid title of Professor the Lord Laird of Artigarvan. Even more resonant is his job description, printed on his card in what I thought was Gaelic, yet was instantly understandable: "Heid-Yin o tha Boord o Ulster Scotch." Sadly it turns out to be some weird spoof language which doesn't exist.

 No bore is worse than a football bore, so I'll keep this short. For someone who was raised in Leicester from the age of 13, and who walked to Filbert Street with his brother every fortnight through the season, it is highly gratifying to see Leicester City on top of the Premiership, even if none of the present team was born when I was a regular. Yes, I know it won't last - they play Manchester United in a week's time - and I know that they're thought dogged but dull. But please allow us our brief moment of glory.

Lacking big money, Leicester have always had to rely on finding their own talent, including Gordon Banks, Gary Lineker and Emile Heskey. There was a fascinating table published this week showing which Premiership teams use the most foreigners. Chelsea were, of course, top with an average of 8.88 foreigners starting in each game. (Arsenal were second with 7.0). Leicester are comfortably bottom, using an average of only 0.88 foreigners at the beginning of each game.

Perhaps if other clubs did a bit more nurturing at home, we might be facing today's game with Germany with a little more confidence.

 The wine writer Tim Atkin was baffled the other day on a trip to Chablis. A Finnish writer on the trip remarked "your cow is in the ditch" and all the other Finns at the table fell about laughing. Apparently it means that you are caught between two stools.

Tim reminds me of his favourite from the great New Statesman competition for meaningless saws: "No leg is too short to reach the ground." I liked "seek not the apple blossom upon the cherry tree". Other examples, real or invented, are welcome.

 At the British Council reception I chatted to Ffion Hague, who's on their board. I can see why the Tories wish she would do more public appearances. She is poised, witty, beautiful, has a lovely speaking voice, and possesses that remarkable gift some women have: she can make any man within 50 yards feel, for a few moments, that he is the most fascinating person in the world. Princess Di had the same knack, which is why weary old goats like me were so completely won over.

I was in a group with my old friend John Cassidy, who comes from Leeds but now works for the New Yorker and is over here researching an article about William Hague.

"So we have an interest in common," he said to her, by way of small talk.

"Well, at least you don't have a haircut in common," Ffion said.

"So that's seen him off," I said, pointing to John, who has a perfectly normal bogbrush haircut.

"Oh, no," she said, genuinely worried that she'd caused offence. "I was complimenting his haircut."

Spelling it out in unnecessary detail, I said, "so by implication..."

"Yes!" she said. No wonder men bend like aspens in the wind.

fields.headline: Dead reckoning
fields.standfirst:
The readers' editor on... using pictures of the boy shot in Gaza
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... using pictures of the boy shot in Gaza
fields.body:
On Tuesday this week the lead story in our tabloid second section, G2, was about the shooting in Gaza of the 12-year-old Palestinian boy, Mohammed al-Durrah. It was illustrated with all but one of the eight available frames showing the last moments of the boy's life, filmed by a Palestinian cameraman working for French television.

These images were shown on television on Saturday night. Two of the frames appeared on the front page of late editions of the Observer, the only paper to use them so prominently on Sunday - something for which several of the paper's readers criticised it (in my view misguidedly, or let us say precipitately, since I believe that the events of the week have endorsed the decision to use the pictures).

I inquired about the reaction from Observer readers to see whether it had differed in any way from the response to the Guardian's use of these images. On almost every occasion in the past three years when we have used pictures as strong as these, and certainly when we have shown pictures of dead people - in Northern Ireland, Kosovo, Sierra Leone or Zimbabwe - a number of you have complained, and on all of those occasions we have considered the pros and cons in this column. This time, by Thursday anyway, many of you had voiced your reaction to the event, and a selection of your letters was published, but no one complained that our use of the pictures was intrusive, exploitative, cynical or sensational, the accusations made on previous occasions. Did we do something right?

By the time the Guardian used the pictures on Tuesday it seems likely that most of the paper's readers had seen some of them already. By Tuesday our website had considered and rejected the idea of putting up the movie footage, I think rightly, although one of the senior journalists involved in our treatment of the story in the paper said he could not see any distinction in ethical terms between showing still pictures (which we did) and moving pictures (which we did not). Can you?

Our Middle East editor has written about this in his column on our website. For those of you who do not have internet access, this is what he says: "Inevitably, video clips have appeared on the internet and now all you need do is click your mouse to have Mohammed brought back to life and shot again and again and again. Apart from being unbelievably ghoulish, this removes the event from the brutal realities of Middle East politics and dumps it in the realm of fantasy video games."

Let us turn back to G2. The front page was stripped of the contents panel that normally runs across the top of the page and instead the contents were flagged in a single line across the foot of the page. This released almost the whole of the page for an image of the terrified Mohammed sheltering beneath the protective arm of his father. It carried the headline: What really happened at Netzarim crossroads?

The following three pages, which included six more of the images from the sequence, sought an answer. Our correspondent went to the scene, spoke to the cameraman, and interviewed the boy's mother and others in a straightforward and memorable piece of reporting that suggested that the boy and his father had been targeted and shot by Israeli soldiers. The Israeli authorities have since said the two were mistaken for gunmen.

The deputy editor (news) said that looking at the situation on Monday he felt that what was needed was a piece of reporting to try to cut through the obfuscation that was then prevalent. The presentation was obviously shocking but not gratuitously so. "For all sorts of reasons you wanted to know exactly what had happened. The boy and his father were there for something like 45 minutes. You felt indignation. And the internal reaction, the reaction inside Israel - 21 lines in the main paper - was past understanding."

The editor of G2 said the image on the front on Tuesday would radicalise you. "It would make you want to pick up a stone." But he said his main anxiety was not to act as judge and jury. If it was a trial you would want more evidence than we had been able to produce, good though it was.

I asked the journalist who wrote the report what effect she thought the pictures had had. She said inside the country they had hardened the hearts of Israelis and made the Palestinians more violent. She felt that more rather than fewer people had died as an immediate result.

Farther away, we hope they have a different effect. Someone in the office said, "You immediately think of the child closest to you, whether you have children of your own or not." You want it to stop. In passing we might ask ourselves what we know about the other children, one of them only two years old, who have died in the violence this week.

 For more on our coverage of the events in Israel and the Middle East visit: www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/israel Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Can't anybody just be me?
fields.trailText: Can anything check the rise of the solipsist? My own poor old trade is now ineradicably polluted by people whose only function is to blather about themselves, and now the same infection is sweeping over politics too.
fields.body:
Can anything check the rise of the solipsist? My own poor old trade is now ineradicably polluted by people whose only function is to blather about themselves, and now the same infection is sweeping over politics too. There used to be a moment at the end of his shows where the impressionist Mike Yarwood would stop being Harold Wilson and Edward Heath and Robin Day and say: "And now this is me."

The same practice has been apparent through this year's party conference season. There was that point in Tony Blair's speech at Brighton where he suddenly abandoned his text and spoke spontaneously (we were supposed to think) from the heart. A lot of people in the hall seemed to find this profoundly moving. Watching it on TV, I found it creepy. Even his diction changed: all at once he was in his chat show mode, saying ah instead of I, and glottal-stopping away like a totter from Tooting. If this is the real Blair, I thought, who was that well-spoken chap we've been listening to for the previous 40 minutes?

Then at Bournemouth this week we had that tear-stained sequence when Michael Portillo, abandoning his text altogether and speaking (we were supposed to think) spontaneously from the heart, came out as - well, all sorts of things. A Spaniard, for instance. And a hospital porter.

This also explains a phenomenon which has baffled Smallweed all year. Why do people warm to Charles Kennedy when he says so little of substance? His leader's speech at the Lib Dem conference last month was as vacuous a concoction as Smallweed has heard in 40 years of conference-going. Yet he is the one whose ratings are rising. Is it perhaps precisely because he seems so unpolitical that the nation is growing to like him?

For reasons beyond my control I write without having seen William Hague's performance, but I think it is pretty clear what form it will have taken. Suddenly half way through he will have abandoned his text, left the rostrum, stood at the end of the stage and begun to confess the terrible grief he felt at the age of four when his teddy bear was snaffled in a Rotherham park by a labrador. With the hall now awash with tears, the mood will then have changed with the appearance of those stroppy sisters of his, as seen on TV last weekend, and a song-and-dance routine of 60s hits will have ensued.

Finally, amidst vast ululations, Ffion will have dropped from the rafters on to the stage like Peter Pan in the pantomime, and she and William will then have gone into a snoggy clinch far out-Goreing the Gores. In the end, the party chairman, a Mr Ancram, will only have prised them apart by throwing large amounts of cold water over them.

Exactly the same is happening in the US. I saw a focus group session after the Gore-Bush encounter in which a woman who looked like an adult said she was swinging to Bush because though Gore had a much better command of the issues. Bush seemed the sweeter guy. A woman who put it the other way round - Bush seemed the nicer guy, but Gore was more in command of the issues and therefore more voteworthy - came across as a frosty old puritan.

Is this is the way the leadership of the world's most powerful nation stands to be decided? Has there ever (final rhetorical question) been a sillier age than ours?

Incidentally, Smallweed was astonished to hear a BBC reporter predicted that Tory chairman Ancram would give a barnstorming speech. I know that as party chairman he has to pretend, like poor old Chris Patten before him, to be what he clearly is not, but barnstorming is not a world I would ever have attached to him.

Were I a barn, I would feel quite unworried if I saw Ancram approaching armed to the teeth. Though he might be uttering monstrous menaces, I would know that when he reached me he would not go through with any of them, but would whip out a guitar and serenade me with whatever brand of music he'd expect a barn to enjoy. Barn dance music, presumably.

Enough of that. The season is changing. For reasons beyond my control, the winds are rocking the trees, and the skies are still dark when I wake in the morning. The stores, meanwhile, are full of Christmassery, and soon one will have to avoid them altogether because the air will be fill of saccharine songs about Santa and sleigh bells. For Christmas this year I intend to give almost everyone one of the most entertaining books in the world: A Lexicon of Musical Invective, by Nicolas Slonimsky, a compilation of insults hurled, mostly by critics, at notable music.

But who - I hear Arthur Tartt, of Northowram, Halifax asking - is Slonimsky? Sadly he recently died, having first passed 100, but he used to be a musicologist, composer, conductor and pianist who performed some of the works most complained about. "For two hours," wrote a critic when he conducted Varèse in Berlin in 1932, "Slonimsky bore down on the Philharmonic musicians until they finally made no secret of their ugly disposition."

After his performance of the same composer's Ionaization at the Hollywood Bowl the following year, he received a postcard imploring him to perform the writer's own composition scored for two stoves and a kitchen sink. It was signed: Iona Lotta Bunk (probably a pseudonym).

His Lexicon is rarely to be spotted in bookshops, so between now and Christmas I hope to unleash some of the riper gems in this great man's collection in the hope that stockists will get the message and race out to order copies from the Washington University Press.

And finally, yet another strange death of a famous musician. The opera composer Vincenzo Bellini (who wrote Norma and La Sonnambula) died in Paris, where he had fled to avoid a scandal, in 1835, a few weeks short of his 34th birthday. The cause of death was given as dysentery and gastro-enteritis. But there have long been suspicions that Bellini was actually poisoned by the husband of one of the many wives to whom he had helped himself. It is now proposed to exhume his remains.

Smallweed@theguardian.com

Even his diction changed: all at once he was in his chat show mode, saying ah instead of I, and glottal-stopping away like a totter from Tooting. If this is the real Blair, I thought, who was that well-spoken chap we've been listening to for the previous 40 minutes? Then at Bournemouth this week we had that tear-stained sequence when Michael Portillo, abandoning his text altogether and speaking (we were supposed to think) spontaneously from the heart, came out as - well, all sorts of things. A Spaniard, for instance. And a hospital porter. This also explains a phenomenon which has baffled Smallweed all year. Why do people warm to Charles Kennedy when he says so little of substance? His leader's speech at the Lib Dem conference last month was as vacuous a concoction as Smallweed has heard in 40 years of conference-going. Yet he is the one whose ratings are rising. Is it perhaps precisely because he seems so unpolitical that the nation is growing to like him? For reasons beyond my control I write without having seen William Hague's performance, but I think it is pretty clear what form it will have taken. Suddenly half way through he will have abandoned his text, left the rostrum, stood at the end of the stage and begun to confess the terrible grief he felt at the age of four when his teddy bear was snaffled in a Rotherham park by a labrador. With the hall now awash with tears, the mood will then have changed with the appearance of those stroppy sisters of his, as seen on TV last weekend, and a song-and-dance routine of 60s hits will have ensued. Finally, amidst vast ululations, Ffion will have dropped from the rafters on to the stage like Peter Pan in the pantomime, and she and William will then have gone into a snoggy clinch far out-Goreing the Gores. In the end, the party chairman, a Mr Ancram, will only have prised them apart by throwing large amounts of cold water over them. Exactly the same is happening in the US. I saw a focus group session after the Gore-Bush encounter in which a woman who looked like an adult said she was swinging to Bush because though Gore had a much better command of the issues. Bush seemed the sweeter guy. A woman who put it the other way round - Bush seemed the nicer guy, but Gore was more in command of the issues and therefore more voteworthy - came across as a frosty old puritan. Is this is the way the leadership of the world's most powerful nation stands to be decided? Has there ever (final rhetorical question) been a sillier age than ours? Incidentally, Smallweed was astonished to hear a BBC reporter predicted that Tory chairman Ancram would give a barnstorming speech. I know that as party chairman he has to pretend, like poor old Chris Patten before him, to be what he clearly is not, but barnstorming is not a world I would ever have attached to him. Were I a barn, I would feel quite unworried if I saw Ancram approaching armed to the teeth. Though he might be uttering monstrous menaces, I would know that when he reached me he would not go through with any of them, but would whip out a guitar and serenade me with whatever brand of music he'd expect a barn to enjoy. Barn dance music, presumably. Enough of that. The season is changing. For reasons beyond my control, the winds are rocking the trees, and the skies are still dark when I wake in the morning. The stores, meanwhile, are full of Christmassery, and soon one will have to avoid them altogether because the air will be fill of saccharine songs about Santa and sleigh bells. For Christmas this year I intend to give almost everyone one of the most entertaining books in the world: A Lexicon of Musical Invective, by Nicolas Slonimsky, a compilation of insults hurled, mostly by critics, at notable music. But who - I hear Arthur Tartt, of Northowram, Halifax asking - is Slonimsky? Sadly he recently died, having first passed 100, but he used to be a musicologist, composer, conductor and pianist who performed some of the works most complained about. "For two hours," wrote a critic when he conducted Varèse in Berlin in 1932, "Slonimsky bore down on the Philharmonic musicians until they finally made no secret of their ugly disposition." After his performance of the same composer's Ionaization at the Hollywood Bowl the following year, he received a postcard imploring him to perform the writer's own composition scored for two stoves and a kitchen sink. It was signed: Iona Lotta Bunk (probably a pseudonym). His Lexicon is rarely to be spotted in bookshops, so between now and Christmas I hope to unleash some of the riper gems in this great man's collection in the hope that stockists will get the message and race out to order copies from the Washington University Press. And finally, yet another strange death of a famous musician. The opera composer Vincenzo Bellini (who wrote Norma and La Sonnambula) died in Paris, where he had fled to avoid a scandal, in 1835, a few weeks short of his 34th birthday. The cause of death was given as dysentery and gastro-enteritis. But there have long been suspicions that Bellini was actually poisoned by the husband of one of the many wives to whom he had helped himself. It is now proposed to exhume his remains. Smallweed@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The secret Edward Elgar
fields.standfirst: Birmingham was the perfect place to celebrate The Dream of Gerontius centenary.  Andrew Clements  on what the work says about its composer
fields.trailText: Birmingham was the perfect place to celebrate The Dream of Gerontius centenary. Andrew Clements on what the work says about its composer
fields.body:
One hundred years ago last Tuesday, Elgar's The Dream of Gerontius was first performed in Birmingham town hall as part of the city's triennial festival. The premiere was not a success; the choir could not cope with Elgar's choral writing, the tenor appeared to believe that he was singing Victorian drawing-room ballads and the bass was a semitone flat throughout his solo in the second part. Only the mezzo-soprano soloist acquitted herself well. Elgar was devastated, and the score was only gradually recognised for the extraordinary achievement that it is.

In Birmingham, the centenary was marked on the day itself, not in the town hall but in Symphony Hall just a couple of hundred yards away, when Gerontius was conducted by Sakari Oramo with the City of Birmingham Symphony Chorus and Orchestra, and an international trio of soloists in a performance that was certainly worthy of the occasion.

The choir had learnt the work by heart and delivered it from the heart, producing singing of huge intensity and dramatic involvement and, although the tenor, American Vinson Cole, was by no means ideal (making some of his phrase too expressively Italianate, and coming up with some very strange vowel sounds), the other two soloists were superb. John Tomlinson was a terrifying Priest and Angel of the Agony, sounding for all the world as if Hagen had survived from Gotterdammerung to take up another role in the afterlife, while Anne Sofie von Otter was simply the best Angel, ravishingly beautiful, that I have heard since Janet Baker, and there can be no higher praise than that.

It's an often repeated observation that if Elgar had been born a German he would have written operas, while if his contemporary Richard Strauss had been an Englishman he would have produced oratorios. Both composers were conditioned by the musical culture in which they grew up. Yet that doesn't make Elgar a peculiarly English composer (or Strauss a particularly Austro-German one for that matter); great composers transcend that kind of labelling anyway. As Gerontius and the major works that came after it - the symphonies and the concertos - demonstrate, he was arguably the least English in his musical outlook of all early 20th-century British composers, with his musical roots in Brahms, Schumann and Wagner; if there is any specific model for Gerontius it is Parsifal, not any of the pallid Victorian oratorios that epitomised the English choral tradition in 1900.

But then Elgar's supposed quintessential Englishness has always been a fiction, the artifact of a musical society that had to find ways of dealing with his genius on terms they could understand; hence the appropriation of Nimrod from the Enigma Variations as some kind of distillation of imperial nobility. And that image of the young Elgar galloping across the Malvern Hills to the accompaniment of the Introduction and Allegro for strings in Ken Russell's famous film is another example of the same make-believe; if you want to regard an English composer as a poet of landscape look at George Butterworth or Vaughan Williams, but not at Elgar.

Gerontius proclaims Elgar as an outsider in the musical establishment; he was a Roman Catholic by upbringing and this is after all a profoundly Roman Catholic work, setting words by the most controversial of 19th- century English theologians Cardinal Newman, yet given its first performance in a city that was the centre of non-conformism in Victorian Britain. To suggest, as Norman Lebrecht did on Radio 4's Today programme on Tuesday that The Dream of Gerontius is an "insincere" piece is absurd; even had Elgar not been contemplating a work on Newman's poem for a decade before the Birmingham commission sparked him into creative action, what possible mileage would there have been in career terms in arousing hostility in his choice of subject matter? He wrote Gerontius because he had to. It remains his greatest choral work and one of his masterpieces, a work by a composer who ranks alongside the finest.

fields.headline: Quick squirt
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
Stress affects us all in different ways, even in homogeneous old Ambridge. David, faced with a nasty outbreak of mastitis (not on his person you understand), is businesslike breezy: "Quick squirt, that should do it." For Jolene, the days when Sid had such sweet nothings to whisper in her ear are long gone. Now it's only talk of alimony and maintenance, and she's not happy, not happy at all.

"Whatever happens to me happens to you," she hissed, and not in a lovey-dovey way. Having listened to Stressed Out (Radio 4), I could recognise the signs all too easily. Jolene, as the Dolly Parton ballad forewarned, finds herself in what anthropologists and Cary Cooper, that ubiquitous psychologist with a name like a film star, call a "fight or flight situation". This is not, as I first heard it, a fight or Flyte (those low-fat scary airy chocolate bars) situation, but the instinctive, primeval response our bodies make to stressful situations.

The consequences of stress are more far-reaching than you might think. We know that prolonged bouts of anxiety can lead to ill health. A child born to a stressed woman (a major cause of premature birth), for example, will have a predilection towards stress for life. Some studies have shown that relaxation and hypnosis can give cancer sufferers a significantly longer life. The cure? A healthy lifestyle with lots of quality, slightly self-indulgent time, and power naps, apparently. Salvador Dali is one of the famous names to have recharged his batteries thus. There, what a role model.

There can be other, nicer kinds of stress, like a very public, nostalgic reunion. This was what Jo Whiley and Steve Lamacq enjoyed this week, as part of the quite justifiably over-the-top celebrations for a decade of the Evening Session (Radio 1). One of the jewels in the station's rather lopsided crown, it kicked off its celebratory week with a live set from Radiohead on the day Kid A was released. There was a newsy look back over the past 10 years: when the Session began, things were rather different: Madchester, mad Thatcher and mad Operation Desert Storm. Nirvana were "this little band", and Lamacq was at the NME.

He had previously worked on a local paper in Essex and a colleague called in with fond memories of the man who would go on to own a greyhound with Damon from Blur. They nostalged away in very Evening Session fashion. Long may it continue.

webTitle: Come on, kd, give us one of your hits

fields.headline: Come on, kd, give us one of your hits
fields.standfirst: kd lang spurned the crowd and stuck to her romantic songs.  Caroline Sullivan  almost dozed off
fields.trailText: kd lang spurned the crowd and stuck to her romantic songs. Caroline Sullivan almost dozed off
fields.body:
It says something about people's innate conservatism that kd lang, who's no longer anyone's idea of a radical lesbian, still makes heterosexuals so uncomfortable that they keep her sexuality at arm's length.

In the Brighton Centre bar, before the show there on Tuesday, one of the few straight women in the crowd said: "I think of her as a cute boy rather than a woman, and then it's fine." Never mind that on the cover of her latest album, Invincible Summer, a sun-dappled lang is most definitely a girl; in the minds of most, she will always be the dieselish chap beaming from the cover of Vanity Fair with shaving foam all over her face and Cindy Crawford's razor inches away.

The overwhelmingly gay female bias of the audience gives her gigs a cultish feel that kd herself seems ambivalent about. She doesn't discourage the fans' risque banter, exactly, but she doesn't participate, and her mainly male band is as geezerish an assemblage as any you'd find backing Paul Weller. Riot Grrrl it's not. lang's current strategy is to edge mainstream and reconnect with the millions who bought 1992's Ingenue album.

As ever, her voice is a thing of springwater purity that redeems even the most middle of the road numbers, of which there are a good few. Half a dozen songs pass in a comfy blur of pedal-steel guitar and kd's embracing croon. She wanders the stage absently, doing a little hula dance to the surf pastiche Summerfling, and flirtatiously raising her baggy top (cue squeals) on the loungey Extraordinary Thing. Mere ballast, really - she doesn't stretch herself till halfway through, with Roy Orbison's Cryin', which has been in lang's set for years and with good reason. The exquisite melody and lang's simple, aching delivery produces chills every time.

This sublime moment is followed by a request from the balcony that she "sing some old songs". They mean "some hits", but lang deflects it by announcing we're about to enter "the dark, luscious waters of romance" with more numbers from Invincible Summer. I'm lulled into a doze by the soporific adult-orientated rock. Come on, kd, act your shoe size, not your age.

 kd lang plays Hammersmith Apollo, London (0870 606 3400), tonight, and then tours.

fields.headline: Snowdonia
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
We came up to the broad, marshy floor of Cwm Eigiau the other day, just as the clouds were breaking to let sunbeams dance across the heathery shoulders of what is, in my opinion, a sombre hollow.

Part of the trouble is that for a large part of the day the light is contre jour as you go up towards the crags - you are looking at the shaded sides of Pen Llithrig y Wrach and Pen yr Helgi Du and so they appear as great, dark wedges threatening this constricted, rushy head of hollow. When rain is falling or about to fall, Cwm Eigiau isn't a favourite spot, but on this morning we were soon up above the abandoned slate workings and sloshing up the virtually pathless eastern flank of Carnedd Llewelyn, and the fitful sun was shining.

A path marked on the map hardly exists on the ground, so you must make your own way up to the broad, grassy top of the ridge. There's a fine view down into crag-girt Cwm Dulyn if you're lucky. Here is a hollow which contains a lake so forbidding that it was traditionally avoided by all wild swans and ducks and contained nothing but deformed fish. A causeway was said to run down into its bottomless waters and its farthest stone was called the Red Altar. It was believed that someone brave enough to stand on the causeway and throw water on the Red Altar could ensure rain before nightfall, even in the hottest weather.

We continued up to the lonely crest of the ridge as wet mist blew in from the west. It could well have been midwinter as we turned towards the south, towards the stony top of Foel Grach, and took temporary shelter in the refuge hut just below the 3,195 feet summit. Later in the day we traversed the broad top of Foel Fras (the rough hill) and turned down under brighter skies where Carneddau's wild ponies were grazing the steep ground above the Garreg-wen, turning their bright eyes on us in causal gaze as we passed on down towards the marshy valley floor.

There were more sunbeams now and soon we watched the heather slopes of Clogwynyreryr come alight as the clouds dissipated. The pale, clipped ewes and their maturing lambs shone, too, in their royal purple setting as we turned down the track beside the ancient sheep pens that made such a wonderful pattern of light and shadow as the sun fell towards the high ridge behind us.

fields.headline: Send for boom service
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Mega Blasts (C5) zoomed in on the only parts that matter in the contemporary Hollywood blockbuster - the explosions. The current multiplex-filler may have a pitiful plot, a screenplay massacred by committee and "acting" which makes the PG Tips chimps look like John Gielgud, but at least you can feel confident that it won't have skimped on the pyrotechnics budget.

It was no surprise that bangs-per-buck specialist Jerry Bruckheimer kept popping up throughout Mega Blasts, since it was he who produced the likes of Armageddon and Enemy of the State. Jerry's prestige in Tinseltown was founded on his grasp of the fact that audiences love to be assailed with terror by proxy and disaster at one remove. "Bad news travels a lot faster than good news," pointed out Jerry the Jeremiah, a trim, bearded figure with that curiously synthetic look that afflicts those who spend too much time and money being massaged and colonically irrigated.

Still, down at the sharp end, the vast explosions that we have come to cherish in place of credible dra matic performances are created by men who still seem to bear some resemblance to the rugged pioneers of the movie industry. We were introduced to the likes of Clay Pinney, a grizzled big-bangs wizard who blew up most of Boston for the mad-bomber flick Blown Away. The burly geezer who concocted the final cataclysm for Universal Soldier: The Return was the nephew of the man who had devised the napalm conflagration in Apocalypse Now.

Meanwhile, the company all the studios go to when they want a building flattened is Controlled Demolition Incorporated, a business which has been run by the Loizeaux family since the 40s. "Everything falls down wherever we go," one of them confessed.

But the way things are going, soon all the good ol' boys who love flattening tower blocks and obliterating ships with real live explosives will be swept away by the incoming wave of super-effects geeks, who thought nothing of spending eight months writing new computer software in order to concoct the preposterous scenes in Armageddon where Bruce Willis's space shuttle landed on a speeding asteroid. Give it up, guys - it wasn't worth it. Well, OK, it was worth 17 zillion dollars, but you catch my drift.

New comedy on BBC1? You have to laugh. About three times in half an hour, in the case of Brotherly Love. Actually this has several agreeable assets, including some resplendent Scottish countryside complete with a loch, Gregor Fisher as Hector the eccentric village doctor, and the reliably glamorous Caroline Langrishe as "starving artist" and potential love interest.

Plot-wise, however, the series seems determined to rely on the tetchy but basically amiable relationship between Gregor and his brother Frank (played rather wetly by James Fleet), which looks likely to cause an inspiration-drought long before we reach episode four. Frank has returned from living in London, where his marriage has failed, and proposes to run the family pub. Clearly he is not going to be assisted in this ambition by having all the cutting-edge business skills of a professor of Egyptology, while bro' Hector immediately throws a spanner in the works by berating Frank's saloon bar customers for excessive drinking, smoking and consumption of cholesterol.

You have to wonder whether the exceedingly parochial locals would ever dream of quaffing a pint in a pub run by a weedy Englishman with a public school accent. You also can't help feeling that Ms Langrishe's presence has more to do with focus-group notions of viewer-friendliness than with narrative plausibility. As for Mrs Grogan, the doughty assistant at Hector's surgery, she is living proof that any series set in rural Scotland must not only contain a GP or a vet, but must automatically be furnished with a clone of Janet from Dr Finlay's Casebook.

For crude functionality, you can't beat The Bill (ITV). Last night, a huge money-laundering racket was exposed, bent copper Don Beech sank up to his neck in sleaze and corruption, and Clare Bolton made an amazing transformation from grouchy, unsmiling Detective Sergeant to John Boulton's swooning bride- to-be. Fortunately, The Bill doesn't have the budget to compensate for its lack of finesse with spectacular explosions.

For crude functionality, you can't beat The Bill (ITV). Last night, a huge money-laundering racket was exposed, bent copper Don Beech sank up to his neck in sleaze and corruption, and Clare Bolton made an amazing transformation from grouchy, unsmiling Detective Sergeant to John Boulton's swooning bride- to-be. Fortunately, The Bill doesn't have the budget to compensate for its lack of finesse with spectacular explosions.

fields.headline: Are you sitting comfortably?
fields.standfirst: The slow, oblique existential film is making a comeback. Jonathan Romney couldn’t be happier
fields.trailText: The slow, oblique existential film is making a comeback. Jonathan Romney couldn’t be happier
fields.body:
I recently sat down with a high-minded cinephile friend for a Saturday night’s entertainment - a video of a seven-hour Hungarian art film. “Not bad,” she said afterwards. “But I thought it slightly went off around the five-hour mark, when the dialogue came in.”

The film in question was Satantango, made in 1994 by the Hungarian director Bela Tarr, and something of a legend among aficionados of painstakingly slow European art cinema. A film that long and that sombre is not likely to become an international art-house hit along the lines of Jean de Florette, or even to find a comfortable slot on the festival circuit. But Tarr’s film has a reputation as something more than a lugubrious oddity of monstrous proportions - it is a powerful, visionary piece of cinema that creates its own stark world and keeps the viewer compellingly locked in for its duration. In a recent international critics’ poll, Satantango was voted one of the 30 major films of the 90s. Yet in Britain its director remains largely unknown.

Not for much longer, perhaps. An earlier, and considerably shorter, Bela Tarr film, Damnation (1987), is due for release here next year, while his most recent film Werckmeister Harmonies recently caused a stir at the Edinburgh Film Festival, where viewers received it as a genuine cinematic UFO. Filmed in Tarr’s characteristic slow, analytically prowling shots, Werckmeister Harmonies is set in a desolate rural settlement where a violent communal madness is sparked by the arrival of a bizarre fairground attraction - the preserved body of a huge whale. The film culminates in a frightening sequence in which a mob marches on, then silently demolishes, the local hospital. The film’s atmosphere has something in common with David Lynch, but the real affinities are with Kafka, Dostoevsky and Beckett.

Tarr and his regular collaborators - his editor (and wife) Agnes Hranitsky and co-writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai - paint society as a simmering nightmare that can explode at any time into brutal dementia. Coming from an eastern European film-maker, the political overtones are evident, if never underlined.

In any period of cinema history, a director like Tarr would be an out right exception, but today his work represents a prodigy of dissidence. Tarr is one of the film-makers named by Susan Sontag - in an article published in the Guardian in 1996 - as offering some hope for the continuation of cinema. Sontag was lamenting the death of cinephilia, the attitude that treats cinema as an exceptional art form, “quintessentially modern; distinctively accessible; poetic and mysterious and erotic and moral - all at the same time.” In the 90s, Sontag argued, cinema had gone into “ignominious, irreversible decline”, and great films would no longer be merely exceptions, but “heroic violations” of the norm.

This may not hold true in all parts of the world - film language seems constantly to reinvent itself in Iran, and in the work of Asian directors such as Taiwan’s Tsai-Ming Liang and Korea’s Hong Sang-Soo. But Tarr is one of a very few European directors determined to work outside mainstream forms, and who still believe in cinema’s potential to transform the viewer. These film-makers are not out to convey obvious messages, and in these pragmatic days, they risk coming across like mystics. But the keynote of their work is not woolly transcendentalism, but intrepid and rigorous formal invention.

The antecedents of such cinema are the likes of Andrei Tarkovsky, the almost forgotten Hungarian master Miklos Jansco, the German Expressionist cinema of the 20s, or the work of 70s German directors, especially Werner Herzog. This school of cinema refuses to spoon-feed us with ready-made experiences or easily recognisable beauty: the beauty in these films is easily mistaken for the ugly or drab. That would certainly account for the impatient, almost offended drubbing that British critics last week gave to Abendland, by the young German director Fred Kelemen - another of Sontag’s favoured few, and a former student of Tarr’s. “Bela and I share the same vision of cinema,” Kelemen says. “We believe in time and not in speed - atmospheres and situations rather than stories.” Needless to say, Abendland has already disappeared from London screens after just a week.

Kelemen’s films are severe to a fault - although he does have a penchant for trashy Euro-disco on his soundtracks. Abendland tracks the nocturnal movements through an unidentified and vaguely medieval European city of a pair of impoverished, weary lovers. The hellish events they face are sometimes realistic, sometimes have the heightened feel of nightmare, but are rooted in real-world politics - Kelemen’s work is set among Europe’s underclass of homeless and unemployed, and especially Germany’s abused foreign workers. His imaginative landscape is all frontiers and journeys, informed by changing European geography; Frost, his sec ond film, has a mother and child trekking across Germany to the Polish border. But there is an existential angle to the theme. “We are on a journey, very simply. We’re born, we die and in between we have to make our way, and there’s no way to stop. Even if you sit in your room and do nothing, time is passing and something is happening - which is a very big adventure.”

Kelemen and Tarr may inhabit the absolute margins of European cinema but they are by no means alone. The science of long takes and landscape tableaux - as if the screen were a huge map to be unfolded - still flourishes in the work of Greek director Theo Angelopoulos, who has been refining his art of geographically spectacular slowness since the 70s. In Russia, Aleksandr Sokurov’s pictorial finesse unequivocally follows Tarkovsky’s mystical tradition: his muted, enigmatic miniature Mother and Son was a cult art-house success (although for my money, his follow-up Moloch, a chilly, anaesthetised political cartoon about Hitler’s home life, is far more interesting). Other pensive outsiders who fit the mould are the truly marginal Portuguese. For example, there is Pedro Costa, whose Lisbon junkie drama Ossos is one of the great overlooked films of the 90s. And surely the most waywardly unpredictable European auteur, bar none, is Joao Cesar Monteiro, who appears as his own roué-philosopher anti-hero in such demented, leisurely rambles as God’s Comedy and The Hips of JW (about a mission to find John Wayne at the North Pole).

It goes without saying that this cinema is very much prey to the vagaries of personal taste. It is possible to believe passionately in the virtues of slowness, alienation, the creation of a dream-like, hermetic reality - and still not be able to swallow the self-importance of a film like Bruno Dumont’s L’Humanité, which would seem to fulfil all those criteria. Kelemen admits that in the kind of cinema he practices, “it’s always a question of openness, of state of mind, whether one enters into it or not - it can even depend on the day you see it.” That is why many of these films are like messages in bottles, thrown into the ocean in the hope that the right viewer will see them in the right frame of mind. You could call it Castaway Cinema, and one of its most heroically strange castaways is globetrotting Lithuanian director Sharunas Bartas. Bartas’s films include Few of Us, about a young woman’s unexplained mission to Mongolia, and the baroque The House, in which a crowd of outcasts stage enigmatic indoor tableaux.

These poetic and exceptionally mysterious pieces are closer to art video than narrative cinema. His latest film Freedom, featured in the forthcoming London Film Festival, is again a wordless affair, of figures in a North African landscape and events replaced by images - crabs falling out of a bag, sand blowing across arid plains. One of the few British screenings of Bartas’ work was provided by Turner Prize winner Steve McQueen, who pro grammed it in a recent season at the ICA. “It’s almost like having a conversation with someone,” McQueen says. “It’s in real time, it takes a long time to finish a sentence, but you go through the whole process, and there’s this result, the pay-off, and you think - yes!”

The work of these rare, rejected but vital castaway directors can’t easily be defined in terms of where it comes from, how it is made, or even how slow it is. That would account for the challenge, and the unusual rewards, of this very subjective cinema, a cinema that practically psychoanalyses you - and if you’re lucky, cures you of your Hollywood-induced traumas.

• Freedom plays in the London Film Festival on Nov 11. Damnation is released here next year.

webTitle: Julie Burchill: Because I want to

fields.headline: Because I want to
fields.standfirst: No one ever went out and deliberately gave themselves cancer because the Velvet Underground had some cool songs about it
fields.trailText: No one ever went out and deliberately gave themselves cancer because the Velvet Underground had some cool songs about it.
fields.body:
For me, the most brilliant bit of that altogether brilliant film Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory is the scene where Veruca Salt, the monstrously spoilt muppet, sings her ode to greed and gluttony, I Want It Now. ("I want a room full of music and laughter/Ten thousand tons of ice cream/And if I don't get the things that I'm after/I'm going TO SCREAM.") I've seen this scene now with four separate people that I've been married to/going steady with, and each time my love object has turned to me with a look of pure glee and recognition on their faces. And this used to happen when I was really thin, too, so you can wipe that smirk off right away.

Wanting gets a pretty bad press these days, so most people, when they want a thing, say they need it instead. I've never understood this, and consider it far more morally dubious and all-round undignified to need something rather than to want it. "Needy", to my mind, is about as unattractive a way for a person to act as is possible, whereas being "wanty" indicates a healthy level of self-worth and faith in one's own judgments. And yet "Because I want to" is still a phrase that strikes many people as being a cue for anarchy - we try to stop children saying it as soon as possible, usually by trumping them with that gem of killer logic, "Because I say so".

Women, especially, are not meant to want things. That's why the aromatherapy racket has proved so successful. The perfectly natural impulse to want things to smell nice can no longer be dismissed as mindless extravagance, as perfume might be, but as a necessity that is actually good for one's soul. When did you last hear a woman say, "Because I want to"? No; instead, she stripped off to empower herself, she committed adultery because her needs weren't being met, she got pie-eyed because she saw Mommy kissing Santa Claus. The last gal I heard saying it was the then 15-year-old Billie Piper, in that incredibly bratty chart-topper of the same name. Well, it only took a couple of years to knock that sort of sass out of her, and now poor Billie spends most of her waking hours denying that she takes drugs, drinks to excess and chucks celebrity boyfriends in order to get publicity for her records. Not so much Because I Want To as I Didn't Do It, Honest!

There seems to be a feeling that if people do what they want and make no bones about it, society will somehow collapse. On the contrary, I believe that denying our desires and excusing them as needs causes a lot more trouble than being straightforward about our selfishness would. A society that recognised that people generally do as they want would stand very little nonsense from the two men per week who kill their wives, partners and exes, usually pleading diminished responsibility and claiming they were "driven" to it by "nagging" or "taunting" witches; the same goes for child molesters who "couldn't help themselves". Of course, we've got to be understanding and sensitive and all that guff but, if someone really wanted to use that old line about not knowing what came over them in order to wangle a lighter sentence, I'd sure as hell make sure they had their voting rights automatically removed, too; we don't let mad people vote, after all. And if you deny that you have free will and are so weak that you can, in fact, have your actions dictated to you by the liquid distilled from a rotting potato (vodka), as alcoholics do, are you really any more deserving of your stake in democracy than a man who thinks he's Napoleon?

I'd have a lot more respect for even nasty people if they just admitted why they do what they do - because they want to. If only a bloke from the Countryside Alliance would stand up just once on Newsnight and say, "Well, Jeremy, the thing is I get the most enormous stiffy when I see that damned attractive little fox bitch being torn apart, and what's wrong with that, what?" But, instead, they wheel out a load of cant about the fox enjoying it (just like rapists!) and it being necessary for the countryside, otherwise all the trees would fall down. People who work in animal labs are another lot: they're sadists, and there's no two ways about it. Why not come out and admit it? They'd probably find that, in the long run, people would be far more understanding and tolerant of their sadism than they are of all those transparent lies about a new mango-and-apple shampoo being absolutely vital for the future survival of mankind and therefore worth the sight of a couple of hundred beagles. Hell, if they came out and said that they were addicted to hurting animals, they'd probably get on Richard And Judy, sharing sniffles and big feely hugs with Denise The Agony Aunt.

Very few things are truly addictive: heroin, for instance, bends over backwards to let potential addicts off the hook, making most people extremely ill the first few times they take it. It is probably harder to become addicted to heroin than to kick it. Yet junkies, and particularly the families and spouses of junkies, clamour for it to be recognised as a "disease", which is pretty damned insulting to people dying of cancer. To my knowledge, no one went out and deliberately gave themselves cancer because they admired a famous cancer-sufferer's cheekbones or because the Velvet Underground had some really cool songs about it. Most alleged drug addicts don't "need" drugs at all; they merely want to need them, because simply wanting them would seem so selfish and swinish. The same goes for shopaholics (want nice things), chocaholics (greedy pigs), sexaholics (slags) and workaholics (can't stand the person they're married to and their whining offspring, so stay at the office all hours God sends). As for alcoholics, they're just self-pitying drunks, and sometimes they're not even that - just people with very dreary inner lives who need a bit of identity and status, however warped. I recently read of an American actress who started attending AA meetings because she was having two Martinis each night after work. Two frigging Martinis!

As people become less willing to stand up and identify themselves as communists or Christians or anything that might be ridiculed as highfalutin or judgmental, they are clamouring to be this-aholics or that-dependants. Apart from anything else, this has upped the bore-quotient at parties something chronic. But, on a more serious level, it has also turned us into a nation of babies, forever mewling at the teat of addiction. How much braver and bolder - and, yes, how much more socially responsible - is my favourite Spanish proverb: "Take what you want, and pay for it, says God."

fields.headline: Breast-based economy
fields.standfirst: The huge awards given by juries were enough to bankrupt the US's main implant manufacturer - and to burst the implant bubble, as it were
fields.trailText: The huge awards given by juries were enough to bankrupt the US's main implant manufacturer - and to burst the implant bubble, as it were.
fields.body:
I have a problem in writing about Anna Nicole Smith, which is that she denies ever having had silicone implants in her breasts. She admits to plastic surgery, even to breast surgery - "My nipples kind of pointed downward, so I had them moved from here to there," she once said in an interview about the after-effects of giving birth to her son, Daniel, in her teens - but "I haven't had silicone implants, no." This is a pity, because she has often been written about confidently as if she had; and, assuming this to be so, I concluded that her triumph last week in a Los Angeles court, where she was awarded $449 million from the estate of her late 90-year-old husband, J Howard Marshall II, was not only a personal triumph but one for the breast transplant industry as a whole.

There were strong reasons for thinking this, because she not only met her future husband in Houston, Texas, the city that pioneered the breast transplant, but she did so as a stripper in Rick's Cabaret, the most famous topless bar in Houston. Everything I know about Rick's comes from an enormously long article, which I read five years ago in the Texas Monthly, entitled "Silicone City: The rise and fall of the implant - or how Houston went from an oil-based economy to a breast-based economy".

"No two products were more interdependent than Rick's and the implant," the article said. Its owner, Robert Watters, a Canadian lawyer with a degree from the London School of Economics, told the magazine, "In the early and mid-80s, the first material acquisition the dancers saved for was breast augmentation." But it seems that Smith was lucky and didn't need it.

A brief history of silicone implants ... Silicone was first used after the second world war, when Japanese women, normally smaller-breasted than American women, had it injected into their breasts to please American servicemen. Then, in 1962, a woman called Timmie Jean Lindsay became the first woman in the world to receive a silicone-gel implant: married at 15 and divorced at 30, after bringing six children into the world, she was in hospital in Houston to have tattoos removed from her breasts when the surgeon asked if she would like to have them made more shapely at the same time. Her answer was yes, and with that there was born a multibillion-dollar industry. Throughout the US, breast augmentation rapidly became a female obsession. One Houston celebrity doctor had already performed between 2,500 to 3,000 implants by 1995. He and his colleagues found their incomes rising from the low six figures up to $2 million a year. And even after 1990, when panic erupted about the side-effects of what had been promoted as a cheap, safe operation, there were millions more to be earned, not only by lawyers but by doctors for taking out the bags of silicone they had put in.

Research by America's most illustrious medical institutions failed to prove that there was any more illness among women who had had breast implants than among those who hadn't, but the huge awards given by juries to plaintiffs were sufficient to bankrupt the country's principal implant manufacturer - and to burst the implant bubble, as it were. Nevertheless, the implant craze had amazing staying power. It survived the fashion for skinny models, and would probably be going as strong now, if it were not for anxiety about the health side-effects.

Trying to explain the phenomenon, the Houston inventors of the silicone-gel implant, Thomas Cronin and Frank Gerow, wrote in the early 60s that it was perhaps "due in large measure to the tremendous amount of publicity which has been given to some movie actresses blessed with generous sized breasts. Many women with limited development of the breasts are extremely sensitive about it". Women who have undergone the operation usually say they wanted to increase their "self-esteem". But it seems to be all the fault of men, really - of men such as J Howard Marshall II, the master of an immense oil fortune, who, although 89 years old and confined to a wheelchair, went regularly to Rick's at lunchtime to drool over the generously proportioned body of Anna Nicole Smith.

Anna, the small-town girl from Mexia, Texas, who dreamt from childhood of being Marilyn Monroe, believes she understands this: "Most men, I think, like a womanly figure." The feminist campaign against the treatment of women as sex objects seems to have completely passed her by, and she is $449 million richer as a result. "Are you a feminist?" she was once asked. "I don't understand the question," she replied. "Do you fight for women's rights?" "Whoever started that, I could kick them in the head." But Anna is a religious person. "What's heaven like?" she was asked. "I think heaven's a beautiful place. Gold. You walk on gold floors." It looks as if she might be there already.
