With great effort, he drags himself over to a barre that runs the length of the room and, his buckled feet scraping the floor, uses it to pull himself along. Only when he has neared the end of his agonising journey, do the lithe, young bodies cease their exercises and stand to attention. "What a beautiful morning," he announces, in a shaking, barely audible voice. "It was this kind of day - bright and sunny and clear - when I landed in New York for the first time and I thought: 'Oh boy, this is it'. Great things could happen here." He then pauses, surveys the dancers for a moment and smiles: "All right then, let's begin..." Merce Cunningham is, without doubt, the world's greatest living choreographer. His name stands alongside Martha Graham and George Balanchine in the pantheon of mercurial figures that transformed 20th century dance, though his work arguably reaches further and deeper, celebrating sheer movement for its own stark, austere sake. "He's just continued to astound people and stay outside of any fashion or polemic," says fellow choreographer Bill T Jones, "Merce is the champion of the struggle to say that dance is it's own primary language." At the height of his powers, Cunningham was also a peerless performer. His ability to launch himself into the air was legendary, often drawing gasps from the audience, most famously in the celebrated scene in Martha Graham's Letter To The World in 1940 when, to the cue of Graham's "Dear March, come in," the young Cunningham, in top hat and tails, would bound across the stage. However, it was through his own, eccentric choreography that his feral radiance really shone: "He never moved like anybody else in the company," says Marianne Simon, a Cunningham troupe member, "he looked not like a man, but like a gazelle or a lily blooming in the field." His genius was like a force of nature, sending unlikely jolting, shuddering ripples through his arms and pelvis and legs. Some say, "he was an animal". And it's easy to see why, in pieces such as the startling 1960 work Crises, with its darting, shifting solo, outstretched one moment, spastic and convulsive the next or in the finale of Place, where Cunningham gave one of his most disturbing performances, thrashing around wildly inside a transparent plastic sack. Even at the end of his career - he performed later than anyone bar Graham herself - just a flicker of his boney hands could radiate a tremendous energy: "I remember watching a new solo of his, and he is crawling around the floor and doing all kinds of crazy things," says Remy Charlip, who danced with the Cunningham company for its first 11 years, "and it was like looking into his psyche. I thought he was having a fit and I remember saying: "He's not going to do that on stage, is he? He can't do that in public?" This same naturally iconoclastic spirit also shaped the radical approach of this choreography. With his partner and mentor, the composer John Cage, Cunningham dreamt up some of the most radical and sometimes downright perverse performance notions of the 20th century: flipping coins or throwing dice to decide the structure of pieces; wilfully destroying the time-honoured bond between dance and music. In the field of modern dance, these ideas would eventually influence Twyla Tharp, Richard Alston and Siobhan Davies. Cunningham would also have an enormous impact on other creative fields, on experimental theatre practitioners such as Robert Wilson and choreographer/director Meredith Monk. It is no surprise that one of theatre's greatest innovators is numbered among his earliest supporters: "Cunningham's group is in the tradition of Martha Graham in many ways, but in one most of all," wrote Peter Brook in 1964. "The very things that are criticised, laughed at and ignored, will only a few months later be imitated everywhere." By all accounts, Cunningham has mellowed considerably. With his halo of untidy white curls, he now comes across as a delightfully charming, easy-mannered, quaintly old-fashioned elderly gentleman, who repeats his well-worn anecdotes with the confidence of someone who knows his word is now creed. The debilitating arthritis and chronic hip condition that finally forced him off the stage in his early 70s gives his body a brittle, almost translucent quality. However, he transcends his frailty with an open smile and a decidedly unpretentious wit. But as long-time members and associates of the company will openly testify, this wasn't always the case. Right up until the death in 1992 of his partner John Cage, who had run much of company life, organised tours, even mediated in disputes with dancers, Cunningham was often an aloof, cold, difficult and demanding presence: "He would have these sort of black moods when you couldn't get through to him at all," remembers David Vaughan, original company manager and now company archivist. "When I started to work with him, on some days I would feel it was like walking into this completely impenetrable wall around him. We all felt that." Some have even gone so far as to assert that the same caprice and obsessiveness that made the work great also led him to take dangerous risks, both with himself and with his dancers: "Of course, he crippled himself by doing some of these wild things," says one company member. "He did a dance where people were like twisting and torqueing and spiralling their bodies. The company used to call it 'whiplash'." Cunningham is also protective of his personal life, and his relationship with Cage still remains one of the great enigmas of the avant-garde. The blank canvas meticulously maintained by both has allowed detractors to paint a picture of the loquacious Cage as "Svengali", feeding ideas and theories to his younger, more taciturn protégé. And while neither denied the fact of his romantic attachment, it had remained until now unfurnished with even the most rudimentary details: "I do the cooking," Cage commented wryly, when pressed once by a gay activist for a few morsels of information, "and Merce does the dishes." Little more than this has ever been divulged before, either in Cage's biography or in the voluminous press coverage of Cunningham. However, it would appear that there was considerably more to their union, which seems to have been marked by affairs with male dancers in the company. At least once they shared the affections of the same young dancer. It is possibly the fundamentally fraught and complex nature of their 50-year relationship - and not, as is often cited, lingering fear from the beginning of their time together, when homosexuality was still an offence punishable by law -that continues to fuel Cunningham's silence in this relatively open-minded era: "I don't think I was guarded about my personal life," he says gently, "It is quite true I didn't speak about it very much but I didn't see any reason to speak about it. John and I were together. We did our work together. We travelled together. What more is there to say?" Mercier Philip Cunningham was born in the small lumber town of Centralia, Washington on April 16 1919, the third son of Clifford Cunningham, a lawyer of Irish descent, and Mayme Joach, a teacher. From a young age, Mercier displayed a gregarious streak that marked him out, as he lightheartedly puts it, as the "criminal" among a family of lawyers: "He liked the beach and beach business - the sand and all kind of captured his attention, whirling around in it," says his older brother Dorwin, a retired lawyer who still lives in Washington State. "And if the circus came to town, when they would be going through the streets, I remember Merce would get up and do sort of a dance, just as a youngster would." At 12 he began studying tap-dancing with a former vaudeville and circus performer named Mrs Barrett, who ran an improvised local academy. After he left high school, Mercier made a half-hearted attempt to study at the George Washington University in Washington DC, taking literature and theatre history courses. Dorwin, who was studying law in DC, kept a journal of this time: "We ate out and Swords [their flatmate] complained about the expenses," he reads falteringly from the entry for October 11 1936. "Then Mercier arrives, bubbling over with enthusiasm after seeing the Jooss ballet in the National Theatre. Such interest as his must be the first outward signs of latent genius." However, Mercier only lasted one semester at university, enrolling instead at the Cornish School for Performing and Visual Arts in Seattle, an astonishing stroke of good fortune that would transform his life. First he got himself into the 8am dance class of Bonnie Bird, an ex-Martha Graham dancer, who would prove a formative influence. Then, during his second year there, a 27-year-old composer named John Cage was employed as rehearsal pianist, relocating from California with his wife Xenia Kashevaroff. Cage had studied composition under Schoenberg and already had something of a radical, iconoclastic outlook: "He started a percussion programme," says Cunningham, "and once I had mastered the piece, he came and said 'You were playing everything absolutely perfectly. Now just go a little further and make a few mistakes.' I thought 'that is a marvellous idea'." At the end of his second year at Cornish, in the summer of '39, Cunningham hitch-hiked to Mills College in California where the Bennington School of the Dance was holding its summer school, with tutorials run by famous figures such as Charles Weidman, Hanya Holm and Martha Graham. "I didn't know anything about her [Graham]; I had never seen her dance," Cunningham admits, "I think that she conducted the last two weeks and I remember this woman who was really small, compared to myself. But such a force." Young Mercier also made an instant impression on Graham, who offered him a place in her company if he came to New York. He immediately travelled back to Centralia to break the news to his parents: "My mother's face fell. But my father, who was a very bright intelligent man, he looked at me and he looked at her and then he said: 'Oh, let him go. He's going to go anyway.' And so I went." After three days on a train, Cunningham arrived in New York on a sunny late-summer day in 1939: "I stepped onto the pavement and I said 'This is home'. It was immediate." He then made his way to the the Martha Graham Studio: "Before classes began, I walked in the door. She was standing there and she said: 'Oh! I didn't think you'd come.' I didn't say it but I thought to myself: 'Lady, you don't know me'." That season Graham was beginning work on her landmark work Every Soul Is A Circus, and she cast Cunningham in one of the lead male roles: "I thought that was wonderful. I get to be dancing. It wasn't until the performances I suddenly thought: 'Oh, I 'm performing on Broadway in New York.' It was really quite a remarkable feeling." As Graham company member, Nina Fonaroff - now 86 - recalls: "As a person he was enticing. He was a Puck - irresistible, and very funny too. And as a dancer he was a phenomenon, absolutely extraor dinary. And he had such passion for it. I remember in Circus, when he made his debut, he had on these pink tights and a pink top, and his heart was beating so hard you could practically see it thumping with excitement." Cunningham, who by now had shortened his first name to Merce, went on to dance lead roles in El Penitente (where he played Christ) and Letter To The World, a piece based on Emily Dickinson's poetry. Graham's relatively narrative-based approach couldn't contain or satisfy Cunningham, who by the end of this time with the company, was already choreographing his own pieces: "I remember one day he came bouncing up saying, 'I have a dance, I have a dance. Come see, come see'." says Fonaroff. "And so I followed him into the studio and he did this thing, almost walking on his knees and jumping up and down. It was called Totem Ancestor. I'd never seen anything like it." The real catalyst for Cunning ham's break with the Graham company was the arrival of John Cage who had moved to New York with his wife Xenia in the summer of 1942. Cage wrote the music for their first solo programme in 1944, which included Totem Ancestor, a solo called Root Of An Unfocus, and Tossed As It Is Untroubled, inspired by Joyce's Finnegans Wake: "I date my beginning from this concert", Cunningham says. During rehearsals, Cage and Cunningham also formulated one of their most fundamental tenets: the separation of music and dance. "We could agree on a common structure for a particular dance and John could compose to that structure and I could choreograph. In the beginning, there were points in that structure where the music and dance came together. But later we abandoned that and made them entirely independent." By the early 50s, at the instigation of Cage, Cunningham began to use "chance operations" to formulate the ele ments of his pieces, particularly in the key 1952 piece Suite By Chance: "The individual sequences, and the length of time, and the directions in space were discovered by tossing coins," he says. Many of these ideas were tested and developed not only through Cunningham's occasional performances but also through the famous summer sessions at the celebrated Black Mountain College, North Carolina, where in 1952 Cunningham and Cage masterminded the world's first "Happening". That summer in Black Mountain also saw the birth of "Merce Cunningham and Dance Company", a startling ensemble of dancers such as Carolyn Brown, Viola Farber, Jo-Anne Melsher and Remy Charlip which, over the next few years, would give form to some of Cunningham's ground- breaking works: 1953's Septet, where a still, balletic style is positioned next to the music of Eric Satie, and Minutiae in 1954, which marks the beginning of Robert Rauschenberg's 10-year stint as resident designer. However, it is not just for the quality of the work that the dancers still nostalgically refer to this early period as the Golden Age, but also because of the distinctive company spirit, forged by communal hardships. Reviews were almost universally negative: "His dance language is for the initiated few who are as interested in contemplating Mr Cunningham's navel as he is himself," Dance Magazine said in 1953. "Have a little Mercy, Merce," a later headline would proclaim. But diatribes did little more than steel a curiously robust sense of mission, as the company toured their pieces in a clapped-out Volkswagen bus, often driving inordinate distances for a single performance and playing to meagre audiences: "It took exactly nine people and a ton of luggage," remembers dancer Carolyn Brown. "We sometimes drove all day and into the wee hours. I remember giving a performance without sleeping at all. But it really was a lot of fun. "John was a wonderful leader. He and [composer] David Tudor would get into these wonderful conversations. Meanwhile, Merce would be very quiet and study Russian and read or knit. The rest of us would play games. It just was a great time to develop a real company because we were so close together." By this time, the relationship between Cunningham and Cage was deeply personal as well as inextricably professional. Prior to this involvement, Cunningham appears to have conducted predominantly heterosexual relationships, both during his time with the Martha Graham company - when he was deeply attached to a Bennington theatre student - and earlier at the Cornish school, when he went out with a dance student named Joyce Holder. "We were very close but it was always ambiguous," Holder recalls. "I was a little wild and was having many flings. I think that one of the attractions for Merce was that my other boyfriends could take him around in their cars if he needed to go someplace." Then, when Holder followed him to New York, she witnessed the formation of the Cage/Cunningham bond in 1942: "Merce would always hint to me that it was very valuable for his work. Music parts drove him crazy and John composing for him solved that problem. His implication to me always was that their relationship was mutually advantageous on that level." Equally indistinct was the nature of the union itself, which remained clandestine for decades: "I didn't have any inkling," says Marianne Simon, who left the company in 1958, "and I don't think I was alone in that among the female dancers. We were all madly in love with [Merce] in those early days." From an early stage, however, there were affairs with young male dancers in the company: "It was and it wasn't [an open relationship]," says one of early dancers, who was close to both men, "it was kind of secretive and at the same time they both slept with other people. Later on, Merce took up with a younger dancer in the company who did not want John to come on tour any more, and that was crushing to John because he built that company. John got all the dates and wrote all of the letters anddrove and cooked and made all the arrangements." At times it seems to have been precisely this dominance that Cunningham was struggling against, both in his affairs and in his general behaviour: "John was the brains and Merce was the body," continues the same troupe member. "Merce couldn't really protect himself, so he would do things like hide in a room for a week and wouldn't come out and wouldn't eat. John would get frantic. That was his way of dealing with John." Yet, if Cunningham really did worry that his work would never be fully appreciated and would always remain in Cage's shadow, grounds for at least some of his fears would evaporate in the pivotal year of 1964. Tiring of New York's indifference, the company decided to tour Europe and Asia to showcase some of their strongest work: Winterbranch, a relentless piece based on the theme of falling, featuring La Monte Young's stereophonic buzzsaw soundtrack; Story, which involved scrap remade by Rauschenberg from whatever junk was lying around the theatre; and Crises, in which the dancers were bound by giant elastic bands. At the first major stopover, Paris, they met a familiar reaction: "People threw things at us," Carolyn Brown recalls, "eggs and tomatoes. During the interval they went out to get more." During the Venice dates, things began to pick up; the press reception was respectful and Rauschenberg picked up first prize at the Bienniale art show. However, by the time they reached London, the Merce Cunningham company was being hailed as a sensation: "At a blow, ballet has been brought right up in line with the front-rank experiments in the other arts," raved Alexander Bland in the Observer, "something which has hardly happened since the days of Diaghilev. Here is heart-warming proof that it is an art with a future, opening up ranges of possibilities which stretch out of sight." After an initial scintillating run at Sadler's Wells, attended by everyone from Frederick Ashton to Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, they transferred for an equally triumphant three-week run at the Phoenix: "Merce was really quite astonished. In New York, the most he'd ever played was two nights," recalls Michael White, who produced the London leg of the tour. The tour proceeded in a rather chaotic fashion through Scandinavia, onward to Prague (where the posters trumpeted dances "in the style of West Side Story") and Poland, and then further east to Bombay. By the time they reached Japan, the strain was beginning to tell, with tensions particularly clamorous between Cage and Cunningham on the one hand and on the other between them and Rauschenberg, who had made the mistake of becoming far too famous in the wake of his Venice conquest. After the general critical success of the tour, and particularly the rapture of the London reviewers, subsequently reported in the US press, the entire character of the company changed. While the controversy, the sporadic booing and walkouts, and the financial crises would continue for some decades yet, the critical climate became infinitely more favourable, the company grew in size and professionalism, and Cunningham him self began a steady upward trajectory towards avant garde canonisation. The latter half of the 60s saw further Cunningham highlights, notably 1968's Walkaround Time, which employed sets based on Marcel Duchamp's Large Glass, and the stunning piece Rainforest, also in the same year, strewn with Andy Warhol's helium-filled pillows. In the 70s and early 80s, alongside the video artist Charles Atlas, Cunningham coopted video techniques in pieces such as 1975's Blue Studio: Five Segments, and Channel/Inserts in 1981. By the early 90s Cunningham's physical condition was beginning to severely restrict how much he could perform or even demonstrate to the dancers, and he turned to computer technology, devising ever more ingeniously abstract and random steps using a computer program called LifeForms. Still on the cutting edge at the age of 81, he has taken this a step forward in a work called Biped, which uses state of the art Motion Capture technology to record the movements of his dancers and reproduce them as computer animations within the dance. As audiences at London's Barbican will discover next week, the piece, featuring the music of Gavin Bryars, is mesmerising, the ultimate combination of art and technology. The main event during this latest period of Cunningham's work and life was, of course, the death of Cage in August 1992. After returning from the New York studio to their Sixth Avenue apartment, Cunningham discovered him collapsed on the kitchen floor, having suffered a stroke. Despite the many difficulties in their relationship, the two men had been, according to Cage's assistant Laura Kuhn, "very affectionate" in their final years together, openly so perhaps for the first time, now that neither had anything left to prove. The loss of Cage would shatter a dynamic established over half a century: "Because John answered the questions so brilliantly, I kept my mouth shut. But suddenly he was not around to do it. And so I was forced to speak." Most tellingly, however, Cunningham was back in the studio the day after Cage's death: "I decided quite quickly: 'Well, John is dead, there is nothing I can do about that, and I'm just going to go on.' I thought about it. I would find my own solution." That solution was of course, the work - the force that had sustained and nourished their relationship, made sense of the affairs and the infidelities, smoothed over the petty jealousies. Cunningham's obsession with his work was also the force that drove him, perhaps, to take risks with his body, to continue performing long after it was wise, to demand - and often get - the impossible from his dancers, to push his choreography beyond the bounds of what was thought possible. "You have to love dancing to stick to it," he has written, "It gives nothing back, no manuscripts to store away, no paintings to show on walls and maybe hang in museums, no poems to be printed and sold, nothing but that single fleeting moment when you feel alive. It is not for unsteady souls." Life at a glance: Mercier Philip Cunningham Born: April 16 1919 Centralia, Washington, USA. Educated: Centralia High School; Cornish School of the Arts,Seattle, 1937-39. Early career: Soloist, Martha Graham company, 1939 to 1945; leading roles in Every Soul Is A Circus, 1939, El Penitente, 1940, and Letter To The World, 1940. Works include: Suite By Chance 1952; Symphonie Pour Un Homme Seul 1952; Septet 1953; Minutiae 1954; Antic Meet 1958; Summerspace1958; Crises 1960; Field Dances 1963; Story 1963; Winterbranch 1964; Variations V 1964; Rainforest 1968; Walkaround Time 1968; Canfield 1969; Changing Steps 1973; Blue Studio: Five Segments 1975; Torse 1976; Channel/Inserts 1981; Quartet 1982; Enter 1992; Ocean 1994; Biped 2000. Some awards: Guggenheim Fellowship for choreography 1954 and 1959; Laurence Olivier award for best new dance production1985; inducted into National Museum of Dance Hall of Fame, Saratoga, 1993; Golden Lion, Venice Biennale 1995; Lilian Gish award 2000.  The Merce Cunningham Dance Company is at the Barbican Arts Centre, London EC2, from October 10-14 at 7.45pm. Merce Cunningham conducts an open rehearsal on Saturday October 14 from 2-6pm. Barbican ticket office 0207-6388891.

webTitle: I come to bury Wembley, not to praise it

fields.headline: I come to bury Wembley, not to praise it
fields.trailText: The Empire stadium has been loved more for its memories than itself.
fields.body:
Like Queen Victoria, Wembley has just made it into a new century. Also like Victoria Regina the place has gained more public affection in its old age than it enjoyed in its middling years.

Whether or not the new Wembley will prove a lusty successor, more ready to cater for bodily comforts while providing public entertainment on a grand scale, remains to be seen. But at least it will last longer than the Edwardians.

Doubtless the next stadium will be a technological marvel of metal, glass and user-friendly odds and ends; so unlike the old place with its cold concrete tributes to Empire and the Raj. The Wembley of the 21st century will create its own legends, its own echoes, its own heroes, but the Empire stadium was there first and nothing is going to replace that throat-tightening sense of history people have experienced on seeing the famous silhouette for the first time and, for many today, the last.

In practical terms Wembley should have been demolished long before now. When it was built in the early 1920s it was ahead of its time, but its times were the 30s, 40s and 50s. By the 60s, despite offering the crowds complete cover, it was out of date. The 1966 World Cup final was the stadium's finest hour. It should also have been its last.

Not that there was any chance of Wembley being knocked down then. Financially the stadium was a burden relieved only by greyhound meetings. For years, the idea of replacing the original back-aching, butt-numbing bench seats with something more comfortable was resisted because, it was argued, the punters would find it more difficult to get to the tote between races.

Eventually the growlers left but the grumblers remained. Even as an all-seater stadium, Wembley has never quite managed to hide its age.

The original design was revolutionary in that it offered crowds of around 100,000 a view of events previously unheard of among the football grounds of the time. Only nine years before the stadium was opened, some spectators were having to balance themselves precariously on wooden fence posts at the old Crystal Palace ground to glimpse an FA Cup final.

But that was then. Now, while the Wembley scene might appear perfect viewed from the expensive seats, the royal box or the press tribune, it is plainly decades behind the sort of stadiums which have been built in Paris, Amsterdam, Barcelona, New Jersey and, not least, Sydney.

For too long too many of Wembley's customers have been paying too much for seeing not enough. Anyone who doubts this should count the number of times during a football match when the first dozen or so rows have to stand up to keep track of what is happening in a corner of the pitch.

When the new stadium is built it should be goodbye to all that. The old Wembley has experienced face-lifts, skin grafts and transplants but the wrinkles have still shown. The next Wembley, it is hoped, will surpass the comfort of the Stade de France or the Amsterdam Arena while achieving a warmth of character which so many of these bland modern stadiums lack.

In the meantime Wembley recollections abound, varying according to age and strength of recall. Lucky are those with sufficient years to remember at first hand the Matthews-Mortensen FA Cup final of 1953, soon to be followed by the nemesis of the traditional English game when Hungary turned up and won 6-3.

The glorious vindication of Alf Ramsey's team and tactics in 1966 and the night in 1968 when Matt Busby's Manchester United brought the European Cup to England for the first time are forever engraved in footballing folklore along with the moment, 10 years later, when Graeme Souness's pass sent Kenny Dalglish through a grudging Bruges defence to keep the trophy at Anfield.

Nor should the lesser finals be ignored: the great Pegasus FA Amateur Cup triumphs watched by crowds of 100,000 in the early 50s; Rodney Marsh's singular contribution to Queen's Park Rangers' victory, as a Third Division side, over West Bromwich Albion in the 1967 League Cup final, the first to be played at Wembley and still the most enjoyable; and more recently a series of highly entertaining Football League play-offs.

The best goals? Largely a matter of preference, although two of those scored in the 1981 FA Cup final replay could hardly have been bettered. First there was Steve Mackenzie's extraordinary 25-yard volley for Manchester City which brought the scores level at 1-1 only for this moment to be upstaged by Ricky Villa's giddy dribble through the City defence to win the Cup for Tottenham.

Two personal memories of the old dust bowl will always endure: being able, as a schoolboy, to watch the 1954 Cup final between West Brom and Preston North End from an expensive seat with the cheapest standing ticket, courtesy of parental connections with one of the stewards, and attending a post-match press conference in the first-aid room with a dead hospital case from the crowd lying in the corner.

Somehow it is hard to imagine the new Wembley being able to match such experiences. The original stadium, twin towers and all, has been loved more for its memories than itself. May it rest in pieces.

fields.standfirst: It can't be easy lap dancing for an all-time movie icon, but for femme fatale Linda Fiorentino, it's just part of the job - and she'd rather be at home anyway
fields.trailText: It can't be easy lap dancing for an all-time movie icon, but for femme fatale Linda Fiorentino, it's just part of the job - and she'd rather be at home anyway
fields.body:
Linda Fiorentino can be fierce (The Last Seduction), freaky (Martin Scorsese's After Hours) and even, occasionally, financially viable (Men In Black). But no matter what screen persona she inhabits, she is almost always memorable and invariably quite funny. She's all that and more in her latest movie Where The Money Is, as a smalltown nursing home attendant intrigued by her latest charge, Paul Newman, whom she uses to scheme her way out of her dead-end life. Forty, unmarried and close to her seven brothers and sisters, the Philadelphia-raised actress is somewhat more satisfied with her own life. And whatever isn't right about it, well, at least it's good for a laugh.

Was there any trepidation about making a movie with a legend like Paul Newman?

Actually, it's such hard work that there isn't time to think that way. Plus, I knew that if I thought that way early on that I would not have been able to work. But while I was watching the film for the first time, about halfway through I started shaking and almost fell off my chair. My friend who was there with me said, "What's wrong? It's not bad, it's pretty good." And I said, "No, it's that I did a movie with Paul Newman!" That was the first time that it occurred to me.

What was the experience of working with him like?

He's such a normal guy. He doesn't think of himself as a movie star or icon; he just wants to get home and go to sleep, I think, like me. That's mostly what you think about when you're working. He is a little hustler, though, pardon the pun. He likes to pretend that he isn't good at certain sports like ping-pong or badminton, and then he kills everyone. His hand-eye coordination is amazing. And he's going to be sexy to his last breath, that man.

Speaking of which, what did it feel like to lap dance for him and not get any response at all?

It was the challenge of the piece. But isn't that also the female fantasy, being in total control of the situation? I mean, all men should be in comas when we make love to them; some of them are.

Are you attracted to playing dangerous women?

I'm not so sure I'm attracted to dangerous women as people are attracted to me playing those parts. But maybe I'm a thrill-seeker of sorts. I grew up in a large family, so there was a lot of competition to be the best, the prettiest and the smartest. So, that's probably where I learned everything I needed to do what I do in the movies.

Didn't you originally intend to be a lawyer?

Yes; my degree is in political science. I was heading to law school and my political philosophy teacher talked me out of it and told me to become an actress.

So now that it's paid off, how do you keep your feet on the ground?

I have really big feet, so that helps. I don't live in LA, I live in New York, and that's a major thing that keeps me stable. The people closest to me are not Hollywood types, they're friends and family. My sisters are my best friends; I've been really lucky to have them.

You seem to have a love/hate thing going with this business.

It's not love/hate; the business aspect is just pure hate! I love what it has afforded me in terms of experiences and excitement and money, and the people I've met and the work I've done. But I find many of the people in this business to be cruel, I find them uninteresting, I find them vain; I just would rather think of it as my job and not my life.

fields.headline: Runless Hussain never got 'moody'
fields.trailText: Nobody was closer to Nasser Hussain during the England captain's batting horrors last summer than Duncan Fletcher. He knows exactly the self-doubt and draining confidence caused by Hussain's sequence of low scores, which produced only 92 runs in six Tests and a total of 166 in all first-class cricket.
fields.body:
Nobody was closer to Nasser Hussain during the England captain's batting horrors last summer than Duncan Fletcher. He knows exactly the self-doubt and draining confidence caused by Hussain's sequence of low scores, which produced only 92 runs in six Tests and a total of 166 in all first-class cricket.

Now, with Hussain showing signs of recapturing his form with an innings of 95 in the eight-wicket win over Bangladesh on Thursday, England's coach has gone public about what Hussain went through.

"Nasser hated the thought that he was letting down the team," Fletcher said yesterday. "But I didn't see any big changes in him. He was a little tense occasionally but, to be honest, I thought he'd be more moody than he was. He handled the situation very well."

The pair have developed a close friendship during their year at the helm. Fletcher said that at no stage did Hussain wallow in self-pity; he was concerned only that his lack of runs were undermining England's chances of success.

"Nasser is a scrapper and we all backed him. We never stopped believing he could do the job with the bat. Now I'm certain he feels more confident. He seems a lot happier.

"I don't think people understand what being England captain involves. It's not just captaining 10 other individuals, you have all the off-the-field stuff as well as trying to keep on top of your own game. It won't get easier having beaten Zimbabwe and West Indies, because people's expectations will now be higher."

Hussain's runs and the team's comprehensive win combined to make a near-perfect start to England's winter activities. Fletcher's only concern was the fielding; they missed at least four shies at the stumps, fumbled several balls and dropped six difficult chances. Fletcher thinks the main reason is that the ball here arrives a fraction more quickly than normal because of the altitude - Nairobi is at 5,300ft - and said England would work hard on their fielding in the next three days.

Essex's Paul Grayson is expected to arrive today, having been summoned because of Ashley Giles's leg injury. But Fletcher was adamant that Grayson's selection had nothing to do with Robert Croft's outburst last month after missing selection for the winter; the selectors simply wanted another left-arm spinner as cover for Giles.

Shaun Pollock, meanwhile, who will lead South Africa into next Tuesday's quarter-final against England, spoke yester day of the need for his team to salvage the country's cricketing credibility in the post- Hansie Cronje era. "We have to show the world what sort of cricketers we are," he said. "It is the only way we can restore people's trust and pride."

Cronje was chastised by Nelson Mandela yesterday when they met for 45 minutes. "It is my duty to say to him, 'You have made a serious mistake' in the fact that you did not right from the beginning confess everything you have done," said the former South African president. "The message I gave to him is that a person can turn tragedy into triumph and he has that capacity. He can be a role model."

webTitle: Keegan flowers as twin towers' powers pale

fields.headline: Keegan flowers as twin towers' powers pale
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: Ron says his Wembley goodbyes.
fields.body:
The ball comes to Manager on the right ... Manager beats one man ... beats two ... moves in ... he's punted it over the bar! ... ho ho ... marvellous ... small boys ... dreams of Wembley glory ... sadly the "Manager Final" was never to be.

So ... sad farewell to the twin towers? ... Guff! ... Good riddance! ... always made me a bit uneasy, big dark horrible things ... slight smell of damp ... hmm? ... well okay ... wee.

Well last week everyone was talking about "the greatest games ever" ... hmm? Wembley '66 ... Charleroi 2000 ... isn't it? ... There's always something satisfying about beating the Germans at their ... at our own game ... and facing each other across the dugouts ... enduring image isn't it? ... the two ex-internationals...Who'll come out on top? ... Big Norm swings both ways ... fancies Keegan ... mind you ... Völler's no titbit...

Germany desperate to erase the memories of that thumping in Belgium ... 80 days of hurt!

Völler's successor ... Christoph Daum ... short for Christopher Daum ... small moustache ... slightly seedy ... reminiscent of Blakey from "On the Buses" ... "I 'ate you Butler..." cocaine-sniffing orgies ... lurid sex ... drugs ... yet a friendly avuncular look in his eye hmm? ... Frank Bough in his pomp!

Franz Beckenbauer reckons "I'm not sure he's the right man..." Franz ... well put!

But Wembley ... isn't it? ... enduring memories ... the Mighty Magyars ... Puskas ... the galloping major ... So he had one good game in '53 ... Custer's last stand ... the battle of the little Big Horn ... er ... hang on ... that can't be right...

Kev? ... well should England fail ... it's the sharp end of the wedge ... the knives will be out ... should he fall on his sword ... would I throw my hat in the ring? ... eh?

Well the day I hung up my boots ... I nailed my colours to the mast! ... hang on ... I'm talking cobblers aren't I?

But Kev ... making a pig's ear of the England job isn't the end of the world ... there's life after! ... Ask Glenn ... new contract at Southampton ... thumped 3-1 by Middlesbrough ... Graham Taylor! ... "the Turnip" went back to his roots ... and already Watford are heading for the play-offs! ... they may be minnows compared to the big fish of the Premiership ... but if it's one of Graham's teams ... they're always cods!

Bobby Robson ... toast of the Toon ... wizened old head on his shoulders ... injury list as long as his arm ...

How Newcastle miss Nico Dabizas ... I was actually sitting next to the Newcastle bench when his injury occurred ... a sickening crunch ... The shout goes up ... "Quick! ... Dabizas!" ... the trainer's there in seconds with the magic sponge ... It's his knee you fool...

And ... a reader's letter ! ... from a woman! ... ho ho! ... marvellous! Noelle Murphy from Mallow ... County Cork writes:

"If Ireland don't stuff Portugal ... me name's O'Donnell! ... 2-1! ... goals from Keane, Quinn and Kinsella!"

...Well Noelle ... nobody else is remotely interested ... however I was thinking about the Irish this week ... er ... meself!

Lot of knees "gone all trembly" in the football world over Beckham's hit list ... he's out for revenge!...and David ... let me say ... a lone voice perhaps ... I thought your petulant kick at the Argie was spot on!

But it reminded me of the scandal over Jack Charlton's little black book ... he's still got it! ... and a night out in the West End with Jack and Michael Flatley at the height of Riverdance! ... ho ho! ... three red-blooded males in the heart of theatreland! ... and as I discovered Jack's infamous black book contained nothing but family trees...!

Within five minutes Jack had convinced me of my Irish lineage ... er ... Bejabers! ... Well the night was young ... Michael demonstrating his moves ... surprisingly physical! ... even Big Jack's a bit wary ... but soon we've worked up a little routine ... however at the after-show party ... I've inadvertently hoofed the Sultan of Brunei's wife up the behind ... dislodging her yashmak ... exposing her rear ... er ... best to draw a discreet veil over that!

Anyhow no Premiership action midweek! ... time for ... Ron dips his toe in the Nationwide ! ... right ... here we go!

Alan Little sacked by Southend - the club want someone who'll get them back into the Second Division ... Alan Ball! ... what? Oh sorry I thought they were in the First.

Fulham! ... ho ho they're doing well ... Grimsby? ... hmm ... not so good ... Well there you have it! ... Ron dips his toe in the Nationwide!

fields.headline: German regeneration keeps Christian confident
fields.standfirst: With Rudi Völler getting things back on track, Christian Ziege is looking forward to the Wembley showdown
fields.trailText: With Rudi Völler getting things back on track, Christian Ziege is looking forward to the Wembley showdown.
fields.body:
When called on to deliver an answer which requires some diplomacy, Christian Ziege often finds it hard to conceal the mischievous child that lurks within the professional man.

Since Germany's disastrous Euro 2000 campaign - three games, no wins, one point, one goal - he has, to a large extent, kept his own counsel.

When, only weeks after England's own Euro adventure reached its solitary peak against the old enemy in Charleroi, it is suggested that Kevin Keegan's team are the favourites for today's rematch, a confident smile creeps across Ziege's features. His message is, for optimistic England fans, rather bleak.

"I am not scared about this game, I am not worried," he says. "Why? Well, because I know, as do all my team-mates in the German squad, that many, many things have changed since Euro 2000.

"The team England will come up against will not be the same as in Belgium. The key thing is it will be the same players but a different team. There has been such a big change in attitude; the optimism which we always used to have is back. We are all happy again and we are thinking about winning this game; we haven't even discussed the possibility of losing or drawing."

The reasons behind the apparent transformation are, according to one of world football's most cultured wing-backs, many and varied. Even so, few German supporters would contest the suggestion that the change of coach has had something to do with it.

The departure of the respected if strangely unpopular Erich Ribbeck, coupled with the installation on a 12-month contract of Rudi Völler, would appear to have done the trick.

A former footballing hero who boasts a Keeganesque rapport with German fans, Völler has somehow succeeded in appeasing the malcontents. He has also won his first two games.

"At Euro 2000 we had as many problems as England," said Ziege. "We had good players and the basis of a good team but we just didn't play as we should have done. When we got home, everyone had their say, trying to explain what had happened. It was a combination of things, I suspect.

"We now have Rudi and he's very good. All the players like and respect him and everything is fine."

Well, fine up to a point. Next June Völler is scheduled to slip away quietly to make room for the Bayer Leverkusen coach Christoph Daum.

But Daum's appointment is by no means certain. Already under investigation in connection with a fraud case, he has been the subject of drug and sex allegations.

If Völler were to stay put, you suspect that Ziege and his mates would not be too disappointed.

"There has already been much discussion in Germany about what might happen if Rudi was to do well," Ziege said. "If that was the case - and he's started well - I think it would be very difficult for Christoph Daum to come in next summer. Rudi was loved as a player and now he is doing well as a coach."

After cutting his Premier ship teeth at Middlesbrough, Ziege is now content on Merseyside where he finds himself surrounded by men he will aid and hinder in equal measure this afternoon.

As well as his international team-mate Dietmar Hamann, he works with some of England's finest: Michael Owen, Robbie Fowler, Steven Gerrard, Emile Heskey and Nick Barmby.

"Rudi came over to Anfield to see one of our recent games," said Ziege. "Yes, he'll ask me about the strengths of the Liverpool boys but when you are talking about people like Michael and Robbie there's not much left to be said.

"Michael is just Michael: everyone knows him and what he can do. He is a top goalscorer, the sort every team needs. I played with Robbie in the reserves recently and he scored five times. You can see that he just loves to play football," he added.

According to Ziege, the sense of history surrounding today's game has not been lost on the visitors.

"This is more than just a qualification game," he said. "It is history in the making and it does mean much to the German people. Every professional player wants to play at this stadium at least once, but to play in the final game . . . well, wow, that would be something very, very special," he added, still sporting the smile of a confident man, but one whose good manners just prevented him from prophesying a German victory.

webTitle: Le Saux returns with new defensive drive

fields.headline: Le Saux returns with new defensive drive
fields.standfirst: Jon Brodkin hears how the England left-back has come back better than ever
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin hears how the England left-back has come back better than ever.
fields.body:
Things began to go wrong for Kevin Keegan in his third match in charge of England, the 0-0 draw with Sweden at Wembley in June 1999. In that game, Graeme le Saux's last for England, the Chelsea man went off at half-time suffering from a virus. England's left side has not had a settled look since. Keegan's team against Bulgaria four days later included Le Saux's replacement, Sunderland's Michael Gray, in an unfamiliar line-up (only David Seaman survives to start today's game). But untested youth gave way to old faithful Stuart Pearce in a 4-4-2 formation for the last two Euro 2000 qualifiers. Then, after flirting with Steve Guppy for a friendly against Belgium, Keegan settled on Phil Neville as the solution to his problem for the pre-Euro 2000 friendlies and the tournament itself. With results that are all too well known. For last month's friendly against France, Gareth Barry filled the slot, but his immediate international future seems to rest either on England reverting to 3-5-2 or on the uncertain fitness of Tony Adams and Martin Keown. Given England's frailty on the left it comes as a shock to discover that Graeme le Saux has not spent the week in bed wrapped in cotton wool. Instead there he was in training, galloping down the wing and whipping over a perfect cross for Robbie Fowler. Bum cheeks were not pointed at him on this occasion.

A simple practice exercise maybe, but a reminder of what England missed at Euro 2000 all the same. If Phil Neville's tackle against Romania is the enduring image of the summer's left-sided crisis, it can hardly be forgotten that going forward England displayed the balance Ann Widdecombe might expect after a few joints.

Ray Harford, who coached and managed Le Saux at Blackburn and trained Neville with the England Under-21s, knows how welcome Le Saux's return against Germany today will be after a 16-month international absence because of injury. "If I wanted someone to defend for me between Graeme and Phil Neville it would always be Phil Neville," he says. "But football is like a fight. If you keep taking punches and don't throw some back you're going to get knocked out.

"What Graeme will do is go outside people and get crosses in. We were obsessed with that at Blackburn. The best ball is the old Stanley Matthews ball, behind the full-back and pulled back. That's where Alan Shearer got most of his goals for Blackburn and he would have prospered more at Euro 2000 if Graeme had been there. There was a certain area of the pitch we would get them to deliver to because I think 95% of goals are scored from that area. Graeme's a good crosser but also knows where the ball should go."

That was evident at Old Trafford last month when Le Saux set up all Chelsea's goals in a 3-3 draw. After a frustrating lay-off because of an ankle problem, the 31-year-old has arguably returned stronger.

He admits a lack of international competition leaves him fearful of lapsing into a "false sense of security" and playing less well. Yet Kenny Sansom, who won 86 England caps at left-back from 1979-88, senses a new determination in Le Saux as he feels his way back. "Before the injury I don't think he was playing as well as he can," Sansom says. "Maybe he wasn't concentrating on the games as he should because he knew he was going to be picked. Since he's come back he's looked a different player. I think he's missed it, and watching matches can help.

"Defensively I have doubted Graeme a bit. He's not the greatest tackler and against Romania at the World Cup he seemed to do half the job and give it up. Going forward is still his best asset but since coming back he's looked strong defensively as well."

This afternoon should test that because Le Saux is likely to face Sebastian Deisler, Germany's wunderkind. Le Saux would not claim to be a Paolo Maldini but his gallivanting style is symptomatic of the modern full-back. Think Silvinho, Roberto Carlos and Christian Ziege for starters.

"The role has evolved," says Tony Dorigo, the former England left-back who played with Le Saux at Chelsea. "Before, a left-back had to be a defender first and foremost, and if he could attack all the better. Now you have to be comfortable in both roles and be a good-quality crosser."

Dorigo says he and Le Saux have used their pace to rescue themselves defensively. What puzzles many is the speed with which the mild-mannered, eloquent Le Saux can metamorphose into an aggressive player capable of rising to Fowler's bait and fighting with a Blackburn team-mate, David Batty, during a Champions League match in Moscow. "The worst night of my life," Harford says.

Le Saux's explanation is simple. "Getting on the bus before the person in front of you isn't the same level of competition. You have God knows how many chemical reactions going on in your body when you run on to a football pitch. I suppose you become an adrenalin junkie and that is something you have to thrive on. It lifts you to a new height, gives you that edge."

Le Saux insists he gets on "fine" with Fowler, and in Harford's opinion the non-conformity which sparks taunts of the sort delivered by the Liverpool striker is a strength. "He's similar to Shearer in that his maturity is a great asset," says Harford. "It's a different maturity but being a nonconformist he's so sure in himself. If everybody was going out for a drink he wouldn't just be a sheep. He's only do it if he wanted to.

"To do that you have to be a very strong character because people will call you all sorts of names. I explained that to him one day and he said it wasn't a problem because he'd had personal problems early on which had made him very strong.

"I loved that about him. He is a great challenge for coaches because he wouldn't be budged unless you convinced him you were right."

How easily Le Saux will be budged from England's left side is uncertain. The future looks bright with Gareth Barry, Ashley Cole and Jon Harley emerging. But Cole and Harley face problems breaking into their club sides, and as Dorigo says: "It will be a while before they bed in. I thought Michael Ball [of Everton] would come through but he never managed it."

Dorigo, who at 34 combines playing for Stoke with running a car business in Knutsford, knows how full-back crises can suddenly arise. He was part of Graham Taylor's squad that struggled up to and through Euro 92 without a right-back. In the final warm-up match, against Finland, Taylor asked him to try the role as a substitute. "I said 'I'm not comfortable there but I'll go on' and Graham said 'Thanks for your honesty, sit down'. I wasn't going to put myself in that position at that level. Keith Curle tried and paid the consequences for a long time after."

Curle never played for England again. Phil Neville's fate will surely be less severe, but welcome back Graeme le Saux all the same.

fields.headline: Tension mounts for fading Brazil
fields.trailText: The pressure is growing on Brazil's caretaker coach Candinho before his side's crucial World Cup qualifier against Venezuela tomorrow.
fields.body:
The pressure is growing on Brazil's caretaker coach Candinho before his side's crucial World Cup qualifier against Venezuela tomorrow.

Brazil lie fourth in the Conmebol qualifying table and Candinho, who took over as coach from Wanderley Luxemburgo, knows that anything less than victory over bottom-placed Venuzuela may see the four-times world champions fail to qualify for the finals for the first time, because only the top three teams are guaranteed to go through.

Under Luxemburgo the once-unbeatable Brazilians suffered a series of shock results, including defeats by Chile and Paraguay. The stuttering form was attributed to dissent within the squad and Candinho has attempted to overcome that by naming a predominantly Brazil-based squad.

In addition to the Vasco da Gama players Romario, Juninho Pernambucano, Juninho and Euller for his first game in charge, the caretaker coach has also called up Cruzeiro's Cleber, Donizete and Ricardinho. "This is a crucial time for us, and it is important to try and take advantage of the understanding that already exists between these players," Candinho said.

Meanwhile the group leaders Argentina face a tense clash with third-placed Uruguay, who are managed by the previous Argentina coach Daniel Passarella. Argentina, who have been hit hard by injuries, will give a late fitness test to Gabriel Batistuta, who suffered a recurrence of a knee injury in Roma's Serie A victory against Bologna last Sunday.

The River Plate playmaker Pablo Aimar and Lazio's Juan Sebastian Veron are also doubtful and Hernan Crespo, Ariel Ortega, Javier Zanetti, Roberto Sensini and Matias Almeyda are all out injured.

Italy's captain Paolo Maldini and the new coach Giovanni Trapattoni both face an emotional World Cup qualifier at the San Siro against Romania today. Maldini will become his country's most capped player on his 113th appearance, beating Dino Zoff's record, and Trapattoni makes his home debut as coach.

It is seven years since Italy played at the San Siro and Maldini, who has spent his entire career with Milan, admitted it would be a moving experience. "It is going to be emotional. I can't pretend that it is just another game, it is like making a debut again," he said.

Romania, beaten by Italy in the quarter-finals of Euro 2000, will be without the strikers Adrian Ilie and Ioan Vladoiu.

Arsenal's Fredrik Ljungberg has shrugged off a tetanus jab and should be fit to play for Sweden in today's World Cup qualifier against Turkey in Gothenburg. Both sides won their opening games in Group Four and Turkey are boosted by the probable return of striker Hakan Sukur after a stomach complaint.

fields.headline: Chile's Acuna bound for Newcastle
fields.trailText: Newcastle try to spend their money while they can as the transfer debate stalls
fields.body:
Newcastle last night agreed a £1.75m deal to sign the Chile midfielder Clarence Acuna. The 25-year-old had faxed St James' Park confirming he had agreed personal terms of a four-year deal and is now awaiting a work permit.

Acuna has just completed a month-long suspension imposed by Fifa after he was found to have taken a banned substance, an offence he has vehemently denied.

He impressed Bobby Robson on trial last month but the deal came close to collapsing when the Newcastle manager failed to reach an early agreement with the players representatives and his Santiago club, the University of Chile.

Chelsea have made a £3m bid for Deportivo La Coruna's Yugoslavia midfielder Savisa Jokanovic, according to the Spanish press. The 32-year-old, a former Partizan Belgrade, Oviedo and Tenerife player, has struggled to hold down a first-team place with the Spanish champions.

Talks in Zurich aimed at finding an alternative to the transfer system have hit trouble with the deadline for a solution less than a month away. And afterwards the Transfer Taskforce, comprising representatives of Fifa, Uefa, Europe's professional leagues and their players, fired a broadside at the European game's ruling body.

The players' representative, Gordon Taylor, accused fellow Taskforce members of stalling tactics in an attempt to keep the current system in place.

Taylor plans to meet the EC's Competitions' Commissioner Mario Monti in Brussels next week to express his concerns. The EC has already said that if the authorities fail to come up with an alternative system that falls in line with the Treaty of Rome's provisions on the free movement of labour, it will abolish transfer fees.

That would throw the game into chaos, but it is a distinct possibility if Taylor's fears are founded.

After the meeting chaired by the Fifa president Sepp Blatter, the international players' union FIFPro, of which Taylor is chairman, said in a statement: "After several working sessions [of the Taskforce] and very long discussions, FIFPro has come to the conclusion that Uefa and the professional leagues have only one objective - namely gaining time and retaining the present system at any cost."

The statement added that FIFPro will participate in one last Taskforce meeting next Thursday but added it did so "more in hope than expectation" of finding an answer.

"We refute the suggestion that we have dragged our feet," retorted Uefa's Mike Lee. "We have only been fully involved since the beginning of September. Other forces seem to be at play within FIFPro which seem intent on stopping this from happening.

"We believe that there is still an opportunity for a positive solution that works for football and is considered to be within European law. But this is not an easy solution to find."

webTitle: Jewell in danger of losing sparkle

fields.headline: Jewell in danger of losing sparkle
fields.standfirst: Wednesday's new boss is already fighting against a familiar scenario
fields.trailText: Wednesday's new boss is already fighting against a familiar scenario, writes Daniel Taylor.
fields.body:
Every once in a while the world of football clears its throat and spits out a fallen power whose decline has been so dramatic and undignified that the subsequent outpouring of sympathy comes with a gnawing sense of embarrassment.

Brian Clough's last, puffy-faced days in management made for just such a scenario. George Best, the person rather than the player, made for another. And now, on a grander scale, it looks like the turn of Sheffield Wednesday.

Bottom of the first division, six defeats in nine games with six goals scored and 18 conceded, eight weeks into the season and Wednesday are falling like a stone in a well.

Last season a gang of four local MPs, led by Joe Ashton, demanded that Danny Wilson be fired as manager halfway through the campaign. They got their way eventually but relegation from the Premiership could not be averted.

After Joe Kinnear turned them down, Paul Jewell then gambled his reputation by leaving Bradford City, whom he had kept in the Premiership against all odds, and jumping into the Wednesday camp.

How far they will drop remains to be seen but if Jewell had hoped the Owls would yo-yo back into the Premiership, he clearly overestimated their powers of elasticity.

"What I've seen so far has not been too good, to put it mildly," he said. "I can't tar everyone with the same brush but, if I'm going to be frank, there are too many players here who are just taking the mickey. They are dragging the club down.

"If I'm being honest, I don't know how some can go home and look in the mirror - maybe they have taken down all their mirrors - but given time I will get them out. Some of the players think they are too good to be here and, mark my words, they will go."

Jewell's credentials indicate he belongs to the slim file of managers capable of lugging Wednesday out of the quicksand, and his threats are not idle. Last week, when his players reported for the coach journey to Gillingham, he told Gilles de Bilde, an anonymous and recalcitrant figure of late, that he did not have a place on the trip. When the Belgian striker protested he got short shrift. Reputations, for Jewell, are a poor substitute for perspiration.

"I've tried everything I can but it has reached the point now where I just have to hope the players' consciences come into it," he said. "We have a lot of young players who are doing well but the club is plummeting because some of the seniors are not willing to put in the same effort.

"What I'm not going to do is insult our supporters by pretending everything is all right when everyone with eyes can see things are anything but. But I will see it through and I will come through the other side. I'll put everything I have into it although my only ambition at the moment is to keep this club in the first division."

Something that will be easier said than done judging by their efforts so far. Wednesday still have debts of somewhere between £16m and £26m, depending on whose version you listen to, and Jewell is in a vicious circle. He needs to bring in money before he can sign new players but, even though Wim Jonk is expected to join Chelsea once a back injury has healed, there have been precious few inquiries for any of his other misfits.

"Some people are prepared to argue that at worst it has been well-meaning amateurism that has brought us to this point," says Barry Birks of the Wednesday Independent Supporters' Association.

"Our view is more damning. The actions of Dave Richards [former chairman], Howard Culley [chairman] and Bob Grierson [finance director] have been nothing less than grossly incompetent in the amount of money that has been thrown away. Quite honestly, the club is rotten to the core." Tomorrow West Bromwich Albion will roll into town and Wednesday's brass band will do their best to lift spirits at a half-empty Hillsborough.

But even they are beginning to sound a touch flat. "People said we were too good to go down last season," adds Birks. "And look what happened then."

webTitle: Norway chill to prospect of Giggs

fields.headline: Norway chill to prospect of Giggs
fields.standfirst: United star the key against familiar opponents
fields.trailText: United star the key against familiar opponents.
fields.body:
Not everyone is obsessed with England's last game at Wembley. This afternoon Wales's third game at the Millennium Stadium will be watched by more than 60,000 people; not bad for a team who last qualified for the World Cup finals in 1958.

Despite decades of disappointment, the Welsh are still more concerned about the dragon than about St George. "I support two teams," reads a favourite T-shirt, "Wales and whoever England are playing."

Ironically, of course, that other quintessentially English joust, the FA Cup final, moves to Wales's new national auditorium from this season. However, today in Cardiff is all about Welsh fervour and pride and the enduring hope that Mark Hughes can produce a team to match those characteristic passions.

Having lost their opening World Cup qualifier 2-1 away in Belarus, Wales desperately need to win at home to Norway today otherwise, after Wednesday's difficult trip to Poland, they may be out of the qualification reckoning already. With Ukraine also in the Group Five the odds are stacked heavily against Wales anyway.

But hope springs eternal. "I have this passion to see Wales progress to a finals," said their captain Gary Speed, who will be collecting his 60th cap today. "That's what all Wales wants, it's what all the squad want and it's what I want. But we do need consistency to put Wales back on the map. Sadly, in Belarus it was a desperately poor performance and we all feel we have to do something to put that right."

webTitle: Celtic to take legal action over Di Canio book

fields.headline: Celtic to take legal action over Di Canio book
fields.trailText: Chief executive Fergus McCann vowes to defend his reputation after comments by controversial former striker in his autobiography.
fields.body:
Celtic's former chief executive and owner Fergus McCann says he will take legal action against Paolo di Canio over comments by the Italian forward in his recent autobiography.

McCann, who now lives in the United States, says Di Canio and the Holland striker Pierre van Hooijdonk made wild allegations about their time at Parkhead. "They were paid generous benefits and salaries while the Celtic support gave them backing they could not receive at any other football club," he said. "Legal papers will be served. I have a personal obligation to defend my reputation."

McCann has also threatened to sue the book's publisher and the newspaper that has published extracts. "In a real world we are all accountable for our words and actions, a lesson Mr Di Canio is about to learn."

Liverpool's American goalkeeper Brad Friedel, 29, has joined the Bundesliga's bottom club Energie Cottbus on a trial basis after his English work permit was not renewed by the department for employment. But Nottingham Forest have secured a work permit for Ben Olsen, Friedel's team-mate at the Olympics; the 23-year-old DC United winger is expected to complete a three-month loan deal next week.

The former Real Madrid coach John Toshack has agreed a 10-month contract with St Etienne, third from bottom of the French first division. The 52-year-old Welshman was sacked from his second spell in charge at the Bernabeu late last year and has not worked since.

Arsenal's Cameroon midfielder Lauren Etame Mayer, who recently won Olympic gold, is in Spain tending his sick father. "I don't know when I will go back to Arsenal, but I know they will understand that I must see my father," he said.

Everton have lodged a bid for a site at King's Dock in downtown Liverpool where they hope to build a 55,000-seat stadium with a retractable roof. But they will not complete any deal until they have talked with supporters.

Dundee, who this week completed the signing of Claudio Canigia, have been invited to play in a tournament involving River Plate and Boca Juniors in Argentina during Scotland's mid-winter break. "Interest in Claudio is just phenomenal over there," said Jim Connor, a club director .

webTitle: McIlroy puts faith in midfield masterplan

fields.headline: McIlroy puts faith in midfield masterplan
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland hope homework pays off against Denmark
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland hope homework pays off against Denmark. Malcolm Brodie in Belfast.
fields.body:
Sammy McIlroy will be banking on a bolstered midfield when his Northern Ireland side continue their Group Three qualifying campaign with the visit of the former European champions Denmark to Windsor Park today.

With a trip to Iceland on Wednesday, McIlroy, appointed 10 months ago in succession to Lawrie McMenemy, has two games in four days in which to make a mark on a group that also contains the Czech Republic and Bulgaria.

He has studied videos of the Danes, including their 2-1 win over Iceland, and also assessed them in their disastrous Euro 2000 campaign in which they failed to score a goal. As a result, the former Macclesfield Town manager is convinced that a five-man midfield is the way to play it.

"Under Morten Olsen, Denmark are much more focused and more vibrant, but I suspect he is experiencing difficulties in midfield," said McIlroy.

"That is a department in which we are exceptionally strong and capable of competing. So many matches are now won or lost in this area and that's why we must concentrate on it."

Injuries have forced McIlroy to make changes to the side that beat Malta 1-0 in their opening fixture. Steve Lomas is switched to right-back in place of Ian Nolan, while in midfield Manchester City's Jeff Whitley replaces Damien Johnson, who is recovering from a groin injury but may be fit for Wednesday's game.

Gerry Taggart, the Leicester City central defender, passed a rigorous fitness test on his knee and will link up again with Colin Murdock of Preston. David Healy, the Manchester United striker who has scored four goals in five internationals, leads the attack.

Denmark start favourites but Northern Ireland will not be daunted. "It is essential to win home fixtures in this group so our approach will be positive," insisted McIlroy. "There will be no question of us sitting back and letting opponents come at us. We'll be adventurous yet cautious.

"This is a much more formidable task than Malta, but if we are in the correct frame of mind we can put Denmark under pressure, retain possession and accept chances on our breakaways."

webTitle: Scotland are rocked by Leighton's own-goal

fields.headline: Scotland are rocked by Leighton's own-goal
fields.standfirst: Preparations overshadowed by veteran keeper dropping the biggest clanger of all
fields.trailText: Preparations overshadowed by veteran keeper dropping the biggest clanger of all. Graham Spiers in Rimini.
fields.body:
Within the canon devoted to great football cock-ups abroad, probably only Scotland could concoct the sort of drama that unfolded on Italy's Adriatic coast yesterday.

Scotland are based in the idyllic town of Rimini before playing a supposedly ordinary World Cup Group Six qualifier against San Marino tonight. But, before a ball has been kicked, the place is already in ferment.

The cause of the latest furore is Jim Leighton, the most capped and surely the most bandy-legged goalkeeper ever to play for Scotland, who joined the squad on the flight out of Glasgow on Thursday, ostensibly to do some coaching with the Under-21 squad.

Leighton, though, over the in-flight refreshments, omitted to tell the Scotland manager Craig Brown that extracts from his forthcoming autobiography were being serialised in a tabloid newspaper this weekend. He also omitted to tell Brown that within those extracts would be some stinging criticisms of Brown's international set-up.

Specifically, Leighton's book attacks Alan Hodgkinson, the Scotland squad's goalkeeping coach, who for years had worked with Leighton on Scotland trips before the goalkeeper's retirement, despite rumours of bad blood between the two. Hodgkinson is on this trip for Scotland's World Cup double-header against San Marino and Croatia, and not surprisingly is said to be fuming.

Yesterday, news of Leighton's impending serialisation provoked outrage in the Scottish media and, perhaps inevitably, led to Brown relieving Leighton of his duties with the squad. Hodgkinson, meanwhile, has been roaming around with a red face threatening to sue the former Aberdeen goalkeeper. Leighton himself spent yesterday afternoon on the phone to the Mail on Sunday, trying desperately to pull himself out of trouble.

"In the light of what I have heard about Jim's book extracts I have chosen to relieve him of his duties with us," announced a peeved Brown.

"When I originally invited him to work with the squad I knew nothing of his book. Then, last Friday, when I became aware of the serialisation I got on to Jim and asked him if there would be anything in them which would specifically criticise our set-up. Jim told me that there would not be.

"Jim said that he has a veto on what the paper carries, and that, while we are abroad with Scotland, nothing critical would come out. This, though, now appears not to be the case. Given that there will be extracts which may criticise me and almost certainly Alan [Hodgkinson] I have chosen to relieve Jim of his duties and he fully understands the decision. Our squad's harmony must come first."

In the entire saga it has been hard to calculate who has been the more foolish in this trivial but disruptive incident: Brown for including Leighton when he clearly did not get on with Hodgkinson, or Leighton himself for being so silly as to accept the invitation while slaughtering his paymasters in print back home.

David Taylor, the recently appointed SFA chief executive who must now have some idea of the carry-ons that engulfed Jim Farry, said: "We cannot condone one member of our staff criticising others like this. It is a situation that has been created and it is only right that Leighton be asked to leave."

But to add to the embarrassment, Leighton will not in fact be leaving Italy. Instead he will be commenting on Scotland's performance in Radio 5 Live's coverage of the match tonight.

As to the game itself, normal news such as who will actually play has been overshadowed by all the internal wranglings, but Newcastle's Kevin Gallacher is expected to captain the team on the occasion of his 50th cap.

Leighton collected 91 of those, but throughout the highs and lows of his long career it is hard to recall the bespectacled goalkeeper dropping quite such a clanger as this.
