fields.headline: Goodbye to '66 and all that
fields.standfirst: England need more than the past to build their future, writes  David Lacey
fields.trailText: England need more than the past to build their future.
fields.body:
England's footballers will this afternoon hope to mark the end of one era with the beginnings of another. At least there is no harm in hoping. In the stands, Wembley will be steeped in nostalgia but on the pitch Kevin Keegan's team would prefer to demonstrate that a nation's footballing prestige cannot be sustained indefinitely by memories of an isolated World Cup triumph in 1966.

Not that the side Keegan fields will contain the degree of youthful innovation for which the England coach had been hoping. Steven Gerrard, the 20-year-old Liverpool player to whom Keegan was looking for an extra dimension in midfield, has been forced out with a recurrence of a groin problem which will almost certainly mean a recall for Paul Ince, who will be 33 in a fortnight, or Dennis Wise, 34 in December.

For England and Keegan losing Gerrard is a bitter disappointment. Although the player has won only two caps, the impact he made as a substitute against Germany in Charleroi during Euro 2000, when England were clinging to a 1-0 lead, clearly marked him out as a probable for the World Cup. But for injuries Gerrard would have played against Romania as well as last month's friendly in France.

Keegan has yet to announce today's side but yesterday admitted that Gerrard would have resumed his confrontation with the Germans. "We were looking to include him," said the England coach. "Steven Gerrard gives you options that not many other players do in our squad."

Kieron Dyer is another option as Gerrard's replacement but Keegan is more likely to prefer either Ince, for his tackling, or Wise, for his accurate passes, in the anchor role. England, then, will have gained in experience through losing Gerrard but may have lost a vital element of surprise as they attempt to compete with Germany's five-man midfield.

It is fitting that the last match to be played at Wembley before the septuagenarian stadium is pulled down should renew England's acquaintances with the Germans. Not so much because West Germany were the fall guys on English football's greatest day 34 years ago but because their international record remains one to which any England footballer or coach should aspire.

At the moment, after a poor European Championship for both countries, neither side can aspire to anything very much. One headline yesterday referred to a "clash of Titans". Tadpoles more like.

Yet, ahead lies a place in the 2002 World Cup and to this end England will be seeking a victory today while Germany would not be dismayed to draw and will play a tight game accordingly. To date the Germans, and this relates to West Germany, have only ever lost one World Cup qualifier (1-0 to Portugal in Stuttgart in 1985). It is not a record easily spoilt and therefore a draw, 0-0 or 1-1, is a likely outcome.

For Keegan this is a chance to make a completely fresh start as England coach. He took over a disaffected team in an emergency following the sudden departure of Glenn Hoddle - sacked by the Football Association for expressing confused thoughts about reincarnation and the disabled - and managed to qualify, albeit narrowly, for this summer's European Championship.

Now it is Keegan's turn to be born again. England's early, fumbling departure from Euro 2000 may have confirmed the doubts about his appointment which still linger in some minds. But if England can take at least four points from this afternoon's match with Germany and Wednesday's qualifier in Finland, Keegan will be spared a renewal of the speculation about his future which followed the retreat from Charleroi.

"I feel more in the job now than I did before and during Euro 2000," Keegan said yesterday. "This is the start of a new campaign and I can no longer say that when I came in we'd got four points from nine, which is basically where I was. Now I'll have to live or die by the results."

England must win their World Cup group to avoid a play-off and while a draw this afternoon would not be a disaster, always provided the Finns were beaten next week, points dropped at home are never good news. Today, therefore, his team will be looking for goals while making sure their enthusiasm does not expose them to the sort of German sucker punch which caught Terry Venables's defence on the hop after Alan Shearer had given England an early lead in the Euro 96 semi-finals.

England will have the attacking pace seriously to disturb Rudi Völler's back three. If Michael Owen gets chances to outrun Jens Nowotny, Wembley will surely have excuses for a few valedictory roars. Yet speed of thought will be as crucial as out-and-out athleticism and here Paul Scholes, with his astutely timed runs from midfield to reach scoring positions, could again be England's golden matchwinner.

Certainly this is one occasion when, for England, silver simply will not do. In immediately altering a way of playing which looked impressive in the Stade de France, even allowing for the game being a friendly, Keegan will risk accusations of not knowing his own mind should today's result go against him.

Moving Beckham back to the right wing and playing two strikers against opponents who will get eight men behind the ball and await chances to attack on the break, risks England yet again being overrun in midfield, as they were by Portugal and Romania in June.

"For this game I want to play a different way," Keegan insisted. "I've looked at the Germans, studied the Germans, looked at them in Hanover against Spain, watched them in Greece, looked at the personnel I've got and I just think this is the right way."

By around 4.45pm today, as Wembley empties for the last time, he will know the truth about what his instincts have been telling him.

webTitle: McCarthy revels in part two of trial by style

fields.headline: McCarthy revels in part two of trial by style
fields.standfirst: Holland dealt with, Irish attention now turns to Figo and co
fields.trailText: Holland dealt with, Irish attention now turns to Figo and co. Daniel Taylor in Lisbon.
fields.body:
Whoever it was that drew out the teams for the World Cup qualifiers, Mick McCarthy would like a quiet word. For the Republic to be dispatched to Holland and Portugal in their opening two Group Two games is rather like Ipswich being invited to start their first season back in the Premiership with back-to-back games at Old Trafford and Highbury.

Yet, as McCarthy's players whiled away the time yesterday at their team hotel, a converted 17th-century fortress set in sumptuous coastal scenery on Estrada do Guincho, the temperatures touching 27C (80F) on Europe's most westerly point, there was no sense of foreboding about the potential horrors to come.

Whether they will be chewed up and spat out by Luis Figo et al remains an unedifying possibility but, for all the Portuguese pomp and flair on parade, there was an air of belligerent defiance at Irish HQ. As contemptuous of starry reputations as ever, McCarthy's men have been invigorated by the sheer audacity of their display in the Amsterdam Arena last month.

By popular consensus they have not concocted such an assured performance since the 1994 World Cup and they will head into Lisbon this evening without trepidation, knowing they have already taken one more point than most people would have expected.

In truth, they were mighty unlucky not to return from Holland with more than a 2-2 draw and, as a guard against complacency, the new Portuguese coach Antonio Oliveira talked his players through a video of the match yesterday.

fields.headline: Wembley makes most of endgame
fields.standfirst: Today may be Wembley's last stand, but the old place isn't going out without a fight
fields.trailText: Today may be Wembley's last stand, but the old place isn't going out without a fight.
fields.body:
It is possible to accuse the old stadium at Wembley of many things - hosting the biggest indoor urine lake in Europe, for instance - but failing to make the most of its end is certainly not one of them. At the end of the month, every bit of the place will be auctioned off to dewy-eyed nostalgists. Though the section of turf on which Geoff Hurst's 1966 crossbar- rattling goal landed has already been sold to Ken Bates (presumably to be stored at Stamford Bridge ready to serve as an emergency going-away present for a future Chelsea manager). You can even have the twin towers for a quid, but like all proper bring-and-buy sales, you will have to collect them. And then when you get them home you'll discover they only have three sides.

Meanwhile, all this week, we have been told that this afternoon's game between England and Germany will be the last ever staged in the ground before the wrecking ball finally swings into view. Which is not strictly true. For the next fortnight, every moment of every day has been rented out to anyone prepared to fork out £25,000 an hour for the privilege of playing on the hallowed turf. There will be more matches scheduled in the stadium after its advertised end than were played in its first five years of existence. Newspapers have bought slots to sell to readers, Radio Five Live is running a competition to enable listeners to stroll down the sacred tunnel listening to the pre-recorded roar of the crowd, while several of the sessions have been bought by the wealthy for a kickaround with their chums.

The 365 corporation, purveyors of fine sporting websites, thought it would be appropriate to invite the most famous footballer never to have played at Wembley to join in the match they have bought: Pele, who once said the only regret of his long and successful career was not stepping out on the sacred turf. But, far from snapping off the hand proffering the invitation, a fee was demanded by the great man. A fee so vast it suggests that it is not just in the boardroom of Wembley plc that sentiment takes second place to commerce.

fields.headline: gogmagogs
fields.standfirst:
gogmagogs
St Andrew's Hall, Norwich ***
fields.trailText:
gogmagogs
St Andrew's Hall, Norwich ***
fields.body:
John Tavener's latest stage-work, The Fool, was written for the amazingly versatile talents of the gogmagogs, the seven-piece ensemble of string-playing actors and singers, and premiered at the Norfolk and Norwich Festival. The work dramatises the theological archetype of the Holy Fool, chosen by Tavener and his spiritual advisor and librettist, Mother Thekla, for its relevance to the corruption of contemporary society.

Thekla and Tavener reveal the essential piety of the fool through seven scenes inspired by Christian festivals, charting a journey from the depths of Good Friday to the transcendence of Easter. The fool begins by debauching and mocking religious and social conventions. But as the work progresses, he becomes an emblem of purity, brought about through his continual self-abasement. Finally, he comes to understand that Christ "has given life", and repeats this phrase in unadulterated, diatonic bliss.

Matthew Sharp's performance in the central role displays consummate theatrical invention. As one of the gogmagogs' cellists, Sharp is used to being asked to act and sing as well as play an instrument. But as Tavener's Fool, Sharp combines this musical multi-tasking with eating and regurgitating steak, and performing acrobatics with a metal bucket full of holy water - while commanding enough vocal and stage presence to carry the work's drama.

The skill of Lucy Bailey's direction and Bunny Christie's designs is in making Tavener's highly specific - and potentially stifling - religious imagery speak for a wide range of experience. From the first scene, they create a compelling interplay between the isolation of Sharp's Fool and the different groups in the drama, from devout pilgrims to drunken revellers.

The other gogmagogs are cast as plaster-clad deities, in costumes which merge with the blasphemous daubings on the walls of the set. They begin by commentating on the Fool's predestined fate, and their music frames the Fool's inebriated ramblings and his sacrilegious sarcasm. Later, they become worshippers at the Cross, which the Fool, now dressed in a dishevelled suit, cannot bear to see.

The final scenes make the Fool's conflict with the world even more overt. Joined by the Viva Voce choir in imitation of a Christmas and then an Easter party, the Fool stands apart and mute, alone in seeing the true meaning behind this worldly chaos.

Tavener's repetition of large paragraphs of this clinching drama ritualises the everyday noises of radios playing and people talking. But this conclusion also breaks the spell of the more subtle images of the Fool's individuality in the earlier scenes, and seems over-emphatic and unbalanced in comparison.

the gogmagogs perform at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), on Monday and Tuesday.

fields.headline: Philip Guston
fields.standfirst:
Philip Guston
Pompidou Centre, Paris ****
fields.trailText:
Philip Guston
Pompidou Centre, Paris ****
fields.body:
In the gift shop outside this exhibition, you can buy a Jackson Pollock jigsaw puzzle. It's a shame that the Pompidou Centre didn't order some Philip Guston merchandise, too - dismembered legs, hobnail boots and Ku Klux Klan hoods.

But Guston's oeuvre is a disturbed one and doesn't lend itself to Cézannewiches, fridge magnets and the other paraphernalia of the modern retrospective. All credit to the Pompidou Centre for staging an exhibition of a painter whose work is as disturbed as it is unpopular.

Guston's first pictures were murals, political affairs, inspired by Mexican painting. By the time he got to New York in the late 1940s and met up with his old school chum, Jackson Pollock, he had developed a nice abstract expressionist counterpoint to Jackson's schtick. Pollock dripped, but Guston wiped and smeared in short, colourful bursts.

The abstract-expressionist works that Guston created until the late 1960s often seem to be concerned with obliteration - if with anything. In Group II (1964), four black patches float on a ground of grey smears, for all the world as though they are the hairdos of four scalped victims. But imputing figurative concerns to paintings from this time, while fun, is hardly warranted. Thus, Clock (1956/57) isn't so much a timepiece but an explosion of time.

During his abstract phase, Guston seems to have got hold of some pink paint from Willem de Kooning. He remained faithful to this colour in his figurative era - a Pop Art colour that makes his KKK hoods and floating limbs even more upsetting. In Deluge 2 (1975), a sort of angsty Pop Art Otto Dix, dirty pink heads bob disconsolately on a viscous sea of red. The critics had loved the abstract Guston, but turned on him when he went figurative in 1970. They hated his appropriation of cartoons, the ugly crudity of his canvases. But for Guston the world - or at least the American part of it - was ugly, replete with Nixons, Vietnams and unedifying human striving, warranting just this painterly project.

Until December 4. Details: 00-33-1-44 78 12 33.

fields.headline: House
fields.standfirst:
House
Project Arts Centre, Dublin ****
fields.trailText:
House
Project Arts Centre, Dublin ****
fields.body:
Somewhere between the writing and the blankly anti-naturalist performance style here, a very peculiar, urban alienation is fetched up by writer-director Richard Maxwell, the emerging darling of the New York scene who earned a commendation at the Obie awards last year for this skilful piece, directed for the New York City Players.

The key to it is that the actors are completely lacking in affect, like mental couch potatoes. They stand languidly in front of the audience, arms hung by their sides, in a set which faithfully replicates a corner of their rehearsal room. They intone their lines fast and deadpan, then stare long at each other, as if in the forlorn hope of deciphering meaning from sedated bewilderment.

The ironic weirdness sends you guffawing in all directions, even at the accumulation of cruelties within a lumpily dressed American family who, as far as we can tell, live on a house on a street full of traffic.

A terminally indecisive Mom serves buttered toast, looking at Pop with a perpetual expression of blank concern. Pop regards her with a disinterest beyond disdain, only addressing his 10-year-old son, who apes his father's toast behaviour like a chess game. But the kid also stares unswervingly up at Pop, asking searching questions that are never answered directly, except with a soliloquoy of deranged fatherly authority (I have never seen a child actor as wise and disciplined as young Aaron Nutter).

Then there's Mike. Mike wears a loud suit, and stands well apart from the family. Eventually, he introduces himself in another derailed word-salad of thoughts, about an unspecified "operation" he set up in which "nobody would get hurt", except that his brother got killed. Now he's looking for revenge.

It's all very clever, the pared-back semiotics of the story-telling kicking off the wildest absurdism. The dialogue is littered with the staccato phrase-fragments of Mamet, with Maxwell's own well-aimed nonsense of perfectly normal crazies, with their paranoia of federal government.

Ends tonight. Box office: 00-353-1-679 6622.

fields.headline: Noises Off
fields.standfirst:
Noises Off
Lyttelton Theatre, London ***
fields.trailText:
Noises Off
Lyttelton Theatre, London ***
fields.body:
I went into the National wondering about the urgent need to revive Michael Frayn's Noises Off. Coming on top of the Ayckbourns, and designed to tour in partnership with a commercial management, the production looked as if it were yet another manifestation of the National's populist credo. But it is difficult to remain captious when confronted by a play that so hilariously explores, and exploits, the insane rituals of theatre.

To be honest, Jeremy Sams's production of Frayn's farce-within-a-farce takes time to get going, and the reason is not far to seek. In the first act we watch a disastrous dress-rehearsal of a show called Nothing On, based on the comic properties of slamming doors, furtive sex and recalcitrant sardines. Frayn accurately pins down a whole range of theatrical types from the sardonic director to the sloshed old pro and the fusspot actor who needs a motive for opening a door.

It struck me that the kind of mechanistic farce Frayn is satirising has all but disappeared from our theatres. But, even if basic British farce is a back number, we soon succumb to Frayn's artful ingenuity. In the second act we watch from behind the scenes as the performers' sexual rivalries outrun the stage's ordered frenzy and, by the last act, chaos completely rules.

Unlike the 1982 original, Sams's version gets funnier as it goes along but the laughs are bought at a certain price. Sams piles up the visual jokes in the final act, even including the old Night at the Opera gag of backdrops flying in at wildly inappropriate moments. The result is theatrical mayhem. What one loses is the sense that in theatre, as in life, only the thinnest of lines separates disciplined order from nightmare panic.

But the laughs arrive in escalating waves and the cast perform with such hectic virtuosity one wonders how they will survive a long tour. Prime amongs them are Aden Gillett, who resembles a peculiarly fluid lamppost, as the ingratiating male lead, Natalie Walter as his pneumatic, defrocked partner who myopically ignores the show's disintegration, and Patricia Hodge as a headscarved housekeeper who privately sports a wonderfully cut-glass accent. With his beard and black suit, Peter Egan's god-like director even bears a libellously accurate resemblance to a former NT boss.

In rep. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

fields.headline: Trackers back on the move
fields.standfirst: Funds that follow the stock market no longer offer spectacular returns, reports Phillip Inman
fields.trailText: Funds that follow the stock market no longer offer spectacular returns, reports Phillip Inman.
fields.body:
Investors tracking the Britain's top 100 companies have seen precious little return in the past year. Words like "doldrums" are used to describe the FTSE-100, which measures the London stock market's 100 biggest players.

But until a couple of years ago it provided consistently high returns. Since then, every boomlet has been followed by a downturn and prices have ended up roughly where they were a year or even two years ago. The FTSE-100 has increased by just 4% in the past year - and has fallen by nearly 10% since last December.

The market has also been skewed further towards the major 12 global companies that have merged their way to the front of the pack. The mobile phone operator Vodafone, the oil giant BP Amoco, the bank HSBC and nine other supercompanies are now so large they account for more than 50% of the FTSE-100 valuation.

Funds inside an individual savings account (Isa) wrapper enjoy tax-free status and allow the investor to keep the few gains on offer from a FTSE tracker. Charges will eat away at the growth, but if the product conforms to the government's charges, access and terms (Cat) standards the annual management fee is no more than 1%. Many trackers charge half that.

Investors who want to use one of the 17-odd FTSE-100 Isa tracker products on the market are also encouraged to think longer term and ignore the current vagaries of the market. They might consider switching to the broader FTSE All-Share trackers- Legal & General has 0.5% annual charges, half the 1% of the highly hyped Virgin fund - and balancing their portfolio with investments in a managed fund.

"Consider trackers because they can be a good investment, but don't put all your money into them," says Justin Modray of the independent financial adviser Chase De Vere. "Even though they have performed well over the longer term, if the market goes nowhere then so does the tracker."

But Mr Modray believes FTSE-100 trackers have now become so skewed towards the top 12 that they are extremely volatile. "In this environment an All-Share tracker could be a better bet."

Some observers expect the large company stocks to bounce back after their faltering couple of years. "The large cap stocks are bound to come back some time and it is good to have a tracker to tap into that rise," says Mr Modray.

"But if smaller stocks carry on performing strongly you will need an actively managed fund. We tell people they need to arrange their funds to catch both waves."

Amanda Davidson, of IFA Holden Meehan, says not more than 10% to 15% of investments should be locked up in a tracking fund. "I would have felt happier going into an index fund last year," she says. "They may be cheap to run, but at the moment you will need to pay [an active manager] for a chance of good returns."

According to the IFA Whitechurch Securities, the top performing FTSE-100 tracker was Marks & Spencer's UK 100 Companies, with a growth rate since April 1998 of 10.84% after charges. But it lies ninth in the broker's list of tracker funds behind a raft of all-share offerings

Legal & General's UK Index All-Share tracker is the top performer with a growth rate since April 1998 of 17.83%. Next in the table comes the Scottish Widows' UK All-Share, generating growth of 16.86%, followed by HSBC's UK Index with 16.41%. Barclays FTSE 100 tracker managed to grow by only 5.14%. Part of the reason can be found in Barclays 5% entry charge, which sucks money out of the fund before it has got going.

Words like "doldrums" are used to describe the FTSE-100, which measures the London stock market's 100 biggest players. But until a couple of years ago it provided consistently high returns. fields.headline: Dave Douglas
fields.standfirst:
Dave Douglas
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.trailText:
Dave Douglas
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.body:
Trumpet player Dave Douglas is a phenomenon - not so much part of a new wave as an entire movement by himself. You could programme a long weekend festival with all his different bands (eight at the last count) and multifarious collaborations and there would still be plenty left unheard by Monday evening. Music tumbles out constantly, in group improvisations, compositions and long solos -he has incredible physical stamina as well.

You could never describe him as someone who transcends his technical limitations - he has none. He has soulful, swinging technique, classical technique, contemporary, avant-garde technique. You get the impression of a big musical mind that has absorbed the entire canon and it's both exhausting and exhilarating.

Douglas opened with the Charms of the Night Sky quartet and closed with the more unbuttoned Tiny Bell Trio, an intense, storming performance with two encores. The trio is built around drummer Jim Black and hard-working guitarist Brad Shepik, playing clean jazz chords, keyboard-like arpeggios and fast ensemble lines in quick succession.

They play numbers such as Prolix, that recall Ornette Coleman's group with Don Cherry, plus jazz standards, odd marches, ballads and even a chunk of Schumann (Nicht so schnell, mit viel Ton zu spielen). Sometimes they just impro- vise, searching, surprising themselves with aural glimpses of show tunes, stop-start grooves and rapid changes of timbre and harmony. Black is a star, a hyper-aware presence poised over his tightly tuned kit, adding splashes of tone colour from a tray of percussion toys.

Charms of the Night Sky features legendary accordionist Guy Klucevsek, bassist Greg Cohen, violinist Mark Feldman and Douglas, who has created some of his best compositions for this little chamber ensemble. Their opening "signature tune", the title track from the Winter & Winter album, encapsulates their qualities - a supple bass riff, flowing, dynamic ensemble work and a beguiling, elliptical melody that could be a timestretched fragment from a Douglas solo.

A strength of the Charms band (whose album A Thousand Evenings has just been released on RCA Victor) is that it is entirely new, yet in a kind of parallel universe. You can imagine a non-wired, 1940s vision of Europe in the year 2000, with steam-powered cars, monorails and atrium chess cafes where you might listen to a charming, "longhair" band play strange and beguiling music like this.

Dave Douglas is at the Jacqueline du Pre building, Oxford (01865 798 600), tonight, then tours.

fields.headline: National treasure
fields.standfirst: New deals from Britain's state-owned bank are ideal for risk-averse investors, says Nick Pandya
fields.trailText: New deals from Britain's state-owned bank are ideal for risk-averse investors, says Nick Pandya.
fields.body:
We may nip in to get stamps or buy a lottery ticket, but the local post office also doubles up as a branch of the state-owned bank, National Savings.

The savings institution has found it hard to compete on interest rates alone, but thanks to its government backing, it offers a wide range of secure, tax-free investments as well as accounts that offer non-taxpayers the full gross return without hassle.

Typically, the best tax-free deals have gone to those who are willing to lock up cash for five years, but recently National Savings launched a two-year fixed-rate savings deal: the fourth issue savings certificate now on sale pays 4.5% tax-free on deposits from £100 to £10,000.

The return on this is worth 5.62% to basic-rate taxpayers and a hard-to-beat 7.5% to those on higher rate tax.

For savers who prefer a longer guarantee, tax-free returns over the next five years, the 55th issue of savings certificates pays 4.15%, fixed for five years - worth 5.18% to a basic-rate and 6.9% to higher rate taxpayer.

For investors worried about inflation eroding the value of their investment, National Savings offers the 17th index-linked issue for a minimum investment of £100. Savers can stash up to £10,000, with no limit on money being reinvested from previously held National Savings certificates.

Again this is a five-year savings plan which ensures the money you receive back will still buy the same goods and services as when you started, because your capital increases in line with the cost of living index. In addition, savers get tax-free interest equal to 2% a year if they hang on for five years.

There is a two-year index-linked deal paying 3% above inflation fixed for two years on deposits of between £100 and £10,000.

Another tax-free National Savings product often overlooked is its Children's Bonds. The current issue S can be bought by anyone over 16 on behalf of those under this age. The minimum investment is £25, with £1,000 maximum in any one issue.

The return on investment is a guaranteed 5.25% tax-free if held for five years and further guaranteed returns are available every five years. No interest is added after the holder's 21st birthday. Tax-paying parents can give money to their offspring in this way without affecting their own tax position.

For non-taxpaying savers aged 60 or over, the Pensioners Bonds Series 15 may be worth considering. Interest is paid before tax each month at a guaranteed rate of 5.75% for five years. The bond is not free of tax, but pays interest without tax deducted. This appeals to non-taxpayers who do not have to bother with paperwork for tax refunds. Savers are obliged to declare the interest payouts to the inland revenue.

Although a tax-efficient National Savings product is useful to plan your overall savings strategy, remember there may be better deals elsewhere on the high street.

Information on National Savings products at www.nationalsavings.co.uk

webTitle: Net closes on the chatroom gossips

fields.headline: Net closes on the chatroom gossips
fields.standfirst: Website bulletin boards have carried unfounded rumours about companies - now one firm affected is resorting to law. Liz Stuart reports
fields.trailText: Website bulletin boards have carried unfounded rumours about companies - now one firm affected is resorting to law. Liz Stuart reports.
fields.body:
This week it has emerged that a small UK-listed company claiming to be the victim of bulletin board market manipulation is taking legal action against the chat room user who posted the rumours.

This news will send shivers down the spines of all web sites, ISPs and bulletin board operators, who are nervous in the extreme about libel and the net. The attitude is understandable; the laws surrounding internet regulation are nebulous to non-existent and any case law has international implications.

In this case, the threatened legal action is over negative information posted about its overseas operations. The share price shot down. The company in question says the information was completely incorrect.

So, just how can the private investor verify the contents of the many regulated, and unregulated, financial cyber lounges? The simple answer is that they cannot, and the Financial Services Authority in March issued a warning to this effect.

A spokesman for the Motley Fool site, which operates over a thousand bulletin boards, argues the financial chatrooms tend to be self-regulating. "If someone posts an incorrect comment, generally the rest of the community will react quickly and clamp down on it. It's a bit like turning up at a dinner party when everyone is having a serious discussion and you come in with a silly comment. You will quickly be told to keep quiet."

He adds that the Motley Fool has created a philosophy of genuine interest in long-term investing and that people who sign up to the board also sign up to this community.

Motley Fool does, however, employ 12 people whose sole role is to monitor the boards. They are automatically alerted every time someone clicks on the "problem post" link. The spokesman says that not every post will automatically be removed, but it will be investigated. Similarly, Hemscott employs a compliance officer, part of whose job is to check for dodgy board entries.

In August, interactive investor international (iii) introduced a requirement for all participants in discussions to submit their email address before posting. The address is verified by sending an email containing a link which must be clicked before the person can contribute to the board, meaning posters using hotmail or even internet cafes, can be tracked.

The FSA and the Stock Exchange monitor the boards on an even more sporadic basis, although this will become more formalised next year once the Financial Services Market Act comes into effect.

If legal action were to be brought against the board providers, it would use the defence of "innocent disseminator": in other words, there is no way that it can effectively monitor everything that is being written, but what the individual posters should remember is that unless you are qualified to do so, giving financial advice -such as tipping shares - is a criminal offence and perpetrators could be imprisoned for up to seven years.

A London company called IBNet is about to start marketing software which monitors all mention of a specific company anywhere on the internet. The CEO, Mark Ommanney, says the product is a result of his own company's experience of fallacious comment that its shares had been suspended.

"The post was on iii and purported to be sourced from an article in the Evening Standard. I checked, and there was no such article, so I called my broker to check whether or not it was true. It wasn't, so my next action was to call my PR company. A message was posted on the same board to say that the rumour was not true, and fortunately, this quashed all discussion of the issue," he says.

He adds that while the iii monitoring service works - allowing people who are unhappy with the contents of a board discussion to appeal directly to iii to have it thrown off site - he felt it was better to counter rumour with truth, rather than having the original posting removed.

A spokesman for iii says: "The boards form an important component for discussion and the potentially libellous information is very much the exception and not the rule."

Earlier this year Scoot, the online information directory, found confidential company information was being leaked onto various boards, including iii. A court order was issued and the boards were forced to hand over email addresses of the posters.

Paul Carratu runs a detective agency offering a dot.com monitoring service. His clients tend to operate in sensitive areas. He watches UK and international financial bulletin boards and gen- eral chat rooms for mention of the client which is suspic-ious, controversial or wrong.

"Nine times out of 10 we don't know ourselves whether or not the information is misleading, so we just pass it to the company to investigate," he says.

fields.headline: Play to Win
fields.standfirst:
Play to Win
Contact, Manchester **
fields.trailText:
Play to Win
Contact, Manchester **
fields.body:
David KS Tse's play, a co- production between Soho Theatre and Yellow Earth Theatre Company, is aimed at the 10-14 age group and their families. The wide age span is a pretty tall order. Tse's play concentrates on Paul, a 12-year-old Philippine boy with an interest in computer games and martial arts, who is finding the transition from primary to secondary school difficult because he is being targeted by bullies who call him "chinky" and duff him up.

But it is out of the frying pan and into the fire when Paul falls in with Anaconda and his gang, whose misunderstanding of Chinese and the martial arts culture, has led them to style themselves as the Black Snake Triad. Soon Paul is truanting and stealing, much to the distress of his hard-working Catholic parents.

What I hoped for from this play, which is performed as part of a new sponsorship initiative called Sainsbury's Checkout Theatre, was a production with strong youth appeal but which actually transcended the barriers of theatre for young people and theatre for the rest of the population. The calibre of those involved suggested there was a good chance that it would succeed. Regrettably what is on offer is a strongly issue-based piece with the unmistakable whiff of theatre in education. There is nothing wrong with theatre in education, but its place is in the school not the theatre.

The young cast are great, particularly Tom Wu, who is not only a martial arts expert but manages to convey all the confusion of a 12-year-old. The martial arts sequences are exciting and the whole thing is technically impressive.

But Tse's script uses language that lacks street credibility and is too transparent; the fantasy sequences are the equivalent of the "it was all a dream" cop-out and the mystic message that you can find strength through gentleness is inadequate. If you were a badly bullied 12-year-old would you find the idea that "the smallest stream can cut through the hardest iron" as much help as Childline?

Until October 7. Box office: 0161-274 0600.

fields.headline: No friend in court
fields.standfirst: Patrick Cullinane is invoking the European Human Rights Act to defend himself against an Inland Revenue claim. Phillip Inman reports
fields.trailText: Patrick Cullinane is invoking the European Human Rights Act to defend himself against an Inland Revenue claim. Phillip Inman reports
fields.body:
An attempt by a taxpayer to use the Human Rights Act to show they had been refused a fair hearing in a dispute with the Inland Revenue failed in the High Court this week.

The European Convention on Human Rights was incorporated into UK law on October 2 with the aim of guaranteeing basic rights, including the right to a fair trial.

Patrick Cullinane, bankrupted by the Revenue four years ago, said the act stated he had a right to be represented in court and should be able to choose a friend rather than conduct his case against the Revenue himself.

Mr Cullinane's friend, Neil Woodward, told the court that Mr Cullinane could not afford to pay for a solicitor to represent him and had failed to gain legal aid. He said Mr Cullinane was dyslexic and didn't feel confident arguing against the Revenue's barris ter, who had been drafted in to replace the tax agency's in-house lawyer only a few days before the case opened at a cost of £1,600 per day.

Instead, Mr Cullinane asked Mr Woodward, who is also involved in a dispute with the Revenue, to represent him, something he had done at two previous appeals against Mr Cullinane's bankruptcy without challenge.

But the Revenue successfully argued that Mr Cullinane and Mr Woodward should be considered "vexatious litigants" who were bringing a series of "hopeless" cases that needed the sanction of a qualified lawyer before the court would hear further complaints. Mr Cullinane was forced to drop his "litigation friend" after the court backed the Revenue. He was refused leave to appeal.

Mr Justice Ferris, presiding over the case, also said friends could only be used as advocates in "exceptional circumstances" and in his view this was not an exceptional case. He gave Mr Cullinane three weeks to find a lawyer.

But Mr Justice Ferris confessed during the debate to knowing little of how the Human Rights Act affected the case and relied instead on research put forward by the Revenue's barrister. Independent advice on the implications of the Act were not sought by the judge.

Mr Cullinane went to court last week to force the Revenue to produce his tax file. He says he was forced to do so after the Revenue refused to let him see it. "I offered to pay administration costs, but they still said no," he says. "That was the only reason we were in court. Not to talk about who should represent me."

"Why doesn't the Revenue want Patrick to see his file? We think it is a deliberate attempt to cover up mistakes," says Mr Woodward.

The Revenue told Jobs & Money this week that tax files are released at its discretion and "each case is dealt with on its merits". The "open government" regulations IR141 that govern the Revenue state that officers can withold information "where it would prejudice the assessment or collection of tax or assist tax avoidance or evasion". They can also prevent taxpayers seeing their records if they "undermine good management or affect the confidential nature of internal discussion and advice". Mr Cullinane says the Revenue refuses to give him a reason for withholding his file.

Last year Mr Woodward forced the Revenue to admit it wrongfully bankrupted him. He won his case after forcing the tax agency to disclose his tax file. The file revealed that taxes claimed by the Revenue were less than the tax relief he was owed. He is now pursuing a £3m compensation claim.

Mr Cullinane, 50, whose case was highlighted in last week's Jobs & Money, says he has been fighting off claims from the Revenue that he owed tax from self-employment and renting rooms in his house since 1984. The Revenue began investigating his case after he made a claim for overpayed tax following a period as a film studio stagehand on an emergency tax code.

He says he has a continuous tax record that shows he was taxed at source through PAYE and didn't generate any self-employed income. He denies he rented rooms in his house at any time. But the Revenue won a bankruptcy order in 1996 after it alleged he owed nearly £40,000 and in 1998 seized his home.
fields.bodyText: An attempt by a taxpayer to use the Human Rights Act to show they had been refused a fair hearing in a dispute with the Inland Revenue failed in the High Court this week. The European Convention on Human Rights was incorporated into UK law on October 2 with the aim of guaranteeing basic rights, including the right to a fair trial. Patrick Cullinane, bankrupted by the Revenue four years ago, said the act stated he had a right to be represented in court and should be able to choose a friend rather than conduct his case against the Revenue himself. Mr Cullinane's friend, Neil Woodward, told the court that Mr Cullinane could not afford to pay for a solicitor to represent him and had failed to gain legal aid. He said Mr Cullinane was dyslexic and didn't feel confident arguing against the Revenue's barris ter, who had been drafted in to replace the tax agency's in-house lawyer only a few days before the case opened at a cost of £1,600 per day. Instead, Mr Cullinane asked Mr Woodward, who is also involved in a dispute with the Revenue, to represent him, something he had done at two previous appeals against Mr Cullinane's bankruptcy without challenge. But the Revenue successfully argued that Mr Cullinane and Mr Woodward should be considered "vexatious litigants" who were bringing a series of "hopeless" cases that needed the sanction of a qualified lawyer before the court would hear further complaints. Mr Cullinane was forced to drop his "litigation friend" after the court backed the Revenue. He was refused leave to appeal. Mr Justice Ferris, presiding over the case, also said friends could only be used as advocates in "exceptional circumstances" and in his view this was not an exceptional case. He gave Mr Cullinane three weeks to find a lawyer. But Mr Justice Ferris confessed during the debate to knowing little of how the Human Rights Act affected the case and relied instead on research put forward by the Revenue's barrister. Independent advice on the implications of the Act were not sought by the judge. Mr Cullinane went to court last week to force the Revenue to produce his tax file. He says he was forced to do so after the Revenue refused to let him see it. "I offered to pay administration costs, but they still said no," he says. "That was the only reason we were in court. Not to talk about who should represent me." "Why doesn't the Revenue want Patrick to see his file? We think it is a deliberate attempt to cover up mistakes," says Mr Woodward. The Revenue told Jobs & Money this week that tax files are released at its discretion and "each case is dealt with on its merits". The "open government" regulations IR141 that govern the Revenue state that officers can withold information "where it would prejudice the assessment or collection of tax or assist tax avoidance or evasion". They can also prevent taxpayers seeing their records if they "undermine good management or affect the confidential nature of internal discussion and advice". Mr Cullinane says the Revenue refuses to give him a reason for withholding his file. Last year Mr Woodward forced the Revenue to admit it wrongfully bankrupted him. He won his case after forcing the tax agency to disclose his tax file. The file revealed that taxes claimed by the Revenue were less than the tax relief he was owed. He is now pursuing a £3m compensation claim. Mr Cullinane, 50, whose case was highlighted in last week's Jobs & Money, says he has been fighting off claims from the Revenue that he owed tax from self-employment and renting rooms in his house since 1984. The Revenue began investigating his case after he made a claim for overpayed tax following a period as a film studio stagehand on an emergency tax code. He says he has a continuous tax record that shows he was taxed at source through PAYE and didn't generate any self-employed income. He denies he rented rooms in his house at any time. But the Revenue won a bankruptcy order in 1996 after it alleged he owed nearly £40,000 and in 1998 seized his home.

fields.headline: Small sum for some
fields.standfirst: Scottish Life policyholders will soon get their windfalls - such as they are.Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: Scottish Life policyholders will soon get their windfalls - such as they are.Tony Levene reports
fields.body:
After weeks of rumour, counter rumour and the withdrawal of one declared predator, Scottish Life policyholders are finally on the way to collecting windfall benefits from Royal London's £1.1bn agreed bid.

But investors in the Edinburgh firm who hoped to finance a world cruise on the demutualisation proceeds had better think again.

Fewer than half - including the bulk of recent customers - will collect cash upfront when predator Royal London finally takes over the pensions specialist next summer. And some will not gain at all from the takeover.

Scottish Life has a complicated rulebook because the present concern was set up by an act of parliament in 1968, year of the Grosvenor Square riots and flower power, when it became a mutual. Prior to that it had been shareholder-owned and some older policyholders will have seen both mutualisation and demutualisation.

The payout will come in one or two instalments, a £500 lump sum for some policyholders and a longer-term boost to eventual plan proceeds for with-profits customers. Members will collect £500 each in cash when the deal is finalised. But there are only 220,000 members out of 560,000 policyholders.

In some ways, the definition of a member is generous. With an important exception, any life policy - with-profits, unit linked, term or non-profits - counts for the £500. Couples whose policies cover both their lives are each members. They will collect £1,000 between them.

But after that, it gets tough. Scottish Life has been selling itself as the "real pensions company". It has attracted more than 100,000 personal pension holders and customers via employer-sponsored group personal pension schemes.

All personal pensions have to be held through a trustee, either appointed by the employer for a group scheme or a Scottish Life appointee for a personal plan. And according to Scottish Life rules, the trustee is the member and will collect the £500. In the case of individual pensions, the £500 would have to be shared out among tens of thousands: a few pence each.

Life policyholders whose plan was written in trust, a device to avoid paying inheritance tax on the proceeds, will also lose out on the £500. Non-members are disenfranchised and will not be able to vote against the deal - even if all the trustees said no, they will be outvoted.

Other policyholders to be frozen out of the cash handout include policies bought from Scottish Life International on the Isle of Man and holders of assigned policies. Older endowments may have been assigned to banks and building societies, while policies bought on the second-hand market lose membership rights and hence the £500.

But there are benefits from the deal for the 280,000 with-profits holders, even for those who lose out on the membership £500 payment. But they will have to wait for them. With-profits plans will be boosted by higher bonuses between next summer and maturity by an average £500, the exact amount will depend on the size of the policy and how long it has been held.

Details will be sent out early next year. There is a helpline on 0845-203-0246, staffed on Mondays to Fridays from 8am to 8pm.

webTitle: Hard-sell firm in a hard place

fields.headline: Hard-sell firm in a hard place
fields.standfirst: The FSA is still dithering over possible action against life insurer City Financial Partners, condemned by the Consumers' Association for its selling practices. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: The FSA is still dithering over possible action against life insurer City Financial Partners, condemned by the Consumers' Association for its selling practices. Tony Levene reports
fields.body:
The Financial Services Authority remains undecided on whether to act on alleged tactics used by one of the best-known hard-sell life insurance outfits despite compelling evidence from a Consumers' Association enquiry.

The Consumers' Association's probe centres on City Financial Partners, a tied sales agent of Lincoln National and, in previous incarnations as well as more recently, no stranger to controversy.

Which? alleges "lying to potential customers, sales tactics reminiscent of pre-regulation days, and possible mis-selling by the Centre Point, London branch of City Financial."

The CA says it found evidence of City Financial advisers "giving blatantly wrong information, not supplying details of products' costs and charges before a sale, and being reluctant to allow customers to take away literature with them before agreeing to buy."

Lincoln National, responsible for tied agents who can sell no other products, says the CA allegations concern "just a couple of cases which we take very seriously. Lincoln has a very good compliance record."

Lincoln has some 650,000 customers, nearly half ac quired through City Financial, which employs 500 sales staff entirely remunerated by commision earnings. It is now closed to new business following a "business review" by its American parent of the same name. The Lincoln label also includes policies from former direct operations Laurentian Life, Cannon Life, and Citibank Life.

The Consumers' Association decided to investigate City Financial following reports of sales of unsuitable policies, 10-year Lincoln endowments known as "maximum savings plans".

Undercover investigators were, the CA claims, steered towards these whatever their needs. One said she wanted to save £300 a month for at least five years, but was not sure whether she would need the money before then.

It was a clear case of a unit or investment trust savings plan which would offer the flexibility to start and stop that she might need.

Instead, she was told to put £200 a month into a Lincoln maximum savings plan and £100 a month into a cash Isa. At the end of three years, based on the Financial Services Authority's 6% growth rate used for illustrations, her plan would have been worth £6,240 although she would have paid in £7,200. And even after five years, the targeted £11,840 was still less than the £12,000 she would have contributed. And had she stopped after one year - after paying in £2,400 she would have collected £780.

She was also told to put the other £100 into a cash Isa, even though next year's annual limit is set to be £1,000. Her adviser told her this high commission paying plan was the only way she could keep her investment tax-free, even though endowment funds are taxed.

City Financial customers who complained to the CA included a man who had paid £25 a month for six years, a total of £1,875, but whose policy was worth just £1,533, and a woman who was sold the plan even though she had no need of the life cover.

The CA also found many of the commission-only sales staff, mostly young graduates who are attracted by high earnings promises, were unqualified. They are usually told to start by selling to friends and family.

City Financial is no stranger to unorthodox sales methods. Five years ago, another undercover investigator found City Financial had a unique line. It told prospective customers that the European Union was about to ban endowments.

It was a case of "buy now while stocks last: this great offer will never be repeated".

How many of the firm's youthful sales staff came up with this line, or where they got it from, is uncertain. But the investigator found that his adviser, selected at random, knew it parrot-fashion.

City Financial comes with a controversial pedigree. It was formed out of the staff of the former MI Group (the present and unrelated MI Group is part of Allianz Group and has totally different sales methods) which was run by the colourful Trevor Deaves.

Mr Deaves, who once owned 19 Ferraris, made and then lost a fortune from the sales tactic of persuading young people into an office and then subjecting them to a hard sell.

On his way down, Deaves became Britain's best-known social security claimant when the Department of Social Security paid the mortgage interest on a house then worth in excess of £500,000.

Before the MI incarnation, the organisation was known as the Porchester Group. Last week, Lincoln's US parent of the same name sold the staff of City Financial to Inter-Alliance, independent financial advisers listed on the Alternative Investment Market. Lincoln retains responsibility for the company itself.

The chairman of Inter-Alliance is Vincent Isaacs, who has a 4% stake in the £190m company. Isaacs set up General Portfolio in the 80s.

General Portfolio, later known as Gan Life, had a controversial reputation. Commission-only sales staff used tactics others questioned, and many policies had no value if cashed in during the first five years.

Lincoln says: " We have some 1m policies in force and by far the great majority of those clients will be happy with their Lincoln products and the service they receive, regardless of whether they bought them through CFPL or direct. We have no reason to believe the FSA are unhappy with what we do."

fields.headline: Schiff
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia /Schiff
Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia /Schiff
Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.body:
The highlights of this year's Bach celebrations have tended to be explorations of his instrumental works. Etched on the memory are Viktoria Mullova's titanic interpretations of the solo violin music, Angela Hewitt's rendition of The Well Tempered Clavier and, in marked contrast, Andras Schiff's ebullient version of the English Suites - a performance that, in many respects, was second to none.

With the Philharmonia - since the 1960s one of the world's great Bach ensembles - Schiff has now launched a massive series of concerts in which he features as conductor and soloist. Whatever his merits as a pianist, Schiff has on occasion been less than ideal on the podium, and time alone will tell whether his ambitious project is successful.

A whiff of controversy looms over the enterprise, for Schiff has opted to work with modern forces, not a period band. This won't please everyone, though Schiff would argue - rightly - that sincerity in performance is more important than historical authenticity.

He began with the Keyboard Concertos, playing and directing the Philharmonia from the piano. These are troubling pieces. Most are compiled from chunks of earlier works. They aren't numbered in order of composition - No 7, for instance, was written first. No 1 in D Minor is so unusual that some have doubted that it was written by Bach in the first place. Schiff closes with it, turning in a bravura performance, but also pointing up its oddness. In place of contrapuntal textures, there's a linear austerity more classical than baroque, while a darkness is all-pervasive with little sense of the transcendent spirituality that we find in the rest of Bach's output.

Schiff's approach to Bach is free from sanctimony and he communicates above all the pleasure and humaneness that he finds in the music.

fields.headline: Scholl
fields.standfirst:
OAE/Scholl
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester **
fields.trailText:
OAE/Scholl
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester **
fields.body:
For the past five years Andreas Scholl's reputation has been growing fast. With many fine recordings to his name, he now counts as one of the world's leading countertenors. The extremely healthy audience he drew in the Bridgewater Hall is a clear sign that a solo singer with a programme of Handel arias is not necessarily the box-office disaster it is thought to be.

The programme was intelligently designed. Accompanied by the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, with the marvellously musical Alison Bury as leader and director, Scholl devoted each half to an oratorio by Handel, opening with their respective overtures: first Saul and then Solomon. Both are heard far too seldom and are therefore welcome, even if presenting just individual arias loses the dramatic imperative that is so central to Handel's genius. The first half ended with an intriguing concerto grosso by Handel's obscure contemporary Pietro Castrucci, and Scholl closed with the eighth concerto from Handel's op 6 set.

So far, so good. But things need tweaking before Scholl's first major British tour gets much further. Of the three arias from Saul advertised he sang only one and a half, so we were sent for coffee after 35 minutes. Though there are only 10 lines of text between them, he read doggedly from the score, thereby seriously impeding direct audience communication. He has a wonderful sound, beautifully balanced across the range, but that was at the price of generalized vowels, changed at will to make the sound nicer.

The Solomon arias were better: the texts came across more clearly and there was more sense of their dramatic function. And I may have been alone in my disappointment, because the audience demanded an encore. Here he sang And Who May Abide, really communicating for the first time in the evening.

fields.headline: It wasn't my fault
fields.trailText: An advert for the Compensation Helpline proclaims: "If you have been injured whilst taking part in any sport, there may be a good chance that you are entitled to a substantial compensation settlement."
fields.body:
An advert for the Compensation Helpline proclaims: "If you have been injured whilst taking part in any sport, there may be a good chance that you are entitled to a substantial compensation settlement."

The advert goes on to promise help in pursuing claims for accidents at work, car crashes and a range of other injuries. And it's a good example of what's meant by the arrival of a compensation culture. A sporting injury would once have meant grinning and bearing it, now it seems it's the kick-off for a legal claim for compensation, spurred on by the type of adverts that say: "Mr J of Croydon was awarded £5,000 for hurting his back at work", or whatever.

But does this really mean that we're moving towards a more American style of trigger-happy litigation, where you sue first and ask questions later? And if there is a sudden rise in compensation claims, who'll end up footing the bill? As with anything to do with insurance, it's the ordinary customer who ends up paying, as increased awards are funded by higher premiums.

Anyone who has renewed their car insurance in the last few weeks will have felt an icy draught blowing through their wallet, as an increase in claims has been followed by a hike in premiums. "It's not necessarily a bad thing if more people are claiming more compensation," says a spokesman for the Association of British Insurers, "as long as it's understood that a rise in successful claims will cause a corresponding rise in insurance costs."

Perhaps the most sobering statistic in terms of the impact of the compensation culture is in the cost to local government services. According to the largest insurer of councils, Zurich Municipal, there has been a five-fold increase in the total cost of insurance and settling compensation claims in the past decade with the current annual total standing at £1bn, the equivalent of 100 new secondary schools.

The type of compensation claims facing local authorities could be anything from the "trip and slip" category involving dodgy paving stones through to complex court cases alleging that a council is responsible for a child's underachievement in school. And a single case, taken through the courts and to appeal, can mean legal fees of up to £500,000. These cases include claims for stress, distress and emotional trauma, along with the more conventional personal accident and injury claims.

"This is the public's money that's being spent, and if it's going in insurance and compensation then it's not going into front-line services. If this rate of increase continues then eventually the entire local government budget is going to disappear into settling claims," says Zurich Municipal's David Forster. Accounting for the increase, he says, is a change in public attitude. "We've seen a cultural shift where people seem to believe that when something goes wrong, it's someone else's fault. And if you can find someone to blame, you claim compensation."

There have been accusations that stoking this rise in claims have been the advertising campaigns of companies such as Claims Direct, which take on compensation cases on a no-win, no-fee arrangement. These television adverts tell people that if they've been involved in an accident that wasn't their fault that they could be in line for a pay-out.

Claims Direct argues that they're extending the legal services to the general public which have always been available to the well-off and that if someone has a legitimate claim for compensation then it's entirely proper for them to be given assistance. The company says that there has been a rapid increase in calls, now running at 30,000 a month.

But it says it has a rigorous vetting procedure before claims even reach solicitors' desks and at present rejects five out of six approaches, advancing only 5,000 claims a month, of which they would hope over 90% would be successful.

In many ways it isn't a bad thing that consumers can get such legal support when they have problems, especially if it makes service providers think twice about the consequences of letting standards slip. Even though we might be suspicious of a whinge-culture, we now expect to receive financial recompense when we're badly let down, such as for holiday disasters or travel disruption.

But there is also a sense in which the compensation culture is a spin-off of the attitude that says that nothing is anybody's personal responsibility anymore. If you walk into a wall, it's the wall's fault for being there. There used to be an insurance advert about not making a drama out of a crisis. Now there's a growing industry dedicated to making a court case out of a crisis.

Email: coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

And a single case, taken through the courts and to appeal, can mean legal fees of up to £500,000. These cases include claims for stress, distress and emotional trauma, along with the more conventional personal accident and injury claims. "This is the public's money that's being spent, and if it's going in insurance and compensation then it's not going into front-line services. If this rate of increase continues then eventually the entire local government budget is going to disappear into settling claims," says Zurich Municipal's David Forster. Accounting for the increase, he says, is a change in public attitude. "We've seen a cultural shift where people seem to believe that when something goes wrong, it's someone else's fault. And if you can find someone to blame, you claim compensation." There have been accusations that stoking this rise in claims have been the advertising campaigns of companies such as Claims Direct, which take on compensation cases on a no-win, no-fee arrangement. These television adverts tell people that if they've been involved in an accident that wasn't their fault that they could be in line for a pay-out. Claims Direct argues that they're extending the legal services to the general public which have always been available to the well-off and that if someone has a legitimate claim for compensation then it's entirely proper for them to be given assistance. The company says that there has been a rapid increase in calls, now running at 30,000 a month. But it says it has a rigorous vetting procedure before claims even reach solicitors' desks and at present rejects five out of six approaches, advancing only 5,000 claims a month, of which they would hope over 90% would be successful. In many ways it isn't a bad thing that consumers can get such legal support when they have problems, especially if it makes service providers think twice about the consequences of letting standards slip. Even though we might be suspicious of a whinge-culture, we now expect to receive financial recompense when we're badly let down, such as for holiday disasters or travel disruption. But there is also a sense in which the compensation culture is a spin-off of the attitude that says that nothing is anybody's personal responsibility anymore. If you walk into a wall, it's the wall's fault for being there. There used to be an insurance advert about not making a drama out of a crisis. Now there's a growing industry dedicated to making a court case out of a crisis. Email: coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

webTitle: England defeat Bangladesh by eight wickets

fields.headline: Hussain cures summertime blues
fields.standfirst:
Bangladesh 232-8
England 236-2
England win by eight wickets
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain scored 95 to help his team to a comprehensive eight-wicket victory over Bangladesh. England can look forward to a quarter-final against South Africa on Tuesday
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain made his first decent score for England for 10 months and Alec Stewart continued his prolific sequence in one-day international cricket as England put Bangladesh emphatically in their place here yesterday.

Hussain's innings of 95 was a relief after his summer of torture with the bat. He started with a couple of imperious drives, felt frisky enough to attempt a reverse sweep and then began hoisting sixes. By the end he was carving merrily at almost everything and in all cleared the boundary rope five times, in addition to nine fours.

Bangladesh's attack is the weakest England will face this winter and Hussain will play on few more benign surfaces, but his foot movement and general air of confidence at the wicket were in marked contrast to his recent problems.

He managed only 166 first-class runs in the summer and, before arriving here last Friday, had not picked up a bat for three weeks. He seems to have benefited from the break.

As for Stewart, he simply continued where he left off in England's NatWest series victory in July. His last five one-day innings have been 74 not out, 101, 100 not out, 97 and now 87 not out. This from a man of 37.

So England skipped past the potential banana-skin offered by Bangladesh and can now look forward to the serious stuff: a quarter-final against South Africa on Tuesday.

England were not at their best in the field, but the second-wicket liaison between captain and former captain, which produced 175 runs from 35 overs, ensured victory was achieved with more than six overs to spare.

Hussain said: "I've been hitting the ball well in the nets and I felt good in our practice match with Australia on Tuesday. And I felt my feet and body moving well today. But one innings against Bangladesh doesn't prove anything."

The surface offered decent pace and bounce - Stewart said it was one of the best pitches he had seen - and Bangladesh's strength clearly lies in their batting. Javed Omar lifted the first ball of the match from Andrew Caddick over square leg for four and, although Caddick and Darren Gough frequently went past the outside edge, England never made significant inroads.

Omar retired hurt at 14 when struck on the hand by Caddick but the past and present captains Aminul Islam and Naimur Rahman made sure England would be set a target of some size.

Omar returned to complete his half-century and help take Bangladesh well beyond 200. Gough's final ball of the innings was a shin-high full toss which Hasibul Hossain clubbed to deep extra cover, but Vikram Solanki let the ball slip through his fingers for six.

Hasibul's efforts with the bat, however, were undone by his first over, of 13 deliveries - six no-balls and a wide - by the end of which England were 17 for no wicket. Marcus Trescothick was soon caught behind but Stewart, Hussain and a late flurry from Graeme Hick completed the job.

England have called up Paul Grayson, the uncapped Essex left-arm spinning all-rounder, as cover for Ashley Giles, who has a strained left calf.

webTitle: Chelsea have Rui Costa in their sights

fields.headline: Chelsea have Rui Costa in their sights
fields.trailText: Chelsea are keen to sign the Portuguese playmaker Manuel Rui Costa as they attempt to rebuild their squad after the arrival of Claudio Ranieri.
fields.body:
Chelsea are keen to sign the Portuguese playmaker Manuel Rui Costa as they attempt to rebuild their squad after the arrival of Claudio Ranieri.

Rui Costa played for Ranieri when the Italian was in charge at Fiorentina, and despite recently signing a new contract the 28-year-old, who would cost about £10m, is believed to be interested in a move away from Florence.

The name of Lothar Matthäus has been added to the list of candidates for the job of coach at Internazionale. According to the German newspaper Bild-Zeitung, the former Germany and Inter captain has been offered the job, but other reports suggest he has merely applied for it.

Meanwhile, Giacinto Facchetti has apparently gone to Argentina on Inter's behalf to interview the former Argentina coach Daniel Passarella for the job, and Marco Tardelli, who coached the Italian Under-21s to European success in the summer, has also been linked with the post.

The Swedish national team doctor has criticised Arsenal for giving Fredrik Ljungberg a tetanus jab after the 1-0 win over Manchester United on Sunday; it made his arm swell and gave him a temperature. Ljungberg had a temperature of 39.5C (103F) and missed the first two days of training before the World Cup qualifier against Turkey in Gothenburg tomorrow.

"It was completely unnecessary," Magnus Forssblad said. "Fredrik has suffered a reaction because he was already protected against tetanus."

Ipswich Town have pulled out of a proposed move for the Belgian international Gert Verheyen. The 30-year-old Bruges midfielder had been expected to sign for £1.7m but the deal fell through when Bruges increased their valuation.

Lincoln's player-manager Phil Stant and his striker Dave Cameron have been banned for three games after a brawl in a friendly against a local non-league side. Cameron was sent off for aiming a kick at Lincoln Moorland's Jamie Sayce and Stant was sent off after a touchline bust-up.

 Catalin Haldan, the Dinamo Bucharest and Romania midfielder, was reported to be clinically dead after collapsing on the field during a friendly yesterday against a second division team from Oltenita.

"Haldan is in the Oltenita stadium in a critical situation," the Dinamo president Marcel Popescu said."It seems he suffered a cerebral attack and according to the team's doctor he is now clinically dead."

webTitle: Scholl puts a spring in Germans' step

fields.headline: Scholl puts a spring in Germans' step
fields.standfirst: More about England v Germany
fields.trailText: Mehmet Scholl has declared himself fit and Carsten Jancker has resumed training as things started to look up for Germany coach Rudi Völler.
fields.body:
After a troublesome few days which must have threatened the mental health of the German team, the influential midfield player Mehmet Scholl was at least happy to declare himself physically fit to face England on Saturday.

Scholl, 29, known by the unflattering nickname of "Schalk", which translates as "Rogue", arrived in England several hours after his team-mates because of an exploratory operation on his left knee. But it revealed no serious damage and he was able to take part in both training sessions yesterday, at Arsenal's London Colney in the morning and at Wembley in late afternoon.

"Things were looking really bad for me on Monday," he said, "but now I am sure I will be fit for Saturday and I am delighted to be able to play in such an historic match, the last one at Wembley." One wonders why he is so keen to play, however, after his revelation that he has become hooked on English football because of the "brutal fouls".

The Bayern Munich striker Carsten Jancker, the Steve Bull of German football, also resumed training, as did the 20-year-old wunderkind Sebastian Deisler. And Carsten Ramelow, rested because of a slight thigh injury, is expected to be on parade today.

No one in the camp wanted to discuss the allegations against Christoph Daum, who is contracted to take over as national coach next June, nor the latest wacky rumour from back home, that he has been asked to submit to a hair-sample analysis to determine whether he has been a long-term drug-user.

The current coach, Rudi Völler, said: "Naturally the players have been affected by all the stories. But this is too big a game for us to be deflected from our job and we have been able to concentrate 99.9% on the match.

"By coming here we have also distanced ourselves physically as well as mentally from the problems. I know they may carry on for a few more weeks, even months, but I hope and pray we can block them from our minds for the next two days."

The Germans have been on a charm offensive since arriving at Luton on Wednesday night, describing Arsenal's training facilities as "sensational" and not only singing the praises of Wembley but praising the singing of the national anthem. Even allowing for the German blood in the royal family, Liverpool's Dietmar Hamann strayed way beyond the call of politeness when he described God Save The Queen as "quite a nice tune. I like it".

As a Liverpool player, he did not go as far as saying he stays glued to his seat when the cry of "Stand up if you hate Man U" goes up. But he was complimentary about the talents of United's David Beckham. "Beckham is the best crosser of a ball in the world and we need to stop his supply to the strikers," Hamann said. "I know he has had his disciplinary problems in the past but when those things happen you can only grow. At 25, there is still a lot to come from him."

 Craig Burley is out of Scotland's World Cup qualifier in San Marino tomorrow. The Derby midfielder has a minor hamstring problem and is not fit to play, but he may well return for Scotland's next assignment, a tough match against Croatia in Zagreb four days later.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk
