webTitle: Ron Atkinson on England v Germany

fields.headline: Keegan's autumn collection need to cut a dash Paris-fashion
fields.standfirst: More about England v Germany
fields.trailText: Owen and Cole up front? I understand the decision but it's not what I would have gone with.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has more or less confirmed that Michael Owen and Andrew Cole will play up front against Germany tomorrow. Both strikers are in such brilliant form that I understand his decision but it's not what I would have gone with.

I'm a big fan of the shape we saw in Paris last month, with Paul Scholes operating behind Cole. Yes, that means leaving Owen on the bench again, but I prefer the idea of throwing him on when games get stretched and defenders are tired.

When there is space behind back lines there are few better than Owen at exploiting it, and he should become an all-time great. But as it is, if Germany defend deep I'm not sure he will be as effective.

That's why employing a link-man such as Scholes can have a real impact. At international level you've got to be patient and cunning and look to pull defenders about. Scholes would set Germany's defence problems, and if he is coming short our midfielders can get past him. They're always harder to pick up coming from deep positions.

Cole has developed his game excellently at Manchester United playing with his partner dropping off, and you don't want to stifle his ability to play on the last man and use his movement. He showed against Chelsea that when he gets one on one with defenders he can beat them.

Owen, of course, has also been on fire. But like Cole his game is based on movement and running on defenders' shoulders. The problem with that pair might be that the ball won't stick up there and England will lose possession. Holding things up and bringing people into play is not Owen's strongest suit.

All the same, I understand Kevin's thinking, particularly as England are at home, and I hope the partnership works. Both players are scoring freely and their pace and movement could cause problems for a German defence which can be static.

But that depends on whether England play to their strengths. It's no good banging high or long balls to them. Shorter passes will have to be played through from midfield and crosses skimmed over, which is why I think David Beckham will go wide right and Graeme le Saux will get the job on the other flank.

I would keep Beckham in the middle of a 3-5-1-1 formation, playing: Seaman; Keown, Adams, Barry; G Neville, Dyer/McManaman, Beckham, Gerrard, Le Saux; Scholes; A Cole.

But however England line up they must get on to Christian Ziege quickly to stop him delivering high-quality crosses, and they have to play with bags of energy and freedom. The players have to be confident and make Germany chase the ball.

Much as I would love to see England win, I think a draw is more likely from a tight game. Germany are not a great side but they will be organised and highly motivated.

Far from being affected by the scandal surrounding Christoph Daum, I'm sure they'll be laughing their heads off and making light of it. And it should not be forgotten that although England won in Charleroi, Germany were maybe the better side.

W hat will help England is if Mehmet Scholl is forced out by his knee injury. Carsten Jancker and Oliver Bierhoff are strikers Tony Adams and Martin Keown like to go against. They're not bright, sharp forwards who drop off and pull into little areas.

I'll be sad to see Wembley's twin towers disappear. Having been to plenty of grounds in Italy and Spain I can assure you Wembley is not as outdated as some people think.

I won four cups there but my overriding memory will be the "Smith must score" episode when I was managing Manchester United against Brighton in 1983 FA Cup final. We had lost the League Cup in extra-time to Liverpool that season and been pipped for the First Division runners-up spot with the last kick of the game.

So when Gordon Smith went through in the last minute of extra-time at 2-2, I remember walking from the bench to the touchline and thinking, "I don't believe this." Those few seconds seemed to last an eternity, and then I saw Gary Bailey sitting on the ball. It hadn't gone in and we won the replay 4-0. Let's hope England can go out in similar style.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Three days in the life of Yugoslavia's top court

fields.headline: Three days in the life of Yugoslavia's top court
fields.standfirst: Three days is a long time in Serbia. The country's highest court, the constitutional court, was forced to complete a u-turn on the legality of the elections. Find out how the rulings changed
fields.trailText: Three days is a long time in Serbia. The country's highest court, the constitutional court, was forced to complete a u-turn on the legality of the elections. Find out how the rulings changed.
fields.body:
Wednesday, 4 October: The court, meeting in emergency session, annulled the results of the 24 September presidential election - although it left the local election results intact. The members of the court are known to be Slobodan Milosevic supporters and the ruling reinforces his position.

Thursday, 5 October: The court lets it be known that it would expect the new election to be held at the end of the Milosevic mandate, ie June 2001. However, the president of the court is later that day quoted as saying a new presidential poll must be held during Milosevic's mandate. According to Radio Free Europe, Milutin Srdic said a new election could be held but hesitates when asked when. "I don't know exactly when this mandate of his expires, in a few months," the radio's website quoted him as saying.

Friday, 6 October: The court rules in favour of the opposition that Vojislav Kostunica had won the election. Efforts to contact the court are unsuccessful as the report is published after the close of business hours. The ruling removes Milosevic's last claim to legality and paves the way for Kostunica to take office.

fields.headline: Wide of the Marks
fields.standfirst: Although currently off balance, Libran Marks & Spencer's future may be on a more even keel, writes Maggie Hyde, the Media Medium.
fields.trailText: October 6: Although currently off balance, Libran Marks & Spencer's future may be on a more even keel, writes Maggie Hyde, the Media Medium.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's Libran Scales (28 September 1894) are tipped out of balance as it struggles to modernise its management, marketing and old-fashioned image.

Trouble has been brewing for years, but a turning point came in August 1999 when the sun's eclipse blotted out the Part of Fortune, a traditionally lucky point, in the financial zone of its horoscope. This was followed by violent oppositions to this point from innovative Uranus, but Marks & Spencer has over-reacted to the demand for change and appears to be spinning out of control.

The astrology looks brighter than current appearances suggest and if M&S gets a new CEO there is a good chance it will turn the corner. Its biggest astrological influence in 2001 is when relationship Venus progresses to its horizon in February, and that could symbolise a takeover, merger or new partnership.

In this broader context, M&S's first major advertising campaign, run by Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/YR and launched on September 8, may be neither here nor there. In choosing it to run the campaign, M&S has the right instinct because this young, colourful agency is a creative Leo (August 10 1993) with its sun exactly on the M&S Part of Fortune. webTitle: Praise for surgery at Alder Hey

fields.headline: Praise for surgery at Alder Hey
fields.standfirst: Whistleblower's concerns unfounded, says inquiry.
fields.trailText: Heart surgery at the troubled Alder Hey children's hospital in Liverpool is as good as or better than anywhere in the country, with death rates lower than the national average, an inquiry has concluded.
fields.body:
Heart surgery at the troubled Alder Hey children's hospital in Liverpool is as good as or better than anywhere in the country, with death rates lower than the national average, an inquiry concluded yesterday.

Alder Hey is at the centre of the scandal over the retention of nearly 900 children's hearts and other organs without their parents' permission. Inquiries are still going on.

The review of the quality of cardiac surgery at the hospital was commissioned after a whistleblower raised concerns about three deaths with the Royal College of Nursing. Parents, shocked and distressed at discovering their children's organs were kept by the hospital, are also wondering whether their children might have died unnecessarily.

The organ retention scandal came to light during the inquiry into children's heart surgery at the Bristol Royal infirmary, where surgeons were disciplined after it was found that death rates for their work were higher than the national average.

But John Ashton, director of health for the north-west, who looked at every hospital death from 1991 to 1999, concluded that the quality of children's heart surgery at Alder Hey was extremely high, with generally good and improving outcomes.

He identified a period when one surgeon, Roger Franks, had a 30% death rate for babies undergoing the "switch" operation to redirect blood around the heart - nearly three times the national average. But the review found no evidence that these children might have survived had they had another surgeon.

The switch operation, a difficult procedure, was one of two operations for which the General Medical Council found there had been unacceptably high death rates at Bristol.

The death rates during or after heart surgery at Alder Hey between 1991 and 1997 were 4.8%, compared with a national average of 6.9%. Between 1996 and 1999 this dropped to 2.5%, compared with 5.2% nationwide.

fields.headline: Surprise Lib-Lab coalition in Wales
fields.trailText: 6 October: The Liberal Democrats and Labour sprung a surprise last night by announcing they were forming a coalition government in Wales to match the similar partnership administration in Scotland.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats and Labour sprung a surprise last night by announcing they were forming a coalition government in Wales to match the similar partnership administration in Scotland.

The deal, announced yesterday, includes nearly 100 joint pledges and follows months of private negotiations between Rhodri Morgan, the Labour Welsh assembly leader, an advocate of coalition, and the Liberal Democrats. The deal was approved by Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy, who agreed it had no implications for closer cooperation at Westminster.

The deal, due to last until the next Welsh assembly elections in 2003, will give the Liberal Democrats two seats on the six strong Welsh executive. Labour has also conceded an inquiry into higher education funding in Wales, similar to the inquiry in Scotland which led to the replacement of tuition fees with a graduate tax.

As part of the annual budget due to be introduced in the assembly in the next few weeks, Labour has also agreed to free dental checks, free prescription charges for under 25s, and below-inflation council tax increases in the spring. Liberal Democrats claimed these as negotiating victories, but Labour claimed the measures had been made possible by a generous settlement in the spending review next summer.

Mr Morgan has also accepted a review to look at proportional representation for local government in Wales, which could end the sometimes damaging Labour monopoly in South Wales councils. Mr Morgan made clear his personal support for coalition government as soon as he took over the leadership from Alun Michael in the spring.

With Labour three short of an overall majority, Mr Morgan regarded coalition as the only way to end political instability and the repeated votes of no confidence which were undermining public support for devolution. The deal is subject to the agreement of the Welsh Liberal Democrat conference in a fortnight.

webTitle: Mandelson jolts Unionists with Dublin spectre

fields.headline: Mandelson jolts Unionists with Dublin spectre
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson last night sparked new controversy when he warned Ulster Unionists that they faced a regime of joint authority involving the Irish government if devolution failed again and there was another return to direct rule.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson last night sparked new controversy when he warned Ulster Unionists that they faced a regime of joint authority involving the Irish government if devolution failed again and there was another return to direct rule.

Angry unionists saw his comments as inflammatory.

Mr Mandelson's move came as the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble was beginning a fresh fight for political survival after party dissidents demanded another meeting of the 860-strong ruling council. The outlook for the Good Friday agreement once more appears to be grim.

Mr Mandelson gave several interviews in an attempt to shore up Mr Trimble, who is seen as key to the survival of the 30-month accord.

He told Ulster Television that if the agreement fell, Ulster Unionists faced: "possibly not even just direct rule, but both governments interfering directly in the affairs of Northern Ireland."

Mr Trimble, who has been dismissive of the dissidents' move ahead of tomorrow's annual party conference, is expected to attempt to delay the council meeting until next month. He will then have a clearer picture of the government's plans on the policing bill, and will be able to determine tactics accordingly.

Dissidents want to force Ulster Unionists out of the province's power-sharing executive, where they sit with Sinn Fein, until the IRA begins to decommission its weapons.

The council meeting should take place three weeks after the 60 signatures demanding it were handed to party headquarters late on Wednesday.

But procedural wrangling is under way, the aim of which is to buy Mr Trimble a little more breathing space.

The Ulster Unionists' leader will test grassroots' opinion at tomorrow's conference. To once more unite the party and try to secure his position as leader, he may yet be forced to forward a motion himself at the subsequent council meeting to offer a timetable for withdrawal from the executive if there is no progress on IRA decommissioning.

Mr Trimble, who will also face a Democratic Unionist motion of no confidence in his performance as Northern Ireland's first minister in the assembly on Monday, criticised the dissidents' move, and allies labelled it self-indulgent.

He said that it was an attempt to upstage the party conference.

There is little doubt the mood among Ulster Unionists is swinging against Mr Trimble, particularly after the party's catastrophic defeat to the DUP in the south Antrim byelection last month.

His winning margin at successive ruling council meetings has narrowed, and is now in single figures.

Dissidents claimed their move was about policy. They insisted no leadership challenge was intended.

But Mr Trimble could hardly stay on if the hardliners forced a switch of his policies. The likely choice would then be between East Londonderry MP Willie Ross, as a stop-gap leader, or Jeffrey Donaldson, who represents Lagan Valley. Both men are strong opponents of the agreement.

Mr Ross said yesterday: "I believe many people in the party now accept this agreement has not delivered. Therefore a change in policy is necessary. The agreement has run its course."

Willie Thompson, MP for West Tyrone, and a long-time Trimble critic, said of his party leader: "He is on the skids. He cannot survive.

"This call for a council meeting is clearly another nail in David Trimble's coffin. Politics is about the art of survival, and no matter how altruistic your policy, you can only survive by getting votes.

"We just haven't been getting them and unless there is a change in policy we will be destroyed at the next election. David Trimble's position is untenable, and it's clear he is panicking."

webTitle: Comatose pair lose right to life

fields.headline: Comatose pair lose right to life
fields.trailText: Doctors were this afternoon given the go-ahead to withdraw artificial life-support on two women patients suffering a "living death" after suffering brain damage.
fields.body:
Doctors were this afternoon given the go-ahead to withdraw artificial life-support on two women patients suffering a "living death" after suffering brain damage.

The case went before the head of the high court's family division to test the effect of the new Human Rights Act on the right of judges to give doctors the power to end treatment in such cases.

Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss agreed to make the declarations after hearing evidence and submissions over two days from representatives of two NHS trusts involved and the patients who were diagnosed as being in a permanent vegetative state.

In both cases, Dame Elizabeth said the two women, identified only as Ms H, 36, and Mrs M, 49, lacked the capacity to make decisions as to their future medical treatment.

She said it was not in their best interests to continue artificial nutrition and hydration.

The judge said all those treating the women could lawfully discontinue all life-sustaining treatment designed to keep them alive and supply treatment and care which may be appropriate to ensure they die with dignity.

A statement issued by the hospital trust treating Ms H read: "The decision today represents a further stage in what has been and continues to be a difficult and very sad time for everyone involved in this tragic case."

The hospital treating Mrs M said: "It is the wish of the family and those responsible for the medical and nursing care of this patient that she is permitted to end her life peacefully and with dignity."

Dame Elizabeth was told that court decisions which began with the case of Hillsborough survivor Tony Bland in 1993 do not infringe the rights to life enshrined in the Human Rights Act, which came into force at the beginning of the week.

John Grace QC, representing the hospitals which are both in the north of England, said: "Expert independent witnesses agree they are undoubtedly cases of PVS, described as a twilight zone of suspended animation where death commences whilst life continues. A living death."

He said the medical technology which was keeping them alive did not exist when the European Convention on Human Rights was formulated in 1950.

It was accepted by Ben Emmerson QC, representing the two patients, that the principles laid down by the House of Lords in the Bland case complied with the convention and that the declarations sought in both cases did not infringe the Human Rights Act.

webTitle: Hague reaches out to blue collar vote

fields.headline: Hague reaches out to blue collar vote
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday sacrificed a ritual Conservative conference triumph with a speech which reached out beyond the Tory heartlands in an attempt to woo disaffected blue collar Labour voters.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday sacrificed a ritual Conservative conference triumph with a speech which reached out beyond the Tory heartlands in an attempt to woo disaffected blue collar Labour voters.

Seven months before the expected May election, the Tory leader used his 49-minute address in Bournemouth to tell floating voters that the Conservatives had learned from past mistakes and want to govern pragmatically "for all the people".

He was firm on the need for tax cuts, but promised better health care and schools, inner city revival and pension rises, all services on which Labour is finally spending billions.

The speech was strong in its populist tone - "no government in recent times has been as tough on criminals as we will be" - but conspicuously short on specific policies.

Labour was quick to complain that the sums did not add up, and that £16bn worth of cuts would follow a Tory victory. It was another key election issue to which Mr Hague made virtually no mention.

Instead he mocked senior ministers and abused Tony Blair as an actor without principles "who is prepared to say whatever will please his audience without the slightest consistent thought or principle entering his head".

What was immediately noticeable was that Mr Hague's oratory did not work its usual magic with the activists in the hall. His speech was punctuated by desultory applause, except during pledges to protect Britain's independence - and the pound - from the EU.

So confident was he that his three year "common sense revolution" has reconnected the Tories with what he repeatedly called "the mainstream majority", the ordinary voters Labour has allegedly ignored, that he challenged Mr Blair to an immediate election. "Go on Tony, call it now," he said.

The volatile state of public opinion, which has seen Labour first lose, then regain an eight-point poll lead in the past month, makes it unlikely that Mr Hague wants his bluff called, especially after this week's mixed messages on social tolerance which pitted Ann Widdecombe against Michael Portillo yesterday.

In a contrite tone which echoed Mr Blair's acknowledgement that voters are alienated by politicians, he said: "I don't think we'll solve every problem, avoid every mistake... I just want to govern with the common sense instincts of the people."

His assessment of those instincts was a blend of familiar rightwing nostrums on Europe, crime, asylum, tax and wasted public spending, and new efforts to persuade people that he understands the fears and aspirations of those who live on sink estates and struggle to pay their way. "I'm in it for you," he kept saying.

Given the mixed signals which some shadow ministers have delivered, Mr Hague said: "There are some who say there is a contradiction between traditional Conservative issues and winning new Tory audiences; between tolerance and championing the mainstream values of the country. There is no contradiction. Being tough on crime, believing in lower taxes and the robust defence of our nation's independence are not in contradiction with wanting better schools and hospitals, and thriving inner cities. They are an essential part of achieving those things."

fields.headline: BT finance director resigns
fields.trailText: Friday 5.30pm: BT's beleaguered finance director has resigned in the face of growing investor unease at the company's stock market performance, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BT's beleaguered finance director has resigned in the face of growing investor unease at the company's stock market performance.

Shares in the telecoms company soared 57.5p to 743.5p with the news that Robert Brace will be replaced by Phillip Hampton of gas company BG Group. BT has come under attack for losing ground in the mobile phone and internet markets, and has been embroiled in disputes with rivals over broadband access.

Analysts have been calling for boardroom changes at BT for some time, and attention will now turn to chairman Sir Iain Vallance, who has denied rumours that he was set to resign.

Mr Brace said: "I have been group finance director of BT during some of the most exciting and challenging times in the history of the company. I have enjoyed myself immensely during this period. However, I would like a change and I am planning to live and work in North America."

Mr Hampton will take over Brace's role on November 1, at a time when BT is undergoing a strategic review to determine what parts of the company should be sold off to combat a mounting debt burden

fields.headline: Potted history
fields.standfirst: Toilet tales, parish polls and a shotgun wedding
fields.trailText: Toilet tales, parish polls and a shotgun wedding.
fields.body:
Stories from the smallest room
The sum of human understanding took a giant leap forward this week thanks to a local historian in Herefordshire.

Paddy Ariss also gave Hereford Times sub editors a welcome opportunity to dust down their tried-and-tested punning headlines ("Flushed With Success" etc).

Herefordshire Privies (Countryside Books, £7.95), a new study by Ms Ariss, of Eardisland, provides insights into the many types of toilets used in the county down the years.

She has spent a year painstakingly researching her work, peering over toilet doors, looking down pans and under seats and collating memories on the subject.

Priscilla Davies, of Weobley, told Ms Ariss of a woman of ill repute mysteriously nicknamed Sixpence (all sorts of recreational activities were cheaper in those days) in Hay-on-Wye. Sixpence had the contents of a chamber pot emptied on her head as she passed below. The wife of one of her gentlemen callers shouted from a window: "You had him last night, now you can have his remains!"

Another anecdote unearthed by Ms Ariss relates the tale of a gardener working at Bredenbury Court, the Barneby family pile. One day he was planting a bulb in a dismal little restroom provided for estate workers when a maid paid a visit. Not noticing the man seated in the darkness, she pulled down her knickers and sat on his lap. Feeling bare legs beneath her, she leapt up with a shriek, adjusted her dress, and fled.

And that astonishing tale has delighted the Bameby family from generation to generation.
Hereford Times

Rural referendum
The future of the single European currency was thrown into turmoil this week by the news that villagers in Groby, Leicestershire, have voted against scrapping the pound.

But before Tony Blair and Gordon Brown dump the government's wait-and-see policy on the euro, they might glean a crumb of comfort from the news that less than one in 10 villagers voted.

Just 522 residents, or 9.14% of the village electorate, voted in a parish poll on the euro. Of those who bothered to vote, 92.7% were against the idea of scrapping the pound, while 88.6% rejected the idea of spending public money on preparing for the euro.

Anti-European Union campaigner George West triggered the vote, citing an ancient law which allows villagers to stage referendums. He hailed the result as proof that people did not support the government's stance on the euro.

Mr West blamed younger villagers for the low turnout, claiming the youth of today did not understand that their national sovereignty was at stake.

Last week, parish polls produced similar results in two other Leicestershire villages, Rothley and Mountsorrel.
Leicester Mercury

Yee-hah!
"I just don't think it is appropriate," said the superintendent registrar for Wiltshire. "There is no legal problem, but I don't want to worry people with the sound of gunfire going off."

Dorothy Windeat was explaining her decision to ban a couple of country and western music fans from firing replica guns at their wedding at Chippenham register office.

George Steele and Doreen Pudney were married at high noon on September 23. They had wanted replica handguns to be fired as they left the ceremony.

But Mrs Windeat blocked their plans because she feared that nearby shoppers would be frightened by the sound of gunfire from behind the High Street.

Letter of the week
I was disgusted by the condescending and despicable comparison of New York's landmarks with some in Blackburn.

It seems that whoever compiled this list is not local and has some sort of grudge against Blackburn.

I think it would have been more appropriate to have likened the town hall with the World Trade Centre, or Ewood Park with the Yankee Stadium.

As for twinning Whitebirk industrial estate with Central Park, I can only presume you meant Central Park, Wigan!

However, the comparison of Larkhill flats to the Bronx is downright insulting and I think an apology is owed to the good people who live in those flats.

If you really want to compare some local landmarks with those in New York, how about Darwen Tower with the Empire State Building; Corporation Park with Central Park; Whitebirk roundabout with Staten Island; Queen Victoria's Monument with the Statue of Liberty - and as for the Bronx, I could think of a few places not a million miles away from Blackburn.
R Jeeves, Blackburn

fields.bodyText: Stories from the smallest room The sum of human understanding took a giant leap forward this week thanks to a local historian in Herefordshire. Paddy Ariss also gave Hereford Times sub editors a welcome opportunity to dust down their tried-and-tested punning headlines ("Flushed With Success" etc). Herefordshire Privies (Countryside Books, £7.95), a new study by Ms Ariss, of Eardisland, provides insights into the many types of toilets used in the county down the years. She has spent a year painstakingly researching her work, peering over toilet doors, looking down pans and under seats and collating memories on the subject. Priscilla Davies, of Weobley, told Ms Ariss of a woman of ill repute mysteriously nicknamed Sixpence (all sorts of recreational activities were cheaper in those days) in Hay-on-Wye. Sixpence had the contents of a chamber pot emptied on her head as she passed below. The wife of one of her gentlemen callers shouted from a window: "You had him last night, now you can have his remains!" Another anecdote unearthed by Ms Ariss relates the tale of a gardener working at Bredenbury Court, the Barneby family pile. One day he was planting a bulb in a dismal little restroom provided for estate workers when a maid paid a visit. Not noticing the man seated in the darkness, she pulled down her knickers and sat on his lap. Feeling bare legs beneath her, she leapt up with a shriek, adjusted her dress, and fled. And that astonishing tale has delighted the Bameby family from generation to generation. Hereford Times Rural referendum The future of the single European currency was thrown into turmoil this week by the news that villagers in Groby, Leicestershire, have voted against scrapping the pound. But before Tony Blair and Gordon Brown dump the government's wait-and-see policy on the euro, they might glean a crumb of comfort from the news that less than one in 10 villagers voted. Just 522 residents, or 9.14% of the village electorate, voted in a parish poll on the euro. Of those who bothered to vote, 92.7% were against the idea of scrapping the pound, while 88.6% rejected the idea of spending public money on preparing for the euro. Anti-European Union campaigner George West triggered the vote, citing an ancient law which allows villagers to stage referendums. He hailed the result as proof that people did not support the government's stance on the euro. Mr West blamed younger villagers for the low turnout, claiming the youth of today did not understand that their national sovereignty was at stake. webTitle: Oct 6: Diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: It's good to talk, so they say
fields.standfirst: With management now in place, Lisa Christensen discusses the department's aims with her staff
fields.trailText: With management now in place, Lisa Christensen discusses the department's aims with her staff
fields.body:
Watershed moment: the new head of children's services started this week. Having survived for nearly a year with a series of temporary arrangements to cover this post - not to mention most of the other management posts in children's services - the sense of relief, achievement and expectation is almost overwhelming. Refrain from flinging my arms round him but am to be seen beaming most of the day.

Phil Howes's arrival completes the management team. No excuse for me not to do my proper job (if I can remember what it is supposed to be, that is). Major effort is required to give sense of direction and leadership. This week, I held the third of what will be a year-long series of weekly meetings with mixed groups of staff. It is an opportunity to talk about our key messages - users first, safe practice, fit for purpose, and information and open communication - and find out how people see the organisation's role and their individual role in achieving improvement.

Staff are feeling battered, bruised and unloved - inevitably call for a stop to "change", ask for better communication, supervision and support. Each time it has taken some effort to remind people that the woes of the customer are what we need to focus on rather than only bemoaning the lot of the staff.

We all agree that to serve Lambeth citizens effectively, we need a motivated, skilled and enthusiastic workforce that acts on facts about performance, rather than gut feeling, rumour and innuendo. Try to pull out their ideas for how this can be achieved - and some good ones emerge. Promise that I will regularly feed back what is coming out of the workshops.

The output will also be analysed and discussed by the management team and used to inform and underpin our improvement plans. Feel this is time-consuming but well worth it. Impressed by the energy, ideas and commitment that come out of people (who confess to being demoralised) if they are given a bit of time and space to reflect on and discuss these issues.

 Lisa Christensen is executive director of social services at Lambeth council

fields.headline: Frankfurt ebook award nominations announced
fields.trailText: Zadie Smith makes the shortlist of the inaugural Frankfurt ebook awards with White Teeth
fields.body:
The Frankfurt Book Fair has pulled itself into the 21st century, and the centre of a controversy, with the announcement of the nominations for its inaugural ebook awards.

Offering prizes of $10,000 in four categories, the Frankfurt committee stated they wanted "o recognise the importance and the great potential of this new media for authors, publishers and the reading public throughout the world", with ebooks broadly categorised as "handheld electronic reading devices or PCs and laptops running special reading software, designed to allow the comfortable on-screen reading of books, periodicals or other documents".

British first-time novelist Zadie Smith has been nominated in the 'converted from print' category for her debut novel about three generations of three London families, White Teeth. A recent nominee for the Orange Prize, she was also tipped for the Booker but failed to make the shortlist. Competing in the same category is Myla Goldberg's first novel Bee Season, a bittersweet coming-of-age tale of an unusual nine year old, and French author Michel Houellebecq's first novel Extension du Domaine de la Lutte (sadly translated as Whatever in English).

The other categories in the competition include ebook originals (non-fiction) and ebooks converted to print (non-fiction). There is also a $100,000 prize for the best overall original ebook and a technology prize for "the advancement and implementation of ebook technologies and features".

The chairman of the ebook award foundation, Alberto Vitalie, was amazed by the number of submissions they received. "The response far exceeded our expectations, overwhelming our initial projections, with submissions arriving from countries as far and wide as Australia, Brazil, China, France, Germany, Italy, Norway, South Korea, the UK and the US," he said, claiming that the nominees were "the pioneers in this powerful and exciting new form of publishing".

However, since the shortlists were announced two days ago, there have been some furious debates over what actually constitutes an ebook. Only three out of the 10 titles have come from ebook-only publishers. The rest originate from traditional print publishers, including US publishing giants Simon and Schuster, who launched their first season of original ebooks this autumn and who have four of their books on the shortlist.

According to internet magazine The Standard, ebook publishers are blaming a "self-interested Microsoft" for the confusion. Connie Foster, who runs the e-publisher Ebooksonthe.net, claimed: "Microsoft paid for these awards, and it's pretty obvious they rely on big publishers to provide content for MS Reader."

Dick Brass of Microsoft has refuted the allegations, arguing that "the only stipulation for the two original categories was that the books had to come out simultaneously with, or prior to, print editions". This has further rattled the e-publishers who claim that, according to Simon and Schuster's own website, Ed McBain's ebook, nominated in the ebook originals section, came out four months after the print edition. Simon and Schuster now say that the listing was a mistake.

There is also controversy over the exact criteria for the nominations, with critics such as Steven M Zeitchic of The Standard posing the question: "If the books were selected on the basis of literary merit, with merely the technical requirement that they have a digital counterpart, what exactly makes the ebook awards different from any other prize?"

"It was a way of shining a spotlight on those who make the effort," counters Vitalie, with Richard Brass adding "ebooks would never get off the ground for a decade if all the content was highly experimental. No one wants that."

 The winners will be announced on October 20 at the Frankfurt Book Fair.

Complete list of ebooks nominated:

Ebook originals (fiction)

The Last Dance by Ed McBain
Morgan's Run by Colleen McCullough
Paradise Square by EM Schorb

Ebook originals (non-fiction)

Nothing Like It In the World by Stephen E Ambrose
Counting Coup by Larry Colton
When Pride Still Mattered by David Maraniss

Ebooks converted from print (fiction)

Bee Season by Myla Goldberg
Extension du domaine de la Lutte by Michel Houellebecq
White Teeth by Zadie Smith

Ebooks converted from print (non-fiction)

Mozart by Peter Gay
Ueberleben in der Sintflut by Vilim Vasata

fields.headline: Laid back, Lucky, and Litigious
fields.trailText: THE FINAL COUNTDOWN
fields.body:
THE FINAL COUNTDOWN

So here we are at last. The day before England take on Germany in the final match at the twin towers of the home of football of Wembley, the national stadium. But, strangely, the Fiver does not feel too excited this afternoon. Rather there's a sense of déjà vu in the air, almost as if we've spent the entire week poring over every last tendon tweak before a game which is likely to be a tedious replay of a fixture we got worked up about only a couple of months ago. Must be something we ate.

Anyway, for one last time, here we go. Kelvin Koogan, England coach, is very excited ahead of tomorrow's crucial crunch clash with the Bosch. Even the withdrawal of Liverpool's Steven Gerrard this afternoon with a recurrence of a groin injury hasn't fazed him. "It's disappointing for him as it's happened before," Koog said. "But it's probably better to happen in training than after five or ten minutes of the match." Too right, and Koog's got loads of other players to choice from anyway. "With the players I have got I think we are covered double and treble in most positions," he said. Please God, don't let it be Paul Ince.

A practical example of Koogan's first law aside, the England meistermind refrained from naming his team and surprisingly chose instead to concentrate on the historical significance of the match. "I have told the 11 players who I have picked, they know this is the opportunity to be part of something special," he said. "Until we lay the ghost of 1966 everyone is going to talk about Moore, Hurst, Peters, Bobby Charlton. But they can do something about that." But after a whole hour pondering the subject, the Fiver still isn't sure what.

England XI (probable): Seaman; G Neville, Adams, Keown, Le Saux; Barmby, Scholes, Ince, Beckham; Owen, Cole.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

AN EXCLUSIVE DAVID BECKHAM INTERVIEW

The only international footballer to have appeared on the front page of a national newspaper last weekend looking like a member of Take That circa 1992 is interviewed in this month's Observer Sport Monthly, which comes free with this weekend's Observer. You can also hang on every word at www.observer.co.uk.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

JIM LEIGHTON, MR LUCKY

Jim Leighton, the vaseline-smothered custodian, had many highlights in his unfeasibly long career. Sadly, no-one will ever remember them, as the lows - losing his place for the FA Cup final replay, dropping howlers that helped Scotland out of, not one, but two World Cups - are so much more memorable. So things looked to be taking an unexpected turn for the better when the SFA asked Leighton to travel with the Scottish Under-21 squad this week, despite having walked out on the senior squad only two years ago. But as Leighton would no doubt testify himself, appearances can be deceptive.

"I don't see it as a problem that [Leighton] is on this trip," Scotland coach Craig Brown said earlier today. "He always played well for his country and I don't think anyone will be complaining." Which makes the fact that Brown was forced to sack Leighton this afternoon all the more unfortunate. Especially since it appears that Leighton was relieved of his duties because of his upcoming autobiography which is said, amongst other things, to have a pop at both Brown and the SFA.

So it looks like another humiliation for Leighton who has packed his bags, left the Scottish camp and is off to do some radio commentary on Scotland's World Cup qualifier with San Marino instead. The Fiver wishes Leighton the best of luck, although if he intends to have a refreshing drink while carrying out his duties tomorrow, we'd advise staying as far away as he can from the electrical equipment.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'll be backing the English and hope that my former Arsenal team-mates and the rest of [Kelvin Koogan's side] are triumphant. On the Dutch side we have a long history of intense rivalry with Germany" - Marc Overmars shows that one-eyed nationalism isn't restricted to these noble isles.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A BHOY NAMED SUE

Last weekend, the Fiver opened a book on who would sue Paolo Di Canio first for remarks made in his snappily-titled autobiography Paolo Di Canio. You could get 5/1 on Ron Atkinson, who was called "a crazy man", and twos on David "cretin" James, the "moron". Meanwhile, odds-on favourite was team-mate Nigel Winterburn, who was referred to as "silly". With a well-balanced book, the Fiver was confident of making a tidy profit, especially when a Scottish-Canadian bloke wearing a false moustache and glasses stupidly risked £500 on 10,000/1 outsider Fergus McCann. But sure enough

"I am taking Paolo Di Canio to task over his recent false and damaging remarks," the former Celtic chief executive quipped today, after the former Bhoy accused him of breaking his word. "Legal papers will be served. In a real world we are all accountable for our words and actions, a lesson Mr Di Canio is about to learn. It is important that individuals such as di Canio are not allowed to get away with misleading the public and particularly the Celtic support. I also have a personal obligation to defend my reputation." He does sound rather determined, doesn't he?

At this stage, exactly what Mr McCann has taken umbrage with is anybody's guess. But the following rant suggests it could be about unreasonable contract negotiations. "I wish I had taken this action some years ago and exposed Di Canio and Pierre van Hooijdonk for the disreputable way they abused Celtic", McCann claimed. "Both individuals signed detailed binding contracts approved by their agents and were delighted to do so, then later - having had their careers greatly enhanced by playing for Celtic - sought to make false claims against myself and the club." In fact, so convinced are we that this is the source of McCann's pique, we've placed a hefty bet accordingly. But seeing we've just had to pawn our last pair of trousers, we don't necessarily advise you to follow suit.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea have made a £3m bid for Deportivo La Coruna's Yugoslav international midfielder Savisa Jokanovic, according to Spanish sports daily AS.

Lazio striker Marcelo Salas could move to Internazionale in a deal worth £15m. Planet Football claims "the deal could see Croatian defender Dario Simic moving in the opposite direction".

Aston Villa are believed to have offered Sheffield Wednesday £1m for striker Gilles de Bilde.

Blackburn midfielder Billy McKinlay - a target for Aberdeen, Hearts and Motherwell - is a target for two as-yet-unnamed English clubs, according to his agent. "There has been interest from two English clubs," said John Viola, "but unless Real Madrid come in with a six-year deal, Billy will take his time before making his mind up."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Arsenal midfielder Patrick Vieira believes one of the reasons he has problems with English referees may be because he is black. "Am I a target because I'm a world champion?" he asked French paper Le Parisien. "Is it because I'm a foreigner in England? Or simply because I'm black? I don't want to be naive, I know racism will still be present even after the year 2000."

Brad Friedel - currently being kept out of the Liverpool first team by in-form Sander Westerveld - has joined Bundesliga side Energie Cottbus on trial.

Gerry Taggart has passed a fitness test on his groin injury and will play for Northern Ireland against Denmark in tomorrow's World Cup Qualifier at Windsor Park.

Kilmarnock manager Bobby Williamson has been named the Bank of Scotland Manager of the Month.

John Toshack has been appointed manager of St Etienne.

Nottingham Forest have signed Ben Olsen, part of the US Olympic team, on a three-month loan.

Former Heaven 17 pop star Martyn Ware has called upon Sheffield Wednesday chairman Howard Culley to resign to allow a group of rich fans to take over the Owls.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Just William and Ffion (4.25am) Absolutely nothing to do with football but worth watching for the bit where William Hague basically admits to drink-driving.

Sky Sports 1: Live International Under-21 Football - England v Germany (7.30pm) This programme may possibly include some jingoistic statements.

Hold The Back Page (10pm) This programme may possibly include an amazing bouffant.

But the following rant suggests it could be about unreasonable contract negotiations. "I wish I had taken this action some years ago and exposed Di Canio and Pierre van Hooijdonk for the disreputable way they abused Celtic", McCann claimed. "Both individuals signed detailed binding contracts approved by their agents and were delighted to do so, then later - having had their careers greatly enhanced by playing for Celtic - sought to make false claims against myself and the club." In fact, so convinced are we that this is the source of McCann's pique, we've placed a hefty bet accordingly. But seeing we've just had to pawn our last pair of trousers, we don't necessarily advise you to follow suit. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Chelsea have made a £3m bid for Deportivo La Coruna's Yugoslav international midfielder Savisa Jokanovic, according to Spanish sports daily AS. Lazio striker Marcelo Salas could move to Internazionale in a deal worth £15m. Planet Football claims "the deal could see Croatian defender Dario Simic moving in the opposite direction". Aston Villa are believed to have offered Sheffield Wednesday £1m for striker Gilles de Bilde. Blackburn midfielder Billy McKinlay - a target for Aberdeen, Hearts and Motherwell - is a target for two as-yet-unnamed English clubs, according to his agent. "There has been interest from two English clubs," said John Viola, "but unless Real Madrid come in with a six-year deal, Billy will take his time before making his mind up." * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Arsenal midfielder Patrick Vieira believes one of the reasons he has problems with English referees may be because he is black. "Am I a target because I'm a world champion?" he asked French paper Le Parisien. "Is it because I'm a foreigner in England? Or simply because I'm black? I don't want to be naive, I know racism will still be present even after the year 2000." Brad Friedel - currently being kept out of the Liverpool first team by in-form Sander Westerveld - has joined Bundesliga side Energie Cottbus on trial. Gerry Taggart has passed a fitness test on his groin injury and will play for Northern Ireland against Denmark in tomorrow's World Cup Qualifier at Windsor Park. Kilmarnock manager Bobby Williamson has been named the Bank of Scotland Manager of the Month. John Toshack has been appointed manager of St Etienne. Nottingham Forest have signed Ben Olsen, part of the US Olympic team, on a three-month loan. Former Heaven 17 pop star Martyn Ware has called upon Sheffield Wednesday chairman Howard Culley to resign to allow a group of rich fans to take over the Owls. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Channel 4: Just William and Ffion (4.25am) Absolutely nothing to do with football but worth watching for the bit where William Hague basically admits to drink-driving. Sky Sports 1: Live International Under-21 Football - England v Germany (7.30pm) This programme may possibly include some jingoistic statements. Hold The Back Page (10pm) This programme may possibly include an amazing bouffant.

fields.headline: A swinging affair
fields.standfirst: You thought the clothes were the most important thing about the Milan collections? Wrong. If you want to get ahead here, better get a handbag.  Deborah Bee introduces the definitive guide to power bag buying and previews the best of next season's styles
fields.trailText: You thought the clothes were the most important thing about the Milan collections? Wrong. If you want to get ahead here, better get a handbag. Deborah Bee introduces the definitive guide to power bag buying and previews the best of next season's styles.
fields.body:
The past is another country, they buy bags differently there. Remember? When you made your handbag choice on the strength of: a) size - could it hold a kitchen sink? b) longevity - would it hold up to the kitchen sink? c) aesthetics - did it go with your clothes, did you actually like it?

Over the past 15 years, handbag buyers have swapped personal needs and taste for status. Rather than wear their hearts on their sleeves, women today are choosing a power bag.

Italians understand this notion very well. They should - they invented it. At Corso Como 10, Milan's most influential fashion store, handbags are displayed with reverence, like works of art, on low glass tables and the fashion elite quietly coos over supple leathers and hand-stitched finishes. The "it's-not-what-you-know-it's-who-you-know" philosophy translates very nicely into Italian bag-buying. Get ahead, get a handbag. The right handbag with the right name on it. You could almost forget about clothes.

Reigning supreme over our taste in accessories stands Prada. Stick your hand up right now, Miuccia. You are responsible for turning us all into handbag junkies. As far back as the late 80s, we swooned for gilt-trimmed Chanel lookalikes; then there were the little black nylon backpacks complete with the Prada triangle of authenticity; and when the rest of the world caught on you went the exclusive route with gorgeous limited editions that got us crashing into Prada stores across the globe.

The lesser-known face of Prada is Patrizio Bertelli, Miuccia's husband. They first met at a trade fair, at which Miuccia accused him of ripping off her bag designs (which she later admitted were very good), and they have since turned Muiccia's grandfather's musty luggage label into a multi-million-pound super-brand.

Following Prada's success, they bought 75% of the Jil Sander label and 51% of Helmut Lang, both of which have produced very elegant handbags this season. At Corso Como 10, an entire table is given over to Lang's petite satin and patent leather envelope bags. Bertelli's influence? Perhaps, because he knows better than anyone how to manipulate us buyers - to give us what we want when we don't even know what it is. This season it was the doctor's bag, which sold almost as quickly as it was copied by the high street. Come spring, a predicted sell-out is the black nappa leather rectangular handbag with an extra wide khaki strap, short enough so the bag can sit elegantly and securely on the wrist.

Hot on Prada's stiletto heels comes Gucci. What Prada gains in fashion kudos, Gucci makes up for in sexiness. Since becoming design director in 1994, Tom Ford has driven the company to the fashion front with a strict regime that presses all our lust buttons at once. The shop interiors, the ad campaigns, the catwalk presentations, the models' hair and make-up, the clothes themselves are all designed to scream sex. Once that association was secure, it was only a matter of time before we started buying the bags.

This season, the most desirable Gucci bag is a golden envelope with a lion's head clasp. In spring, the overall trend moves towards a military look with elegant silver cases hanging from wide leather straps. Worldwide turnover at Gucci stands at $2.2b and the company is currently being fought over by two big French groups, LVMH and Pinault-Printemps-Redoute. Everybody, it would appear, wants to grab a bit of the Gucci magic.

Which leads us neatly to Fendi, another Italian powerhouse, which only a year ago transferred 51% of its capital to a venture equally owned by LVMH and Prada. But to be fair, Fendi were fighting for space in your wardrobe already.

Since 1965, Karl Lagerfeld has fused his creative genius with the expert craftsmanship of the family-run company set up in 1925. It enjoyed great success in the 70s with its luxurious ready-to-wear collections and the Fendi handbag took off when Lagerfeld helped to define 80s logo excess with the birth of the Fendi double F logo.

But the giant step forward came in the late 90s with the advent of its patisserie-inspired bags (baguette, croissant) which immediately became collectors' items. This season's return to an unabashed flaunting of wealth suits Lagerfeld down to the ground. His most sought-after handbag is an updated version of the baguette in flash gold sequins. It is a Fendi handbag that remains true to its roots, unapologetic in its extravagance.

In a much quieter way, luxury leather label Bottega Veneta has slipped into our consciousness with a range of handbags that has a different association - underground cool. How do you get instant street cred? With a collection designed by ex-St Martins student Giles Deacon and UK stylist Katie Grand (formerly with Alexander McQueen at Givenchy).

After showing two collections in New York and masterminding a sophisticated ad campaign, Bottega Veneta have become something of a fashion insider's secret. Their definitive woven nappa bags sold out this season before half the fashionistas had a chance to snap them up. Get down there early for next season's sure-fire hit - a white woven envelope sprayed with multicoloured graffiti.

Tod's are also relative newcomers to the handbag war. Just three short years ago, Diego Della Valle, son of the founder of the company, introduced a limited range of handbags to his already highly successful Tod's shoe line. The D bag, with instantly identifiable D-shaped straps, found its way on to the shoulders of Hillary Clinton, the late Princess Diana and Cindy Crawford. Since then, Tod's have formed a loyal following among the LA celeb brigade. But with Tod's it's not just about celeb endorsement. Della Valle prides himself on the quality and longevity of his goods. "Sharon Stone might get the customer to buy initially," he has said, "but unless the handbag lives up to the expectation, unless it is practical and hardwearing, then the customer won't come back. Seventy per cent of our customers are regular clients."

So if you want what Calista Flockhart has got, check out the next American awards ceremony. You can bet she'll be holding one of Tod's minuscule sequined sacks with silver hoop handles. Make sure you get on the three-month waiting list early.

webTitle: Jackie Moore Award for Fashion Journalism

fields.headline: Over to you
fields.standfirst: Jackie Moore Award for Fashion Journalism
fields.trailText: Jackie Moore Award for Fashion Journalism... Why not you?
fields.body:
This award commemorates Jackie Moore, one of Britain's most respected freelance journalists, who died 10 years ago in the Sheraton Heliopolis Hotel fire. Most of Jackie's 30 years in journalism were devoted to writing about fashion - a field in which she demonstrated great generosity of spirit, encouraging newcomers, both writers and designers. As an experienced commentator, she was highly regarded for her knowledge and her fair, balanced outlook on fashion. This award is intended to follow the example of Jackie's life and work by promoting new talent and high standards of professionalism within fashion journalism.

THE AWARD

Write on the following, in no more than 500 words per topic.

1 Interview your style icon (anyone from your mum to Donatella Versace).

2 Is shopping for clothes a drug or a disaster?

THE PRIZE

An all-expenses-paid visit to the Paris couture collections in January 2001 and the opportunity to write a report to be published in Guardian Style.

HOW TO ENTER

Send entries to the Jackie Moore Award for Fashion Journalism, PO Box 31352, London SW11 5YG by November 17 2000. The winner will be announced in the Guardian on December 9. Entries must be typewritten and applicants should state their name, age, sex, occupation, address and telephone number. Entry is open to anyone with not more than three years' experience in fashion writing. There is no age limit.

THE JUDGES

Jess Cartner-Morley, fashion editor, the Guardian; Iain R Webb, fashion director, Elle; Mimi Spencer, editor, ES Magazine, and 1999 Fashion Journalist of the Year; Harriet Quick, fashion features editor, Vogue, and a previous winner of the award; Francesca Fearon, fashion editor, Hello!

fields.headline: What's your bag?
fields.body:
1 The In-Yer-Face bag

Live in the Home Counties? Have friends who wouldn't know a baguette from a Waitrose french stick? Go for an all-over logo print. In case they aren't so well up on abbreviations, it's up to you to leave your bag open at all times with a nice fat label sticking out. Either that or leave the swing tag in place.

2 The Wonderbra bag

Still single? Having trouble attracting members of the opposite sex? No one but Gucci can provide the handbag alternative to a deep cleavage. And there's less disappointment after the "coffee back at mine".

3 The Excessive bag

Need to prove your worth? Stun your colleagues with your inflated ego and personal wealth with a limited edition excessive bag. A major investment which will require a second mortgage, the good news is that if you keep it under wraps at the back of your wardrobe, it'll probably be worth a fortune in a century or so.

4 The Cool bag

Not to be confused with a cooler picnic bag, the "cool" bag is for London-based consumers only and requires a sharp group of fashion junkie friends to spot its value.

5 The Celeb bag

Only for the dinner party set who feed off celeb gossip and leave no room for the hors d'oeuvres. Consumers of In Style, American Vogue and Harper's Bazaar most welcome.

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst: She goes to the parties so you don't have to
fields.trailText: She goes to the parties so you don't have to...
fields.body:
Party animal instincts went on temporary hold this week after a mosquito spent the night on my eyelid. Imagine starting Milan fashion week with a throbbing, scarlet shiner. My only get-out was to do the Anna Wintour thing of wearing sunglasses throughout. "Pretentious cow," the fashion scum sniggered. "Hey, girls, wanna see something scary?"

The Italian aftershow "do" is a world away from Britain's cooler, livelier but ultimately pointless club party. The Milanese are consummate professionals. Never ones to miss a business opportunity, they combine the after-show celebration with a shop opening - bright lights, brighter foundation, champers all round. Trouble is, this goes on night after night. Same people, same street (only two doors up from the night before), same champagne. Different nibbles if you're lucky.

Roberto Cavalli's store opening promised loads of excess, judging by the metalicised tiger-printed invitation. Not known for his reticence, Cavalli's rails were chock-a-block tiger print with fur trim. My eyelid and I had little room for manoeuvre. Neither did Signor Cavalli, surrounded as he was by lean, blonde fashion groupies. Now, forgive me, but Roberto Cavalli: give me a mental image based on that name. Roberto - more butch than a Romeo, bronzed, floral shirt unbuttoned to the waist, right? Cavalli - Italian word for horse, enough said? Imagine our surprise when Signor Cavalli turns out to be the most diminutive chap you could ever hope to clap eyes on; Don Johnson leather jacket (sleeves pushed up), blue-tinted sunglasses and trousers that your mum and dad would call "jeans" but which we know are just cringey trousers made out of denim. Well, he wasn't what we'd conjured up. "Bit of a sheep in tiger's clothing," we giggled. Canapés were great, though. Sausages wrapped in prosciutto on sticks. "These are known as 'pigs in blankets' back in England," I proudly informed the waiter. Not a snigger. Wasted.

New evening, new shop opening, this time in the road next to the road where we were the night before, where Italian label Moschino were paying for the champagne. The gowns were glorious, the red roses stunning, the hors d'oeuvres came on cocktail sticks stuck into wee flower posies. But without the game of Spot The Designer to play (Franco Moschino died in 1994), we were left with little to idle away the minutes. (We had played Alphabet Of Dogs earlier.) So we mingled and eavesdropped. My favourite line came from a Brit who has developed a serious attack of TAD (transatlantic accent disorder), a condition that often affects fash hacks after the NY leg of the international collections. It's especially weird from her - she's dead plummy the rest of the time. "I just love my new boots," she drawled. "They're so, you know, well-balanced." (Answers on a postcard, please.) Quote of the night, though, came from a young blonde Amercian who was relating her wedding plans to one of the Moschino crew. "I don't wanna have just fashion people, yeah? I mean, a party full of just fashion people is like, totally boring, right?" It's been that sort of week.

fields.headline: The main loser: Ehud Barak
fields.standfirst: Israel's embattled prime minister is plunging deeper and deeper into crisis as the peace process totters
fields.trailText: Israel's embattled prime minister is plunging deeper and deeper into crisis as the peace process totters.
fields.body:
Israel's embattled prime minister, Ehud Barak, is plunging deeper and deeper into crisis as the peace process totters.

This afternoon the only slender thread of hope, that a ceasefire may end a week of bloody clashes between Israeli security forces and Palestinians, appeared to be close to breaking. Fresh outbreaks of rioting were reported in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, and at least two more Arab youths have been shot dead.

In Jerusalem, where the first clashes erupted last week, there were minor skirmishes as the al-Aqsa mosque emptied after Friday worship. Palestinian security guards moved in swiftly to prevent youths hurling stones at a dense mass of Israeli police.

The Israeli security forces were on maximum alert, in advance of warnings of a fresh surge of Palestinian demonstrations. All crossing points on the borders of the Palestinian territories were closed as renewed tension gripped the region.

The bloodshed, which has now claimed some 70 lives, is developing into a full-blown political crisis for Barak, whose fragile coalition has already lost its majority in the Knesset (parliament).

Today's Jerusalem Post carries a grim portent for the prime minister, in an opinion poll showing public support draining away towards the man he defeated in last year's general election, rightwing hawk Binyamin Netanyahu. If a snap poll was held now, the survey suggests, Barak would be defeated.

The Jerusalem Post has a suggestion of its own: that Netanyahu's Likud faction be invited to join a broadbased coalition. National unity, the paper argues, is more important than political advantage.

Evidence is mounting that Israelis are increasingly disillusioned with Barak's policy of pressing for a final peace settlement with the Palestinians, while maintaining a tough stand on security issues. Rightwingers and religious Jews have been shocked by his hints that Israel may have to share sovereignty in Jerusalem, while the more liberally minded have been sickened by the security forces' brutal response to the rioting.

Barak is under diplomatic fire too. Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak, Israel's staunchest friend in the region, furiously rebuked the Israeli prime minister for failing to attend peace talks in Egypt, and for refusing a Palestinian demand for an international inquiry into Israeli army tactics.

Mubarak met Palestinian president Yasser Arafat and US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright in the Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheik, and was clearly deeply offended by the last-minute message from Barak that he would not attend. "I am not going to force anyone to come," said the Egyptian leader angrily. "He who does not want peace, won't come".

The Barak government is also under pressure from the United Nations, where non-aligned nations are trying to promote a resolution critical of Israeli army tactics. The move is, as ever, being blocked by the USA, but Israel is highly sensitive to UN condemnations, and Barak will lose still more prestige at home if even a toned-down version is formally adopted.

If a snap poll was held now, the survey suggests, Barak would be defeated. The Jerusalem Post has a suggestion of its own: that Netanyahu's Likud faction be invited to join a broadbased coalition. National unity, the paper argues, is more important than political advantage. Evidence is mounting that Israelis are increasingly disillusioned with Barak's policy of pressing for a final peace settlement with the Palestinians, while maintaining a tough stand on security issues. Rightwingers and religious Jews have been shocked by his hints that Israel may have to share sovereignty in Jerusalem, while the more liberally minded have been sickened by the security forces' brutal response to the rioting. Barak is under diplomatic fire too. Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak, Israel's staunchest friend in the region, furiously rebuked the Israeli prime minister for failing to attend peace talks in Egypt, and for refusing a Palestinian demand for an international inquiry into Israeli army tactics. Mubarak met Palestinian president Yasser Arafat and US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright in the Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheik, and was clearly deeply offended by the last-minute message from Barak that he would not attend. "I am not going to force anyone to come," said the Egyptian leader angrily. "He who does not want peace, won't come". The Barak government is also under pressure from the United Nations, where non-aligned nations are trying to promote a resolution critical of Israeli army tactics. The move is, as ever, being blocked by the USA, but Israel is highly sensitive to UN condemnations, and Barak will lose still more prestige at home if even a toned-down version is formally adopted. fields.headline: Randall quashes rumours of Express move
fields.standfirst: Randall approached by Barclay brothers
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall denies that he has been approached to edit the Daily Express, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Randall approached by Barclay brothers
fields.body:
Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall, whom newspaper reports have claimed has been approached by the Barclay brothers to edit the Daily Express as part of their bid to buy the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star titles from United News & Media, claims he has not been offered the editorship of the Express.

Mr Randall told MediaGuardian: "It's well known inside this group that I will be stepping down from the editorship of Sunday Business next year. It's true that I have been offered another interesting and wide-ranging editorial position within the group and I am thinking about it, but no offer concerning the Express has ever been made to me."

This week it has been reported that the Barclay brothers have offered United News & Media chief executive Clive Hollick £75m for the Express titles, which he has rejected.

The Barclay brothers are understood to have made clear to Mr Randall that he would be guaranteed a senior editorial position within European Press Holdings. Sources have speculated that Mr Randall could be offered a roving editorial brief across the European Media Holdings titles, including the Scotsman, Scotland on Sunday and Sunday Business.

Meanwhile, the Barclay brothers are understood to be considering tabling a bid to buy the Herald Newspaper titles from owner SMG.

Last month former Scotsman editors Tim Luckhurst and Alan Ruddock approached the Barclays with an offer which would have seen the Scotsman and Herald titles moving towards shared back office functions with a view to an eventual merger. The Barclays are understood to have considered and finally rejected the offer, but are thought still to be interested in bidding for the Herald titles.

webTitle: Barclay brothers line up editor for Express takeover

fields.headline: Barclay brothers line up editor for Express takeover
fields.trailText: The Barclay brothers have approached the Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall in the hope of persuading him to take the Daily Express helm if they succeed in their bid to buy the paper from Lord Hollick's United News & Media.
fields.body:
The Barclay brothers have approached the Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall in the hope of persuading him to take the Daily Express helm if they succeed in their bid to buy the paper from Lord Hollick's United News & Media.

The millionaire brothers approached Lord Hollick early last month with an offer of £75m for the Daily Express, the Sunday Express and Daily Star. The offer was firmly rejected by United, which is believed to have told them to double the sum.

United's hand, though, will be weakened by a note pub lished by its City advisers, Merrill Lynch, yesterday which put a value on the newspapers of between £74m and £105m. The newspapers had revenues of just under £200m.

The Barclays are understood to hope that Mr Randall, a former Sunday Times executive, would become editor at the Express if they could agree a price with United. Mr Randall has made a success of Sunday Business, also owned by the Barclays, and is contracted to stay at the title at least until next February.

Rosie Boycott, current editor of the Daily Express, has been running the title for the past two and a half years and has engaged in the task of wrenching it to the left. Sales of the daily are just above 1m a day.

One executive close to the Barclays' empire said that there was still a wide margin between them and Lord Hollick. The source claimed internal Express figures were "horrendous" and suggested the newspapers were barely profitable.

"They [the Barclays] will pay what it costs to buy them but are not going to pay what they are not worth," said the source.

A senior Express source said that face-to-face discussions were held early last month between United and the would-be buyers.

None of the parties involved would comment.

fields.headline: Four killed as clashes resume
fields.standfirst: Map: Jerusalem's holy shrines
fields.trailText:
Israeli troops killed four Palestinians today in renewed clashes with thousands of demonstrators in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in
what the Palestinians billed as a "day of rage".
 
Israel had attempted to head off new outbursts of fighting by sealing off the
Palestinian areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israeli forces also pulled back from
a potentially explosive confrontation near a bitterly contested religious site in Jerusalem's
Old City.
fields.body:
Israeli troops killed four Palestinians today in renewed clashes with thousands of demonstrators in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in what the Palestinians billed as a "day of rage". Israel had attempted to head off new outbursts of fighting by sealing off the Palestinian areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israeli forces also pulled back from a potentially explosive confrontation near a bitterly contested religious site in Jerusalem's Old City.

In a direct challenge to Israel's sovereignty claim, Palestinians raised their flag on the Al Aqsa Mosque in the walled compound revered by Muslims and Jews.

As the ceasefire negotiated yesterday collapsed, Israeli troops and Palestinian gunmen exchanged fire at several places in the West Bank and Gaza where tens of thousands of protesters marched on Israeli military positions. Two Palestinians were killed in the West Bank town of Nablus, one died nearby in Tulkaram and one was shot dead in Gaza. Dozens were injured.

Overall, 71 people have been killed and about 1,900 injured, most of them Palestinians, in nine days of fighting since a controversial visit by the rightwing Israeli politician Ariel Sharon to the compound, revered by Jews as the biblical Temple Mount. Israel says the Palestinians seized on Mr Sharon's visit as a pretext for fighting.

Today's clashes eruped after midday prayers at the controversial al Haram al-Sharif mosque in Jerusalem when Israeli police fired tear gas at Palestinian stone throwers.

The trouble erupted almost immediately after some 8,000 worshippers came out of the mosque, where last week's Israeli-Palestinian violence started.

In an unprecedented act of cooperation, Israeli and Palestinian security forces coordinated security efforts. Plainclothes Palestinian security agents formed a line to block people from throwing stones and leaving the compound in the direction of Israeli forces.

However, clashes between Israeli forces and the Palestinians erupted just outside the exits and the Palestinians were driven back by tear gas near an entrance to the Old City. Israeli police eventually withdrew from the area, in an apparent effort to avoid direct confrontation.

Israel had succeeded in its aim of keeping down the number of Muslims travelling from the volatile territories to the mosque, and the number of worshippers was well below the usual figure of 10,000 to 15,000. Some were prevented from reaching the mosque by the closure of the Palestinian territories, and others may have stayed away over concern about potential clashes.

Tension eased temporarily yesterday after security measures were agreed to in talks in Paris between Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak. The Israelis withdrew tanks from several of the most explosive sites, and the Palestinians sought to keep rioters in check.

An Israeli army spokeswoman said Israel's border with the West Bank and Gaza Strip had been sealed early this morning, barring Palestinians from entering Israel until Monday night, the end of the day-long Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement.
