webTitle: A new pilot in Europe's cockpit

fields.headline: A new pilot in Europe's cockpit
fields.standfirst: Most of the Balkan's wars have been forced upon them by European powers willing to exploit local rivalries to further their own ambitions, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Most of the Balkan's wars have been forced upon them by European powers willing to exploit local rivalries to further their own ambitions, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Serbia and neighbours are too often vilified as a nest of vipers, absorbed with ancient and obscure feuds. That analysis is insulting not only to human nature, but to history. To be sure, the Balkan nations are no strangers to bloody conflict, but most of their wars have been forced upon upon them by bigger powers, ever willing to exploit local rivalries to further their own ruthless ambitions.

It is not altogether fanciful to trace back such outside interference to the dawn of recorded history, when the Slavic nations first emerged from central Asia to batter at the crumbling doors of Roman power.

Certainly, throughout the long decay of the Byzantine empire and the centuries of Turkish expansion, emperors found willing vassals among the warlords and princelings of the Balkans.

Nearer our own time, the retreat of the Ottoman empire fired the nationalism of Serbs, Bulgars, Greeks and other nationalities of the region - but it also sparked the ambition of the Habsburg rulers of the Austro-Hungarian empire, and the Romanovs in Moscow.

Hungry to become a naval power, the Habsburgs contrived the annexation of Bosnia, a central event in the deadly sequence which led to the first world war.

That war was the greatest military disaster which had yet befallen Europe. The Treaty of Versailles, which followed it, was our greatest diplomatic disaster - nowhere more than in the Balkans.

The dismemberment of the Habsburg domains allowed the creation - or rather, imposition - of a new kingdom in the region, bringing together the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, plus a large number of ethnic Albanians. The new 'nation' became Yugoslavia, the land of the south Slavs.

Centuries of history were repeated in the second world war, when the Balkans again become a cockpit for the battles of the great powers. Yugoslavia was invaded and occupied by the Italians and the Germans. The splintered resistance movements were eagerly supported, first by Britain and then by the USA, as they diverted huge numbers of Axis troops from the main fronts.

In the beginning the Allies backed the Chetniks, or royalist army of resistance, but fairly quickly switched their aid to the much more effective communist partisans led by the remarkable Josip Tito. His forces liberated Belgrade in 1944, fighting alongside the Red Army, and swiftly snuffed out the remnants of the old order.

By the early 1950s Marshal Tito had broken with Stalin's Soviet Union and established his own form of communist control, dodging nimbly between Moscow, Peking and the West as circumstances dictated. He strove to establish a new sense of common Yugoslav identity among the federation's ethnic groups, with remarkable success.

But Yugoslavia's history caught up with it yet again after Tito died and ethnic nationalism revived. Slobodan Milosevic, who grabbed the main throne in Belgrade in the late 1980s, had all Tito's ambition to weld together the south Slavs - but none of his subtlety.

As the cement holding together the federation dissolved, the Western European powers also rediscovered their history. Newly reunited Germany, with its revived sense of destiny in Middle Europe, rushed to recognise the breakaway republics of Slovenia and Croatia, with disastrous consequences for the latter. France and Russia, sensing a seismic shift in the region, made knee-jerk gestures of support to Belgrade. And Britain revived the ancient diplomacy of power-balancing by promoting military intervention to keep the warring groups apart.

The pattern of events and alliances was uncannily similar to that before the first world war, 70 years earlier.

Milosevic, for his part, did what he could to stoke up the fires of Serbian nationalism to their fierce 1914 heat. He cajoled, armed and incited the Serb communities in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo, and when he thought the occasion demanded, did not hesitate to deploy the Yugoslav army.

Yet again the European powers intervened, with muddled 'peacekeeping' operations, diplomatic threats, sanctions and, ultimately, last year's atrociously ill-judged air strikes against the remnants of the federal republic. That onslaught resulted in the double ethnic cleansing of Kosovo - first the Albanians were herded out and then the Serbs - and has left the province (still ostensibly an integral part of Serbia and of Yugoslavia) a battered ruin.

The federation is effectively finished. Kosovo has gone, and Montenegro is set to secede. What Vojislav Kostunica won in last week's vote was the federal presidency. What he has actually got, is the leadership of Serbia.

Interestingly, many of the pronouncements being made in the first flush of post-Milosevic exhilaration explicitly recognise this reality. They talk of Serbia rather than Yugoslavia, and portend yet another re-drawing of Balkan boundaries.

But before that happens, Kostunica has to consolidate his hold on power, and address the appallingly messy business of reconstructing the country, both physically and politically. Given the history of the region, both ancient and recent, he will not lack advice and help from outside.

Already, Moscow is trawling in Belgrade, and the West too is making overtures. The new regime has to decide whether there are doves of peace circling over Belgrade, or vultures gathering for a new feast.

fields.headline: BBC pins hopes on Weakest Link
fields.standfirst: Parkinson moves to Saturday
fields.trailText: 1.15pm update: The BBC is throwing BBC2's Anne Robinson-fronted sleeper hit, The Weakest Link, into the peak time ratings battle between BBC1 and ITV, writes Jason Deans .
fields.body:
The BBC is throwing BBC2's Anne Robinson-fronted sleeper hit, The Weakest Link, into the peak time ratings battle between BBC1 and ITV.

The quiz show, which has been dubbed "mean TV" by BBC2 controller Jane Root because of Ms Robinson's stern treatment of contestants, is expected to move to a peak time BBC1 slot before the end of this month. The show will also continue to go out on BBC2.

The BBC would not officially confirm the move, but sources close to the production say that The Weakest Link has been given a weekly BBC1 peak time slot for eight weeks.

Moving The Weakest Link is a further sign that the BBC is pulling out all the stops to shore up BBC1's ratings with the new 10pm news schedule, which launches on Monday October 16. The speed of the move, announced earlier this week, has led industry observers to speculate that the BBC will soon run out of suitable programming to run in the new-look BBC1 schedule.

It is thought the quiz show will go out in an early evening slot, at 7pm or 7.30pm. If the trial run proves successful, BBC1 could follow ITV's lead with Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and strip the show nightly.

The Weakest Link has been going out daily in a 5.15pm teatime slot on BBC2, giving Channel 4's previously strong late afternoon line-up a ratings drubbing. This week, between Monday and Wednesday, the show averaged 3.4m/24% share.

BBC controller of daytime programmes Jane Lush recently ordered a further 90 episodes of the show.

fields.headline: Parkinson loses Friday night slot
fields.standfirst: BBC1 slot for Weakest Link
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The BBC is said to be planning to reschedule Parkinson, which was bumped out of the BBC1 Friday night schedule by Have I Got News For You earlier this week, on Saturday night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC is moving Parkinson, which was bumped out of the BBC1 Friday night schedule by Have I Got News for You? earlier this week, to Saturday night.

The long-running chat show, which returned to BBC1 in 1998 after a 16-year break, was the highest-profile casualty of the more populist weekday peak time line-up the BBC has scheduled around its new 10pm news.Parkinson starts in its new Saturday night slot on October 21.

Parkinson has been running at 9.30pm on Friday nights after the 9pm news bulletin. The show was pencilled in at 9pm in preliminary BBC1 schedules for the week beginning Monday October 16, when the 9pm news moves back an hour.

But the final BBC1 Friday line-up had Have I Got News for You? moving from 9pm from the same slot on BBC2, a Vicar of Dibley repeat at 9.30pm and new sitcom Too Much Sun after the news at 10.30pm.

In the four weeks of its autumn run to date in the 9.30pm Friday night slot, Parkinson's share has dropped from 37% to 24%.

fields.headline: Son rises: Lachlan Murdoch moves closer to succession
fields.trailText: Lachlan Murdoch, the elder son of Rupert Murdoch, has been appointed deputy chief operating officer at News Corporation underlining his position as his father's eventual successor.
fields.body:
Lachlan Murdoch, the elder son of Rupert Murdoch, has been appointed deputy chief operating officer at News Corporation underlining his position as his father's eventual successor.

Lachlan, 29, will become the third most powerful figure in News Corp behind his father and Peter Chernin, president and chief operating officer of the sprawling media group which has interests ranging from the Sun news paper to the film-maker 20th Century Fox.

He is the only one of Mr Murdoch's children to sit on the six-strong executive board and has been referred to as "first among equals".

Mr Chernin was recently identified by Mr Murdoch as being the executive who would take charge of the business until Lachlan was ready.

Mr Murdoch's youngest son James, 27, who built News Corps' new media business, is also in the ascendancy and was recently appointed to run Star TV, the group's pan-Asian pay TV operation.

James has gained his father's ear increasingly because of his knowledge of new media.

Elisabeth Murdoch, 32, who had been a senior figure at BSkyB quit the family firm earlier this year to set up her own production business.

Lachlan will retain responsibility for all News Corp's Australian operations as well as the print- based business in the US including the New York Post and book publisher HarperCollins.

The new role has been vacated by Chase Carey, co-chief operating officer, to run Sky Global Networks which will combine all the company's satellite TV businesses worldwide with the aim of building a platform for broadband internet access.

The company is being lined up for a separate stock market flotation.

Mr Murdoch's youngest son James, 27, who built News Corps' new media business, is also in the ascendancy and was recently appointed to run Star TV, the group's pan-Asian pay TV operation. James has gained his father's ear increasingly because of his knowledge of new media. Elisabeth Murdoch, 32, who had been a senior figure at BSkyB quit the family firm earlier this year to set up her own production business. Lachlan will retain responsibility for all News Corp's Australian operations as well as the print- based business in the US including the New York Post and book publisher HarperCollins. The new role has been vacated by Chase Carey, co-chief operating officer, to run Sky Global Networks which will combine all the company's satellite TV businesses worldwide with the aim of building a platform for broadband internet access. The company is being lined up for a separate stock market flotation.

webTitle: Man in court accused of murdering wife and four children

fields.headline: Man in court accused of murdering wife and four children
fields.trailText:
A 33-year-old man appeared in court today charged with murdering his wife and four stepchildren.
 
Lee Ford, of Carnkie, near Helston, Cornwall, appeared before Truro magistrates court after police announced the discovery of two more bodies in a field at Treluswell, about four miles from the family home.
fields.body:
A 33-year-old man appeared in court today charged with murdering his wife and four stepchildren. Lee Ford, of Carnkie, near Helston, Cornwall, appeared before Truro magistrates court after police announced the discovery of two more bodies in a field at Treluswell, about four miles from the family home.

Three bodies were discovered yesterday in a shed in the garden of the family's detached bungalow.

Mr Ford was charged with murdering Lesley Ford, 36, Sarah-Jane Tranter, 17,Ann-Marie Tranter, 16, Stephen Tranter, 14, and Craig Tranter, 13, between August 26 and October 5 at Carnkie this year.

Mr Ford was remanded in custody to reappear at Truro magistrates court on October 12.

His wife and her four teenagers from a previous relationship were reported missing to police at the end of last month.

fields.headline: Press Review
fields.standfirst: Russia's role in Yugoslavia, the court case against Edward Pope and dramas at the Bolshoi are the stories dominating the country's press, says Amelia Gentleman in Moscow
fields.trailText: Russia's role in Yugoslavia, the court case against Edward Pope and dramas at the Bolshoi are the stories dominating the country's press, says Amelia Gentleman in Moscow.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia

Pictures of the crowd and smoke-filled streets of Belgrade are shown on the front pages. The pro-Kremlin daily Izvestiya comments: "Once again the Yugoslav crisis is developing in the worst direction. The country is on the brink of civil war... Milosevic is confident of himself. That is his strength. And he will fight. It is possible that he will try to drag us into his war, on his side".

The liberal business paper Kommersant concludes that civil war has already begun in Yugoslavia and criticises Russia for being ineffective in its attempts to mediate. "Moscow's attempts to stave off at any cost the use of force in the resolution of the Yugoslav crisis were wholly justified. It was just that the tactics used by Russian diplomats to achieve this end were mistaken," the paper writes. "Instead of trying to persuade Milosevic to agree at least to a comparison of the official and opposition figures for the results of the first round, Moscow was more concerned about how to avoid offending him. This tactic of conciliation meant that Milosevic wrongly believed that Moscow was on his side."

Spy scandal The court case against Edward Pope, the American businessman charged with spying, will begin on October 18, most papers report.

The FSB - Russia's successor to the KGB - states that Pope used various official and unofficial channels to carry sophisticated new Russian technology to America. According to Izvestiya, he was particularly interested in the latest space and submarine technology. Pope has denied the charges and the US embassy has been negotiating for his release.

The paper quotes an FSB official's criticisms of the US government for its attempts to intercede on Pope's behalf. "Attempts to put pressure on Russia's investigative and legal bodies do no credit to the Americans," senior FSB official Andrei Laryushin said. "Once again we see the latest manifestation of political double standards. The Americans have not softened their stance towards those accused of similar offences on US territory, but at the same time they are demanding a different approach from other countries."

The liberal daily Sevodnya reprints extracts from a letter from the US state department, warning western entrepreneurs working in Russia of the dangerous consequences which could result from them meeting with representatives from Russia's military-industrial sphere - commenting that "any misunderstanding" might lead to a spying charge.

Bolshoi revolution continues

The drama behind the scenes at the Bolshoi continues, with most papers reporting the sacking of the ballet's artistic director Alexei Fadeyechev.

Internal upheaval at the Moscow theatre began in August when most of the senior management of the Bolshoi - including its director - were removed and a new team was imposed by the Kremlin.

Fadeyechev was one of the few old guard members left in his post, but last week he gave a furious press conference, slamming the plans by the Bolshoi's new overall artistic director - the world-famous composer Gennady Rozhdestvensky - to drop many of this season's productions and to disrupt its touring programme.

His outspoken criticism of the new regime caused a worsening of the Bolshoi scandal and the company's new general director, Anatoly Iksanov, sacked him yesterday after failing to reach an agreement. No one has yet been appointed to replace him.

Fadeyechev told Kommersant that he had been accused of "rocking the boat". He is toying with the idea of taking the Bolshoi to court for breach of contract.

Russia budget The 2001 budget is to be debated in Russia's Duma today, and most papers analyse the likelihood of another tortuous round of discussions before it can be passed.

The Duma's communists - the largest faction within the house - are set to vote against what they see as excessively modest expenditure proposals at a time when Russia is wallowing in extra funds supplied by high oil prices.

But Kommersant, Sevodnya and Hezavisimaya Gazeta all conclude that the government will probably manage to pass the bill after the first reading.

webTitle: Gerrard not fit to face Germany

fields.headline: Gerrard not fit to face Germany
fields.standfirst: More about England v Germany
fields.trailText: Steven Gerrard will miss tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against Germany after the Liverpool midfielder suffered a recurrence of his long-standing groin injury in training. Gerrard had looked certain to start at Wembley tomorrow but will now not be risked.
fields.body:
Steven Gerrard will miss tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against Germany after the Liverpool midfielder suffered a recurrence of his long-standing groin injury in training. Gerrard had looked certain to start at Wembley tomorrow but will now not be risked.

Kevin Keegan revealed the news in a press conference this afternoon. "It's disappointing for him [Gerrard] as it's happened before," he said. "But it's probably better to happen in training than after five or ten minutes of the match tomorrow."

There was better news for Keegan over the fitness of David Beckham, after the Manchester United midfielder showed no after-effects from today's training session and is definitely fit to play tomorrow.

"This is too big a game to start risking players", Keegan said. "David Beckham is not a risk, Steven Gerrard would have been a risk."

Keegan insisted it would not be a problem to replace the 20-year-old player, who was one of England's best performers in the 1-0 victory over Germany in Euro 2000. "With the players I have got I think we are covered double and treble in most positions," he said.

fields.headline: Who's going to pay?
fields.standfirst: Lee Elliot Major asks who is going to address the poverty divide affecting students' chances of reaching university
fields.trailText: Lee Elliot Major asks who is going to address the poverty divide affecting students' chances of reaching university.
fields.body:
The most dramatic figures published today by university funding chiefs in the latest set of academic performance statistics concern neither Oxford nor Cambridge, or the numbers of state schools students admitted to elite academic institutions.

The statistics expose a gaping divide in educational prospects of people from the country's poorest and richest neighbourhoods. People from the country's poorest postcodes (Egbaston, Birmingham, B14 for example), stand less than a one in ten chance of getting to university, according to statistics compiled by the Higher Education Funding Council for England. But at least eight out of ten people who live in the richest areas (King's Heath Birmingham B15 for example) are destined to become future graduates.

The fairness of admissions procedures in elite universities such as Oxford and Cambridge has become a big political issue since the Laura Spence affair erupted earlier this year. But this surely pales into insignificance compared with the fact that thousands of people still don't get to university at all.

"The big issue is surely that there are whole swathes of the population who are in social conditions which mean that they are highly unlikely to get near a university - top one or otherwise," said Bahram Bekhradnia, head of policy at HEFCE. "We need to devote most of our efforts to addressing this inequity. What university they go to is a secondary question."

Just by raising participation rates to universities from the poorest areas to the national average, would generate an extra 100,000 university students. But there needs to be a sea change in school performance and society as a whole for this to happen. But would the government be genuinely willing to pay for these extra student places, if the deep educational divide across the country's postcodes is ever addressed?

webTitle: Switchdigital wins central Scotland digital radio licence

fields.headline: Switchdigital wins central Scotland digital radio licence
fields.trailText: 3pm: The Switchdigital consortium has won its second digital radio licence after the Radio Authority awarded it the central Scotland multiplex. Jason Deansreports.
fields.body:
The Switchdigital consortium - which has backers including Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group (TWG) and Capital Radio - has won its second digital radio licence after the Radio Authority awarded it the central Scotland multiplex.

The central Scotland digital radio licence, which covers Glasgow and Edinburgh, is the largest to be awarded outside London and has the potential to reach an audience of almost 3m people.

TWG and Switchdigital (Scotland) chairman Mr MacKenzie said: "The central Scotland multiplex is an excellent addition to TWG's digital radio portfolio and will offer Scottish listeners an exciting range of new and existing services."

TWG has a controlling 55% stake in Switchdigital (Scotland). The other backers are Capital (20%), Clear Channel International (20%) and the Carphone Warehouse (5%).

The consortium is planning to offer nine digital radio services, of which TWG will provide three. The group's adult contemporary service Scot FM is to be rebroadcast in digital, along with two new services: rock and sports format BIG Scotland and easy-listening service the Lounge.

The other Switchdigital (Scotland) services will be a new jazz, soul and blues offering from Jazz FM; a new Beat 106 rock and dance service; a Ministry of Sound chart hits/club dance station; new classic soul service the Rhythm; new classic hits station WSCO The Mix; and BBC Gaelic service Radio Nan Gaidheal.

Switchdigital (London) - in which TWG holds 42.5% a stake - went live in July with the second digital licence for London.

fields.headline: Publicis appoints Morin for Saatchi & Saatchi integration
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Publicis has named its general secretary, Jean-Paul Morin, to oversee the integration of Saatchi & Saatchi into its international holding company, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Publicis has named its general secretary, Jean-Paul Morin, to oversee the integration of Saatchi & Saatchi into its international holding company.

Mr Morin, previously the chief financial officer at the French group, played a key role in bringing about Publicis' $2bn friendly takeover of Saatchi & Saatchi, which was completed in mid-September.

The move catapulted the French group into the world's fifth-largest consolidated advertising organisation, with global revenues topping $2bn.

Mr Morin will face the task of bringing the two groups together while maintaining their brand differences.

A priority is the consolidation of real estate in many areas of the world, including the merger of existing administrative centers into one sole corporate headquarters, to be located in Paris. He will also oversee creation of joint management teams for corporate activities and realignment of financial reporting and tax-filing procedures to match the group's new merged profile.

Jean-Michel Etienne will replace Mr Morin as chief financial officer at Publicis and the two will work closely together. Mr Etienne will be responsible for all aspects of the group's financial operations, including control, treasury operations, accounting, audit and tax matters.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life - week eight

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life - week eight
fields.standfirst: Each week throughout the season, Football Unlimited writers take on the bookies. Online bookmakers Blue Square gave us £100 each - will we make our millions or, more likely, blow it all?
fields.trailText: Current totals (from initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £126.11, Sean Ingle = £90.21, Football Unlimited punters' collective = £78.28, Paul MacInnes = £77.10
fields.body:
Current totals (from initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £126.11, Sean Ingle = £90.21, Football Unlimited punters' collective = £78.28, Paul MacInnes = £77.10

Scott Murray

England v Germany: Correct score 0-0 £5 @ 5/1

Ah, look! Here's a high-pressure fixture involving two low-quality sides both petrified of defeat. Now, if it was played five times, do you think it would be a tedious load of attritional tosh on more than one occasion?

And there's nothing more yawn-inducing than a nil-nil draw. Apart from an FA Cup final, of course.

Paul MacInnes

England v Germany: Half-Time/Full-Time - England/Draw £5 @ 14/1

Despite losing every single bet I have made since my inaugural win, this is the first time I feel I have let myself down. As Mr Murray pointed out on Monday, betting on two draws in two big games, no matter how likely they seemed, was risky and the odds on offer weren't exactly spectacular either. But after locking myself in a cupboard for 50 hours and lashing myself with many types of whip, I feel I am ready to return to the gambling forum and try once more to win some cash.

I think, and hope, that Kevin Keegan's magnificent England collective will win their qualifying tie with Germany at Wembley tomorrow. But nothing, not even Andy Cole's finishing, is certain and the odds of 14/1 on England failing to hold an early lead look a bit too big to pass up.

Of course, England have thrown away advantages in the recent past. Some of you may recall that they were two goals up against the Portuguese, and they were also 2-1 ahead against Romania before Nigel Martyn and Phil Neville got involved. Even if Martin Keown and Tony Adams play together in the centre of defence, I can still see them conceding a goal, or maybe even two, and if this event occurs at the right time, then I'm in the veritable money.

Sean Ingle

Millwall to beat Luton @ 6/5; Walsall to beat Colchester @ 11/10; Finland to beat Greece @ 4/1; Rep of Ireland to draw with Portugal @ 5/2: 4 x £1 trebles and 1x50p accumulator

For too long I have turned the other cheek as Blue Square's Patrick Murray has belittled my bets, called me "irksome" and smarmed his way through my analysis. But for no longer: I respect Mr Murray's number-crunching skills, but that's it.

Of course, having never met the man it's hard to judge (although that doesn't stop Mr Murray), but he strikes me as the kind of man who spends his whole life checking probability tables while the rest of us get on with watching the game. Maybe I'm being harsh, but perhaps that's probably why Mr Murray acts the way he does.

Anyway, on to this week's bets. After failing twice with safe-looking singles and succeeding with more glamorous permed bets, I am returning to the latter. Second Division leaders Walsall look great value to trounce Colchester, who have failed to fire since Lua Lua left for Newcastle. Similarly Millwall, with Mark McGhee at the helm, should prove too strong for Ricky Hill's Luton.

I've also gone for Finland to beat Greece: don't forget, Greece lost to Latvia and drew with Slovenia during their Euro 2000 campaign, while Finland beat Turkey 3-1 in Istanbul. Therefore, I think the Finns at 4/1 represents great value.

Speaking of value, I think the Republic of Ireland are a reasonable bet to get the draw with Portugal at 5/2.

The Football Unlimited punters collective: Hugh Mac Evilly, working in supply chain for Johnson and Johnson

Finland to beat Greece: £5 @ 4/1

Must think value! Must think value!

With no Premiership action this weekend I am skilfully avoiding the betting minefield also known as the Nationwide League. Instead I have gone for the international games as there is one little gem hidden amongst the usual tricky selections.

I have decided to go for Finland to do the business against the mighty Greeks (4/1 with Blue Square). Although the Greeks will be a hostile crowd the Fins are no longer as useless as they previously were. Players such as Hyypia, Litmanen and Johannson, currently in great form with Charlton, mean that this is a banker. Honestly.

fields.headline: Russia joins chorus of approval
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Russia today joined the rest of the world in accepting the new order in Yugoslavia, when it dramatically changed tack and congratulated Vojislav Kostunica as Yugoslavia's new leader.
fields.body:
Russia today joined the rest of the world in accepting the new order in Yugoslavia, when it dramatically changed tack and congratulated Vojislav Kostunica as Yugoslavia's new leader.

Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, travelled to Belgrade conveying congratulations from Russian President Vladimir Putin to Mr Kostunica, the opposition leader being hailed by Western heads and even Yugoslav state media as the "president-elect."

Mr Kostunica's legitimacy was underlined as the European Union invited him to the EU-Balkans summit in Zagreb, Croatia, on November 24, according to French officials.

In another move signalling the overthrow of the old order, former supporters of the disgraced former president, Slobodan Milosevic, in the republic of Montenegro declared their loyalty to the new president. Mr Milosevic, who presided over a disastrous dismemberment of Yugoslavia, was swept out of power in exuberant mass demonstrations in Belgrade yesterday.

In keeping with the new mood, foreign secretary Robin Cook said that Yugoslavia had released two British policemen jailed for spying.

Adrian Prangnell and John Yore were arrested in Montenegro in August with a Canadian colleague.

Mr Cook welcomed the overthrow of Mr Milosevic, saying that sanctions against Yugoslavia could be lifted on Monday when the European parliament next meets.

There is widespread speculation that Mr Milosevic will seek asylum abroad, possibly in Belarus, but the ousted leader's brother, who is Belgrade's ambassador in Moscow, said he was not planning to go anywhere.

"Why should he leave the country? Half the population openly supports him. He is the leader of a major party," said Borislav Milosevic.

The ambassador said Mr Milosevic was still in Belgrade and would discuss his options with Mr Ivanov. President Bill Clinton has urged Russia, Yugoslav's traditional ally, to help resolve matters by persuading Mr Milosevic to quit.

In the Kazakh capital, Astana, the Russian prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, said the question of asylum for Mr Milosevic in Russia "has not been raised and is not being discussed". Mr Milosevic has been indicted as a war criminal by a UN tribunal in the Hague, and his status will be one of the tricky issues to be sorted out in the new Yugoslavia.

The west has expressed its determination to put Mr Milosevic on trial for war crimes, whereas Mr Kostunica, a constitutional lawyer, has refused to recognise the Hague tribunal. Should Mr Milosevic fetch up in Russia, it would be expected to hand him over as it is a member of the UN security council.

Tony Blair, in Warsaw for a speech on Europe, said: "There is a legal process in respect to Milosevic. The most important thing now is for him to go... the legal process takes its course. Let us hope this is indeed the first day of liberation of the people of Serbia from President Milosevic."

In Belgrade, jubilant crowds roamed the streets early this morning, celebrating the end of 13 years of Mr Milosevic's rule.

Fears persist that there could be counterattacks by remnants of the discredited regime. Through the night, tens of thousands danced and sang in celebration of the seizure of Yugoslavia's parliament and other key symbols of the Milosevic regime.

All state-owned media were working normally, broadcasting or publishing apologies for their past support for Mr Milosevic.

Serb television occasionally flashed its logo during broadcasts, with the slogan: "This is the new free Serbian television."

State-owned or formerly pro-Milosevic dailies issued special editions reflecting the change in their editorial policies.

Politika featured a front-page photograph of Mr Kostunica, his arm raised triumphantly in the air over a headline: "Serbia on the road to democracy".

fields.headline: Eidos undermined by loss of senior staffer
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Eidos, the gaming company which launched the Tomb Raider franchise, has been rocked by the sudden departure of its chief financial officer, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Eidos, the gaming company which launched the Tomb Raider franchise, has been rocked by the sudden departure of its chief financial officer.

The company said Jeremy Lewis had resigned immediately to "pursue a range of other interests", with Eidos shares tumbling 7.5% to 288p on the news.

Eidos stock has been dogged over the past month by takeover rumours and supply problems with Sony's next-generation PlayStation 2 console.

fields.headline: Regime's media mouthpiece falls
fields.standfirst:
State TV: Protesters seize building and set it on fire

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The hated symbol of Slobodan Milosevic's propaganda machine was blazing last night after demonstrators stormed the state television building in Belgrade in the face of teargas and bullets. Two hours later, a crowd watched as five fire crews sought to control the fierce blaze.
fields.body:
The hated symbol of Slobodan Milosevic's propaganda machine was blazing last night after demonstrators stormed the state television building in Belgrade in the face of teargas and bullets. Two hours later, a crowd watched as five fire crews sought to control the fierce blaze.

The authorities knew the television station might be invaded, and from early morning several hundred police were in the building and an armed guard was stationed outside.

A bar worker in a nearby cafe said that youngsters began a two-prong attack on the headquarters of Radio Television Serbia (RTS), from the park behind and from the road. They threw petrol bombs at police.

Branko Pavlovic, a vice-president of the opposition Social Democratic Union, said: "It was pretty nasty. Police responded with tear gas, then rubber bullets, then real bul lets. Then a bulldozer, driven by the demonstrators, started to smash the [entrance to the] building. The demonstrators then set alight a corner of the building and stormed in."

Another man, Vladko Sekulovic, said: "For a moment it seemed as if the police would push people back. There were a lot of shots with real and rubber bullets. The crucial thing was the bulldozer that broke the doors. After that, police stepped back.

Earlier in the day, more than 160 state television employees were dismissed after walking off to demand more objective reporting.

As tens of thousands massed for the anti-Milosevic rally in central Belgrade, a huge cheer went up as dozens of the sacked staff joined the protesters. "Like all sane people, we don't agree with this lunatic editorial policy," said an assistant producer, Geno Juric.

webTitle: Ministry of Sound to publish books

fields.headline: Ministry of Sound plans books launch
fields.trailText: 2pm: The Ministry of Sound is understood to be on the brink of further expansion, with a series of spin-off books lined up for a pre-Christmas launch, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Sound is understood to be on the brink of further expansion, with a series of spin-off books lined up for a pre-Christmas launch.

Mike Dash, publisher of the company's magazine division, would not comment on speculation that the company was going to launch books on the back of its successful magazine brand.

But one insider said: "It's a logical thing to do. We are in the very early stages and the infrastructure isn't in place, but it's something we are working on."

Last week the company recruited Claudette Laws, group advertorials and sponsorship manager at the BBC, as its commercial manager.

Ministry is currently diversifying away from its two magazines, Ministry and Hip Hop Connection, offering a range of services such as new digital radio statio, Digital Dancefloor.

Mr Dash, former publisher at men's magazines publisher John Brown, was recruited earlier this year as managing director of the Ministry of Sound's magazines division, with a brief to look at launching more magazines.

Ministry, launched two years ago by the superclub Ministry of Sound, has been successful in the booming dance music magazines market. It posted a 13.9% period-on-period rise to a circulation of 95,088 in its last ABC figures.

fields.headline: Another setback for Granada Media stock
fields.trailText: 11am: Granada Media's stock had another torrid time on the stock market this morning following a negative note from Merrill Lynch, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Granada Media's stock had another torrid time on the stock market this morning following a negative note from the Merrill Lynch investment bank.

Granada's stock fell 5% to a year low of 422p in early trading after Merrill cut its earnings forecast by £15m to £233m, due to higher digital TV costs and the prospect of paying United News & Media £1.25bn in cash for its ITV interests. The shares recovered to 428p by midday, a fall of 3.7%.

Merrill also slashed its Granada forecasts last week after predicting a drop in broadcast revenues, causing the group's shares to tumble 20% in two days.

Merrill's note said: "There will be higher ONdigital costs, but the payment for United television assets should be in cash, not shares."

Merrill's short-term rating is "neutral", though long-term its recommendation is "accumulate".

fields.headline: Fluoride
fields.standfirst: A new report says adding fluoride to tap water cuts tooth decay. Julian Glover examines the issue
fields.trailText: A new report says adding fluoride to tap water cuts tooth decay. Julian Glover examines the issue.
fields.body:
What is fluoride?
Fluoride is a common chemical - in fact the 13th most common element on earth - and occurs naturally in almost all foods and water supplies. Levels of fluoride vary: some foods, such as tea and fish, contain quite high quantities and some water supplies have high natural concentrations.

What does it do to people?
In small quantities fluoride does not seem to harm people's health - though there have been claims that adding fluoride to people's diet is linked to increased risk of cancer, Downs Syndrome and the crippling bone disease osteoarthritis. In larger quantities scientists also believe that it can actually do good by making tooth enamel more resistant to attack by the acids formed by sugar.

Are they sure?
A report from the University of York has been published which promises to be "the final word" on the subject. It found that children given extra fluoride had around 2.5 fewer decayed, missing or filled teeth than everyone else. That's the good news. The bad is that the study found a "strong association" between taking extra fluoride and a disease called "dental fluorosis", which causes permanently mottled teeth. But the study said there was no strong evidence that adding fluoride created any other adverse effects, such as cancer or an increased risk of bone fractures.

Interesting. But why is fluoride a big issue?
Because for many years dentists have campaigned for fluoride to be added to water supplies, in order to improve people's teeth. Fluoride is already added to water supplies in 60 countries worldwide. In the US 145 million people are exposed to treated water supplies. About 10% of the UK population drinks artificially fluoridated water, mainly in the Midlands and the North East.

How is this done?
Fluoride is added to the water supplies at the treatment plant via two chemicals (hexafluorosilicic acid or disodium hexafluorosilicate) which contain the element. In Britain, the cost is met by the NHS.

What has the response been?
Many people object to fluoridation, partly on health grounds but mainly because they believe that individuals should be left to decide whether or not they want to take fluoride, not have the substance fed to them in tap water without being consulted. This opposition is the reason that most British water is left untreated.

National Pure Water Association British Dental Association

fields.headline: In brief: The Hiding Place by Trezza Azzopardi
fields.standfirst: Post your reviews and comments on the book
fields.trailText: The inclusion of Azzopardi on the Booker shortlist gives a well-deserved fillip to a novel that seemed to come from nowhere and to have been gaining ground steadily ever since. Critical reaction to this searing and delicate family saga was, if anything, on the patronising side, with plenty of tips to a budding author: trust your readers, mind your ending, don't be so relentlessly gloomy and doomy. One has to wonder if they would have been so free with their advice had this been a second or third novel, especially since it was unanimously agreed that Azzopardi was a writer of unquestionable talent.
fields.body:
The inclusion of Azzopardi on the Booker shortlist gives a well-deserved fillip to a novel that seemed to come from nowhere and to have been gaining ground steadily ever since. Critical reaction to this searing and delicate family saga was, if anything, on the patronising side, with plenty of tips to a budding author: trust your readers, mind your ending, don't be so relentlessly gloomy and doomy. One has to wonder if they would have been so free with their advice had this been a second or third novel, especially since it was unanimously agreed that Azzopardi was a writer of unquestionable talent.

The Hiding Place is set in the Cardiff docklands, where a Maltese immigrant hooks up with a pretty young Welsh woman in a disastrous union that produces six daughters before he disappears back on a boat whence he came. The narrator is Dolores, baby of the family, with a hand burnt to a hook in an accident she can only recall through the family anecdotage - she was a baby at the time.

Several reviewers noted the similarity between the novel and Frank McCourt's memoir Angela's Ashes: Dominic Bradbury in the Times went so far as to describe father Frankie as a charmless version of Malachy McCourt. There was some divergence as to how bleak Azzopardi's vision finally was. At one extreme, Andrea Henry in the Mirror placed it in the folksy camp with Angela's Ashes : "You get the tears, the laughter, the poverty, and the same compulsive reading... read it and weep." At the other extreme, Polly Sampson in the Independent was unsettled by the "toe-curling cruelty, the gruesome authenticity of the writing". Maggie O'Farrell in the Observer argued that, though Azzopardi wrote about the extremes of havoc and despair to which a family could be driven, she also showed how the bonds formed within that family could not be destroyed by violence, poverty or time. It is a mark of the quality of Azzopardi's writing that it can enfold such differences in interpretation.

fields.headline: The Serb uprising
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the tumult in Belgrade
fields.trailText: 1. After the election that Slobodan Milosevic lost - if you've got time (it's slow to download) have a look at his hilarious pre-election broadcast - the hectic pace of events in Belgrade has left even local observers gasping. Exhilaration, uncertainty and foreboding are mixed in equal measure.
fields.body:
1. After the election that Slobodan Milosevic lost - if you've got time (it's slow to download) have a look at his hilarious pre-election broadcast - the hectic pace of events in Belgrade has left even local observers gasping. Exhilaration, uncertainty and foreboding are mixed in equal measure.

2. The continuing confusion is reflected in the internet community. Sites supporting the former opposition are struggling to keep up with events, while the mouthpieces of the old regime, like the Information Ministry, have simply abandoned ship. Less than 24 hours old, its incoherent last communique already seems frozen in time.

3. Serbs are enjoying for the first time a torrent of news untainted by official propaganda, as broadcasters and print journalists throw off the shackles of censorship, and join the free media, typified by Radio B2-92, and the Free Serbia website.

4. Already, there are strident demands for the quick release of journalists and other prisoners of conscience locked up by the old regime.

5. Slobodan Milosevic has gone to ground.

6. His last hope, the largely conscript Yugoslav federal army, has opted for neutrality.

7. The de facto new president, Vojislav Kostunica, has appealed to his supporters to remain vigilant against any backlash by the defeated Socialist faction.

8. There are also clouds of uncertainty over the dawn of freedom. The Albanian majority in Kosovo has reacted with caution to the dramatic events in what is theoretically their national capital.

9. Even when the dust settles, there is much unfinished business to be done. Milosevic, the last Soviet-era strongman to be ditched by his people, remains an indicted war criminal.

10. And with Kosovo still effectively under Nato rule, and Montenegro - Serbia's only partner in the rump of the federal republic- threatening to secede, Yugoslavia itself could be doomed to oblivion.

fields.headline: The butt of the joker
fields.body:
Barely believable
Kevin Brown, founding partner of Soul and a successful and no doubt wealthy ad man, is simply unable to resist starring in his own ads. However, friends of his have this week admitted he's now taken things too far by stripping down to the short and curlies - something he appears to have plenty of - for the sake of the Daily Star's "MegaStar" campaign. The poster features a nude - and rather flushed - Mr Brown covering (just) his modesty with a board advertising the site. Mark Cranmer, chief executive at Starcom Motive and a dear friend of his, said: "Kevin has a long history of exhibiting himself. He's done ads promoting gambling, alcohol and now blatant sex. I feel he should have asked for his legs to be retouched, though, because he seems to be suffering from the skinny legs/far gut syndrome that comes to all men as they get older. I love Kevin, but he is mad." Even one of Kevin's co-founders is advising people to turn a blind eye to the stunt. "I wouldn't look at it if I were you - you might find it offensive," he said. You're not wrong, Duncan.

Caught out on a techie point
Programmers panning TV shows? Geeks up in arms about TV stars? What the heck is going on? Anyone would think the BBC had made a show about a dot.com start-up. TV audiences may be unimpressed by This Life 2, the one set in a new media start-up and called Attachments, but those whose lives BBC2 is trying to mimic are even more unimpressed. True, World Productions may have done some homework, but those finicky techies are taking umbrage at any slight faux pas - such as transferring files by throwing floppy disks across the office and talking about downloads and demos as a revenue model. Those that haven't vented their spleen already are invited to do so at Everyonehatesattachments.com. But be careful, these hardcore new media types don't take prisoners.

Invaluable sentiment
Granada Media chairman Charles Allen began his first address to troops of his newly acquired United News & Media by declaring how much his company values programme-makers. Not such a surprising sentiment, you'd imagine, coming from the boss of a company with a significant TV production arm - but the jaws of senior United TV execs hit the floor all the same. Apparently the only word they were used to hearing from former boss Clive Hollick in the same sentence as "value" is "shareholder".

When the caption fits...
Sir Christopher Bland got a morning grilling from the delectable Sophie Raworth (isn't Jeremy looking fetching too with his matching purple tie?) on BBC breakfast news today. Pity about the caption though, which read: "Fiona Mannion: mini owner".

expectingcomplaints.com
Monkey apologies for allowing a cad like Danny Kelly to blatantly pull the wool over readers' eyes in Monday's edition of the Media Guardian. Asked about his favourite websites, Kelly named expectingrain.com and woolyrockstars.com. Pernickety readers, i.e. those that go through absolutely everything with a fine-tooth comb, immediately pointed out that the latter website does not in fact exist. More importantly neither the .com or the .co.uk domain names for Woolyrockstars have been registered. Was Kelly making a mockery of us all or was he merely pointing out a new market niche? Kelly says neither: "I'm very much afraid this thing does exist. The url, however, is woollyrockers.com. Check it out!!" Duh! Monkey did and fell in love with the Bee Gees doll. Could Kelly have created a monster?

Minutes matter
What's this? The BBC's famously impartial news reporting standards slipping over its own 10pm news bulletin announcement? The Monkey has got its paws on an internal email from BBC Online producer James Thornet that was sent round after the news broke to BBC online hacks out in the sticks. He draws his colleagues' attention to the fact that the switch to 10pm means the regional bulletin tacked on at the end of the proper, grown-up news will be extended to a massive six-and-a-half minutes. "We must put this story at the top of online news stories asap," says the excitable Thornett. Is he worried viewers in the regions wouldn't notice the difference otherwise?

Only slimline warriors need apply
Monkey has received an email from Rainbow network, home of Xena fans (see proud to portly, below), anxious to set the record straight. "Firstly, the generosity of Channel 5 in offering Rainbow a box of T-shirts goes without saying - we were delighted to receive them, and we had loads of entrants to the competition in which they were the prize. On opening the eagerly awaited box of goodies, however, we could tell straight away that there was no way, with the best will in the world, anyone other than a small teenager or large Teddy bear was going to be able to get into them.
We closed the competition as images of irate readers struggling to get an arm in a size 6 garment sprang to mind. As Tamara, the Xena co-ordinator at Channel 5, said: 'Annoyingly our merchandise person fits these and didn't consider the more womanly figure, ie me.' We're with you, Tamara!
Some lucky winners did decide to hang on to their prizes, although we still have 35 or so here in the Rainbow office. Send us your address and we'll happily send you one." Monkey is unsure about being compared to a large teddy bear, but may well have to take up Rainbow's kind offer in the spirit of investigation.



Sticky gimmicks
Monkey was amused to discover an overflowing pot of honey in the post today. The honey pot subsequently attacked all surrounding computers and made everything in the office sticky. Eugh. The penny finally dropped when Monkey found the attached (and at this point very sticky) note, saying that eBay was stickier than QXL. Point taken. But did it really have to destroy my workspace to tell me that?

Clash of the dot.com giants
Plunging dot.com stock prices are nothing new, but the long-term ramifications are starting to impact heavily on those big boys we call Amazon and eBay. Rumours have started to surface about a mooted merger between the two e-commerce giants, which have both been rocked by the recent downturn in dot.com fortunes. A tie-up would make sense, particularly for Amazon, which is struggling to convince investors of its long-term earnings. Perhaps it should take a leaf from eBay's gimmick book and start sending out plants and pots of bottled Amazon river water to prove to investors that Amazon can make things grow. Just a (naff) suggestion.

Proud to portly
Channel 5 kindly sent 50 of its finest Xena, Warrior Princess T-shirts to the gay and lesbian website Rainbownetwork.com for a competition giveaway, on account of the pigtailed one being terribly popular with the target audience. Channel 5 was staggered, then, when Rainbow very apologetically sent them all back. It seems the T-shirts are of the cropped belly button-baring variety and, after a bit of market research in the office, Rainbow discovered they were too petite for its users. Seems a shame to let them go to waste, so Monkey is happy to try to squeeze into one to show support.

Bad taste sensation
GMTV managing director Christopher Stoddart is so concerned about reports of tasteless office banter that he has issued an email to all staff reminding them of the company's equal opportunities policy. In a carefully worded memo, he also reminded staff of the company's grievance procedure and told them that they mustn't feel frightened of whistle-blowing on their bosses. "From time to time we will be drawing your attention to important company policies which we all need to follow. Our equal opportunities policy is particularly important because its scope is both on-screen and off-screen," he wrote. "Should any employee have a complaint under this policy [or for any other reason] he should feel free to raise the matter." He continued: "If it concerns their line manager, then they may wish to consult personnel." Who on earth has prompted this and what on earth did he or she say? Answers on the back of a cornflakes box, please.

Rings a bell
Readers of the Scotsman who also take Sunday Business may be suffering from a sense of déja vu. A few weeks ago top Sunday Biz hack Richard Northedge wrote a coruscating profile of some suit or other doing something fantastically important in the City. Two weeks later a frighteningly similar article (exactly the same except for two small amendments) appeared in the Scotsman's revamped business section, albeit under a different byline. Perhaps Northedge should sue for plagiarism. But then the ed-in-chief of the pink Sunday is one Andrew Neil, who is also in charge of the Scotsman. Other Sunday Business hacks should expect further doppelganger copy to start appearing north of the border under increasingly ludicrous invented bylines.

Not quite all over for Wembley commentator
The man who coined the immortal phrase "They think it1s all over..." really did think Wembley was going to be all over without him. Kenneth Wolstenholme, commentator at the historic 1966 England World Cup victory at Wembley over Germany, hadn't been invited to the England-Germany match on Saturday, the final game before the stadium is demolished. Now Sport First has hired the game's most memorable voice to write about the last match. What a joy, says Kenneth. Well, it is now!

What's in a suffix?
Associated New Media finally came clean with its plans and new name for lead balloon CharlotteStreet.com this week, scotching rumours that it was going to launch you.co.uk. Instead we're to get femail.co.uk and rumour has it this new strategy of using the mail suffix will be applied to a number of Associated New Media websites. Staunch Royalist The Mail is said to be keen to develop a site devoted to that bastion of British culture, the Royal family (no, not the TV programme) but unfortunately for The Mail, a certain carrier of letters has already had the foresight to register royalmail.co.uk. Keen checkers of domain name registrations however, will be aware that Associated has already registered travelmail.co.uk, shopmail.co.uk, moneymail.co.uk and financialmail.co.uk. In fact the only one that is still available is showbizmail.co.uk - better snap it up quick.

The poster features a nude - and rather flushed - Mr Brown covering (just) his modesty with a board advertising the site. fields.headline: OpenTV claims 'one-click' TV shopping patent
fields.trailText: 12.15am: The battle for the patent for "one-click" shopping is about to become more cut-throat with OpenTV claiming that it effectively holds the patent for "one-click" TV shopping. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The battle for the patent for "one-click" shopping is about to become more cut-throat with OpenTV, the supplier of interactive television software, claiming that it effectively holds the patent for "one-click" TV shopping.

OpenTV has filed an application with the US Patent & Trademark Office to broaden the scope of one of its patents - filed more than three year ago - that describes "single interaction shopping in client/server and interactive television environments".

If it is decided OpenTV's existing patent implies that it has the rights to "one click" shopping and set-top box storage of personal information, Amazon.com, which was last year granted the US patent for "one-click" shopping, could be precluded from using its patent against anyone, according to OpenTV.

OpenTV president and chief operating officer James Ackerman, who joined in July from interactive platform Open (no relation), said: "One click shopping is very useful to interactive television. It's so easy to place an order by simply pressing one button on the TV remote control. We believe that our intellectual property and our technology provide OpenTV with a clear leadership position in the market for interactive television commerce."

OpenTV, which is controlled by the South African MIH group, with shareholders including AOL, Motorola, General Instrument, Liberty Digital, News Corporation and Time Warner, builds the software and infrastructure platform that enables digital interactive TV. In the UK, the company developed the infrastructure for BSkyB.

webTitle: Aiding and Abetting by Muriel Spark

fields.headline: Aiding and Abetting by Muriel Spark
fields.standfirst:
Viking, £12
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Dame Muriel puts her mind to Lord Lucan, who disappeared 25 years ago after the murder of his children's nanny. Two Lord Lucans turn up at the Paris consulting rooms of Dr Hildegard Wolf, but only one has a story that is all-consuming
fields.body:
"I have sold myself to the devil."

"Let me tell you about myself," replied Dr Hildegard Wolf, who had become Paris's most successful psychiatrist by virtually ignoring her patients for their first three sessions.

"I am Lord Lucan," Lucky eventually said a month later. "There is another Lord Lucan in Paris at the moment," she replied, "whom I am also seeing. He goes by the name of Walker."

Hildegard reflected on the merits of the two Lord Lucans with her long-time companion, Jean-Pierre. "It could be either or none of them."

"You are the fake stigmatic, Beate Pappenheim, who was exposed in 1986," said Walker at their next session. "I take it you want money. Prove you are Lord Lucan and I'll pay you."

"Why didn't you tell me?" asked Jean-Pierre. "They must be in league together."

"I suppose your accomplice told you that I am Pappenheim," said Hildegard.

"I know the name, but I have no accomplice," replied Lucky. "Do you think the lower orders bleed more than we aristocrats?"

"Which of you is real?" asked Hildegard.

"I am," said Walker. "Lucky is my accomplice. I hired him to collect the money my friends put at my disposal."

Hildegard fled to London. Ever since her secret had come out she had known she would have to go into hiding. Jean-Pierre rifled through her diary looking for clues to her whereabouts; he called a Dr Jacobs. "London is where I would hide," said the doctor.

"I'm going to have to kill Walker," mused Lucky. He had been fortunate to have been given Walker by one of his friends in Mexico 10 years ago. But his usefulness was over. As Lucky's friends died off, the funds dried up and new DNA tests meant they could no longer pass off as one another.

Jean-Pierre discussed the Lucan problem with Dr Jacobs. "They need to go back to Africa."

"They went to work for my grandfather in central Africa," Jacobs later reported. "Unfortunately, Lucky was clubbed to death and eaten by the children. My grandfather thought it would turn them into earls."

"And Walker?"

"Back in Mexico."

Suddenly, thought Hildegard, the world seemed a little cleaner.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested:

fields.headline: Holby City operates successfully on BBC1 ratings
fields.trailText: 12pm overnights:BBC1 staged a peak time ratings recovery last night, following its Wednesday night disaster, thanks to EastEnders and the return of Holby City. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1 staged a peak time ratings recovery last night, following its Wednesday night disaster, thanks to EastEnders and the return of Holby City.

The channel averaged 31.6% in peaktime (7-10.30pm) last night (Wednesday: 18.5%); while ITV slipped back to 34.6%, from 42% the previous evening, according to unofficial overnights.

EastEnders averaged 11.7m/55% from 7.30pm (the previous night Battersea Dogs Home managed just 3.2m/15% against Coronation Street), anchoring the BBC1 evening line-up and helping pull the ratings for the rest of the schedule up to more respectable levels. This on a night when Coronation Street was not around to do the same for ITV.

Following on at 8pm, the new run of hospital drama Holby City (7.2m/31%) opened respectably in a tough slot, pegging back Who Wants to be a Millionaire? (9.7m/41%). On Wednesday night BBC1 offering The Dream Academy drew just 3.9m/18% against The Bill.

The BBC1 9pm news - doubtles boosted by events in Serbia - averaged 6.3m/29% (Wednesday: 4.5m/20%); while from 9.30pm schoolroom drama Hope & Glory rallied to a still disappointing 5.2m/26% (3.9m/19%). From 9-11pm ITV had the concluding instalment of Trial and Retribution IV (6.4m/33%).

Elsewhere last night, Channel 5's fast turnaround profile, The Paula Yates Story, drew 1m/4%, 8-9pm; while on Channel 4, 8-9.30pm, repeated documentary Hitler's Search for the Holy Grail took 1.7m/8%.

Both channels grew stronger as the evening wore on. From 9pm Channel 5 had movie DNA (2m/10%) and adult documentary G-String Divas (1.3m/10%), 10.50-11.25pm. Channel 4 debuted encryption documentary the Science of Secrecy (2m/10%) at 9.30pm and followed up with the Mobo Awards (1.4m/10%), 10-11.35pm.

The third outing this week for The 11 O'Clock Show's new presenting team of Jon Holmes and Sarah Alexander was watched by a healthy 0.8m/13% on Channel 4 from 11.35pm. The new series debuted on Tuesday night at 11.05pm (1.1m/11%) and on Wednesday went out at 11pm (1m/9%).

webTitle: In brief: 'Simple entertainer' Archer courted by Hollywood

fields.headline: 'Simple entertainer' Archer courted by Hollywood
fields.trailText: Plus: No Coens for Ocean's Eleven, George busts a gasket over leaks, Jennifer Love Hewitt plays it devilish and Richard Stanley returns after Moreau fiasco
fields.body:
 Former Conservative party vice-chairman Lord Archer has been approached by Hollywood to become a film star. The 60-year-old, currently on police bail for charges of perverting the course of justice has admitted he has been offered four film roles, including three from Hollywood. He is currently appearing in a play called The Accused. The disgraced peer who describes himself as "a simple entertainer" reveals: "My agent is dealing with the offers. I would like to be in a film, possibly in America. I enjoy acting immensely. I concentrate on it fully. I am literally not thinking about anything else at the moment."

 It seems the Coen brothers will now not be appearing in Stephen Soderbergh's adaptation of the Rat Pack film Ocean's Eleven. According to Ain't It Cool, twin actors Mark and Michael Polish (recently seen playing conjoined twins in the strange Twin Falls Idaho) have been bought in to take over the roles of the hapless getaway drivers from original cast members Owen and Luke Wilson

 Star Wars honcho George Lucas is supposedly getting fed up with leaks from the set of Episode II appearing on the internet. Lucas is reportedly furious after photos, storyboards and shoot schedules (some fished from rubbish bins) have appeared on fan websites. He has demanded that security be stepped up on set.

Jennifer Love Hewitt is to star as the devil in Alec Baldwin's directorial debut The Devil and Daniel Webster. She will star alongside Anthony Hopkins and Baldwin in a story about a struggling writer who makes a pact with the devil to become a bestselling author. "It's definitely a different role than I normally take,but the character is amazing and incredibly well-written," Hewitt told the Hollywood Reporter. "It is a more grown-up role for me. And I want to show that I am growing as a woman and human being and am ready to take on more adult roles."

Controversial director Richard Stanley is steadily returning to the public eye with the announcement of his third film since being unceremoniously booted off The Island of Doctor Moreau in 1996. According to Screendaily South African-born Stanley is to return to the sci-fi genre of his 1990 debut Hardware, in a $9m futurist thriller called In A Season Of Soft Rains. Set in the UK after a revolution, the story focuses on an American assassin planning to kill a young English prince who is hiding out in Wales. Shooting is due to begin early next year.

.

I am literally not thinking about anything else at the moment."  It seems the Coen brothers will now not be appearing in Stephen Soderbergh's adaptation of the Rat Pack film Ocean's Eleven. According to Ain't It Cool, twin actors Mark and Michael Polish (recently seen playing conjoined twins in the strange Twin Falls Idaho) have been bought in to take over the roles of the hapless getaway drivers from original cast members Owen and Luke Wilson  Star Wars honcho George Lucas is supposedly getting fed up with leaks from the set of Episode II appearing on the internet. Lucas is reportedly furious after photos, storyboards and shoot schedules (some fished from rubbish bins) have appeared on fan websites. He has demanded that security be stepped up on set. Jennifer Love Hewitt is to star as the devil in Alec Baldwin's directorial debut The Devil and Daniel Webster. She will star alongside Anthony Hopkins and Baldwin in a story about a struggling writer who makes a pact with the devil to become a bestselling author. "It's definitely a different role than I normally take,but the character is amazing and incredibly well-written," Hewitt told the Hollywood Reporter. "It is a more grown-up role for me. And I want to show that I am growing as a woman and human being and am ready to take on more adult roles." Controversial director Richard Stanley is steadily returning to the public eye with the announcement of his third film since being unceremoniously booted off The Island of Doctor Moreau in 1996. According to Screendaily South African-born Stanley is to return to the sci-fi genre of his 1990 debut Hardware, in a $9m futurist thriller called In A Season Of Soft Rains. Set in the UK after a revolution, the story focuses on an American assassin planning to kill a young English prince who is hiding out in Wales. Shooting is due to begin early next year. .

fields.headline: New Media Markets round-up
fields.standfirst: Published on October 6
fields.trailText: October 6: Channel 5 is considering launching new services on digital TV and taking back the spare capacity that it leases.
fields.body:
Channel 5 is considering launching new services on digital TV, according to New Media Markets. The station is one of the few free-to-air broadcasters not to have used up all of its extra multiplex capacity and it is considering taking back the spare capacity it leases to SDN, which in turn is leased to ONdigital's pay-per-view movie service Onrequest.

Spanish telecoms company Cableuropa is to press ahead with its planned flotation. The company, which in Spain trades as Ono, is selling just over 20 per cent of its equity, and looks set to raise between E270m (£162m) and E388m.

Carlton Active, the interactive division of Carlton Communications, is said to be putting pressure on ONdigital, in which Carlton owns a 50 per cent stake, to as soon as possible establish return path capability in its hardware.

Telewest has relaunched its cancelled digital cable offering, following its suspension three months ago. And there is speculation that Telewest will be swallowed in a "complex carve-up", in which UPC and Microsoft could transfer Telewest's assets over to NTL in order to take control of NTL's European holdings.

fields.headline: Strong earthquake hits western Japan
fields.standfirst: Map
fields.trailText: A very strong earthquake struck south western Japan, destroying at least six homes, burying three people in  landslides, and cutting off power supplies to thousands of houses and businesses, police said.
fields.body:
A very strong earthquake struck south western Japan, destroying at least six homes, burying three people in landslides, and cutting off power supplies to thousands of houses and businesses, police said.

The quake was even stronger than the 7.2 magnitude one that struck Kobe, Japan, in January 17, 1995, killing 6,425 people and destroying 250,000 homes.

National television showed live footage of workers at an NHK broadcasting newsroom in Matsue city clutching desks as notebooks fell to the floor. One hanging lamp was shown swinging wildly back and forth.

In other buildings in the city, the white foam of ceiling fire extinguishers set off by the quake could be seen raining down from balconies onto the streets.

In Hinocho town, a small hospital shook so violently that the staff evacuated all 80 patients from the building to check it for damage.

"It was so strong that I couldn't stand up," Shinichi Nagami, a government spokesman in the large city of Sakaiminato, said on national television. Cracks appeared in the walls of some of the buildings there, NHK reported.

The quake also knocked over display cases at stores and supermarkets in Yonago city, and television showed shattered glass and products strewn across the floors of several shops.

At least 10 landslides were caused by the earthquake across the large, hilly region, including one that blocked a railroad line and one that closed part of a two-lane highway.

Six homes in Tottori prefecture, or state, collapsed, and one man was injured when the roof of his home fell on him, said Toshikatsu Naoi, a National Police Agency spokesman.

Three other people were hurt when they were buried in landslides and rescued by civilians and local officials. Two of the victims were trapped inside their car. The third man suddenly disappeared while working at a roadside construction site.

The tremor was so strong it was felt 155 miles away in Suzuka city, where drivers from around the world were practicing for the F-1 Grand Prix auto race on Sunday.

Shortly after the earthquake struck at 1:30pm (04:30 GMT), officials closed several railway lines and highways to check for damage, NHK reported. Two nuclear reactors had recently been shut down in Tottori prefecture for repairs before the quake struck.

The tremor cut electricity supplies to nearly 9,300 homes and businesses, and many traffic lights at intersections, but power was restored to most of them soon afterward, Kyodo News agency said. At least one water pipe ruptured. The magnitude 7.3 earthquake was centred six miles beneath Tottori prefecture, 315 miles southwest of Tokyo, the Japan Meteorological Agency said. A 7.0-magnitude quake is capable of causing heavy, widespread damage.

Despite the strength of the quake, and many powerful aftershocks, the agency said no tsunami was expected in the Japan Sea along the coast of the prefecture.

fields.headline: Plane fare
fields.standfirst: It tastes funny. It comes in odd little containers. And it was cooked up to eight hours earlier.  Victoria Moore on why the appointment of a professor in airline food can't come too soon
fields.trailText: It tastes funny. It comes in odd little containers. And it was cooked up to eight hours earlier. Victoria Moore on why the appointment of a professor in airline food can't come too soon.
fields.body:
Food tastes different at 30,000ft. And that's nothing to do with the "Ooh, I'm in an aeroplane off on my holidays," effect. It actually does taste different. No one knows why this should be, nor even whether it is the food itself that is materially altered at altitude, or the palate's ability to interpret flavours or, indeed, whether everything just tastes odd when you eat it from a plastic tray, legs scrunched up half to your chest, chin butting against the seat in front, surrounded by screaming children.

Soon, though, we should find out, because this is just one point on a long list of tasks that will be assigned to the new professor of airline food at the University of Surrey whose imminent appointment was announced this week. "So much fun has been made of airline food but it's a big industry," says Willie Seeman, founder-president of the International Flight Catering Association (IFCA) which represents all major airline food producers and is funding the appointment. The professor will have a three-pronged brief: to do research into the industry, to teach, and to cooperate closely with the IFCA committees that work on food safety, education and care for the environment.

We have come a long way since Charles Lindbergh made his 34-hour solo flight across the Atlantic with just five sandwiches in his travelling bag. In-flight catering is now a £10bn-a-year global industry employing more than 100,000 people. Virgin Atlantic says catering is its third biggest cost, behind fuel and engineering and maintenance. A jumbo jet preparing to set out on a long-haul flight may be loaded with up to 42,000 separate catering items. British Airways passengers flying out of London Heathrow chew their way through 70,000 meals each day and consume 41 tonnes of chicken breasts, 45 tonnes of strawberries, 127 tonnes of tomatoes and 600,000 pints of milk every year. All BA meals are cooked two to eight hours before they are needed and are kept chilled before being loaded onto the plane where they are reheated in ovens that have the capacity to steam and bake. First class and business class meals are at least partially fresh - you can boil an egg and cook pasta on a plane.

"Psychologically we attach great importance to the food we're given in the air," says David Airey, head of the school of management studies at the University of Surrey. "I get very agitated if I'm not served quickly, or if my wine doesn't come straight away with my food, in a way that I just don't in restaurants on the ground. And if I think I'm going to miss my turn I get very upset too."

For airline passengers may be a captive audience but they are also highly critical. Now that air travel is as routine as boarding the 8.43am to Waterloo we're not willing to forgive those who fail to meet the exacting standards demanded by our newly educated palates. Though this doesn't explain why we get so ridiculously worked up about it.

"The actual purpose of the carrier is to get people from A to B without killing them and if everything goes all right they forget this," points out Michael Kipps, co-author of a book on flight catering and professor of food management at Surrey. "The only variable part of the service is the food and that's why we talk about it so much."

So will the appointment of a professor make airline food more tasty, and bring more sophisticated meals to our laps?

"We're trying to bring restaurants into the skies," says British Airways which, like the other major airlines, commission extensive research into passenger appetites. According to both BA and Virgin, we want three things: nutritious and healthy food; the ability to control both what and when we eat; and menus to reflect the sort of food we eat on the ground.

The core menu choices in Virgin's economy class are roast beef with Yorkshire pudding, roast potatoes, broccoli and gravy; chicken korma with coriander rice; and pasta with roast vegetables and goat's cheese. On a typical flight, 40% of passengers will go for the roast, 40% for the korma and the remaining 20% for the vegetarian pasta.

But travellers are a tricky lot to please. BA was surprised when no one wanted to eat beef rangdang, a dish they put on their world traveller menu. It turned out that no one knew quite what it was. So the airline changed its name to Malaysian-style beef curry and its popularity soared.

Some airlines have developed a system that allows people to order food whenever their body-clock demands it. Virgin calls it the freedom menu and says that, while it offers a range of sophisticated dishes from aromatic Thai prawns to beef medallions, the favourite for businessmen returning from meetings in the Far East or America is that old comfort food, the bacon sarnie.

What you eat out of is also critical. In economy class foil containers have in many cases been replaced by a more pleasing plastic version. Passengers who upgrade get proper cups and plates. BA has just signed a contract with Wedgwood while Virgin has found that what their customers like to drink with their bacon butties is tea - in a mug rather than a cup.

In a few years time we might reach the stage where, on short-haul flights at least, the airline doesn't serve us food on the plane but allows us to buy it from the departure lounge. There would be scope for much more choice but Michael Kipps doesn't think airlines will ever let it happen. "The debris on the aircraft afterwards would be dreadful."

So, for now, that idea remains nothing more than pie in the sky.
