fields.headline: Obscure authors make Booker history
fields.standfirst: But Atwood and Ishiguro emerge favourites for £21,000 prize as unprecedented shortlist is unveiled
fields.trailText: Atwood and Ishiguro have emerged as favourites for £21,000 prize as an unprecedented shortlist is unveiled.
fields.body:
The £21,000 Booker prize yesterday threw up a surprise unprecedented in its 30 years as the country's most influential literary award.

Its judges unveiled a shortlist of six which included three little-known authors, one of them a woman first novelist.

Their three novels have sold a total of only 553 copies in Britain. But now Trezza Azzopardi, Michael Collins and Brian O'Doherty can expect this figure to rise at least tenfold thanks to the pulling power of the Booker.

The more eminent novelists they beat include Muriel Spark, Doris Lessing, JG Ballard, Julian Barnes, Fay Weldon, AS Byatt, Michael Ondaatje and Zadie Smith, whose novel White Teeth was shortlisted for the Orange prize.

Yesterday morning copies of their work were being snapped up at Waterstone's bookshop, in Hampstead, north London, as customers heard about the shortlist by grapevine.

"I am so glad the judges have gone so deep into the pile of novels and found these titles," said the manager, Francis Cleverdon. "They are all very well thought of."

O'Doherty's The Deposition of Daniel McGreevy, his second novel, is published by a tiny London press, Arcadia. The other two are Azzopardi's The Hiding Place (Picador) and Collins's third novel The Keepers of Truth (Phoenix House).

On the shortlist, these relatively obscure authors stand beside two of the literary book world's bigger established names: the 1989 Booker winner Kashuo Ishiguro, who is in the final six for When We Were Orphans (Faber and Faber), and the Canadian author Margaret Atwood, listed for the fourth time with The Blind Assassin (Bloomsbury).

The sixth author, Matthew Kneale, who has won two other awards for novels, wins a place for The English Passengers (Hamish Hamilton).

Julian Barnes's Love, Etc, a sequel to his 1992 story Talking It Over, almost made the shortlist, according to one person close to the judging. So did White Teeth. But another source disputed these claims.

Insiders tipped Atwood and Ishiguro as likeliest to win the prize, to be announced on November 7. Azzopardi was named a potential outside candidate for her picture of the 1960s Maltese underworld in Cardiff.

Atwood is early favourite at 2-1, the bookmakers William Hill said yesterday. Second favourite is Ishiguro at 5-2, Kneale is 4-1, Collins 9-2, and O'Doherty 5-1, with Azzopardi the outsider.

The prize administrator Martyn Goff said yesterday the shortlist was unprecedented not only for the number of lesser-known writers but for its completely open field. "In 30 years, there hasn't previously been a time when I have felt unable to forecast a winner. This year any of the six could win.

"People have often said about some books in previous shortlists 'I gave that up after 50 pages'. This year they are all very readable."

He added: "There was a pretty general disappointment among the judges in the work of most of the major names. This led them to look more closely at the rest."

The latest pre-shortlist sales figures for the six titles highlight the importance of literary prizes in pump-priming the dismally low demand for quality modern novels. By last week Atwood's recently published novel had sold 1,069 copies, according to high street figures from Whitaker BookTrack. Azzopardi had sold 227, Collins 184, Ishiguro 8,408, Kneale 1,120, and O'Doherty 142.

Six of the best

The Blind Assassin

Margaret Atwood, 60

Bloomsbury, £16.99

Guardian odds 9/2

This long, structurally complex novel features the elderly Iris Chase Griffen reviewing her life, and, in particular, her relationship with her sister Laura, whose premature death in the 1940s affords her icon status as the author of a scandalous novel. That book, also entitled The Blind Assassin, blends the story of a forbidden love affair with pulp sci-fi, and excerpts from it are interspersed with Iris's account. Atwood's exploration of themes of authorship, secrecy and female fulfilment also accommodates much historical material concerning industrialism and labour relations leading up to the second world war.

The Hiding Place

Trezza Azzopardi, 39

Picador, £14.99

Odds 3/1

Azzopardi's debut novel is more daring in setting and content than those of many novice writers, which might account for the attention she has garnered in literary circles. A world away from the hip, slender metropolitan tale, The Hiding Place centres on the Maltese community in Cardiff in the 1960s. It is narrated by Dolores, youngest daughter of compulsive gambler Frankie Gauci and his long-suffering Welsh wife, Mary. Her story, complete with the machinations of the local Mr Big, the various fates of her four elder sisters, and a terrible accident that she meets with as a baby, is searingly painful and vividly communicated.

The Keepers of Truth

Michael Collins, 36

Phoenix House, £9.99

Odds 7/1

Bill is a washed-up, washed-out reporter for a dying newspaper in a moribund mid-western town. He has grand dreams of composing requiems on the death of the American dream, but the baking contests must still be reported, and his fancy prose is licked into shape by a hard-drinking, old-school editor. Only with the disappearance of Old Man Lawton and the determination of the local cops to fix murder on his son, Ronny, does the dust of the place get under Bill's nails.

When We Were Orphans

Kazuo Ishiguro, 46

Faber & Faber, £16.99

Odds 7/2

Ishiguro's first novel for five years, following the complex and intractable The Unconsoled, is an unusual detective story set in 1930s England. Its narrator, the celebrated sleuth Christopher Banks, looks back on his Shanghai boyhood and the mysterious disappearance of his parents, prompting an emotional journey to "the foreign land of childhood" and a literal return to China. Banks's poignant ruminations on his past, combined with his inability to speak freely of his feelings, puts one in mind of Stevens, the butler-hero of Ishiguro's Booker prize-winning The Remains of the Day.

English Passengers

Matthew Kneale, 40

Hamish Hamilton, £15.99

Odds 6/1

This riotously populated long novel tells the 19th century voyage by ship to Tasmania of a motley bunch among whose number lurk an English reverend, who hopes to prove through geography the real existence of Eden, and a surgeon who nurtures disturbing racist theories. The ship is crewed by crafty, smuggling Manxmen, who have taken on the hazardous journey only in order to pay off a customs fine. Meanwhile, the aboriginal population of the island is being hunted to extinction by white settlers. Central to the story is Peevay, a native boy who offers to guide the Englishmen's expedition into the mountainous heart of his homeland.

The Deposition of Father McGreevy

Brian O'Doherty, 72

Arcadia, £11.99

Odds 8/1

This tale of decay in rural Ireland is framed as a deposition by a heartbroken priest after he has been defrocked for what amounts to the death of his mountain village in County Kerry. In fact, Father McGreevy tried desperately to halt the decline, to grapple with poverty and superstition, and to prevent the heartless dispersal of his people. The village died during the second world war, but the tale is punctuated by footnotes supposedly written in the 1950s by a rakish magazine editor who came upon the story of this, his birthplace, while drinking in a London pub.

fields.headline: Media Week round-up
fields.trailText: October 6: The BBC has unveiled an unashamedly populist peaktime schedule that will support the move of BBC1's news on October 15.
fields.body:
The BBC has unveiled an unashamedly populist peaktime schedule that will support the move of BBC1's news on October 15.

Granada Enterprises has only reserved two positions on its board for senior TSMS executives when the two sales houses merge next year.

MindShare has picked up Nike's £60m centralised media account.

Emap Performance has appointed BBC Music Entertainment head Trevor Dann as managing director with responsibility for pop bands.

Optimedia has beaten Carat in a head-to-head pitch for the £5m media task for Conde Nast's Glamour.

Bass Pubs has dropped Sky Digital's pay sports services from its 500 pubs, and could introduce ONdigital.

The Evening Standard is launching an interactive magazine called hot:disk.

Emap Performance has appointed BBC Music Entertainment head Trevor Dann as managing director with responsibility for pop bands. Optimedia has beaten Carat in a head-to-head pitch for the £5m media task for Conde Nast's Glamour. fields.headline: Yugoslav army 'accepts Milosevic demise'
fields.trailText: The Yugoslav army today indicated its acceptance of the uprising that overthrew Slobodan Milosevic by saying it will act only if its military facilities, personnel and material goods come under direct threat.
fields.body:
The Yugoslav army today indicated its acceptance of the uprising that overthrew Slobodan Milosevic by saying it will act only if its military facilities, personnel and material goods come under direct threat.

The Tanjug news agency, which yesterday abandoned its support for the Milosevic regime, said the top army leadership had met early this morning. Citing sources close to the army leadership, it said: "The Yugoslav army remains consistent to the stands publicly announced several times that it will act within its constitutional powers."

Today's meeting, a day after opposition supporters took control of the Yugoslav parliament building and state media, is seen as crucial to the outcome of the popular revolt as it appears that the army and security forces have accepted as a fait accompli the end of Mr Milosevic's reign.

The army will take comfort from the fact that Vojislav Kostunica, the opposition leader who has been declared president after last month's presidential election, does not accept the jurisdiction of the Hague tribunal on war crimes and is a fervent Serb nationalist.

No movements by military units were reported anywhere in the country today. Momcilo Perisic, a former army chief of staff and now an opposition figure, said he had contacted Yugoslavia's military leaders and that they had promised not to intervene.

The whereabouts of Mr Milosevic are unclear, but there are reports that he is in a bunker in Beljanica, some 25 miles west of the town of Bor, which is close to the Romanian and Bulgarian borders.

The Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, arrived in Belgrade today, the first foreign official to arrive in Serbia since yesterday's tumultuous events. He is to meet Mr Kostunica and there were suggestions that he would also meet Mr Milosevic. But Russia, one of Yugoslavia's traditional allies, says the question of asylum for the fallen tyrant is not under consideration.

Russia's Interfax news agency quoted the Russian prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, as saying that the question of asylum "has not been raised and is not being discussed. We are a long way from looking at the question in that way."

In Belgrade, jubilant crowds roamed the streets early this morning, celebrating the end of 13 years of Mr Milosevic's rule. Fears persist that there could be counterattacks by remnants of the discredited regime. Through the night, tens of thousands danced and sang in celebration of the seizure of Yugoslavia's parliament and other key symbols of the Milosevic regime.

All state-owned media were working normally, broadcasting or publishing apologies for their past support for Mr Milosevic. Serb television occasionally flashed its logo during broadcasts, with the slogan: "This is the new free Serbian television."

State-owned or formerly pro-Milosevic dailies issued special editions reflecting the change in their editorial policies. Politika featured a front-page photograph of Mr Kostunica, his arm raised triumphantly in the air over a headline: "Serbia on the road to democracy" with a subtitle describing him as president.

The only voices of dissent in the overwhelmingly positive international reaction to the popular revolt came from Russian officials. The Interfax news agency quoted the head of Russia's communist party, Gennady Zyuganov, as saying he did not approve of events. "This is not democracy, it smells of marijuana, vodka and dollars," he said.

Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, welcomed the overthrow of Mr Milosevic, saying that sanctions against Yugoslavia could be lifted on Monday when the European parliament next meets. He added: "We can then get down to the task of rebuilding."

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE TIMES
fields.body:
THE TIMES

MEDIA PAGES
The life of Conrad Black - extracts from an interview taken from Talk magazine. (p12)
Brian MacArthur's paper round - The Express & the Barclay brothers; do royals sell papers? The freedom of the press. (p13)
Steve Clarke on Greg Dyke - 1200 job cuts in the pipeline at the BBC and more economies on the way but the staff still respect him. (p14)
Raymond Snoddy says that Sir Christopher Bland, the BBC chairman, is trying to defend the indefensible in introducing a 10pm news slot. (p15)
How Anne Robinson has turned Watchdog into a mini television industry in its own right. (p17)
DIARY
A flurry of newsroom bets over the next editor of the Daily Express: firm favourite is Sue Douglas, formerly of the Mail, Mail on Sunday and Sunday Express. (p14)
Parky miffed with the BBC for making it look like his programme was shunted in favour of Vicar of Dibley. (p15)

MAIN PAPER
Lottery commissioners are expected today to unreservedly apologise for getting the bidding process wrong. (p16)
AOL deal cleared as EMI calls off merger. (p27&31)
Barclay brothers in talks with the Express. (p27)

THE GUARDIAN

The Barclay brothers have approached the Sunday Business editor, Jeff Randall, about the editorship of the Daily Express. (p8)
The People's Lottery has accused Camelot of hounding the National Lottery commissioner Dame Helena Shovelton out of office. (p8)
Race to save EMI/Time Warner deal. (p25)
Teamtalk, the publisher of sports information on the internet, is to supply football news to AOL. (p27)

THE INDEPENDENT

Camelot has called for the lottery regulator to make further concessions in its dispute over the next licence. (p5)
EMI insists that its proposed deal with Time Warner's music division is not being abandoned. (p16)
China Mobile deal triggers strong Vodafone demand. (p21)

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Tobacco advert ban reversed. (p15)
Time Warner puts AOL before EMI. (p33) and comment (p35)

FINANCIAL TIMES

The government intends to strip BBC governors of their regulatory powers following their snap decision to change the time of the evening news. (p1)
The National Lottery regulator will apologise today for being unfair to Camelot. (p3)
EMI and Warner still aim to merge. (p21-22)
Barclay brothers table an offer for Express titles. (p22)
Teamtalk.com, the internet sports content supplier signs deal with AOL. (p24)
Lachlan Murdoch has been made deputy chief operating officer for News Corporation Worldwide. (p28)

WALL STREET JOURNAL

Time Warner and EMI deal scrapped. (p1&10)
European court overturns ban by EU on tobacco advertising. (p3)

DAILY EXPRESS

Tobacco advert ban is illegal say European judges. (p15)
Three members of the National Lottery commission had personal ties with Richard Branson and his People's Lottery bid. (p22)
EMI/Warner deal hits a sour note. (p71)
BSkyB's pay TV service has been dropped from 500 pubs by Bass because of a subscriptions hike. (p71)

THE MIRROR

The Royle Family is to return with new baby: the Mirror has the first photos. (p3)
Parkinson to return to prime time Saturday night slot. (p15)

THE SUN

TV chefs come to blows - this time it's Gordon Ramsey and Ainsley Harriot (p3)

And finally

DAILY STAR

Claire Strutton, of the Big Brother clan, claims that co-star Craig has ruined her sex life. (p1&5)
Phillippa Forrester, Trude Mostue and Charlie Dimmock to front new BBC animal shows.
The new Royle Family baby. (p11)

webTitle: McCann poised to scoop £105m Opel account

fields.headline: McCann poised to scoop £105m Opel account
fields.trailText: 9.15am: General Motors Corp is poised to appoint McCann-Erickson Worldwide to its £105m Opel account, says Jade Garrett
fields.body:
General Motors Corp is poised to appoint McCann-Erickson Worldwide to its £105m Opel account.

The move promotes McCann to Opel's main European agency. It also means the UK is now the only significant European market where Lowe Lintas & Partners handles the GM account - known in the UK as Vauxhall. McCann will run the business from its German offices.

After nearly 60 years of handling the Opel account in Germany, McCann lost the then £19m business unexpectedly in 1986 to sister agency Lowe Howard-Spink. Lowe then set up a Frankfurt office for the blue-chip client.

IPG's November 1999 merger of Ammirati Puris Lintas (APL) and Lowe & Partners Worldwide to form Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide put pressure on this relationship. Problems occurred because a former APL subsidiary was handling some Toyota business.

There have been suggestions that Opel has not been happy with Lowe's work. The Opel Agila mini car rolled out in May was backed by a campaign through McCann, and not Lowe Lintas.

fields.headline: Wanadoo posts £40m pre-tax loss
fields.trailText:
9am: French internet service provider Wanadoo has boosted customer revenues and increased its user base, but the good news sent its balance sheet into the red, says Dan Milmo.
Wanadoo's fortunes may reflect stock market ambivalence
fields.body:
French internet service provider Wanadoo has boosted customer revenues and increased its user base, but the good news sent its balance sheet into the red.

The company posted a first-half pre-tax loss of E66.9m (£40m), against an operating profit of E39.6m for the whole of 1999. Wanadoo was reporting its first set of results since being spun off from parent company France Telecom in July.

Wanadoo said revenues were E456.3m, at the bottom end of analysts' expectations, and the number of active users had risen from 1.38m in June to 1.5m in September.

A six-month E110.1m investment spree appears to have paid off, however, as the average revenue per customer rose from E8.4 for the whole of 1999 to E9.4.

"Bearing in mind the continued growth of internet activities and the seasonal nature of the directories business, the group should be able to achieve second-half turnover significantly above that of the first half," Wanadoo said.

fields.headline: Dark Angel and West Wing lead out US season
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Titanic director James Cameron's first foray onto the small-screen, post-apocalyptic drama Dark Angel, made a strong debut on the Fox network in the US this weekt. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Titanic director James Cameron's first foray onto the small-screen, post-apocalyptic drama Dark Angel, made a strong debut on the Fox network in the US on Tuesday night.

The two-hour pilot, which is reputed to have cost $8m, averaged 17.4m viewers from 9pm, with an 11 rating/16 share, according to preliminary Nielsen ratings.

The Cameron drama was helped by the fact that ABC and CBS were showing the first Bush-Gore presidential debate, but still turned in a promising performance.

Dark Angel helped Fox to its best ever Tuesday primetime ratings and drew a bigger audience than any of the channel's 1999-2000 dramas except the season premiere of The X Files.

On Wednesday night, the magisterial return of White House drama West Wing helped NBC to a comfortable ratings win. The two-hour episode, which unravelled the cliff-hanger end to the first series,, was the most watched show of the evening, with 18.7/27.

Titans, the new Aaron Spelling soap starring Yasmine Bleeth, Caspar Van Dien and Victoria Principal, also had a promising first outing on NBC earlier that evening. Titans rated a respectable 9.3/14 from 8pm, against ABC's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? (13/20).

fields.headline: Deutsche Telekom's debt rating gets a red flag
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The debt rating of Germany's Deutsche Telekom has been slashed, as fears mount that European telecoms companies are sinking too far into the red, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The debt rating of Germany's Deutsche Telekom has been slashed, as fears mount that European telecoms companies are sinking too far into the red.

Credit rating agency Moody's Investors Service cut Deutsche's long-term debt rating from Aa2 to A2, following the company's E15.5bn (£9.2bn) outlay on third generation mobile phone licenses in the UK, the Netherlands and Germany.

Moody's said Deutsche's investments in the wireless, internet and data markets leave it well positioned to take advantage of those sectors, but they "expose the group to substantially greater business risk because of integration risk and the volatile nature of these markets."

British Telecom and Telefonica of Spain have also received ratings downgrades since the E50.5bn (£30bn) German mobile phone licence auction in August. BT is committed to shaving £10bn off its £28bn debt burden by the end of next year, with the flotation of BT's Wireless division becoming the most likely option.

Telefonica is to float its mobile phone arm at the end of the year, with Orange set to be spun off from parent company France Telecom in early 2001 as BT's European rivals rush their IPOs to market. Analysts are concerned that the impact of the share offerings will be diluted by a crowded IPO market.

Nigel Hawkins, telecoms analyst at Williams de Bro, said: "The tip is to get your IPO away quickly, so Moviles and Orange are well positioned. But a BT Wireless flotation may be several months away, if it is to happen at all."

webTitle: Space shuttle launch postponed until Monday

fields.headline: Space shuttle launch postponed until Monday
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Discovery's flight to the international space station has been postponed until next week because of a sluggish valve and suspect bolts.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Discovery's flight to the international space station has been postponed until next week because of a sluggish valve and suspect bolts.

Nasa called off last night's launch because of last-minute concerns over bolts on the external fuel tank. A valve problem found later in the shuttle's main propulsion system delayed liftoff until at least Monday.

The valve, which controls the flow of fuel, appeared to be sluggish during routine operations. Workers will have to enter Discovery's engine compartment to check the valve; to replace it, if necessary, will take three days.

This 100th space shuttle flight is a crucial space station construction mission. Nasa, however, is in no rush.

"We think it's prudent to stand down," shuttle manager James Halsell said. "In other words, we do not want to get 'go fever."'

Before launching Discovery, Nasa also wants to understand what caused a bolt malfunction on the last space shuttle flight. The problem occurred during Atlantis' liftoff on September 8, but was discovered only Wednesday.

While analysing film returned to Earth aboard Atlantis two weeks ago, engineers noticed that one of the three bolts between Atlantis and the external fuel tank did not retract properly eight minutes into the flight. Photographs showed some of the bolt sticking out on the tank.

Nasa wants to determine, among other things, whether the bolt malfunction poses a danger. At worst, a protruding bolt could cause the separated tank to tumble and slam into the shuttle.

"I think the word you use would be 'catastrophic,"' said Halsell, himself a shuttle pilot. "I would not want to expose astronauts to that risk."

Halsell said Nasa remains committed to launching space shuttles seven or eight times a year. Next time, though, the space agency may try to analyse the film more quickly, he noted.

The troublesome bolt from Atlantis is at the bottom of the Atlantic, along with what is left of the rest of the external fuel tank. The 153-foot, rust-coloured tank is jettisoned once the shuttle reaches orbit.

There is evidence of bolt problems on previous flights, including Endeavour's launch in February, said launch manager Bill Gerstenmaier. But the bolts have never protruded like this, he said.

Nasa would not speculate on how long it would take to replace or fix the bolts on Discovery's fuel tank, if that became necessary.

"We hold out all hope that through analysis... we can make ourselves feel comfortable that we're safe to go fly," Halsell said. "I also want to say our minds are wide open; to the possibility of a lengthy delay, he added.

Discovery holds two new segments for the international space station, a girderlike truss and a docking port for future shuttle visits.

Nasa wants these parts installed before the first permanent crew lifts off at the end of the month.

Nasa usually has more time between flights to review all the data from the previous mission, but has quickened its launch pace to build the international space station.

The minimum number of days allowed between shuttle launches is 21. This gap would have been 27 days if Discovery had soared Thursday.

webTitle: Sunday Business strikes co-branding content deal with website

fields.headline: Sunday Business strikes co-branding content deal with website
fields.standfirst: MediaVest
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Sunday Business has followed in the footsteps of the Wall Street Journal Europe and BreakingViews.com by signing a co-branded column deal with a website, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Sunday Business has followed in the footsteps of the Wall Street Journal Europe and BreakingViews.com by signing a co-branded column deal with a website.

The mergers and acquisitions website, mergermarket.com, has been commissioned to write a weekly comment on M&A deals of the week, complete with a table detailing the top 16-18 deals in Europe. The first column and table is to appear on October 8.

Sunday Business will have exclusive English-language European print rights to the column, which will be edited by Charlie Welsh, former editor of Corporate Money, now mergermarket's editor-in-chief.

Jeff Randall, editor of Sunday Business, said: "I believe this alliance will bring considerable value added content to our readers, and give Sunday Business a significant advantage in the competitive market for weekend financial news."

webTitle: Race to save EMI-Time Warner deal

fields.headline: Race to save EMI-Time Warner deal
fields.standfirst:
Venture partners plan new concessions in move to avoid EU regulators' block

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: EMI and Time Warner are working frantically to resurrect their £13.7bn joint venture by the end of the year after European regulators yesterday confirmed that the concessions proposed to address competition concerns were inadequate.
fields.byline: John Cassy  and  Andrew Osborne  in Brussels
fields.body:
EMI and Time Warner are working frantically to resurrect their £13.7bn joint venture by the end of the year after European regulators yesterday confirmed that the concessions proposed to address competition concerns were inadequate.

The companies said they were still committed to a plan that would create the world's largest music group, however.

They withdrew their original proposals yesterday morning ahead of a European commission meeting which was set to block the deal. By doing so they believe they have given themselves time to work on a solution that would appease the commission.

It is understood EMI hopes to update investors at its interim results meeting, scheduled for November 21.

EMI shares fell 31.5p to 528p as weeks of horsetrading ended in failure and analysts struggled to see a way forward for the group.

Some suggested the last-minute concessions the firms had offered had been too little and too late, and could leave EMI exposed to a counterbid. Disney, Sony, News Corpand Bertelsmann were possible predators, analysts said.

Others believe that the EC's intansigence all but rules out a counterbid from another big record company.

The fact that the link-up is dead in its present form means that the EC is now far more likely to clear America Online's £80bn merger with Time Warner - which it is considering separately.

It had feared that the merged entity would enjoy a dominant position in the markets for online music delivery and music software, but the collapse of the EMI deal appears to go a long way to removing these concerns.

Officials in Brussels confirmed that the EC had been poised to block the EMI-Time Warner deal because it believed it would be anti-competitive and against consumers' interests.

The tie-up would have left 80% of Europe's recorded music business in the hands of four multinationals and brought greater pressure to bear on small independent labels, the EC believed.

The EMI-Time Warner behemoth would have boasted of roster of international stars including David Bowie, Madonna, the Beatles and Eric Clapton. In an effort to ensure the deal was cleared the two firms are said to have offered to dispose of Virgin Records and Chappell Music Publishing, but only after Brussels' strict deadline for remedies had passed.

Eric Nicoli, chairman of EMI, said: "The withdrawal of our applications allows additional time to reassess regulators' concerns and pursue solutions in Europe and the US. We have been, and will continue to be, flexible in responding to the EC's concerns.

"We continue to believe that a venture with Warner Music Group can create substantial value for our shareholders and benefit our artists, consumers and employees by bringing together two companies with complementary strengths."

The EC acknowledged that that the tentative concessions proposed over recent days had "improved substantially the initial remedies", but said EMI and Warner had simply run out of time.

"It's very dangerous to leave your undertakings to the last minute because it leaves very little time for the EC to consider them," said EC spokeswoman Amelia Torres.

fields.headline: Leeds team wins football news deal with AOL
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: Teamtalk.com, the Leeds-based publisher of sports information on the internet, is to supply football news to AOL and its ISP merger partner, CompuServe.
fields.body:
Teamtalk.com, the Leeds-based publisher of sports information on the internet, is to supply football news to AOL and its ISP merger partner, CompuServe.

Club-specific news, comment, previews and a monthly celebrity column will be provided for AOL's Clubs' Corner and the CompuServe sports service.

Teamtalk, which floated in April, hopes the agreement will increase its exposure to a global audience.

Bill Wilson, the chief executive, said: "It's part of our strategy to work with the major players in the world." He would not say what the deal was worth, though there will be advertising revenue.

Gareth Evans, analyst at ABN Amro, said: "It is a sensible move for Teamtalk to push their content out to as many people as they can...The potential audience through AOL's sites is 1m."

fields.headline: Kenneth Fleet
fields.standfirst:
Journalist who brought financial news out of the City

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: As city editor of the Daily Telegraph from 1966-77, Kenneth Fleet, who has died aged 70, was well placed to champion the interests of small investors and influenced the votes of many private shareholders in takeover battles.
fields.body:
As city editor of the Daily Telegraph from 1966-77, Kenneth Fleet, who has died aged 70, was well placed to champion the interests of small investors and influenced the votes of many private shareholders in takeover battles.

He also had the knack of winning the confidence of company chairmen and chief executives, merchant bankers and stockbrokers, and encouraging them to communicate with the wider public, long before the public relations industry turned the flow of information from a trickle into a torrent.

In those years, Fleet was one of a small group of leading financial journalists who could write both well and knowledgeably, and helped transform City and business news from a dry-as-dust record of company profits and losses and daily price changes to a broad-based subject that today rivals politics and even sport in the public consciousness.

Mindful of the job specification handed to him by the Telegraph's then proprietor, Lord Hartwell - "Fleet, your job is to tell my readers how to make money" - he was also instrumental in creating Family Money-Go-Round, one of the earliest specialist sections covering all aspects of personal finance. His style and skill helped to make economic and financial policy interesting to a wider public, and persuaded many readers without share portfolios to learn about mortgages, unit trusts and pensions.

Fleet marshalled a growing team of financial writers and established the city comment column, which helped explain the wider significance of the day's news stories, took sides on important issues and included speculation about events - which had a habit of coming true.

He modelled himself on his great rival, the Daily Mail's city editor Patrick Sergeant, and, in the opinion of many, outshone him as an influential writer, and ran him close as a City figure - without ever joining the City establishment. He had a keen eye for talent, employing both Jim Slater and John Redwood as columnists.

Twice a week for a decade, his small lunch-parties at the Telegraph's city office were attended by leading politicians, bankers and captains of industry. He once succeeded in getting the late Iain Macleod and Roy Jenkins round the same table, discussing economic policy.

Fleet was born at Moreton, in the Wirral, and educated at Calday Grange grammar school, Cheshire. After reading economics at the London School of Economics, he worked on the Journal of Commerce in Liverpool, from 1950 to 1952, before moving to the Sunday Times in London. He was then deputy city editor, first, of the Birmingham Post, and from 1958, of the Manchester Guardian.

H e joined the Daily Telegraph as deputy city editor in 1963, before succeeding Nigel Lawson as city editor of the newly-established Sunday Telegraph. In 1966, came the city editorship at the daily.

Quick to appreciate the importance of financial advertising and the globalisation of business, Fleet travelled widely, although, curiously, trips to the less developed nations with tropical climates tended to be offered to subor dinates. In 1973, after a trip to the factory in Germany he chose an Opel as his next company car, only to be told by Lord Hartwell that a foreign car would be "unthinkable".

Fleet responded by choosing the most expensive Brit- ish vehicle available within the price limit of £1,500 imposed on him, and, for the next two years, the red Triumph Stag - which met that specification - became part of his persona, in spite of its legendary unreliability.

He made no secret of his hopes of being appointed editor of the Daily Telegraph when the job became vacant in 1974, but, at the age of 45, he was considered too young and too ambitious by the paper's notoriously conservative management. The job went to Bill Deedes, 16 years his senior. In 1977, Fleet accepted the post of editor of the business news section of the Sunday Times, where he headed a small, established team "more interested in writing books and becoming MPs than in journalism".

A year later, he moved to the Sunday Express, where he stayed for five years, but he never repeated his earlier successes, and, in 1983, returned to the Times stable with the title of executive editor (fin- ance and industry), in overall charge of the largest team of daily financial journalists outside the Financial Times. He retired in 1987 and became a consultant to the securities house Smith New Court, until the onset of his final illness.

Fleet had a lifelong interest in the theatre and was a director of the Young Vic from 1976 to 1983, and chairman of the Chichester Festival Theatre from 1985 to 1993. A man of considerable personal charm, he was also a stylish cricketer and an accomplished ballroom dancer.

He married Brenda Wilkinson in 1953. She survives him, together with their three sons and a daughter.

 Kenneth George Fleet, journalist, born September 12 1929; died August 21 2000

Fleet marshalled a growing team of financial writers and established the city comment column, which helped explain the wider significance of the day's news stories, took sides on important issues and included speculation about events - which had a habit of coming true. He modelled himself on his great rival, the Daily Mail's city editor Patrick Sergeant, and, in the opinion of many, outshone him as an influential writer, and ran him close as a City figure - without ever joining the City establishment. He had a keen eye for talent, employing both Jim Slater and John Redwood as columnists. Twice a week for a decade, his small lunch-parties at the Telegraph's city office were attended by leading politicians, bankers and captains of industry. He once succeeded in getting the late Iain Macleod and Roy Jenkins round the same table, discussing economic policy. Fleet was born at Moreton, in the Wirral, and educated at Calday Grange grammar school, Cheshire. After reading economics at the London School of Economics, he worked on the Journal of Commerce in Liverpool, from 1950 to 1952, before moving to the Sunday Times in London. He was then deputy city editor, first, of the Birmingham Post, and from 1958, of the Manchester Guardian. H e joined the Daily Telegraph as deputy city editor in 1963, before succeeding Nigel Lawson as city editor of the newly-established Sunday Telegraph. In 1966, came the city editorship at the daily. Quick to appreciate the importance of financial advertising and the globalisation of business, Fleet travelled widely, although, curiously, trips to the less developed nations with tropical climates tended to be offered to subor dinates. In 1973, after a trip to the factory in Germany he chose an Opel as his next company car, only to be told by Lord Hartwell that a foreign car would be "unthinkable". Fleet responded by choosing the most expensive Brit- ish vehicle available within the price limit of £1,500 imposed on him, and, for the next two years, the red Triumph Stag - which met that specification - became part of his persona, in spite of its legendary unreliability. He made no secret of his hopes of being appointed editor of the Daily Telegraph when the job became vacant in 1974, but, at the age of 45, he was considered too young and too ambitious by the paper's notoriously conservative management. The job went to Bill Deedes, 16 years his senior. In 1977, Fleet accepted the post of editor of the business news section of the Sunday Times, where he headed a small, established team "more interested in writing books and becoming MPs than in journalism". A year later, he moved to the Sunday Express, where he stayed for five years, but he never repeated his earlier successes, and, in 1983, returned to the Times stable with the title of executive editor (fin- ance and industry), in overall charge of the largest team of daily financial journalists outside the Financial Times. He retired in 1987 and became a consultant to the securities house Smith New Court, until the onset of his final illness. Fleet had a lifelong interest in the theatre and was a director of the Young Vic from 1976 to 1983, and chairman of the Chichester Festival Theatre from 1985 to 1993. A man of considerable personal charm, he was also a stylish cricketer and an accomplished ballroom dancer. He married Brenda Wilkinson in 1953. She survives him, together with their three sons and a daughter.  Kenneth George Fleet, journalist, born September 12 1929; died August 21 2000

webTitle: Comment: Bel Littlejohn's new diet book

fields.headline: Burn off that fat
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Following the success of my last-but-one cookery book, Eat to Slim (Boxtree, £9.99), and its bestselling follow-up, Eat More and Knock Off Pounds (Boxtree, £14.99), Channel 4 approached me with an idea for a brilliant new TV series, which would offer a radical approach to the whole cookery and dieting thing.
fields.body:
Following the success of my last-but-one cookery book, Eat to Slim (Boxtree, £9.99), and its bestselling follow-up, Eat More and Knock Off Pounds (Boxtree, £14.99), Channel 4 approached me with an idea for a brilliant new TV series, which would offer a radical approach to the whole cookery and dieting thing.

Only a fortnight to go, and you'll find it impossible to avoid my TV series, Pig Out and Lose Weight, and its lavishly illustrated tie-in book of the same name. The book's cover - also the logo of the TV series - has yours truly in a mauve leotard and jogging pants, sweating it out on a cycling machine while eating the most gorgeous slice of my own Thick and Creamy Chocolate Cake to Die For.

It's all still firmly under wraps, and I know all my lovely friends at Channel 4 will absolutely kill me for this, but just to give you a taster, here's how programme one goes. It opens with me in my leotard on my bike with the cake - cue titles and music - and then there's a great close-up of yours truly licking her lips while Simply the Best! blares out in the background.

I then get off my exercise bike and jog around all four sides of the open-plan kitchen, touching each wall in turn, until I get to my fridge. A fridge, I tell the viewer, is the very best place you can think of to perform those vital body-toning exercises that are so necessary for a shapely "tum". I then lean against the fridge with my right arm outstretched, slowly moving my left foot through an arc of 180 degrees, then I turn around and do the same thing with the other arm and foot. After a couple of minutes of this exercise, I take a well-earned breather and open the fridge to fetch out all the ingredients for one of my all-time favourite starters: Timbale of Smoked Salmon with a Low Fat Cottage Cheese on a Bed of Lean Bacon Potato Cake with Extra Thick Chocolate-and-Peanut Custard.

With all the ingredients laid out before me on my stainless steel work-surface, I tell viewers that this is a brilliant "bluffer's" dish that takes only a matter of minutes to prepare - yet is guaranteed to impress even your most standoffish guests! Then, before embarking on the preparation, I remind everyone that the absolute best way to lose weight in the kitchen is to engage in a tightly controlled regime of aerobics while doing all the cooking. For instance, it's easy as pie to perform my stretch-and-stretch/stretch-and-stretch exercises with your knees and lower thighs while preparing the Extra Thick Chocolate-and-Peanut-Custard with your upper body.

With the starter all ready and looking simply out-of-this-world, I jog backwards (excellent for slicing pounds off the buttock area, would you believe!) to the fridge and move straight on to the main course - Boudin of Guinea Fowl Stuffed with Veal Sweetbreads with Mussel and Saffron Sauce on a Coulis of Low Fat Blackcurrant Yoghurt. But before I embark on the preparation, I am filmed strapping on my rollerblades, switching my CD to full-blast and then -between the stirring and the pummelling, the slicing and the frying - letting it all hang out and shedding inches off the old waistline by boogying on down to the all-time greatest hits of Macy Gray.

To complete the meal, I prepare a simple Butterscotch Mousse with Vanilla Ice-Cream and Low-Fat Crème Fraiche on a tray on the floor while performing 10 old fashioned press-ups. Smashing! And so - with all the hard work completed - I get myself in the mood for my dinner party by slipping into a favourite frock and pouring myself a rewarding glass of champagne, accompanied by some wholemeal taco chips and an amazing marzipan and cream-cheese dip.

The lovely thing about the TV programme is that it doesn't just show the food preparation à la Delia - it also lets the viewers participate in the dinner party itself (though not literally, obviously: I haven't got a clue who half of them are!). In that first programme, my guests include arts supremo Chris Smith, the inspirational Anita Roddick, the ever vivacious Eve Pollard and top lyricist Tim Rice (who, he tells me, is fighting a losing battle with his waistline!).

Talk flowed. As usual, it began with cooking ("Don't tell anybody - promise!" said Eve as we dug into our Smoked Salmon Timbales, "but I've just picked up the most brilliant way of stuffing an artichoke with that marvellous new Tesco's wholemeal blancmange"), before moving on to dieting ("I've lost just over three pounds in six weeks on my splendid new break-dancing machine," revealed Chris. But I mustn't give too much away. You'll have to watch it for yourselves - and do please mark spring 2002 in your diaries for my follow-up series, Cook that Flab. Enjoy!

fields.headline: Blow for Microsoft as NTL is latest to plump for rival system
fields.trailText: 8am:NTL has become the fourth digital TV provider to choose Liberate's TV platform software over Microsoft's for its enhanced TV services, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
NTL has become the fourth digital television provider to choose Liberate's TV platform software for its enhanced TV services, in what is seen as a further blow to Microsoft.

The Liberate software will be used to connect NTL's UK digital cable services with those of recently acquired Cable & Wireless, which already use the technology.

NTL follows cable companies Telewest, UPC and Spanish Ono, which have recently chosen Liberate's technology over Microsoft's.

The move is likely to infuritate Microsoft, which has has invested nearly $10bn to gain a foothold in the interactive TV operating system market. It has investments in all three companies - $2.6bn in Telewest, $353m in UPC and $500m in NTL, but its efforts to move into interactive TV have been beset by problems. Microsoft's software was not delivered on time to UPC for its Amsterdam roll-out.

webTitle: Brussels stops EMI and Warner merger

fields.headline: Brussels hits right note on merger
fields.standfirst:
Watchdogs leave the door ajar

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Brussels gets more than its share of brickbats. EMI shareholders must be tempted to hurl a few in the direction of competition commissioner Mario Monti after their company's merger with Warner Music had to be dropped because the partners were unable to satisfy the commission within the formal time scale.
fields.body:
Brussels gets more than its share of brickbats. EMI shareholders must be tempted to hurl a few in the direction of competition commissioner Mario Monti after their company's merger with Warner Music had to be dropped because the partners were unable to satisfy the commission within the formal time scale.

The disappointment reflected in the fall in the EMI share price is understandable enough. The merger would have put the pair at the top of the music business. Some industry watchers were already tagging the deal as a likely trigger for further industry consolidation.

Now, however, shareholders are confronted with a series of uncertainties: will the two sides be able to put together a restructured deal, will the regulators wear it and will any deal which gets through the competition watchdog deliver the benefits expected from the original merger?

There has been widespread speculation that EMI and Warner had been prepared to sell off the Virgin music label and Chappell Music to get the deal through - sacrifices which some analysts reckoned would have knocked some of the gloss off the whole idea.

Nevertheless, Mr Monti and his team are right to have taken a tough line over the deal given the scale of the resulting operation within the global industry and the likely impact of Time Warner's planned tie-up with AOL.

EMI's management is unlikely to lose its enthusiasm for the Warner link and Brussels has left the door ajar. EMI might be able to find an alternative partner to Warner but one which provided benefits on the same scale - Bertelsmann, for example - would face similar regulatory hurdles. On the other hand any deal that would easily clear the regulators would be unlikely to deliver the same benefits. Nor would shareholders be keen to have to start the whole merger process again. Indeed if that were to happen, they might find another target for their brickbats.

Rate for the job

The members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee clearly have more sense than the euroland interest rate policymakers in Frankfurt. Circumstances fully justified the British decision to leave rates on hold. Little had changed since the MPC had last met and decided to leave well alone on monetary policy. Inflation has remained subdued, sterling is strong against the euro, if not the dollar, the labour market is hardly sending out distress signals - even the oil price has weakened in the last couple of days. About the only factor which might, at a great stretch, have disturbed the balance of the committee was some evidence of a rise in the housing market.

So, thankfully, the committee has followed its own logic and decided the appropriate policy response in the present situation is to leave rates on hold.

Not so in Frankfurt, where the ECB has decided that rates have to go up, although the rise of only 25 basis points leaves rates some way below those in Britain and the US. But is the day when figures showing consumer confidence slipping the best time to push up borrowing costs?

Nor did the ECB get the most out of the move. The euro rose initially after the rate rise in the belief that it was an underpinning to the intervention to support the euro two weeks ago. When ECB president Wim Duisenberg explained it was all to do with worries about inflationary pressure - in which euro weakness does have a role - the currency promptly sank back.

The ECB does have a mandate for price stability rather than one for an exchange rate or growth. But it is hard to avoid the view it is living in the shadow of the Bundesbank - without the latter's credibility or touch with the markets.

LSE learns

Yesterday's salvo from the London Stock Exchange against hostile bidder OM has the appearance of a real defence document about it. Its approach is robust, its language trenchant and it attacks OM on pretty well all fronts. If only the exchange could have shown the same sort of crispness earlier in the continuing saga of exchange alliances.

The confident tone of the circular suggests that the LSE reckons it is going to see off OM. But if such turns out to be the case, what then? Yesterday Werner Seifert, the chief executive of the Deutsche Börse, said his exchange is still interested in the iX alliance plan with London which the LSE dropped to concentrate on beating off OM. Euronext - Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam - has left the door open for London. Others too will be watching events.

No doubt it is nice to be in demand, but there is a sense that the LSE's suitors may want the exchange less for itself than to stop it falling to someone else. The LSE needs to be thinking beyond OM and with the some of the clarity shown in yesterday's defence document.

webTitle: Heye and Bates win Ferrero ad business

fields.headline: Heye and Bates pick up Ferrero brands
fields.trailText: 8am: Italian confectioner Ferrero has appointed DDB Worldwide-owned Heye Partner and Bates to handle its £12m Rocher and £7m Raffaelo brands respectively. by Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Ferrero, the Italian confectioner, has appointed DDB Worldwide-owned Heye Partner and Bates to handle its £12m Rocher and £7m Raffaelo brands respectively.

The brands were previously handled out of Franfurt by Lowe & Partners until its merger with Ammirati Puris Lintas, when the businesses moved in-house. The winning agencies have worked with Ferrero on projects before.

The Italian company is one of the largest FMCG advertisers in Europe. It spent a hefty £150m globally on advertising last year, according to AC Nielsen.

European agencies are still awaiting the result of a review of Ferrero's Tic Tac brand, which was called in August this year.

The confectioner has become renowned for its trademark badly scripted, cheap-looking TV ads, such as "The Ambassador's Party". The latest reviews are being seen as an indication that Ferrero wanted to move its advertising upmarket.

webTitle: BBC Worldwide to work in Canada

fields.headline: BBC Worldwide to distribute Discovery in Canada
fields.trailText: 8am: BBC Worldwide Americas and Discovery Communications have signed a deal for BBC Worldwide's Canadian office to act as a distributor for Discovery in Canada, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide Americas and Discovery Communications have signed a deal for BBC Worldwide's Canadian office to act as a distributor for Discovery in Canada.

The agreement will make a range of serials and specials from Discovery's catalogue available to English- and French-speaking Canadian audiences.

Meanwhile, BBC Worldwide's Sydney office has sold a package of programming, including dramas Attachments, Take a Girl Like You and Glasgow Kiss, and factual series The Human Face, Brain Story and State of the Planet, to Australia's ABC.

fields.headline: Israel braced for further violence
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Madeleine Albright's office
Yasser Arafat's office
Ehud Barak's office
Israeli government
Palestinian National Authority
fields.trailText: Israeli riot police fanned out around the holiest Muslim site in Jerusalem last night in preparation for today's afternoon prayers, which will provide the definitive test of the latest tentative truce.
fields.body:
Israeli riot police fanned out around the holiest Muslim site in Jerusalem last night in preparation for today's afternoon prayers, which will provide the definitive test of the latest tentative truce.

After the eight-day spasm of violence which reduced parts of Gaza and the West Bank to a state of near war, diplomatic efforts produced a relative reprieve. But reports of casualties still trickled in. A Palestinian was shot dead by Israeli snipers outside a flashpoint in the Gaza Strip, and on the West Bank a 20-year-old Palestinian man was shot dead in Beit Jala, near Bethlehem.

Their death underlined the tenuous grip of the ceasefire agreement extracted from the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, during a six-hour session in Paris with the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright.

Mr Barak instructed his army to withdraw the tanks which have been staging a showof force from the entrances to Palestinian cities and return its soldiers to the posts they occupied before the clashes. A parallel order was issued to the Palestinian security forces and the activists who have steered the protests.

But within minutes the two were exchanging angry accusations after Mr Arafat demanded an international investigation into the week of bloodshed, in which 69 people, mostly Palestinian, have died. Mr Barak refused, and boycotted yesterday's follow-up summit, hosted by the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, at a resort on the Sinai peninsula.

Their failure to agree written ceasefire guarantees underlined the precarious situation on the ground. With tempers still running high, the call to Friday afternoon prayers at Haram al-Sharif mosque could provoke a conflagration. There was an increase in tension with the Palestinian release of Hamas prisoners in Gaza, and a call by Hamas for a day of protest today.

The Haram al-Sharif, which houses the golden Dome of the Rock, has been the centre of the protests, which were triggered by the visit there last Thursday by the hardline leader of the Likud opposition party, Ariel Sharon.

Mr Arafat returned to Gaza from his meetings with Mrs Albright and Mr Mubarak accusing Israel of using excessive force and renewing his demand for an inquiry.

"We will insist . . . on the necessity and the importance of convening an international fact-finding panel on what our people have suffered from massacres and severe aggression that violate international law," he said.

After flying home from Paris, Mr Barak met military chiefs, and cabinet ministers to try to plot a way out of the disaster.

He reaffirmed his pledge to the peace process, jeopardised by the week of violence. Mrs Albright has invited both negotiating teams to Washington next week to try to restart the talks. Israel has yet to accept, but Mr Barak told a press conference: "I will leave no stone unturned in the path for peace."

Yesterday began with encouraging signs. Two dozen Israeli tanks trundled back to their base from the West Bank city of Nablusand the outskirts of Ramallah and Jerusalem. But as the afternoon brought more of the funerals which have driven the recent events, violence erupted anew.

At Netzarim junction, where an army bunker guards a Jewish settlement loathed by Palestinians as a symbol of occupation, Israeli snipers fired lat Palestinians, killing at least one man, and injuring 10 more. Protesters armed with petrol bombs had gathered at the post after the funeral of a 13-year-old boy. On the West Bank, soldiers fired rubber-coated bullets in Hebron, wounding three people.

But while a tense calm fell on other deserted flashpoints, the failure of the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to endorse a truce kept the atmosphere tense.

In Tel Aviv and Jerusalem the US were operating their missions with a skeleton staff, in response to the stoning of their embassy in Damascus. Missions have been closed in the Arab world until next week.

There was an increase in tension with the Palestinian release of Hamas prisoners in Gaza, and a call by Hamas for a day of protest today. The Haram al-Sharif, which houses the golden Dome of the Rock, has been the centre of the protests, which were triggered by the visit there last Thursday by the hardline leader of the Likud opposition party, Ariel Sharon. Mr Arafat returned to Gaza from his meetings with Mrs Albright and Mr Mubarak accusing Israel of using excessive force and renewing his demand for an inquiry. "We will insist . . . on the necessity and the importance of convening an international fact-finding panel on what our people have suffered from massacres and severe aggression that violate international law," he said. After flying home from Paris, Mr Barak met military chiefs, and cabinet ministers to try to plot a way out of the disaster. He reaffirmed his pledge to the peace process, jeopardised by the week of violence. Mrs Albright has invited both negotiating teams to Washington next week to try to restart the talks. Israel has yet to accept, but Mr Barak told a press conference: "I will leave no stone unturned in the path for peace." Yesterday began with encouraging signs. Two dozen Israeli tanks trundled back to their base from the West Bank city of Nablusand the outskirts of Ramallah and Jerusalem. But as the afternoon brought more of the funerals which have driven the recent events, violence erupted anew. At Netzarim junction, where an army bunker guards a Jewish settlement loathed by Palestinians as a symbol of occupation, Israeli snipers fired lat Palestinians, killing at least one man, and injuring 10 more. Protesters armed with petrol bombs had gathered at the post after the funeral of a 13-year-old boy. On the West Bank, soldiers fired rubber-coated bullets in Hebron, wounding three people. But while a tense calm fell on other deserted flashpoints, the failure of the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to endorse a truce kept the atmosphere tense. In Tel Aviv and Jerusalem the US were operating their missions with a skeleton staff, in response to the stoning of their embassy in Damascus. Missions have been closed in the Arab world until next week.

fields.headline: Strongman defeated by people power
fields.standfirst:
Milosevic: Deserted by his police, his army and his propaganda machine, the ousted president faces the prospect of exile or even trial for war crimes

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Deserted by his police, his army and his propaganda machine, the ousted president faces the prospect of exile or even trial for war crimes
fields.body:
After 13 years as unquestioned leader of Yugoslavia, Slobodan Milosevic was left with few cards to play last night. Deserted by the people who he put through three wars, he was also deserted by the media machine that faithfully pumped out his propaganda. In the final sudden hours he must have realised that, after the police melted away in the face of the huge crowds outside the parliament building in Belgrade, the army would stay doggedly neutral. The loyalty of his feared paramilitary police was also in question.

These last lines of his defence crumbled rapidly last night in the face of people power as the opposition led by Vojislav Kostunica, organised and unified as never before, secured interior and defence ministry guarantees that they would not launch a crackdown on their own people.

There were conflicting reports last night about the whereabouts of Mr Milosevic. Unconfirmed reports said that he had left the country by plane, while others indicated he was still in Yugoslavia.

An opposition source claimed he was in a bunker near the eastern town of Bor, protected by army troops from the 92nd light infantry brigade.

There were no guards outside the ousted president's official residence in Belgrade last night, suggesting he had fled the capital. Mr Kostunica, addressing supporters, said there was no need to go to the house in the luxury suburb of Dedinje. "He has fled from here," he said.

A former Milosevic loyalist, army chief of staff, and key figure in the Bosnia war, General Momcilo Perisic, went to the army command to negotiate the military's neutrality against the insurgency.

But while the military top brass has been relatively loyal to the regime, the army has been loath to get involved in an internal policing operation. During the past decade the army has consistently been neglected by Mr Milosevic in favour of his well-armed and well-funded praetorian guard, the 120,000-strong interior ministry troops, who were the president's shock troops in the ethnic cleansing of Bosnia and Kosovo.

In any case the pace of events on the ground last night in Belgrade was creating its own new reality and it appeared that Mr Milosevic's survival options were increasingly focused on flight abroad.

He may well be able to buy himself a safe haven. All through the 90s, his regime has been stripping the assets of the Yugoslav state and salting them abroad - in Cyprus, in Russia, in China and other offshore treasure chests.

A sign of panic from the Belgrade regime surfaced in Moscow at the weekend when crony companies of the regime in Russia were ordered to repatriate their assets to Belgrade in apparent preparation for appropriation by the Milosevic clan. Borka Vucic, the septuagenarian head of Serbia's biggest bank, Beobanka, and a kind of godmother to Mr Milosevic, is reported to have made two visits to China in the past two months. The regime is reported to have $200m in Chinese banks.

Mrs Vucic is Mr Milosevic's key financier. Mr Milosevic himself headed Beobanka in the early 1980s and Mrs Vucic has been a faithful acolyte for 15 years. She worked in New York and London before becoming boss of Beobanka in Cyprus, the biggest offshore bank on the island, and masterminding the asset stripping of the early 90s which was aimed at counteracting UN sanctions.

She has been unfailingly faithful to Mr Milosevic and his orthodox communist wife, Mirjana Markovic, regarding him as a proxy son after losing her own son in a car crash, western bankers said.

The favoured boltholes for Mr Milosevic, his wife, his daughter and son are Russia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, and China. Yesterday in Moscow the smart money was on Belarus.

The former Soviet foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, said yesterday that Mrs Markovic could be in Moscow within days, though Mr Milosevic's elder brother Borislav, the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow and the alleged source of the information, instantly denied it.

As a permanent member of the UN security council which voted to set up the Hague war crimes tribunal on former Yugoslavia in 1993, Russia would be in an awkward position were it to afford the Milosevic family asylum. Mr Milosevic faces charges of war crimes in Kosovo and charges relating to crimes in Croatia and Bosnia are being prepared.

But that does not mean that the Kremlin may not be organising an alternative shelter for Mr Milosevic. Belarus fits the bill because Moscow has clout there and the authoritarian regime of its president, Alexander Lukashenko, is sympathetic to the Serbian strongman.

The American military is monitoring Yugoslav airspace from their base in Bosnia for any unusual air traffic, particularly by the Falcon or DC-10 aircraft favoured by the Milosevic regime.

For a decade, ever since Mr Milosevic turned tanks against his own people on the streets of Belgrade in March 1991 and before he launched wars in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo, a widespread view has been that the president would go down fighting, not against Croats, Muslims of Bosnia or Kosovans, but against his own people in the country he destroyed. As long ago as 1991, the demonstrators on the streets of Belgrade compared Mr Milosevic with Saddam Hussein and predicted that he and Mirjana would suffer a similar fate to that of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu in neighbouring Romania, who were executed at Christmas 1989.

The other widely predicted view was that Mr Milosevic, having destroyed Yugoslavia and turned himself into the biggest menace to European peace since the Nazis, would end it all as Adolf Hitler did in his bunker in 1945 - by killing himself just as his preacher father did in 1962 and his teacher mother did 10 years later.

webTitle: Petrol prices on the way down

fields.headline: Petrol prices on the way down
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Relief was in sight yesterday for Britain's hard pressed drivers as supermarkets and oil companies began cutting petrol prices in response to tumbling world oil costs.
fields.body:
Relief was in sight yesterday for Britain's hard pressed drivers as supermarkets and oil companies began cutting petrol prices in response to tumbling world oil costs.

Safeway announced yesterday that it was cutting 3p off the price of a litre of petrol, taking it to 77.9p - 7p lower than the peak the supermarket chain established two weeks ago when world oil prices were at a 10-year high.

"Prices are on the way down and I imagine that would continue for a bit," said Stephen Brooks of oil consultancy Wood Mackenzie. "Petrol prices have eased off by 1p or 2p a litre over the last few days, they're now generally below 80p a litre."

A spokesman for Shell said that while it was not cutting prices nationally, it was taking part in local reductions. BP Amoco said it was monitoring international price movements.

World oil prices fell again last night as it emerged that the US government had found willing buyers for all 30m barrels it is releasing on to world markets from its emergency reserves.

"The fact that the whole 30m barrels has been taken up has had quite a dramatic impact on the market," said Tony Machacek of brokers Prudential Bache.

Brent crude futures, the benchmark oil price, slipped 87 cents to $29.65 per barrel in afternoon trading, taking losses over the past two days to more than $1. In New York, US light crude oil futures were off 70 cents at $30.73 per barrel.

Japan contributed to falling prices earlier in the day, when it called on refineries to export more gas oil to ease shortages of heating oil. Fears are growing that US heating oil supplies may be insufficient to meet winter demand, despite the release of emergency supplies.

webTitle: Fuel duty case to be made at oil depots

fields.headline: Fuel duty case to be made at oil depots
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Eco-warriors and truck drivers risk confrontation in any new fuel price protest after Greenpeace yesterday said it would send teams to oil depots to argue the case for higher duties.
fields.body:
Eco-warriors and truck drivers risk confrontation in any new fuel price protest after Greenpeace yesterday said it would send teams to oil depots to argue the case for higher duties.

Policy director Stephen Tindale told a Greenpeace business conference attended by the industry secretary, Stephen Byers, that his organisation would take a more active role.

"Greenpeace is not afraid to make the case for high petrol prices and we will go out to the fuel protests and put it directly to truckers and farmers if they return to the refineries," he said.

Mr Byers argued that pressure groups should be more vigorous in making the environmental case for fuel taxes. He confirmed plans to get tough with electricity suppliers to ensure they produce 5% of their power from renewable sources by 2003 and 10% by 2005.

Power suppliers last night claimed the policy was flawed and contradictory. The Association of Electricity Producers was worried about costs and said ruling out energy from waste incineration made the targets unattainable. The policy conflicted with new electricity trading arrangements which acted against the interests of renewable energy.

The Confederation of Renewable Energy Associations said the policy was "a great leap forward" but questioned whether Mr Byers could meet his targets without other measures.

webTitle: The vision thing: Blair sets out UK stall for new EU

fields.headline: The vision thing: Blair sets out UK stall for new EU
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister today staked out his vision for an expanded European Union, says Andrew Osborn in Brussels
Blair calls for rapid expansion of EU
fields.trailText: The prime minister today staked out his vision for an expanded European Union, says Andrew Osborn in Brussels.
fields.body:
The European Union will never be the same again and Tony Blair knows it.

Exactly what the 15-nation club will look like five years from now is, however, less certain - and different countries have different ideas about how it should evolve.

Today in Warsaw, in front of an audience of Polish politicians and business leaders, the prime minister staked out his vision for a 21st century European Union. It is a vision which he hopes will resurrect the bloc's dismal popularity back home and ensure that Britain is not sidelined by the likes of France and Germany.

The stakes are high and time is running out.

A wave of crucial reforms that will alter the balance of power in Brussels are just months away, and 12 mostly eastern European countries including Poland are knocking at the EU's door and will not take no for an answer.

The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, and the French president, Jacques Chirac, have had their turn at doing the vision thing and now it's Blair's chance.

But his words are likely to rattle the European Commission's faltering president, Romano Prodi, who wants to extend the powers of his own unelected institution. And they will irk Chirac, who effectively advocates a Europe led by Paris and Berlin.

For Blair is effectively signalling that the rules of the EU game - for so long set in stone and unchallenged - are about to change, and that Britain will struggle to ensure that the new rules are to its liking.

The European commission's days as a motor of integration, guiding nation states closer and closer to the holy grail of a United States of Europe with power concentrated in Brussels are numbered, Blair said today.

The prime minister believes it is democratic and elected governments who should be in control, and there should be checks and balances to ensure that institutions in Brussels do not exceed their authority.

As such, he is proposing a second chamber for the European Union made up of prominent MPs from national parliaments to keep an eye on the EC and the sometimes erratic European parliament.

French ambitions of a "pioneer group" of more federalist-minded countries - streaking ahead of the rest and wielding far more power as a result - are also kicked into touch.

Blair has no problem with countries stepping up EU cooperation in areas such as defence, justice and home affairs. But that must not, he insists, be at the expense of others.

"Deepening can include enhanced cooperation, but that does not mean exclusive bodies. We must preserve equality in the EU, including for the new arrivals," says one government official.

The subtext is clear - no to a two-speed Europe; but a grudging yes to a multi-layered or multi-tiered Europe, as some officials like to call it.

Blair is also showing that Britain may be out of the euro but that does not mean it is out of the game. He is, as he puts it, making Britain "a champion of enlargement". And he is the first European leader to come out and say he wants the first new EU members to be signed up by a certain date - in this case 2004.

This is astute. For it comes at a time when the timetable for enlargement seems to be slipping and aspirant countries are growing increasingly frustrated at the slow pace of negotiations.

Blair is therefore making friends in eastern Europe and ensuring that the project - which is seen as vital to Britain's own interests - remains on track.

For a bigger club is likely to be a far more democratic club and that will make profound reform of the EU a crushing inevitability.

That should ensure that the growing gap between Europe's ruled and its rulers closes and should make the European project far easier to sell back at home.

Blair said today in Warsaw: "The problems Europe's citizens have with Europe arise when Europe's priorities are not theirs."

Romano Prodi must be livid: a more democratic Europe will see his own powers diminished.

But change is coming. And whatever the outcome of the debate which is about to erupt, Europe will never be the same again.

webTitle: Witness in Noye murder trial shot dead

fields.headline: Witness in Noye murder trial shot dead
fields.trailText: A witness who gave crucial evidence to convict underworld boss Kenneth Noye of murder was yesterday killed in a gangland-style shooting.
fields.byline: Steven Morris, Nick Hopkins and Keith Perry
fields.body:
A witness who gave crucial evidence to convict underworld boss Kenneth Noye of murder was yesterday killed in a gangland-style shooting.

Alan Decabral, who described in court how he saw the sun glinting off the blade of Noye's knife before he stabbed 21-year-old electrician Stephen Cameron, was shot twice in the head at close range as he sat in his car.

Since Noye was jailed for life in April for the M25 road rage killing, Mr Decabral has lived at a secret address fearing for his life.

Such is the fear of Noye's power though he is behind bars that Mr Cameron's fiancee Danielle Cable has been given a new identity and 24-hour police protection. During the trial the jurors were guarded round the clock and their names kept secret.

Mr Decabral was in his car waiting to leave the Warren retail park, in Ashford, Kent, at about 1.30pm when he was shot. Witnesses told police they heard the victim scream: "Please don't kill me. Don't shoot."

Paul Winters, 41, said: "I didn't even really hear the sound of any shots, so the killer might have used a silencer."

Anton Kaye, 26, a deputy shop manager at the park, said: "There were no doors open and no signs of broken glass, so the killer obviously got up pretty close to him and was possibly in the car."

Though officers were not officially naming the victim, a police source confirmed that it was Mr Decabral and said: "He was the victim of a cold-blooded execution. It is too early to say whether there is any link to Noye but Detective Chief Superintendent Dennis McGookin, who investigated Noye for the Cameron murder, was called in once the police had established the victim was Decabral."

In July Mr Decabral, a father of three who is separated from his wife, gave an interview to the Sunday Mirror in which he admitted he lived in constant fear but said he was glad he had helped put Noye behind bars.

He said before the trial he had been ordered by "gangsters" to "shut up or we will shut you up" and became terrified after three bullets were pushed through his letter box. He said: "I look over my shoulder every time I go to Sainsbury's."

Noye is considered one of the most clever and dangerous criminals of his generation. He was cleared of murdering an undercover detective in the grounds of his Kent home in 1985 but was jailed for 14 years for laundering the proceeds of the £26m Brinks Mat gold bullion raid of 1983.

After murdering Mr Cameron at the M25's Swanley interchange, in Kent, in May 1996 Noye, 52, fled Britain but after one of the largest manhunts ever was found in Spain and brought back for trial.

Police believe Noye pulled his knife because he was losing the fight and could not bear to think a younger man was standing up to him and beating him.

Mr Decabral's wife said last night: "I have just woken up my children to tell them what has happened. I am devastated."
