webTitle: Blair calls for rapid expansion of EU

fields.headline: Blair calls for rapid expansion of EU
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today laid out his vision of the European Union's future. The EU, he said, must become a "superpower but not a superstate".
fields.body:
Tony Blair today laid out his vision of the European Union's future. The EU, he said, must become a "superpower but not a superstate".

Speaking in Warsaw to members of the Polish stock exchange, the prime minister called for rapid progress towards enlarging the EU to include eastern European states. And he said there must be major structural reforms to the way the EU operates.

His speech follows Denmark's decision not to join the euro zone and signifies an attempt to map out a European policy for Britain which is more engaged than that of the Conservative party and also acceptable to an increasingly sceptical British electorate.

He linked an overt commitment to national sovereignty with an implicit acceptance that a wider Europe may also become a "deeper" one. That is Euro-speak for a more powerful political centre in Brussels.

The prime minister spoke against the background of political turmoil in Yugoslavia. He said that what Poland had begun in the 1980s - the collapse of communism - the Serbian people would finish.

"Milosevic has done enough damage, for one man, in one country," he said. "Three wars. Tens of thousands dead. Millions displaced. Acts of barbarism not seen in Europe since the second world war. Their effect felt throughout Europe. The sooner he is gone, the better for Serbia, the better for the whole of Europe."

Addressing the future of the EU, Mr Blair said: "We need to get the political foundations of the European Union right. These foundations are rooted in the democratic nation state."

He did not favour the development of a multi-speed Europe, with some states, such as Germany and France, integrating ahead of others, particularly in the east. "Without enlargement, western Europe will always be faced with the threat of instability, conflict and mass migration on its borders. Without enlargement, the political consensus behind economic and political reform in the weaker transition countries may splinter.

"Should that happen, we would all lose. That is why supporting enlargement in principle but delaying in practice is no longer good enough," he continued. "I want to see new member states participating in the European parliamentary elections in 2004 and having a seat at the table at the next IGC [inter-governmental convention]."

He also repeated the view of successive Conservative prime ministers that Britain formed a key "bridge" between Europe and the United States.

He repeated the government's wait-and-see policy on the euro, cautioning those who saw the Danish referendum as ruling out British membership for the forseeable future.

The prime minister attacked the increasingly sceptical stance of the Conservative party. "We can choose not to be there. But no one should doubt the consequences of that choice and it is wildly unrealistic to pretend those consequences are not serious," Mr Blair said.

The speech also suggested a range of ideas for structural reform of Europe's core institutions. The prime minister called for a second chamber of the European parliament, to contain members of national parliaments, and for changes to the existing system of individual countries holding the EU presidency.

He argued that "the primary sources of democratic accountability in Europe are the directly elected and representative institutions of the nations of Europe national parliaments and governments."

fields.headline: 'Good evening, liberated Serbia'
fields.standfirst: New leader Kostunica urges orderly transition
fields.trailText: The triumphant leader of the opposition, Vojislav Kostunica, last night addressed jubilant crowds outside the looted parliament building in the centre of Belgrade. He appealed to the army not to intervene and asked supporters to stay on the streets until dawn in case of counter-attacks.
fields.body:
The triumphant leader of the opposition, Vojislav Kostunica, last night addressed jubilant crowds outside the looted parliament building in the centre of Belgrade. He appealed to the army not to intervene and asked supporters to stay on the streets until dawn in case of counter-attacks.

"Good evening, liberated Serbia," the 56-year-old former law professor told the cheering crowd. "We call on the military and police to do everything to ensure a peaceful transition of power. Serbia hit the road of democracy and where there is democracy there is no place for Milosevic."

Later in the evening Mr Kostunica appeared on the main state television service where he was described as the new president. His message again was a plea for an orderly hand-over of authority. He said he looked forward to a democratic Serbia that had normal relations with other countries and did not suffer sanctions imposed by the US and the EU.

Mr Kostunica said from now on state television would be open to a variety of different viewpoints. "It must be a mirror of all the people's sensibilities," he said. "It's a right of the citizens to be well informed." He added: "We can't forget what some countries did to us last year during the Nato aggression."

Earlier in the day the television station, a hated symbol of Mr Milosevic's propaganda machine, had been set alight after demonstrators stormed its headquarters in Belgrade in the face of teargas and bullets.

Mr Kostunica may not be renowned for his charisma, but the diligent academic has succeeded, unlike any other challenger in the past decade, in inspiring hope among the country's people that a future is possible without Mr Milosevic.

He enjoys a reputation for honesty. He is known to drive around in a small car in contrast to the government officials who used Mercedes-Benzes. During the election he campaigned door-to-door and listened to people's views - a concept unheard of in a country where Mr Milosevic was usually seen only on television.

During the election, he covered more than more than 3,000 miles, addressing rallies at every stop. Long a staunch anti-communist, Mr Kostunica pursued an academic career until he was kicked out of Belgrade Law School in 1974 for his views. While other opposition leaders cut deals to stay in power, he founded his own party in 1992 and has led it ever since.

Even in his moment of triumph last night he expressed humility. "Serbia, thank you for your trust," he told the crowd. "Thank you for being with us. You are staying here with me. I'm staying here with you."

fields.headline: East, west, home is best
fields.standfirst:
If the last century was a conflict between left and right, this century's contest will pit local claims against those of globalisation

Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: Prague saw a dawning realisation by those responsible for international finance as much as by those on the streets that globalisation has perverse consequences. Free market theory has been put into practice but the result has been the opposite of what was promised.
fields.body:
Prague saw a dawning realisation by those responsible for international finance as much as by those on the streets that globalisation has perverse consequences. Free market theory has been put into practice but the result has been the opposite of what was promised.

The moves, not least under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation, towards the liberalisation of commerce is built on the theory of comparative advantage. Everyone is supposed to benefit. The international institutions on parade in Prague and Seattle promulgated an edict of international competitiveness. It promised growth would ensure wealth for all. Yet comparative advantage - "do what you do best, and trade for the rest" - ignores differences in power between traders and producers. The result has been a rise in the gap between rich and poor. The latest World Bank development report, source of the chart, shows average income in the richest 20 countries is 37 times the average in the poorest 20 - a gap that has doubled in the past 40 years.

Comparative advantage assumed money would remain local. Since the 70s there has been an acceleration in the opposite direction, in pursuit of "capital advantage". This free flow of money internationally is supposed to ensure its efficient and rational use. Again the majority are supposed to be the winners.

The 1997 Asian crisis made clear such global flows could have adverse effects. The "tigers" had used an astute mixture of domestic protectionism and export-led growth to become the only area in the south where widespread poverty reduction has been achieved. In east Asia, the number of people living on less than $1 a day fell from around 420m in 1987 to around 280m in 1998.

After Seattle and Prague we need to think again. Globalisation needs to be replaced by "localisation", protecting and rebuilding local economies. Long-distance trade would be gradually reduced to supplying what could not come from within one country or region. Trade is conducted under rules which give preference to goods supplied in a way that benefits workers, the local community and the environment. The global flow of technology and information would be encouraged only when and where it can strengthen local economies.

Globalisation's advocates want to maximise trade and money flows for profit. From this comes a clear set of policies and trade rules. Localisation reverses this by discriminating in favour of the local (which may embrace a regional grouping of states. At the heart of localisation is a rejection of today's environmentally and socially damaging subservience to international competitiveness. If control of the economy falls to communities and nations social cohesion could be built, poverty and inequality reduced, livelihoods improved.

This does not mean a return to overpowering state control. But new rules would have to be enacted to stop imports of goods and services that could be produced locally. Industries will have to be located in the local community if they are to win permission to sell in it. Flows of money would be controlled. Competition policy would discriminate in favour of local production. New resource and pollution taxes would be levied to pay for the transition.

Today's global casino consists of traders gambling on minute market fluctuations. In 1980, the daily average of foreign trading was $80bn. Today, more than $1,500bn flows daily across international borders. Some 90% of capital flows are speculative (based on movements in currency and interest rates) rather than productive. Democratic control over such capital is the key to providing the money for governments and communities to rebuild. As well as a Tobin-type tax on international capital transactions to curb currency speculators, broader re-regulation of finance capital will be required. This would include physical controls on capital flows, taxes on short-term speculative transactions, tightening of easy credit that allows speculators to multiply the size of their "bets" way beyond the cash required to cover them. Also essential is a widespread and coordinated attack on corporate tax evasion, including offshore banking centres.

Any one country proposing such controls on its own would immediately be punished by the markets. However, a regional grouping of powerful states such as the European Union would be a secure and lucrative enough market to ensure that those who control money would not dare to leave the safety and security afforded by such a bloc. This pattern would then be attempted globally.

In a small way the process has already begun. Last year two Green members of the European parliament, Caroline Lucas and Jean Lambert, were elected from the UK on a platform that included such localisation. Ms Lucas, as a member of the parliament's trade committee, has initiated discussions about the Europe-wide changes needed to achieve such an end goal.

Politically, the 20th century was a battle between left and right. In the 21st the contest will pit localists against those merely trying to manage globalisation. The former will seek control over the local economy. The latter will continue to see globalisation to be as inevitable as gravity; their role will be to attempt to make it kinder and gentler. The contest will not just play out internationally but - if recent protest is any guide to the movement of opinion - in the internal politics of the rich countries, too.

Colin Hines is the author of Localisation - a global manifesto, Earthscan £10.99. chines@dial.pipex.com

fields.headline: A hated regime crumbles
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia last night slipped from the iron grasp of Slobodan Milosevic, the communist-turned-nationalist who ignited three Balkan wars in the past decade.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia last night slipped from the iron grasp of Slobodan Milosevic, the communist-turned-nationalist who ignited three Balkan wars in the past decade.

Unable to stand up to a tidal wave of protest sweeping Belgrade's streets, he saw some of the key pillars of his power crumble last night in rapid succession, after an extraordinary day which left the parliament building smouldering, the state RTS television station gutted by fire and several police stations in the hands of protesters.

No one knew the whereabouts of the world's first president to be indicted for war crimes by an international court. But three military aircraft took off from Batajnica airport near Belgrade last night, the independent Beta news agency said.

A former Yugoslav army chief of staff turned opposition figure, General Momcilo Perisic, said the army had pledged to stay neutral. "I talked to the army leaders and they promised not to intervene," he said. But he warned that Mr Milosevic and his cronies were "determined" and might be planning a counter-attack from somewhere "outside Belgrade".

Last night, Zoran Djinjic, campaign manager for the 19-party opposition alliance, claimed Mr Milosevic was in the eastern Serbian town of Bor, near the Bulgarian and Romania borders, and was preparing a coup. Other opposition sources said he was in a bunker in the village of Beljanica, 25 miles west of Bor, and was protected by the 92nd light infantry brigade.

But Vojislav Kostunica, the opposition leader, was declared president in front of jubilant crowds in Belgrade, hailing a new era for the country. He said he was reconvening the parliament.

"Good evening, liberated Serbia," he told them. "What we are doing is making history. We call on the military and police to do everything to ensure a peaceful transition of power."

The crowd chanted for Mr Milosevic's arrest. "He doesn't need to be arrested," Mr Kostunica told them. "He arrested himself a long time ago."

He appealed to people from the countryside to stream into Belgrade for rallies today. Mr Kostunica said later on state television that he wanted normal relations with the west. The US and other western leaders have already pledged to lift sanctions if Mr Milosevic goes.

The conquest of the parliament was highly symbolic. But the loss of the state media and the government-run newspaper Politika was a bigger blow to Mr Milosevic, denying him his biggest propaganda tools. "From this moment Tanjug [the state news agency] informs the Yugoslav public that it is with the people of this country," a statement by the agency said. Another Tanjug report referred to Mr Kostunica as "president-elect".

The uprising swelled as security forces showed little willingness to battle the largest-ever protest in Belgrade. Many police joined the flag-waving crowds. Thousands more people joined smaller rallies throughout the country.

Last night lorries with loudspeakers drove through the capital playing folk and rock music. Protesters stormed and ransacked a building housing the executive of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party, while others sacked the headquarters of the Yugoslav Left, the neo-communist party run by his wife.

The "people's power" demonstrations that toppled eastern European regimes in 1989 were on course to be repeated in Belgrade as hundreds of thousands of Serbs demanded democratic change. Police used teargas at noon when a first group of protesters, many of them workers who had come in from provincial towns, tried to break into the parliament. They used gas again at around 3pm when protesters again approached the building, using a bulldozer to threaten police lines.

The police were outnumbered and fled as protesters broke through and rushed into the building, hurling photographs of Mr Milosevic out of the windows.

MPs' chairs were brought out into the street, where demonstrators sat on them, sipping plum brandy.

Later, as crowds set up makeshift barricades across main streets with rubbish bins and paving stones, a busload of special police in blue uniforms inched its way nervously through the crowd. Several officers gave victory salutes to the protesters, who let them through.

The crowd then turned its anger on the headquarters of Radio Television Serbia, which had spent a decade pumping out the regime's propaganda. Last night it was in flames.

"They came with a truck and destroyed the entrance," said Tamara, a 28-year-old school teacher, as she watched the building burn. "If [Milosevic] stays here, people will put him on trial for everything he has done to make Serbs refugees from Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo."

The elation of the crowds was dampened when it was revealed that a girl had died after being run over by the bulldozer which stormed the parliament. Three other people were injured by bullets, Beta news agency said. About 100 suffered other injuries.

"This is the last time that Serbia and Yugoslavia will bleed for its freedom," a protester, Srdjan, said. "[Milosevic's] main crime is that he did not listen to his people, and hid in his bunker."

Popular wrath was directed only at buildings of political significance. Many people paraded through the streets with the chairs stolen from the parliament. Others waved abandoned police truncheons, riot shields and helmets.

"We will treasure this as a souvenir," said Zoran Petkovic, who runs a pet shop, as he and his girlfriend each held an arm of a leather chair they were taking home. "This is a memento of the day Slobo was finished."

Next to the television building a 17-year-old secondary school pupil said: "[Milosevic] destroyed the lives of millions of young people in this country. Our life was not normal." Yesterday's protest had begun before dawn as people from all over Serbia prepared to board buses for the capital in what was meant to be the climax of eight days of strikes and demonstrations after Mr Milosevic refused to recognise the opposition's victory in the elections on September 24.

As he refused to give way, the opposition put five demands which it said had to be met by 3pm. Charges against all strike leaders had to be lifted, the detained had to be set free, the editors of state-run radio and television had to be sacked and their places taken by people who would produce fair and objective reports, the election commission had to publish the proper results - which the opposition was convinced would show it with enough votes for a first-round victory. Above all, Mr Milosevic had to go.

Eight days of anger exploded after the constitutional court on Wednesday night responded to an opposition complaint of fraud in two of Serbia's electoral districts by declaring the entire election invalid.

The ruling raised the spectre that the poll would have to be run again at a time of Mr Milosevic's choosing. In the meantime, he would stay in power.

Charges against all strike leaders had to be lifted, the detained had to be set free, the editors of state-run radio and television had to be sacked and their places taken by people who would produce fair and objective reports, the election commission had to publish the proper results - which the opposition was convinced would show it with enough votes for a first-round victory. Above all, Mr Milosevic had to go. Eight days of anger exploded after the constitutional court on Wednesday night responded to an opposition complaint of fraud in two of Serbia's electoral districts by declaring the entire election invalid. The ruling raised the spectre that the poll would have to be run again at a time of Mr Milosevic's choosing. In the meantime, he would stay in power.

fields.headline: Bournemouth diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Away from the prying lenses of the world's media, an emotion charged handshake signalled the dawn of a new era as two senior Tories buried the hatchet. Ann Widdecombe and Michael Howard kissed and made up.
fields.body:
 Away from the prying lenses of the world's media, an emotion charged handshake signalled the dawn of a new era as two senior Tories buried the hatchet. Ann Widdecombe and Michael Howard kissed and made up to end a feud that rivalled those of new Labour. Doris Karloff and the man with "something of the night" about him, the Home Office's odd couple until they fell out and she destroyed his leadership ambitions, are back on speaking terms. Widdecombe's friends denied she was dazed at the time by a bad experience with drugs.

 Bosses of the BBC, or Bolshevik Broadcasting Corporation as one Willieville resident put it, bowed yesterday to Tory pressure. Michael Heseltine, who blows hot and cold about Hague, was lined up to be the main commentator during its live coverage of the Tory leader's speech. After central office protests, very on-message mouthpiece Andrew Lansley was picked to voice much of the (un)critical analysis with Hezza relegated to a lesser role.

 Mother Goose, aka Swaledale B&B proprietor Doreen Whitehead and purveyor of hearty fare to Hague, had a walk on part in the great Willieville pantomime. She tipped up for tea with the Tory leader ("he said hello Mother Goose") and a seat for his speech. Her favourite moment? "I have just met Richard Whitely," she cooed. "I've got a signed photograph of him. We watch Countdown every day."

 Bad Willieville party moment (1). The fizz went out of the Tories on the eve of Hague's speech when the Highcliff hotel was forced to introduce a "special offer" cutting Laurent Perrier Grand Siècle Vintage 1990 from £105 to £85 a bottle or, if you prefer, from 28 to 23 hours toil on the minimum wage.

 Bad Willieville party moment (2). Political editor Andrew Marr dancing at the BBC disco.

fields.headline: Cannabis country: the facts
fields.standfirst:
Special report: drugs in Britain
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Roast beef, warm beer, cricket, and cannabis. How Britain became a nation of dope smokers...
fields.body:
Perhaps she could have elicited more derision by proposing to make the saying of grace before dinner compulsory, or calling for on-the-spot fines for ladies who show their ankles in public. But failing that, it seems hard to imagine how else Ann Widdecombe could have invited as much undiluted scorn as she did by telling the Conservative party conference on Wednesday of her plan to levy fixed penalties of £100 on anyone found in possession of any quantity of cannabis. Not practical, said the Police Federation. A step backwards, said the Police Superintendents' Association. Not Conservative Party policy, said William Hague.

It instantly became clear that the response to her speech wasn't being bolstered by the recreational legalisation lobby - most of whom stopped wasting any of their chemically curtailed anger on the likes of Widdecombe long ago - or simply the indignation of medicinal users. Instead, it reflected a reality even her closest colleagues could not summon the energy to deny: that Britain, statistically speaking, is a nation of cannabis users just as much as it is a nation of golf players or a nation of casino gamblers. Those who behave as if it is still taboo can expect the same mixture of pity and amusement that they might receive had they declared an unshakeable faith in the tooth fairy.

According to the most recent figures (the 1998 British Crime Survey), 42% of 16 to 29 year olds have tried cannabis. There is a gulf between the under-30s and over-30s: taken as a whole, only 5% of 16 to 59 year olds had smoked a joint in the last month, though even that compares favourably with many activities, like playing football, or darts, or going jogging. The same statistics provide little evidence of the "slippery slope" argument: fewer than 0.5% of 16 to 29 year olds had taken heroin, crack or methadone in the last year; 3% had taken cocaine. "The experience of getting a criminal record [for cannabis] seems to be much more closely related to developing a future problem with heroin or crack cocaine than simply using cannabis," says Matthew Atha, director of the Independent Drug Monitoring Unit, a research consultancy. "So the experience of being busted is probably far more damaging to society as a whole."

Attitudes have shifted accordingly: a Mori poll published last year as part of the Police Foundation's radical report - which recommended downgrading marijuana to class C - found that 61% of the public considered cannabis "not very or not at all harmful"; only 15% felt the same way about tobacco. In places, the legal system has adjusted, too: if you even make it as far as a court after being arrested on suspicion of cannabis possession in Northamptonshire, for example, you stand only a 7% chance of being convicted. But in Dorset, the figure is 63% - and convictions for possession nationwide almost doubled from 26,600 to 40,199 between 1996 and 1998.

We spend somewhere between £2bn and £5bn annually on cannabis, according to the IDMU: at the higher end of this estimate, if it were a company, British Cannabis plc would be almost twice as large as ICI, or bigger than Stagecoach, Iceland, Airtours and Eurotunnel combined. About 60% of its business is in cannabis resin, predominantly north African, purchased wholesale at between £1,000 and £1,500 per kilo and smuggled through Spain, France and Belgium; the other 40% - in leaf form - is largely home-grown.

A mid-1990s study found that sales of Rizla cigarette papers had grown by 16% over a five year period during which sales of rolling tobacco had declined by 11%: draw your own conclusions.

The result, among younger people, has been a profound normalisation of cannabis use. "Our drug users are essentially extending the same decision-making processes to illicit drugs as others do in respect of cigarette smoking or drinking alcohol - or, indeed, horse-riding, hang gliding or mountaineering," three Manchester University researchers wrote in a pathbreaking 1998 study. "'It's your decision; you take the risk.' "

In the case of cannabis, much medical evidence would seem to suggest that the risk is considerably smaller than that attached to standing up in front of a roomful of people - even Conservative conference delegates - and proposing a hardline alternative.

fields.headline: Where there's smoke...
fields.standfirst:
Ann Widdecombe has been branded out of touch for proposing a crackdown on cannabis use. But who really smokes it? (And do they inhale?)

Special report: drugs in Britain
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe has been branded out of touch for proposing a crackdown on cannabis use. But who really smokes it? (And do they inhale?)
fields.byline: Interviews by Merope Mills, Nicola Norton, Claire Phipps and Zoe Rigden.
fields.body:
Ian McEwan, novelist

I certainly have smoked cannabis in the past. Ann Widdecombe's remarks about cannabis smoking are ludicrous. The swilling of 14 pints of lager constitutes a far greater social threat than a shared joint. One good development is that this pronouncement will alienate a lot of younger voters and keep the Conservatives out of power. I take heart from this. We've seen enough of them these past two decades.

Alex Salmond, former leader of the SNP

I have never answered the question of whether I have smoked cannabis and I don't intend to now. There are good reasons for not saying. If you say "yes" people claim you're encouraging and supporting it and if you say "no" it looks like you're a prick. So basically my answer is it's none of your business, but as far as Ann Widdecombe is concerned: I don't agree with her policy. I think she's a very foolish lady.

Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror

Do I smoke cannabis? No comment, but you can draw your own conclusions by our front page today. If I ever had smoked cannabis, and I'm not saying I have, I certainly would have inhaled. I'm sure it would have the same effect on me as most people - very little, calming and mellowing. Do I still smoke it? No - not that I ever did. I certainly do not currently partake in any drug taking, but my editing would probably improve if I did. Ann Widdecombe has lectured young people on the perils of having sex, while being a self-confessed virgin. She's now lecturing us on joints, having never been near one in her life. Her comments will have a derisory effect on young people in this country. Ecstasy and other class A drugs are the real problem.

Martin Bell , MP

I would not be in favour of criminalising people just for smoking marijuana though I am strongly opposed to drugs. I think the present policy of flexible response and caution is right. I've never smoked it myself. I'm so old, it wasn't even a temptation back in those days. It was hardly even heard of.

Ben Bradshaw, Labour MP

I think it's potty. It's a crack-pot idea. 'Scuse the puns. But the irony of William Hague toasting her speech with a glass of champagne just seems to have been lost on them. The police will tell you how barmy it all is. The idea we should be asking our already overstretched force to take time out from patrolling the streets to criminalise these people is absurd. I'm not answering the question of whether I've smoked it myself.

Nigel Evans, Conservative Party vice-chairman

I have never smoked cannabis and have turned it down on the few times I have been offered it. Like all so-called soft drugs, cannabis is a gateway to hard drugs. Cannabis is also highly dangerous - it is made up of 400 chemicals.

Michael Grade , chairman of Pinewood Studios

I'm on the record as saying I have [tried it] and yes, I did inhale. It was all right, not as good as Charlton winning. I don't have a strong view but, by and large, I think it should be decriminalised. I think the police have got better things to do.

Eleanor Laing, MP for Epping Forest, and shadow Welsh minister

I have never smoked anything, not even cigarettes. I have always preferred gin. At Edinburgh University I must have been to lots of parties where people may or may not have smoked cannabis. It never attracted me. In the law faculty, where I studied, nobody touched the stuff because they didn't want a criminal record.

Jacqui Lait, shadow social security minister

I tried smoking a cigarette when I was 10 or 11 and immediately gave up because it spoiled the taste of my food. I tried cannabis 10 years later, when I was working for Visnews, and it had the same unpleasant effect. One puff and it was not for me. I couldn't honestly tell you what the taste was like.

Jon Snow, newscaster

I have tried cannabis. I'm very bad at inhaling because I don't smoke, so I can't say I found it easy. It seemed to me to be perfectly mellow and the only drawback seemed to be the tobacco.

Charles Moore, editor of the Daily Telegraph

I don't think this is a suitable subject for autobiography. I think the Tories are quite mistaken. I'm against all on-the-spot fines because it gives too much power to the police without legal remedy. I also think it would be a huge burden on the police which would prevent them from pursuing crime that mattered more, and make them unnecessarily unpopular.

Stephen O'Brien, MP for Eddisbury and parliamentary aide to Tory party chairman Michael Ancram

Have I ever taken a banned substance? The answer to that is no. But when I was a student traveller in Peru in 1978 I chewed a coca cud because it was legal to do that at 9,000ft. I did it for three seconds and was sick. In Bali I was fed a magic mushroom omelette by Australian backpackers who had a good time at my expense.

Claire Rayner, agony aunt

Oh, of course I smoked it in the 60s - didn't we all try? But no, I didn't like it much. Everyone was trying it and I never believe in condemning something you don't know about, so I tried it but I didn't like it, but I don't like booze either. But alcohol and tobacco do infinitely more harm. I would like to refer Ann Widdecombe to a little bit of American history. Prohibition encourages people: a) to find the product terribly glamorous, and b) sets up a market for wicked people to make a fortune. The only sensible thing to do with cannabis - I'm not going to talk about the others - is to decriminalise it. Any government that has the sense to decriminalise it, shove a hefty tax on it and use the proceeds on the health service, now they would have some sense in them.

Roy Hattersley, Labour peer

My view of Ann Widdecombe's proposal is that it is impractical to an extent which proves that the Tory party is totally out of touch with 21st-century Britain. I've never taken cannabis, and I never would. I'd be terrified out of my wits.

Martin Amis , novelist

The proposal is miserably retrograde. Cannabis should be legalised. I've experimented with it myself, but I'm not telling you if I take it now; if I say that she'll be round here, won't she?

Anthony Julius, solicitor

I wouldn't like to comment on Widdecombe's proposals because I don't know my own mind on the matter.

Bill Giles, former BBC weatherman

I've never smoked it. I've just not come across it. The job I had in the early days meant you didn't have much of a social life anyway. You used to get the odd one who smoked some wacky baccy, but we did something just as bad, which was drinking a lot of beer. In my day it would have been frowned of because it was just "horror, horror, horror, it's drugs" and any drug was under the same title, but now I don't think it would bother too many people. I don't have strong views about it except when it comes to kids. If my child or my grandchild used it I'd probably go ape. I'm not absolutely sure whether it leads to anything else - if not it's not too much of a problem. Unless in 20 years time, like with cigarettes, we find it's been causing lots of damage.

Zadie Smith, novelist

I have never smoked cannabis in my life ... OK, so I have, but I'm not a huge smoker. I've no objection to it being smoked - it makes people merry. What is there to say about it? It's such an innocuous drug; everyone does it. I would say there are certain people you go to school with who just smoke it forever, and they become quite dull. Ann Widdecombe's idea? I think Ann must have been smoking too much.

Andrew Neil, publisher and editor-in-chief, The Scotsman

I've never tried it because I'm a rebel and in the 60s everybody was taking it. I didn't like the smell so I'm not happy to be in a room where everybody's smoking it. But if I'm walking down the King's Road and a bunch of kids are coming the other way I'd rather they were high on a bit of weed than tanked up on Carlsberg. I think [Ann Widdecombe's proposal] is bonkers. When you think of all the problems of crime, to start picking up kids because they've got a couple of pieces of marijuana is bizarre.

Lewis Wolpert, biologist

Everybody smokes dope. The policy is just monstrous, completely out of touch with reality. Have I smoked it? Certainly, of course. Very seldom, now, but I would unhesitatingly have some - and why not? It's lovely. All young people do, too. How dare the Tories interfere. Two-thirds of violent crimes are associated with alcohol. What percentage is involved with pot? Absolutely none. It doesn't make for violence; in fact, you become quite boring. It's outrageous that it isn't freely available. I don't see Ann Widdecombe saying the same things about alcohol. Her speech was impertinent and out of touch.

Peter Bazalgette, creative director of Endemol, creators of Big Brother

The idea is completely ludicrous, utterly ridiculous. She made herself a laughing stock. Alcohol causes far more problems, and yet she attacks drugs and then downs a glass of champagne. She should be fined for antisocial behaviour. It's fantastically ironic, and pathetic. I have smoked it, the answer has to be yes, like most of my generation. I don't so regularly now, but certainly when I was a schoolboy in the 60s and a student, yes. There are problems with it; there are problems with any substance that intoxicates you. It depends on how it's handled in society. In this case, the law is obviously an ass. The Tories are going in the wrong direction. There are so many more important things to concentrate on.

Peregrine Worsthorne, former editor of the Sunday Telegraph

It's a ridiculous thing to do - even more ridiculous than the American prohibition idea, which, of course, was a terrible flop. You can't pass a law which a significant minority are not going to pay any attention to. You can't get crazier than that. I have smoked it. It wasn't for me. I'm an alcohol addict, so I didn't need anything extra. But so many friends do smoke it. It's now just a common occurrence.

Peter Carter-Ruck, solicitor

I resigned from the Conservative Party because of their failure to deal with law and order. I admire Ann Widdecombe, but I don't think that one zero tolerance measure will deal with the problem of drugs. It needs to be dealt with in a far more sophisticated way. A £100 fine is not enough - some young people would brag about it. A correction course would be better, with instruction on the great harm of drugs. That would be much more effective. I've never tried drugs and I wouldn't risk it. There is such a great danger of becoming addicted. The thing with drugs is that the effect wears off, and then you have to take something a little stronger.

Alcohol causes far more problems, and yet she attacks drugs and then downs a glass of champagne. She should be fined for antisocial behaviour. It's fantastically ironic, and pathetic. I have smoked it, the answer has to be yes, like most of my generation. I don't so regularly now, but certainly when I was a schoolboy in the 60s and a student, yes. There are problems with it; there are problems with any substance that intoxicates you. It depends on how it's handled in society. In this case, the law is obviously an ass. The Tories are going in the wrong direction. There are so many more important things to concentrate on. Peregrine Worsthorne, former editor of the Sunday Telegraph It's a ridiculous thing to do - even more ridiculous than the American prohibition idea, which, of course, was a terrible flop. You can't pass a law which a significant minority are not going to pay any attention to. You can't get crazier than that. I have smoked it. It wasn't for me. I'm an alcohol addict, so I didn't need anything extra. But so many friends do smoke it. It's now just a common occurrence. I admire Ann Widdecombe, but I don't think that one zero tolerance measure will deal with the problem of drugs. It needs to be dealt with in a far more sophisticated way. A £100 fine is not enough - some young people would brag about it. A correction course would be better, with instruction on the great harm of drugs. That would be much more effective. I've never tried drugs and I wouldn't risk it. There is such a great danger of becoming addicted. The thing with drugs is that the effect wears off, and then you have to take something a little stronger.

fields.headline: Widdecombe fights back firm
fields.standfirst:
Drugs row

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe refused to water down her anti-drugs policy yesterday as she hit back at the Tory leadership, which distanced William Hague from her plans.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe refused to water down her anti-drugs policy yesterday as she hit back at the Tory leadership, which distanced William Hague from her plans.

Angered by hostile briefings, the shadow home secretary declared that there would be "no rowing back" on her plan to impose an automatic £100 fine on anyone caught in possession of cannabis.

She predicted that her policy would be included in the Tories' manifesto for the next election and said that both Mr Hague and Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, had been briefed on her plans. The Tory high command was in disarray over the policy yesterday when the party chairman, Michael Ancram, appeared to be unaware of a Tory briefing note outlining the new penalty.

In an interview with ITN, he said that the Widdecombe plan would not criminalise cannabis users because the fines would be imposed in the same way as a speeding ticket. When it was pointed out that a Tory briefing paper said offenders would "receive a criminal record", he refused to be drawn. Tory sources said later that the briefing document was wrong.

The row over Ms Widdecombe's plan, which formed the centrepiece of her conference speech on Wednesday, cast a shadow over the party's final day in Bournemouth yesterday. Ms Widdecombe hit back as leadership sources distanced Mr Hague from the policy late on Wednesday night after the plans were dismissed by the police and human rights groups.

"William Hague has been aware of this policy and has cleared it," she said. "Michael Portillo was aware of the cost implications and cleared it. I do not understand where these rumours that it has not been cleared have come from."

It is understood that the first Mr Portillo knew of the £100 automatic fine was when he heard Ms Widdecombe's speech. She had cleared the general policy with him - she needed his approval to fund the extra police needed - but not spelled out all the details.

Central office sources were gleeful about the damage inflicted on Ms Widdecombe. "It is extraordinary that she should come up with such a policy without running it past the police."

Such criticism surprised Ms Widdecombe yesterday because Mr Hague's advisers were involved in promoting the policy before her speech.Mr Hague's chief spokesman, Nick Wood, briefed right-wing newspapers on the policy the night before the speech and was said to be delighted with the favourable coverage.

Speaking at a fringe meeting organised by Charter 88 and the YMCA yesterday, Ms Widdecombe said: "I would not expect one fixed penalty fine to actually prejudice someone's life."

webTitle: Tories pitch for poll position with radical blend of old and new

fields.headline: Tories pitch for poll position with radical blend of old and new
fields.standfirst:
Policy Hague looks to US for ideas to reach beyond core voters

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: William Hague started this week's pre-election conference by promising One Nation politics and he ended four relatively successful days by returning to the theme, promising to govern for all the people and even for all hard working families - the term first coined in the United States by New Democrats such as Bill Clinton and Al Gore.
fields.body:
William Hague started this week's pre-election conference by promising One Nation politics and he ended four relatively successful days by returning to the theme, promising to govern for all the people and even for all hard working families - the term first coined in the United States by New Democrats such as Bill Clinton and Al Gore.

For the true political purpose of this week for the Conservatives was not just to tap into the evident disillusionment with the government, but to reposition the party - and its state educated leader, William Hague - as a party that can reach out beyond its core vote.

The loudest cheers in the conference hall were reserved for the familiar attacks on Brussels, section 28 or the dome. But Central Office knew that if they were to be truly ready for government, and the electorate was to be ready for the Conservatives, Mr Hague needed to seize back the issues on which elections are fought and lost: the economy, education and health.

Just as George W. Bush's US election campaign is focused on traditional Democrat issues such as schools and health care reform, so Mr Hague knows he has to have something distinctive to say across the policy board. In his closing speech, he tried hard to shift from traditional Tory ground.

Alongside the "common sense" Tory issues of tax cuts, nationalism and crime, he tried to reconnect with teachers by promising better comprehensive schools, and with doctors by increasing overall spending on health. The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, has promised to spend as much as Labour did in any year of its first term.

Yet this concern for the public services does not mean Mr Hague has chosen to return to some kind of post-war or even Majorite consensus on welfare, health and schools. His aides insist there is no ideological contradiction between traditional Tory themes and trying to reach out to new voters.

Mr Hague has this week extended the Conservatives' privatisation agenda of the 1980s into areas that Lady Thatcher never considered. His ideology, seen in the round for the first time at this conference, is based on the assertion that the private sector is best equipped to run schools, improve health care and regenerate inner cities.

In some cases Labour has travelled the same road, contemplating some private sector school companies, a wider role for private health insur ance, and public-private partnerships in the cities. But the Hague plans are altogether more radical. In education, for instance, he is no longer just promising grammar schools in every town, but that his free schools scheme will allow every state school, largely out of the control of the local education authority, to introduce entry by selection. Many current state schools would be funded by private firms.

Similarly, the scale of the revolution being proposed by the shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, in the NHS is potentially vast. Mr Fox presents his proposals as pragmatic and non-ideological. He is promising to match Labour spending on NHS and make private health care more attractive by lifting some of Gordon Brown's taxes on private health insurance. The private sector would complement rather than replace the NHS.

This clearly does not represent the privatisation of the NHS, but as Matthew Taylor, the director of the leftwing IPPR think-tank told a fringe meeting in Bournemouth: "Any insurance based system, however you manage it, will lead to greater inequality of access to health care. Over time, the state system becomes a residual system and any service reserved for poor people becomes a poor service."

On environment and transport, Archie Norman's radical plans to revive deprived inner cities by setting up regeneration companies and issue bonds to prime and run key services has huge, and so far, ill-explained consequences for local democracy. These pri vately run regeneration companies, on which local councillors would have minority seats, go further than the enterprise zones run by Michael Heseltine in the mid-1980s - with a loosely defined role in taking over failing schools. Even police manpower would in part be brought under control of the private sector.

Housing associations and regeneration companies would be free to buy in extra policing to ensure a higher density of uniformed officers.

In welfare, drawing on a scheme already in place in various US states, the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, is proposing that private sector firms should take responsibility for finding work for the unemployed, in effect replacing public sector job centres. In time, the role of the basic state pension would be reduced as younger people would be encouraged to take out private pension schemes funded from the stock market.

The Conservatives have been criticised for failing to offer sufficient detail for such a radical programme, but Mr Hague's advisers argue that the aim is to present themes and that they are constantly struggling to dissuade frontbench spokesmen from going into the positioning of desks.

But it is a tribute to Mr Hague's revived fortunes that the public is beginning to examine what is potentially the most radical programme to be offered to the British people in many decades.

webTitle: Woolly words for a wider flock

fields.headline: Woolly words for a wider flock
fields.standfirst:
Special report: William Hague
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: William Hague addressed the Tory conference like a rather cross sheep. He loves lists, and he bleats them out in a very sheeplike voice: "For all the people who are sick of the spin and the waste and the lies and the cronies and the sycophants..." Sycophants, eh, don't they make yer sick?
fields.body:
William Hague addressed the Tory conference like a rather cross sheep. He loves lists, and he bleats them out in a very sheeplike voice: "For all the people who are sick of the spin and the waste and the lies and the cronies and the sycophants..." Sycophants, eh, don't they make yer sick?

If sheep had pubs (with lounge baas) regulars would cluster together when he walked in. They'd avoid eye contact. They'd take a close interest in the flock wallpaper. He'd approach him with a smile on his woolly face, but they would hurriedly drink up.

"Yer know what I think, lads: red tape is prolific, waste is endemic, the bureaucracy is bloated, and political correctness is rampant. Now, what's yours? Or ewe's?"

"That's reet kind of you," they would mutter into their now empty glasses. "But I'd best be off home or the missus'll have me docked..."

I assume that the dullness of the speech, which left Tory delegates cheering and clapping but curiously unsatisfied, was deliberate. Mr Hague was talking to the country rather than to them.

The point is that Conservative conferences are quite different from Conservative voters. Millions of people vote Conservative, but only rather strange people come to Conservative conferences - people with staring eyes, people whose centre of gravity is one foot from the floor, people who wear weird glasses, young men who look as if their hair was cut with pruning shears, people who wear pound signs in their lapels; in short, people unlike any other people we know.

But they are well aware that they are set apart from the rest of us. That's why they were so pathetically grateful for the arrival of Jim Davidson, the comedian, who made the appeal for funds in the unavoidable absence of Jeffrey Archer.

Mr Davidson wasn't actually funny: "I know the chancellor is grateful for all those Olympic gold medals; he wants to melt them down to prop up the euro" was one of the better gags, but it didn't matter.

They roared hysterically, because they were so pleased and touched that he had come, a real famous person who occasionally appears on television, unlike the shadow cabinet. Imagine Terry Wogan arriving on the platform with the train spotters in Crewe. They'd be thrilled.

Before the leader's entrance, the shadow cabinet was ushered on stage. It was a series of small humiliations which the party management visited upon them. When Ann Widdecombe came out from behind the lights, her face was lit by a hideous green. Then Michael Portillo, bathed in blue. He looked like Richard Nixon with a hangover.

The two were forced to sit together, since Mr Hague knows that as long as these two rivals cancel each other out, his position is safe. Then they were forced to sit through jaw aching tributes to constituency chairmen, agents and membership secretaries.

Finally Mr Davidson walked over and demanded money from them. "Come on," he said, "they don't spend a lot on clothes, do they?"

Then the leader emerged. Or rather we had a dramatically dull cine-verite shot of him walking down corridors to the platform. As he reached the hall the stage lights changed to a brilliant, dazzling white, like a Victorian painting of the kingdom of heaven. Triumphalist, martial music boomed out. He stood smiling in the lights, the fighting foetus, ready to rock. His trousers were surprisingly crumpled. Memo to Tory leader: if you decide to wrestle a few energising rounds with Seb Coe before a speech, take your suit off first.

Finally the speech was over, and we emerged blinking from the light. On cable news, Belgrade was burning. Poor William, upstaged by the people of Serbia, but also, deliberately, by himself.


How the conference saw it

Jim Davidson, comedian, ardent Tory fundraiser, and warm-up act for Mr Hague.

"He was very good, wasn't he, much better than that other funny bloke - what's he called, the prime minister? This is a politician that speaks from the heart, rather than just saying, like Blair, anything he thinks people want to hear."

Michael Heseltine , former deputy prime minister.

"This is a speech that's placed him firmly back in the centre of the great tradition of one nation Conservatism and drawn the battle lines from which the Conservatives will appeal across a broad front to the British people. The divisions over Europe will remain. But if Europe is the one area of policy about which there will remain disagreement, on a vast range of policies there will be unity."

Lord Strathclyde, Tory leader in the Lords.

"William Hague is an orator - but this wasn't just a normal, highly effective performance. He was reaching out to people who share Conservative values but weren't here for the conference - people in inner cities, in sink estates, people on pensions, who feel politicians have let them down."

Doreen Whitehead, aka "Mother Goose"- William Hague's friend of 10 years and kitchen table adviser.

In her sixties and from Keld, Swaledale, North Yorkshire, she runs a B&B where the Hagues often stay and where he "tests out" future policies with her. "It was a wonderful speech. It made me so happy and so proud of William that everything just welled up inside me. It also made me feel so British and we want to stay that way, controlling our own destiny, setting our own interest rates."

Sharon Buckle, a pharmacist and would-be Tory candidate, from Nottingham.

"It wasn't a tirade. It wasn't too over the top about being British. It was very sensible, very open, very honest, and it was upbeat. What came across to me very strongly was his stature. A lot of people have said in the past he's too funny, whereas today he was talking to the adults, and what we saw was him being very statesmanlike. Genuinely PM material."

Ray Miles, aged 76, a retired site manager from Wellinborough, Northants.

"His speech was absolutely excellent. First class. He covered all sorts of issues and I think he appealed to the younger generation as well as us older ones. I don't know why you say the applause was subdued: from where we were he seemed to be rapturously received. And of course I was particularly pleased because of his pledge to keep the pound."

Liam Fox, shadow health secretary.

"I thought it was the most mature conference speech he's given. It was less gimmicky and I think it was reaching out to people beyond the hall in a much more effective way.

"What it did was to say to people: If you're becoming disillusioned with politicians, if you think they're all the same, they're not. The tone of the speech also treated the audience with respect, as intelligent people capable of grasping subtle messages. I really liked it a lot."

fields.headline: Placing a heavy bet on disillusionment
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Yesterday, William Hague felt obliged to remind  us nine times that the Conservative party was ready to govern.
fields.body:
A political party exists to govern. That's what parties are for. They're not for clog-dancing, flag-waving, or even for debating the finer points of education policy. Yet nine times, yesterday, William Hague felt obliged to remind us that the Conservative party was ready to govern. What a discovery! Never has a leader protested so often that his entire purpose in life is, actually, within his capacity. The more resonantly he repeated it, the more it dawned that this might be exactly the thing he wasn't ready for.

This was a performance of extraordinary emptiness. Here was not a government-in-waiting but an opposition that has yet to develop a constructive view of the world it might inherit. The entire thrust of Mr Hague's pre-governmental speech was negative. It depended for all its best lines on Labour's iniquity and for all its political energy on the trite proposition that disillusioned voters will prefer anything to the present lot.

It was plainly trying to connect with the generalised sense of discontent that burst out of last month's fuel crisis and became the pretext for the Tories' advance in the polls. But because Mr Hague misunderstands the nature of this public cynicism, he failed to address the true anxieties underlying it. He placed a heavy bet on total disillusionment - as if this absolved him from getting to grips with any deeper reality, beginning with his own inability to strike a chord with a congregation beyond the home church.

His critique did chime, at a certain level, with the public mood. There have been a lot of Labour failures. People look at the health service and wonder whether they would ever get a hospital bed. They were appalled by Mr Blair's inability to keep the petrol tankers running. The Greenwich dome is no longer even worth a sick joke. Three-and-a-half years is a long enough period for the blame for many things to be switched from the Thatcher-Major years to the Blair record.

It is also fair enough to rail against the cronyism of New Labour, and light a fire under the elitist bistros of Islington. The Blair style has had arrogance pinned on it, but the more credible reproach is that it is out of touch. Laying claim to the real heart of old England, though Wales and Scotland were not mentioned, is standard stuff for an opposition leader.

But people are not that stupid. Mr Hague spoke like someone who thought public cynicism derived from fury with Labour, failing to see that the problem is not rage but caustic indifference. They didn't have especially high hopes of Labour. A lot more than Mr Hague's ranting will be needed to persuade them that he would be much different.

When he allowed us some relief from his anti-Blair hyperbole, and his insecurity about being fit for government, he ran over the thin policy pickings: lower fuel taxes, "free" schools, tax relief for private health insurance, jail for asylum seekers. But the general thrust was insulting in its lack of specifics. Though the speech had a certain hard-line coherence - nothing here for inclusive softies - it treated his wider audience with intellectual effrontery.

Mr Hague expects the voters to be satisfied with the mere assertion of a better way, rather than its depiction. He devoted not a single line to expounding a credible position on tax-and-spend or how he would satisfy the taxpayer's revolt without provoking the service-user's revenge. webTitle: Hague appeals to blue collar vote

fields.headline: Hague reaches out to blue collar vote
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader's political gamble fails to enthuse party activists

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday sacrificed a ritual Conservative conference triumph with a speech which reached out beyond the Tory heartlands in an attempt to woo disaffected blue collar Labour voters.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday sacrificed a ritual Conservative conference triumph with a speech which reached out beyond the Tory heartlands in an attempt to woo disaffected blue collar Labour voters.

Seven months before the expected May election, the Tory leader used his 49-minute address in Bournemouth to tell floating voters that the Conservatives had learned from past mistakes and want to govern pragmatically "for all the people".

He was firm on the need for tax cuts, but promised better health care and schools, inner city revival and pension rises, all services on which Labour is finally spending billions.

The speech was strong in its populist tone - "no government in recent times has been as tough on criminals as we will be" - but conspicuously short on specific policies.

Labour was quick to complain that the sums did not add up, and that £16bn worth of cuts would follow a Tory victory. It was another key election issue to which Mr Hague made virtually no mention.

Instead he mocked senior ministers and abused Tony Blair as an actor without principles "who is prepared to say whatever will please his audience without the slightest consistent thought or principle entering his head".

What was immediately noticeable was that Mr Hague's oratory did not work its usual magic with the activists in the hall. His speech was punctuated by desultory applause, except during pledges to protect Britain's independence - and the pound - from the EU.

So confident was he that his three year "common sense revolution" has reconnected the Tories with what he repeatedly called "the mainstream majority", the ordinary voters Labour has allegedly ignored, that he challenged Mr Blair to an immediate election. "Go on Tony, call it now," he said.

The volatile state of public opinion, which has seen Labour first lose, then regain an eight-point poll lead in the past month, makes it unlikely that Mr Hague wants his bluff called, especially after this week's mixed messages on social tolerance which pitted Ann Widdecombe against Michael Portillo yesterday.

In a contrite tone which echoed Mr Blair's acknowledgement that voters are alienated by politicians, he said: "I don't think we'll solve every problem, avoid every mistake... I just want to govern with the common sense instincts of the people."

His assessment of those instincts was a blend of familiar rightwing nostrums on Europe, crime, asylum, tax and wasted public spending, and new efforts to persuade people that he understands the fears and aspirations of those who live on sink estates and struggle to pay their way. "I'm in it for you," he kept saying.

Given the mixed signals which some shadow ministers have delivered, Mr Hague said: "There are some who say there is a contradiction between traditional Conservative issues and winning new Tory audiences; between tolerance and championing the mainstream values of the country. There is no contradiction. Being tough on crime, believing in lower taxes and the robust defence of our nation's independence are not in contradiction with wanting better schools and hospitals, and thriving inner cities. They are an essential part of achieving those things."

fields.headline: Is this really the rudest woman on TV?
fields.standfirst: 'I'm not really horrible. I have my moments but I'm only there on behalf of the viewer.' Anne Robinson, pitiless presenter of The Weakest Link, tells  Simon Hattenstone what she thinks about that TV Times vote
fields.trailText: 'I'm not really horrible. I have my moments but I'm only there on behalf of the viewer.' Anne Robinson, pitiless presenter of The Weakest Link, tells Simon Hattenstone what she thinks about that TV Times vote.
fields.body:
Anne Robinson lies on her sofa in her black leather pants and her black boots and her black sleeveless T-shirt, knees up, legs akimbo. We're at her Kensington home, she feels relaxed; I feel like a gynaecologist. The investigative journalist, bitchy columnist, consumer champion and TV personality has finally transcended her previous achievements. She's now a fully-fledged star. As presenter of the phenomenally successful afternoon programme The Weakest Link, she has just been voted the rudest woman on television by the TV Times.

The Weakest Link is the general knowledge equivalent of Big Brother. Contestants form a team and fight for money. In the process they stab fellow contestants in the back and front, as they vote the others off the team round by round. There are none of the niceties associated with quiz shows. Robinson berates the players, tells them they are a disappointment, that they deserve to be dumped. When they lose they leave with nothing beyond the curtest "You are the weakest link. Goodbye." There's something of the school ma'am in her, something of the dominatrix, something of the PoW camp commandant.

I tell Robinson that when I see her I want to turn the television off, that I can't abide her, she's vile. "Did you come back and watch again? All I can say is 4.8m viewers at 5.15pm. What else can I say, Simon."

John Penrose, her husband and manager, serves the coffee, and asks if it's OK. Occasionally she calls him Johnny, but more often Penrose. I can't help thinking of Hudson in Upstairs Downstairs. He's off to buy Annie a new printer. She buys a lot of printers. Actually, she buys a lot of everything. Robinson tells me how yesterday she was shopping and came across this wonderful wallet for her Psion organiser. The only problem was that she didn't have an organiser. She bought it anyway. Still, what's £200?

"I said you're supposed to look at the features of an organiser before you buy the case," Penrose says. "Shall I just give you a kiss for the benefit of the visiting journalist?" He plonks a smacker on her crown as he leaves. She gives him a farewell wink.

Ask journalists what Robinson was like 30 years ago and you get a pile of admiring tributes - what a great reporter she was, smart, unflappable, determined. Ask people who have worked with her more recently. They tend to talk about her bossiness, her intolerance, her queenliness, and the banality of her columns in the Times.

What the carpers can't deny is Robinson's success. She was famously the best-paid woman in British journalism, and recently said she planned to earn £1m a year. Had she managed it? She shuts her legs. "Yes. Actually, last year I hit two million. But I work really hard. We didn't quite hit it, and I said to Penrose, let's do one more gig."

She loves money, says that she always thought the smart way to freedom for women was through the purse strings. "It cut out a lot of crap and a lot of having to go to meetings to campaign for equality." She stage-whispers when I ask her for figures - the £2m, the £250,000 advance for her autobiography, the £350 for her leather pants.

Money isn't everything, though, she says. Take TV - you must be careful with the choices you make. She gives out handy hints by the second. Robinson was asked to read the news way before Angela Rippon but she turned it down. "I thought I was too good a journalist to do that." She's got a fabulous way with putdowns. The black suede boot with steel toecaps.

The Weakest Link has been called "mean TV". She says she doesn't know about that, but what she does know is that so much television is bogus, soft, and offers false comforts. "It's not Noel Edmonds, Lulu, Little and Large. There's an edge to it. They say they couldn't have found anyone else who is prepared to talk like that."

What does she mean? "Well I'm not really a showbiz person. I'm just a direct person." Did they mean they couldn't find anyone who would be so horrid to the contestants? She recoils. "I'm not really horrible." You have your moments. "I have my moments, but I'm only there on behalf of the viewer."

She's certainly not being horrible now. Far from it.

"What about having a look at the photos?" She gives me a guided tour. Annie Robinson, a life in pictures. Here's Annie in the pony club as a kid ("middle class me"), Annie with Michael Foot and Jill Craigie not long before she died - "My Labour credentials. No don't quote that. They're like step-parents ... sooooh sad." Her first marriage to Charlie Wilson. "Those knees! I look like Cilla Black." Wilson is her first husband, father of her daughter Emma and her former boss at the Mirror.

"Charlie rang Johnny yesterday because I was voted the rudest woman on television and they both said that the public had learnt what they'd known for 30 years."

Why is she so rude? "I don't think I am that rude, Simon." But they do. "It was a joke. God almighty, as Emma says, j-o-k-e. What else can we show you?"

Of course she's not rude. She talks about journalists who have visited in the past. "The advantage of you, Simon, is you're not female, you're not tired , you've not got a problem with not having a boyfriend, you're not worried about the cats at home, and you're not drinking all my white wine. Because that's often the situation I find myself in sitting here." Brilliant! Massage my ego, while putting down the rest of the world.

She tells me of a journalist who said she had flabby arms. "What d'you think? Have a go." I take her upper arm and give it a wobble as instructed. Have you been working on them? "Yes, I've been swimming every morning. Do you work out?" I say I've done the occasional press-up in my time. "Do you have a male or female partner?" Female. "How old are your kids?" Eight and six. "You don't look old enough." Rudest woman in Britain!

She starts impersonating Margaret Thatcher, and says that after all those years hounding her she discovered she admired her courage. Does she detest weakness? "Well all bullies hate weakness." Are you a bully? "Yes. I'll bully anyone who's up to it." She mentions Watchdog when she's had enough of listening to her juniors and says, "No, right, we're doing it this way."

She says she's never been a team player and returns to her childhood to explain why. Her mother started selling chickens on the market and became the poultry queen of the north-west. "One of the problems in life is that all the qualities you require to get ahead in a commercial way require you to not trust and do your own things and to hell with the rest, and in a sense they are opposite to the qualities you require to live in harmony with a partner."

Robinson has a knack of telling anecdotes from out of the blue. She talks about Ian MacGregor, Thatcher's henchman in the mining strike. "He was married for 47 years, and everyday he asked his wife whether she took sugar in her tea."

Does she relate to that? "I certainly keep forgetting whether Penrose's birthday is the 9th or 10th. But I know the first car registration I had at 18. PAR18."

The conflict between team play and individual ambition is at the heart of the Weakest Link. She tells me of a tribe in Uganda that had been dumped in the mountains, and how within three generations they had turned into savages who threw out their grandparents when they couldn't provide food. "I believe there's a savage in most people."

I tell her again that I think the way the quiz show exploits the savage in us all is cruel. "You're missing the whole point, Simon." Which is? "The point is ... Somebody at the BBC, somebody very courageous, said I don't like you on that programme. You are so rude, and I just went, 4.8 ... the viewing figures are unheard of."

She asks me if I'd like something to eat. "Because I'm always on a low carbohydrate diet, we've only got raspberries and yoghurt or All Bran and yoghurt. Simon, can I just say I'm now 56 ... I do enjoy the position of not that many people arguing with me. Do I look 56?" she does a twirl.

What if I said to you, yes you do, and some. She burst out laughing. "I'd say you're lying. You're lying. Because I don't look 'and some'. 50 maybe."

Anyway this rudeness stuff, she says, is nonsense. "If you see the show once you think I'm very rude, if you see it more than once and you see the wink at the end you know it's a conspiracy between me and the viewers." Conspiracy shmiracy, it's just Annie and her old shtick. She says the Annie of Watchdog is much closer to her real self than the Annie of the Weakest Link, but I'm not so sure.

We're running out of time. Robinson has to be at the Beeb for Watchdog. "They can't start without me." On the way out she hands me a press release from yet another telly thing she's doing. "It won't do you any harm darling." She once said that in order to succeed in life you need an uncrushable belief in yourself. Has she had it? No, she says, everyone's vulnerable. "No one who drank like I did has an uncrushable belief in themselves. The opposite." She's been a teetotaller for 20 years. "Don't do my drinking story, its soooooh boring."

Her driver gives me a lift to the tube, and she's dishing out the advice in the back.

She stares at me intensely, and pops the question. "So what do you want to do?" I look blank, bewildered. "Whose job d'you want?" she asks in a hurried whisper. No one's, I say, I like what I'm doing, I don't want anyone's job. She stammers her reply. "Well, that's good isn't it?" But she looks horrified.

We're running out of time. Robinson has to be at the Beeb for Watchdog. "They can't start without me." On the way out she hands me a press release from yet another telly thing she's doing. "It won't do you any harm darling." She once said that in order to succeed in life you need an uncrushable belief in yourself. Has she had it? No, she says, everyone's vulnerable. "No one who drank like I did has an uncrushable belief in themselves. The opposite." She's been a teetotaller for 20 years. "Don't do my drinking story, its soooooh boring." Her driver gives me a lift to the tube, and she's dishing out the advice in the back. She stares at me intensely, and pops the question. "So what do you want to do?" I look blank, bewildered. "Whose job d'you want?" she asks in a hurried whisper. No one's, I say, I like what I'm doing, I don't want anyone's job. She stammers her reply. "Well, that's good isn't it?" But she looks horrified.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Up, Down And Sideways/The Impresarios
fields.body:
Sue Perkins investigates the mythology of lifts in Up, Down And Sideways (11.0am, Radio 4). After 150 years of operation, they have inevitably gathered a deep patina of anecdote. The great technical breakthrough came from Elisha Otis in 1853, when he invented a gadget to stop faulty lifts plunging to the ground. But Graham Coates knows all about the other side of the story. His faulty lift stopped wonderfully safely - then caged him for 62 hours before he was rescued.

The larger-than-life characters who bankroll the entertainment business are put under the microscope by Michael Freedland in The Impresarios (10.0pm, Radio 2). First of his six subjects is Florenz Ziegfeld, who devised the famous Follies in 1907. He worked as manager for a strong man at the Chicago World's Fair in 1893, until he realised that bulging male biceps would never attract punters like the female gluteus maximus. And he did his own casting.
