fields.headline: The message from the west: get out
fields.standfirst:
World leaders unite in warning Yugoslav president against using force on demonstrators, but rule out military intervention

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The west piled on the pressure on President Milosevic last night in the hope that he might finally be pushed out of office.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  and Julian Borger  in Washington
fields.body:
The west piled on the pressure on President Milosevic last night in the hope that he might finally be pushed out of office.

The US, French, German and British governments united in warning him against using force to quell protesters and calling on him to accept the will of the population and resign.

United States

President Bill Clinton yesterday ruled out the possibility of US military intervention in Serbia, but Washington stepped up pressure on Moscow to recognise the opposition victory in last month's election.

Mr Clinton said the international community should stand by "the will of the people" but warned that any overt interference in the course of events could backfire.

"I don't believe it's an appropriate case for military intervention and I don't believe the US should say or do anything that would only strengthen Milosevic's hand," he said.

Mr Clinton said that even though the opposition candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, had "strong differences with us", the US would respect his election victory.

"This is not a question of whether he agrees with us," Mr Clinton said. "All we want for the Serbian people is what we want for people everywhere - the right to choose their leaders... The people are trying to get their country back."

Russia

President Vladimir Putin continued to adopt an even-handed approach to the crisis in Belgrade, seemingly untouched by the events on the streets.

He said his offer remained to mediate if Mr Milosevic and Mr Kostunica were prepared to travel to Moscow. He called on other countries to support his initiative.

Speaking to reporters in Bombay on the final day of a visit to India, Mr Putin said Russia would adjust its position as details emerged of the constitutional court decision in Belgrade annulling the September 24 election.

"We would like the dramatic events in Yugoslavia, our friend, to end with a close to the crisis and the lifting of sanctions," he said. "We are prepared to work with the international community and with the sides in Yugoslavia to achieve that goal. My offer still stands."

Britain

The prime minister, Tony Blair, joined the chorus urging Mr Milosevic to leave. But the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, was cautious about military intervention, fearing such a threat from either the US or Britain could provide Mr Milosevic with an excuse to declare a state of emergency.

"The verdict of the people in the election is clear," Mr Blair said. "The verdict of the people in the streets is clear. The message for Milosevic is clear.

"Your time is up. Go now. Don't wait until there has been more death and destruction."

Mr Cook avoided any hints of Nato intervention: "I'm not making threats. The last thing that would be helpful for the people of Serbia today is threats. That is what he wants."

France

President Jacques Chirac endorsed the protests. "Serbs are confirming today their [election] victory of September 24 and Milosevic must understand this," he said.

"If he did not, he would con front his country with the worst dangers. History cannot be stopped.

"I want to solemnly tell all those who support Milosevic that they are taking very, very big risks and a very, very serious responsibility towards their country."

Germany

Chancellor Gerhard Schröder urged restraint by both Mr Milosevic and opposition leaders. "My appeal is: don't resort to violence, don't shoot on your own people. That would be catastrophic," he said.

He warned that violence in Belgrade would trigger "resistance" from the international community.

European Union

The EU condemned the constitutional court's decision to annul the election. "The only aim of this decision is to deny the victory of Vojislav Kostunica in the September 24 poll," a statement issued by the French presidency of the 15-country union said.

"Slobodan Milosevic, after trying to rig the results of the September 24 poll and hold a fraudulent second round, is trying again to steal victory in a stubborn rearguard battle."

United Nations

The secretary general, Kofi Annan, said there was little the UN could do to defuse the situation or help opposition forces ease Mr Milosevic out.

"There have been quite a lot of statements by UN member states who have tried to move the situation forward and encourage a rapid solution," Mr Annan said. "Beyond that I'm not sure if there is any concrete action one can take in this situation."

Greece

The government of Greece, much of whose population opposed the Nato bombing of Belgrade last year, warned that if Mr Milosevic used force against demonstrating civilians he could spark a civil war.

"It would be tragic for the region and for Yugoslavia itself," the foreign minister, George Papandreou, told Greek television. "Every democratic country... resolves its problems in a peaceful way. This is what we are asking."

webTitle: Judge likely to rule that two patients can die

fields.headline: Judge likely to rule that two patients can die
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: England's senior family judge is expected to rule today that two patients in a state of "living death" can be allowed to die, despite the right to life enshrined in English law this week by the Human Rights Act.
fields.body:
England's senior family judge is expected to rule today that two patients in a state of "living death" can be allowed to die, despite the right to life enshrined in English law this week by the Human Rights Act.

Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court family division, has been asked to decide whether the act, which came into force on Monday, prevents doctors from withdrawing artificial feeding from patients in a permanent vegetative state (PVS).

The two women, named as Mrs M and Ms H, are oblivious to their surroundings and have no hope of recovery, according to independent specialists.

The official solicitor, Laurence Oates, representing the two patients, had considered opposing applications from their doctors for the go-ahead to withdraw tubal feeding. But yesterday both sides agreed that the right to life, though it places a positive obligation on the state to safeguard life, allows withdrawal of treatment from which a patient derives no benefit.

Around 20 PVS patients have been allowed to die since the House of Lords ruled in 1993 that feeding could be withdrawn from the Hillsborough survivor Tony Bland.

But the courts have had to consider the issue afresh after implementation of the Human Rights Act, which makes the European convention on human rights part of English law.

Mrs M, 49, has been in PVS for three years after an anaesthetic mishap during surgery in a foreign hospital. Ms H, 36, had a heart attack that deprived her brain of oxygen in January, when she was in hospital being treated for pancreatitis.

John Grace QC, representing the two north of England hospital trusts treating the women, told Dame Elizabeth that the families in both cases supported the application to withdraw feeding.

"No amount of rhetoric as to the law should obscure the tragedies behind these cases," he said. "Expert independent witnesses agree they are undoubtedly cases of PVS, described as a twilight zone of suspended animation where death commences while life continues - a living death." Both patients were the "victims" of medical technology that did not exist when the human rights convention was formulated in 1950. But the principles established in the Bland case amounted to "an adequate protection" under the convention's right to life provisions.

He said this was accepted by Ben Emmerson QC, who is representing the patients through the official solicitor.

Mr Grace said doctors had estimated that if life support continued Mrs M could live for 12 years or even longer. If doctors withdrew feeding and hydration, she would die within five to 14 days without distress.

A relative had described her as "someone who was full of life" who would not want to live as she was now.

Ms H, who suffered from severe epilepsy for most of her life, was "described by everyone as having been a lively and bubbly personality", said Mr Grace.

Artificial feeding had been a constant problem. Her feeding tube had become blocked on September 23, so she was receiving only hydration and drugs.

 European convention on human rights
 Home Office human rights unit
 Details of the passage of the act through parliament

webTitle: Culture of late nights and heavy drinking 'endemic among air crew'

fields.headline: Culture of late nights and heavy drinking 'endemic among air crew'
fields.standfirst:
Pilot of passenger jet sank equivalent of 10 pints before take off, says TV documentary whistleblower

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Pilot of passenger jet sank equivalent of 10 pints before take off, says TV documentary whistleblower
fields.body:
A British Airways captain drank the equivalent of 10 pints of beer and had less than three hours sleep the night before he took charge of a passenger flight from Barcelona to London, the makers of a Channel 4 drinking-and-flying exposé have claimed.

But Chris Salmon and nine other pilots alleged to have flouted rules on alcohol were just the tip of an iceberg, the whistleblower at the centre of the investigation said yesterday.

A former BA flight attendant, Caroline Wooliston, 31, said a culture of late nights and heavy drinking was "endemic", particularly on short-haul, one night stopovers. "The extent of the problem had to be addressed," she said. "And someone had to put their head above the parapet."

The Dispatches programme, to be broadcast next Thursday, reports that Captain Salmon drank at least 20 units of alcohol - including seven bottles of beer and over a bottle of wine - the night before a flight to Gatwick. He was said to have slept in the cockpit for much of flight BA2485 on July 25.

His first officer, James Sharples, and a purser and a flight assistant were also in the Barcelona drinking party secretly filmed by Ms Wooliston. Mr Sharples was alleged to have drunk at least 16 units, the equivalent of eight pints of beer.

Capt Salmon was heard off camera saying: "I can't believe I've got to take an aircraft back." Three hours before reporting to duty, he added: "I'm taking it fairly easy gotta pace yourself."

Earlier, Mr Sharples had told Ms Wooliston: "I'm gonna do the landing tomorrow because I just fancy the practice, and he'll be fucked."

Dorothy Byrne, commissioning editor of Channel 4's current affairs programmes, said she had been astonished at the pervasiveness of the culture of heavy drinking that Ms Wooliston had unearthed among BA pilots.

"We filmed six crews and each time we witnessed heavy drinking," she said. "The pilots were not known to us and were not targeted."

In total, the programme names five pilots who were said to have breached rules on drinking, but producers claimed to have passed evidence against a further five to BA and the Civil Aviation Authority.

On July 1, Captain Mark Phillips and his first officer, Jason Owen, were filmed on a night out in Frankfurt before taking charge of a return flight to Gatwick the next morning. Much of the evening was spent in a pizza bar, where, after several drinks, Captain Phillips was filmed recalling an occasion when he "had been very, very drunk in Copenhagen".

Mr Owen is seen to joke that the amount of beer he has drunk had brought on "the DTs".

The programme alleges that after Captain Phillips had gone to bed Mr Owen threw a party in his hotel room, where a cabin crew member produced some drinks which were said to have been taken from the plane.

Less than seven hours before reporting for duty for flight BA 2715, Mr Owen is alleged to have drunk 12 units of alcohol, with his captain having drunk the same amount.

The programme-makers yesterday dismissed suggestions that the pilots were entrapped or enticed to drink to excess. "We had very clear guidelines," they said. "We never invited them for a drink, all bills were shared to avoid suspicion and we never asked 'anyone for another drink'."

Ms Wooliston, who regularly drank at similar stop-over destinations while a flight assistant more than a year ago, denied that her presence had altered the social pattern of the pilots featured in the documentary.

"I have seen it before," she said. "I would not say that my presence influenced them in any way."

BA said it had yet to see the film but had suspended 11 pilots and three cabin crew, all of whom worked on short-haul routes, after the allegations came to its attention last Friday. A spokeswoman said the airline would be conducting an internal inquiry.

The British Air Line Pilots' Association attacked the programme for "its underhand and disgraceful journalistic methods, which could be described as entrapment".

Two years ago a BA pilot, Nigel King, was sacked after breaking the airline's rule on not drinking for before a flight.

Last year the pilot of a Virgin Express Boeing 737 resigned after passengers complained he appeared to be drunk.

Last month two EasyJet pilots were grounded after claims that they drank a "small amount" the evening before they were due to leave Luton airport.

Legislation bringing in random alcohol breath-testing for all pilots is to be introduced as soon as parliamentary time permits, the Department of Transport said yesterday.

But consultations with the civil aviation authority, European flight regulators and unions have been slow, and the draft legislation, begun under the previous government, has made little progress.

 Working for BA
 British Airline Pilots Association
 International Civil Aviation Authority safety regulation group

fields.headline: Camelot 'hounded lottery chief'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery yesterday accused its rival Camelot of "hounding" the national lottery commission chair Dame Helena Shovelton out of office.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery yesterday accused its rival Camelot of "hounding" the national lottery commission chair Dame Helena Shovelton out of office.

Simon Burridge, chief executive of the People's Lottery, accused Camelot of trying to derail the process of choosing which company would win the next licence to operate the game. In what has become an increasingly acrimonious affair, he described the behaviour of Camelot as outrageous.

"I feel they have hounded her out," he said. "They talk about her delivering 'gross insults' but they called her a liar and have been waging a campaign to get her removed.

"This is a reasonably obvious strategy. They are trying to get new commissioners and a new bidding process. That's the only slim chance they have. Camelot have been taking this moral high ground but actually it's precisely their lack of morality that has got them into this situation in the first place."

Dame Helena resigned late on Wednesday night after a tumultuous few weeks citing her "personal villification" in the media. She is being replaced temporarily by Harriet Spicer, who helped launch the feminist publisher Virago Press.

Camelot chief executive designate Dianne Thompson said she was not satisfied that the commission would act fairly in awarding the next licence. It was her furious response to a letter from the commission that finally triggered Dame Helena's resignation.

Camelot was angered by a decision in August made by the commission to negotiate excusively with the People's Lottery despite having reservations over both bids.

Ms Thompson said: "Dame Helena's resignation is a step in the right direction because it shows they are now taking this seriously. We are not seeking the resignation of the others but the decision taken in August was taken unanimously and we want them to reassure us that we will be treated fairly."

She said the delays which have caused fears that charities could lose funding were the commission's fault.

Camelot wants a public statement from the commission admitting culpability for the chaos surrounding the bid and to retract comments that the People's Lottery would deliver more for good causes.

It also wants the evaluation of the two lottery bids to be made public.

Ms Thompson said further legal action was still likely if the assurances aren't given.

Ms Spicer, 49, who has taken on the task of picking a winner, has the type of CV which makes for early self-confidence - Benenden school and St Anne's College, Oxford.

On leaving university she had a brief dalliance promoting ice cream before being rescued by a friend at the publisher Quartet who knew that Carmen Callil needed a secretary. Ms Spicer quickly became co-director and business manager and was made managing director in 1992.

fields.headline: Protests break out across country as activists smash police roadblocks
fields.standfirst: Serbia: Riot officers swept aside as convoys head for capital
fields.trailText: As convoys of opposition vehicles converged on Belgrade yesterday, a shockwave of protests spread across the countryside. Hesitant riot police stood by, or were swept aside by the popular uprising.
fields.byline: Gillian Sandford  in Kolubara  and  Owen Bowcott
fields.body:
As convoys of opposition vehicles converged on Belgrade yesterday, a shockwave of protests spread across the countryside. Hesitant riot police stood by, or were swept aside by the popular uprising.

In the northern town of Subotica, near the Hungarian border, the arrest of a student activist triggered a rally of 10,000 people in the town square. In the third largest city, Nis, a similar sized demonstration tried to force its way into the local offices of President Milosevic's Socialist party but was persuaded by opposition leaders not to give police a reason to attack them. Water cannon vehicles remained parked.

Attempts to block the roads leading to the capital were easily thwarted. Where the police had set up roadblocks they were overwhelmed by the numbers pressing forward. A procession of vehicles carrying 2,000 people was briefly stopped near the town of Smederevska Palanka, 30 miles south of Belgrade, but eventually pushed its way through barricades.

Protesters used an excavator to shove aside two lorries laden with sand and parked across the main road from the opposition-held town of Cacak to Belgrade. Police in riot gear did not intervene as a 12-mile-long column of cars and buses, with opposition and Serbian flags fluttering from the windows, ferried 15,000 people into the capital.

At other roadblocks, lorries were pushed off the highway while demonstrators negotiated with police commanders to be allowed through. At one blockade, protesters overturned a police car into a ditch. Several thousand people were marching on foot towards Belgrade from the industrial city of Pancevo, six miles to the north.

There were more defections to the opposition from the state-controlled media. The Dnevnik newspaper in northern Serbia carried reports on opposition activities and the wave of strikes and blockades. At the strikebound coal mine in Kolubara, where police first gave ground to the crush of opposition demonstrators on Wednesday night, the occupation by miners continued in defiance of the police who had taken over part of the complex in an attempt to prevent widespread power cuts.

The strike committee in Kolubara decided to stay put rather than join in the march to Belgrade. "We are not afraid, we have to keep up," a member, Zoran Cvetanovic, said. "We want to keep our workers in the pits - we do not want them to go to Belgrade because we must persist in our demands and defend ourselves."

Another strike leader said: "There should be no confrontation with [the police]. If they know how to make the machines work, then they can make them work. We won't work until the true results of the presidential elections are recognised. Until Vojislav Kostunica is president."

An opposition leader declared: "We found the fire in Kolubara, this dynamite that has activated people all around Serbia."

The 7,500 strikers at Kolubara understood what was at stake. "I'm not afraid of the police. There's no reason to be afraid," said Miljana Ljuba, a 36-year-old who spent 17 years working the pits in a region that until last week solidly supported Mr Milosevic. "The police are people, just like us. We are fighting for justice."

"We are not interested in bloodshed," said Milos Maksimovic, 35. "Milosevic had enough in Bosnia and Croatia. I respect Mr Milosevic. In the past I voted for him. But now we need another man. The opposition is careful - and there will be no bloodshed."

Under a moonlit night in the wasteland of the massive strip mine, Mr Milosevic's political game of 13 years finally looked to be up. Some strikers even shared a cigarette with police.

The machines that dig the coal for the electricity-generating plant were still. The police lurked around the perimeters of the mine like ghosts of the force Mr Milosevic once used to suppress dissent. The miners had simply downed their tools.

Ljubisa Petrovic, pensive with slate grey eyes and stubbled beard, worked in the eastern field, one of many mining strips in the complex.

"They called us from D field. They said they had stopped production and decided to strike," he said. "Then everyone who was working stopped working in my field. We just want a confirmation of the opposition win. We know that the votes Milosevic claims were stolen."

In Serbia's junior federal partner, Montenegro, the presidential adviser Miodrag Vukovic warned: "Milosevic is still alive politically. He is more dangerous than ever." Against a background of fast-moving events, Mr Vukovic also suggested that Montenegro's union with Serbia was essentially dead.

"There is definitely no Yugoslavia," he said. "In Montenegro everything is working perfectly, while Serbia is coming to a standstill. If Yugoslavia still existed we would probably be having anti-Milosevic demonstrations here, but we are not."

Mr Vukovic said fears Mr Milosevic would stage a coup in this tiny coastal republic to divert attention from the election chaos in Serbia had subsided. "We are past the worst. The soldiers are now back in their barracks."

He added that if Mr Kostunica managed to wrest power from Mr Milosevic and wanted to be taken seriously as a democrat, he would need to overhaul all federal institutions and call new parliamentary elections. He said talks would be needed to establish a new union between Serbia and Montenegro.

"This entity need not be called Yugoslavia," he said. "Montenegro is already independent economically and politically."

webTitle: How the end came for Milosevic

fields.headline: How the end came
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Timeline
fields.body:
1999

January 29 Slobodan Milosevic does not know it, but the latest of his Balkan wars is soon to begin his own destruction: the smouldering conflict in Serbia's Kosovo province catches fire with two massacres of ethnic Albanians by Serb special forces. In one of them, at the village of Racak, 45 Albanians are shot.

The atrocities prompt foreign ministers from Britain, the US, France, Germany, Italy and Russia to give the two sides three weeks to agree on giving Kosovo "substantial autonomy".

February-March Talks between Kosovo Albanians and Serbs reach partial agreement in Rambouillet, France. Yugoslav army tanks and troops enter Kosovo. Talks are suspended on March 20 when Milosevic refuses to sign an autonomy deal. Killings are unleashed in Kosovo

March 22-24 Nato authorises air strikes across Yugoslavia. Belgrade declares a state of emergency. Air strikes begin

April By the tenth day of bombing, more than 180,000 refugees have fled to neighbouring states

April 6 Nato rejects unilateral ceasefire declared by Yugoslav forces. The alliance admits to killing dozens of refugees in an air strike

June 3 After 72 days of Nato bombing, Milsosevic accepts a peace plan agreed by Nato and Russia calling for an end to violence and repression in Kosovo and the withdrawal of Serb forces from the province

June 9 Serbian military leaders sign peace terms. The conflict leaves 1,200 civilians dead and hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanians displaced

June 15 Serbian Orthodox Church calls for Milosevic and his government to resign

July 4 Zoran Djindjic, leader of the Democratic party, returns to Serbia to rally opposition to the regime. He predicts that Milosevic will be ousted within six months. A summer of anti-government protests ensues

2000

April 14 More than 100,000 demonstrators from all Serbian opposition parties cheer as Zoran Djindjic, and his rival Vuk Draskovic, of the Serbian Renewal Movement, share a stage and call for free elections

May 9 Milosevic blocks an opposition rally in his home town, Pozarevac. A crackdown against dissidents starts

July 27 Milosevic sets general elections for Sept 24

September 1 The opposition in Serbia launches its election manifesto in Belgrade. Opposition rallies proliferate and end in clashes with police

September 7 Opposition leaders blame Milosevic for disappearance of a potential political rival, Ivan Stambolic

September 11 Nato sends 2,000 more troops to boost the K-for peacekeeping force in Kosovo before the elections

September 22 An off-duty policeman in Montenegro is shot and killed by a Yugoslav military policeman, raising tension before Sunday's elections

September 24 Election day. A huge turnout, 7.8m people. Election monitors are banned from observing voting

September 25 The candidate of the main opposition alliance of 18 parties, Vojislav Kostunica, claims victory

September 26 Federal election commission declares Kostunica took 48.22% of the vote, and Milosevic 40.23% - but calls a second round since neither won a majority. Kostunica rejects this

October 2 Protesters block roads and miners stage strikes across Serbia. Milosevic says he will not step down. The opposition begins five days of strikes

October 4 Police raid Serbia's biggest coal mine at Kolubara, south of Belgrade and try to arrest leaders of striking miners. Thousands of people join strikers

October 5 Yugoslav constitutional court annuls election result, saying Milosevic should complete his term (ending July 2001) and then call new elections. Mass protests in Belgade with storming of the parliament building.

webTitle: A year on, pall of grief hangs over Paddington

fields.headline: A year on, pall of grief hangs over Paddington
fields.standfirst: Special report: Paddington train crash
fields.trailText: It was a dismal morning on which to remember a desperate day.
fields.body:
It was a dismal morning on which to remember a desperate day.

Drizzle smothered the arched roof of Brunel's grand train sheds at Paddington station; inside a cloud of grief hung over the small group that gathered to mark the first anniversary of the crash that, a year ago to the minute, left 31 commuters dead and changed the lives of hundreds more.

At 8.11am on October 5 last year, a Thames Turbo commuter train bound for Slough passed a red signal two miles out of Paddington and crossed the path of a Great Western express, causing Britain's worst rail disaster for a decade.

Yesterday survivors of the crash and families of the dead huddled under the station clock and, as the digits clicked to 8.11, fell silent. Around them the frenetic routine was stilled by a tannoy announcement: "A year ago today 31 people died in a tragic accident at Ladbroke Grove outside Paddington. As a mark of respect we invite you to join with the railway industry to remember them in a minute silence."

The hurrying suits stopped, aware that the devastation wrought that day was indiscriminate and random; it could have been them.

Pam Warren, whose scorched face has come to symbolise the tragedy of Paddington, stood at the heart of the group, gently weeping. She clutched the hand of Andrea Bryce, 24, a passenger on the Thames Turbo. She was pulled from the wreckage by fellow survivors Tony Jasper and Helen Mitchell. As the two women struggled across the tracks away from the carnage they fell over on a severed arm. They have become friends, sharing flashbacks and the struggle with the routine of working life; Ms Bryce is unemployed and Ms Mitchell, 37, has taken time off from her job as a research fellow.

"I wish I didn't have to be here but seeing the other survivors has helped," said Ms Bryce, who suffered back, neck, hip and facial injuries.

She had started a new job in Windsor two weeks before the crash. "It was supposed to be the start of a new career," she said. "Sometimes you cry for no reason. But I'm alive. Imagine what today is like for the families of 31 people who died," said Ms Mitchell. One such family, the Macaulays, came together to remember Matthew, a 26-year -old from New Zealand killed in the crash. His grandparents had flown in for the anniversary and stood weeping beneath the departure boards.

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack chairman joined the survivors yesterday morning, saying their campaign made the case for safety reform more compelling. There were signs however that the industry is yet to grasp the depth of feeling evoked by Paddington.

One survivor asked staff at the Great Western information desk to look after completed petitions during the minute's silence.. "We can't take responsibility," they said.

fields.headline: 'Kosovo's problems will not change'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Reaction in the Kosovo's capital to events in Serbia verged on indifference as the news slowly spread.
fields.body:
Reaction in the Kosovo's capital to events in Serbia verged on indifference as the news slowly spread.

In the Kukri bar, the only multi-ethnic bar in the centre of the city, music drowned out the sound from a television screen showing the latest events in Belgrade.

The barman, a Serb who declined to give his name, said: "I don't care and it's my country". His Albanian colleague, Burim, added that it did not matter what happened in Serbia. "Before we had a problem, now Nato is here, we don't. I don't care what happens to Milosevic, I'm just thinking about our future".

On Mother Teresa Street, a road lined with cafes and restaurants, many people were unaware of developments. "I saw Tony Blair on TV saying it was time for Milosevic to go, but I didn't know what it was about," said one man.

When told what was happening, he said: "Maybe it's a sign of change in the Balkans, but I don't think it will have a big effect on Kosovo. Kosovo is different from Yugoslavia."

His colleague, an Albanian expatriate who had returned to work in the province this year, added: "Kosovo's problems are not going to change because of a change of government in Serbia.

"It has deeper roots than that. I have followed the opposition's stand on Kosovo and it is not that different from Milosevic's.

"This was not the matter of one person committing genocide, I am sorry to say that the majority of Serbian people feel the same as Milosevic regarding Kosovo."

Perhaps the only significant reactions to be seen in the city were at the UN's headquarters, where Serb translators, many of who come from Belgrade, spent most of the afternoon glued to television sets and the internet.

webTitle: Leader: Dame Shovelton's departure from lottery commission

fields.headline: She walked the plank
fields.standfirst:
The lottery commission can now decide

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Dame Helena Shovelton's departure from the quango regulating the lottery clears the air. However much personal responsibility she bears, sometimes in public life it is the captain who has to walk the plank.
fields.body:
Dame Helena Shovelton's departure from the quango regulating the lottery clears the air. However much personal responsibility she bears, sometimes in public life it is the captain who has to walk the plank.

The important thing now is to move speedily to a fair decision. That is more likely since the National Lottery Commission has substituted as its advisers a hot City legal firm for the Treasury solicitors. There is no good reason why, within a matter of weeks, Harriet Spicer, the stand-in chair, and her colleagues should not be able to pronounce definitively on the two bids before them.

The grounds for their judgment are clear. The new contract should go to the consortium which offers the greatest flow of funds for charitable purposes and which scores highest on tests of probity and reliability. The commissioners cannot guarantee their call is going to be judge-proof, but they can ensure it is transparent.

Camelot blusters. It threatens to sue and sue again for the profit it loves. It has a strong hand: like a railway contractor refused a renewal, it might lose interest over the next year and jeopardise a smooth handover to any replacement.

Meanwhile, it has gone on a PR offensive, trotting out Olympic athletes to advertise its cause - the lottery certainly seems to have done British sport a power of good. But let us remember Camelot is no philanthropist. It is in the business of maximising profit. The question before the lottery commissioners is whether its business plan will maximise revenues and that is not so straightforward. The "not-for-profit" aspect of the People's-Branson bid might stimulate the punters.

Making such an assessment is what the quango was set up to make. Chastened, Ms Spicer and colleagues must go ahead and make their call ignoring Camelot's bullying and the misogynist tone which has crept into media coverage of a public body where (how rare this is) women are in the majority.

fields.headline: Hague reaches out
fields.standfirst:
But the Tory problem remains

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
Special report: William Hague
fields.trailText: William Hague may well be the most fluent public speaker in the country, able to deliver a 49-minute address, word perfect and with no autocue - albeit in a voice that can verge on the whiney. He may also be a natural comic, with a gift for timing that allows him to make toxic mockery of the government. But neither of those talents is ever going to be enough to persuade the country to elect him - and yesterday that was his task.
fields.body:
William Hague may well be the most fluent public speaker in the country, able to deliver a 49-minute address, word perfect and with no autocue - albeit in a voice that can verge on the whiney. He may also be a natural comic, with a gift for timing that allows him to make toxic mockery of the government. But neither of those talents is ever going to be enough to persuade the country to elect him - and yesterday that was his task.

To that end Mr Hague sought to use his fourth leader's speech to reach beyond the conference hall to the voters who have never been part of the Conservatives' natural constituency. He wanted to address the inner cities and the "hard-working families" (a Labour phrase) of Britain, and explicitly those who had voted for Tony Blair in 1997 but had been "so bitterly disappointed". He spoke of pensions and the NHS, of schools and the people who struggle to get by: Ilkley Man, not Islington Man, is his concern.

But there are problems for Mr Hague in this approach. For one thing, it does not delight his own party: they let most of these passages go by without applause. Second, the Tories have a credibility problem in this area: few voters see them as obvious trustees of the nation's public services. Third, they have a circle to square: how can they spend all this money turning round failing cities and schools when they also plan to cut taxes? Cutting out waste, when the Tories had 18 years to make the state as lean as a whippet, just does not wash.

A deeper problem is the second half of the message which Mr Hague served up yesterday. For he combined his commitment to match Labour on schools and hospitals with old-fashioned talk in the social, cultural sphere. He threw the Daily Mail plenty of red meat on Section 28, political correctness and the like. The hall enjoyed that, but it hardly seems smart. Surely the Conservatives should aim to be the inclusive, modern body sketched out by Michael Portillo rather than the hard-faced outfit promised by Ann Widdecombe. fields.headline: Campaign to curb 'identikit England'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Tories yesterday joined the countryside lobby in opposing the development of greenfield sites by pledging to give local councils stronger powers to control the number and style of new homes, particularly in the booming south east.
fields.body:
Tories yesterday joined the countryside lobby in opposing the development of greenfield sites by pledging to give local councils stronger powers to control the number and style of new homes, particularly in the booming south east.

The shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, said it was time to "break the culture of centralisation", in which governments set housebuilding targets on a national and regional basis.

With the Department of the Environment preparing to tell counties in the south east how many houses they should accommodate over the next 15 years, Mr Norman said authorities should instead be able to specify styles of architecture and construction materials.

Earlier this year John Prescott, the environment sec retary, said 43,000 new houses annually were needed in the south east - mainly to cater for demand inside the region - representing a 10% increase over the last decade.

Mr Norman warned that England was becoming a "country of identikit houses the same in Kent as in Norfolk".

Pledging that Tories would scrap national housebuilding targets, Mr Norman said Labour was "hell bent on building on the countryside, extending urban sprawl and destroying villages and towns". But in the October issue of the magazine Showhouse, Mr Norman conceded that the demand for new housing was such that development would be needed not just on recycled urban land, but on greenfields as well.

"I am a practical guy," he said. "We all live in the real world. I have been involved in development myself and I recognise that unfortunately it is inevitable we will lose some countryside."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Police are hunting a paedophile who failed to appear at Swindon crown court on Monday, when he was jailed for eight years in his absence for a string of sex attacks on young boys in Bristol. Lee Tucker, 36, had been given bail to have HIV treatment in London.
fields.body:
Paedophile jumps bail

Police are hunting a paedophile who failed to appear at Swindon crown court on Monday, when he was jailed for eight years in his absence for a string of sex attacks on young boys in Bristol. Lee Tucker, 36, had been given bail to have HIV treatment in London.

HIV warning for dental patients

More than 5,000 Essex dental patients have been sent letters offering HIV tests after a dental assistant found he had the virus. The health authorities involved say the risk is minuscule.

Man held in murder hunt

Detectives looking for the killer of a teenage dance student yesterday arrested a man aged 44 in Tamworth, Staffordshire. Heather Tell, 17, was found in a park in the town on August 26. This week police revealed she had been strangled.

£24,000 safety fine for BNFL

British Nuclear Fuels was yesterday fined £24,000 after admitting mismanagement of radioactive sources at Sellafield in Cumbria . The case follows repeated failure to comply with a safety notice.

Ford confident on race deadline

Ford said yesterday it would meet an October 13 deadline from the commission for racial equality to agree a review of race relations at its Dagenham car factory in Essex. It was inviting its workers to attend a race awareness course, and had set up an incident hotline.

Cash found for Enigma ransom

Bletchley Park, the wartime spy centre in Bedfordshire, yesterday said it was willing to meet a deadline of midnight tonight to hand over £25,000.

The cash was given privately after the museum decided that paying was the only way it would recover a Nazi Enigma coding machine stolen in April.

webTitle: Leader: Milosevic's long rule of fear is over

fields.headline: A farewell to fear
fields.standfirst:
Slobodan Milosevic is on his knees at last

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The popular revolt that exploded across Belgrade yesterday afternoon marked the end of Slobodan Milosevic's long rule of fear.
fields.body:
The popular revolt that exploded across Belgrade yesterday afternoon marked the end of Slobodan Milosevic's long rule of fear. After 13 years of lies, assassination, repression, and war-mongering, the Serbian people, bravely marching and striking in their hundreds of thousands, have finally demonstrated, once and for all, that they are no longer afraid of the "butcher of the Balkans".

The uprising was the culmination of a week of hitherto non-violent civil disobedience that united miners, industrial workers, students and shopkeepers in an unprecedented show of defiance. It reflected in effect a national refusal to accept the gerrymandered results of last month's presidential election.

It was an expression of the long-suppressed yearning for change which Vojislav Kostunica, the opposition leader, successfully turned into a tidal wave of votes on September 24. It was, above all, a total, contemptuous and fearless rejection of one man. Mr Milosevic's sole remaining motivation now is his own fear, of retribution, assassination, of the waiting war crimes tribunal in The Hague. The question for him last night was whether to give in or fight back. His Socialist party insisted it would resist to the end by every means. But the outcome appeared to rest, crucially, on the reaction of the Yugoslav army, should it be ordered to send tanks against its own people.

The cathartic trigger for this upheaval was the most egregious effort yet by Mr Milosevic to thwart the people's manifest will. Abandoning the charade of an electoral second round this Sunday, which the opposition was in any case determined to boycott, he prevailed on his cronies in the constitutional court to annul last month's result outright. Rather than order a recount, as Mr Kostunica demanded, the court has apparently ruled (although its precise intentions remain unclear) that a completely new election must be held some time between now and next July, when the president's mandate officially ends. This, in theory, could keep Mr Milosevic in power, buy time, could discourage and divide his opponents and may somehow defuse the bomb of popular will that threatens to blow him into oblivion.

The court's ruling was immediately condemned by Mr Kostunica, who saw it as the trap it undoubtedly is; by Britain, which described it as an "unacceptable device"; and by the EU and the US. But significantly, the reaction in Moscow was quite different. Appearing to welcome the court's ruling, President Vladimir Putin reissued his invitation to Mr Milosevic and Mr Kostunica to go to Russia for trilateral talks. Apparently deaf to the virtually unanimous cry of the Serbian masses, Mr Putin's post-communist spokesmen suggested there would now be time for a calm discussion!

Such trimming, such compromising, such appeasement is just as repulsive as the UN Balkan envoy's earlier suggestion that Mr Milosevic be given an amnesty. As the crowds stormed parliament, took over the state TV, and as police joined the protesters, many were convinced that it was just a matter of time, perhaps only hours, before the dictator cut and ran. Perhaps he is still deluded enough to think that he can hang on. Perhaps Mr Putin will at last be persuaded to stop playing politics and definitively pull the plug on Russia's ugliest ally. Last night Mr Kostunica boldly declared himself the new leader of a "liberated Serbia". Whether Mr Milosevic yet accepts that verdict is still in doubt. But one thing is certain: his power has gone, as surely as fear of him has fled. He is on his knees at last. He must be given no quarter.

fields.headline: Conference verdict
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Good week
fields.body:
Good week

Michael Portillo , the shadow chancellor, despite disturbing the grass roots with his touchy-feely appeal for more tolerance - not to mention his surprising outbreak into Spanish. Proof that Senor Porteeyo is the most probable heir apparent was all-too-clear at Politico's bookstore, where knickers proclaiming I (heart) Michael Portillo outstripped those declaring affinity to the party leader and became the clear bestsellers.

John Major , who - in contrast to last year's conference where the former PM was airbrushed out of the picture - saw his appeal for the party to recapture the centre ground warmly received by both sides of the party.

Claus Bunk Pederson , a member of the Conservative People's Party of Denmark, who won a standing ovation for being Danish. Oh yes, and for campaigning against the euro.

Bad week

Ann Widdecombe , shadow home secretary, who succeeded in pushing rival Michael Portillo off the front page of the Daily Telegraph by pledging to bring in automatic minimum fines of £100 against cannabis users - but was then ordered to tone it down by her boss William Hague, who hadn't sanctioned the details, and was criticised by police, human rights groups and drugs charities.

Lady Thatcher who failed to command the rapturous applause of previous years and, by pledging not to speak at fringe meetings, was effectively gagged.

Former chancellor of the exchequer Kenneth Clarke and Michael Heseltine , the former deputy prime minister. Both were provocative - the pro-Euro Mr Clarke attacking William Hague over the euro at the same time as the leader attended a Save the Pound rally, and Hezza likening the party to Labour in the early eighties - but neither commanded extensive coverage for their exploits, suggesting their clout is diminishing.

Joke of the week

William Hague condemning the return to trade union power shown at the Labour conference last week. "Tony Blair likes beer and sandwiches without the beer. I like it without the sandwiches."

Key moments

Monday William Hague himself unveiled what was billed as the sign of a "bold new social agenda" - new private sector led regeneration companies for inner cities. Mr Hague was forced to admit the bold proposals were, however, not costed.

Tuesday "Antes de ques te cases, mira lo que haces!" (roughly, look before you leap), declared Michael Portillo in his first conference speech as shadow chancellor. The speech, full of touchy-feely confessionl politics, was described by some as his first leadership bid

Wednesday Ann Widdecombe's typically rumbustious home affairs speech, and the reaction to the idea of automatic £100 fines for anyone caught with even the smallest amount of cannabis. The reaction was cool with the police making clear they could not support it, as well as many in her own party

Thursday William Hague's prepare for government speech. It went down well of course, with a standing ovation, although other observers complained it was rather flat. The conference was less preparing for government and more - like this delegate carrying a souvenir cardboard cut-out of William Hague from the conference centre - just preparing to go home.

webTitle: Comment: Joan Smith comments on Dame Shovelton's resignation

fields.headline: Woman trouble
fields.standfirst:
The lottery commission head is just the latest victim of those who insult and torment females in public life

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: So farewell then, Dame Helena Shovelton, newly resigned chairman of the National Lottery Commission. The tabloids have collected your scalp, to place alongside those of a host of other famous women who have endured similar vilification.
fields.body:
So farewell then, Dame Helena Shovelton, newly resigned chairman of the National Lottery Commission. The tabloids have collected your scalp, to place alongside those of a host of other famous women who have endured similar vilification.

"Quangocrat" was the politest expression used by the Daily Mail about Shovelton yesterday, in a two-page article crowing over her sudden departure. The paper managed to find unflattering pictures of all five lottery commissioners, demanding: "Would you trust this lot to run a whelk stall?"

It just so happens that four of the five are women, which naturally precludes any of them being taken seriously. "One disliked washing machines and motorways," the paper declared, as though this was conclusive proof of her unsuitability for public life. (How many professional men, I wonder, have been questioned about their attitude to domestic appliances? Would we switch our votes to William Hague if we discovered he felt warmly towards his vacuum cleaner?)

Even more damningly, another was - wait for it - a "feminist publisher". The sole male commissioner, Brian Pomeroy, got off more lightly, described as the best qualified of the five and accused only of letting his politics get in the way of his judgment. (At least they admitted he had some in the first place.) Nor is this coincidental for, as Shovelton has just discovered, the abuse reserved for women in public life is peculiarly vitriolic and astonishingly personal.

Something similar happened earlier this year to Jennie Page, chief executive of the Millennium Dome; whatever the dome's failings, it is clear that Page was virtually hounded out of her job, a sacrificial victim whose neck was laid on the block while more powerful people, mostly male politicians, sat tight. The Mail's writers and columnists, often women themselves, are particularly flagrant offenders: Mo Mowlam decided to reveal she was suffering from a brain tumour after Lynda Lee-Potter, remarking on the fact that the MP had gained weight, described her as resembling "an only slightly effeminate Geordie trucker".

On that occasion, the Daily Express was equally personal and nearly as offensive, asking: "Why are so many people afraid to give up smoking? Ask Mo Mowlam. She's the Labour frontbencher who put on two stone in just three months - and doesn't it show." Janet Street-Porter, editor of the Independent on Sunday, is a perennial target, attacked as much for her clothes and her accent as the way she does her job.

The arbitrariness of the process is demonstrated by the beating handed out to Betty Boothroyd, retiring Speaker of the House of Commons, who was transformed apparently overnight from a national treasure - show us your legs, Betty! - to an unpopular politician whose colleagues were glad to see the back of her.

The abuse is so relentless, and so unrestrained, that it hints at the existence of a widespread, probably unconscious hostility to the presence of women in public life at all. It is, apparently, acceptable to mock a woman's face, hair, body, age, experience, interests, politics, boyfriends (or lack of them), even where she lives; yesterday's Daily Mail uncovered the sinister fact that Shovelton lives "close to several golf clubs", which clearly casts doubt on her qualifications to award the lottery franchise.

The standard reply, whenever someone protests about all this misogyny, is usually a paraphrase of President Truman's remark about people who can't stand the heat getting out of the kitchen. This would carry more conviction if men and women in public life were treated equally, but they are not. On the contrary, some of the editors who unblushingly preside over the spectator sport of insulting and degrading women show an unusual degree of sensitivity when it comes to their own sex. A joke about William Hague's baldness earned a stern rebuke this week from no less a source than David Yelland, editor of the Sun, whose finer feelings were offended by a column in the Guardian.

But the problem is not just unfairness. It is that capable women are being terrorised out of public life, unable to bear the slights and deliberate humiliations, while a younger generation is getting the message that it is no place for a woman. The call from a minister, asking you to become a regulator or chair a commission, will al most certainly be followed, in due course, by breathtakingly nasty articles in the press questioning your abilities, experience, perhaps even your integrity. Look at what has happened to Shovelton, Mowlam, Page, Boothroyd et al and ask yourself this question: is it worth the aggravation?

Some women will go on saying yes. They have names like Ann Widdecombe, and survive by mocking themselves as cruelly as any journalist, thereby earning the title of "good sport". They are just as much victims of the misogyny stakes, colluding with their tormentors at who knows what cost to their self-esteem. But whether this contemporary version of the survival of the fittest, or the most thick-skinned, is good for our polity is another matter.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Harvey Nichols ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Harvey Nichols ad says about you...
fields.body:
The ad: Two knitted dolls, Harvey and Hibby, are going home after a typically extravagant shopping expedition to top fashion store Harvey Nichols, laden with bags and decked out in designer gear. They bump into Mr Gray in the lobby. He's another knitted doll, and he has caught fire. The duo are faced with the dilemma of how to put it out. A voiceover suggests that Harvey throws his coat over Mr Gray. "My Dries Van Noten? No way," comes the reply. Hibby similarly barks "As if!" to the suggestion that she use her posh Luella jacket instead. Eventually a passer-by puts out the fire using his "last season" coat.

The jargon: This rather curious 30-second cinema ad is an animated development of an earlier print campaign in which we were first introduced to Harvey and Hibby, a pair of anti-heroic fashion victims. The film departs from the more classic fashion retail ads (stunning photography, gorgeous models, etc) to help recapture the cutting-edge cache Harvey Nichols had 10 years ago.

fields.headline: Serbia keeps its date with revolution, a decade late
fields.standfirst:
Belgrade is finally rejoining the east European story

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The scenes in Belgrade yesterday were reminiscent of those across eastern Europe in 1989. Then, in capital after capital, the squares also filled with hundreds of thousands of people, and a beleaguered leadership met behind shuttered windows to make the decisions which determined whether they would cede power more or less gracefully or whether their regimes would go down in blood.
fields.body:
The scenes in Belgrade yesterday were reminiscent of those across eastern Europe in 1989. Then, in capital after capital, the squares also filled with hundreds of thousands of people, and a beleaguered leadership met behind shuttered windows to make the decisions which determined whether they would cede power more or less gracefully or whether their regimes would go down in blood.

It is still an open question whether Belgrade in the year 2000 will go like East Berlin, Warsaw, or Prague or like Bucharest. Perhaps not as smoothly as the first three, but not as violently as the last: one of the few advantages of having your revolution more than 10 years later than everybody else is that some of the pitfalls are more apparent.

Everyone now knows the pathology of this final phase - the numbers in the streets, the reluctant or even mutinous security forces, the classical music on the state channels, the weird silence from those usually so vociferous. On the evidence of these vital signs, the end in Serbia cannot be far away.

It was not foreordained that Serbia would be the dunce of eastern Europe, delaying for so long the changes the rest of the region began to embrace a decade ago. If it was less prosperous and advanced than Croatia or Slovenia, or than Czechoslovakia, it was still a reasonably modern society and one accustomed to innovate and lead.

History is hard to untangle, but it is possible that, had there been a different leadership and less of a heritage of nationalist preoccupations, Serbia could have followed sharply on the heels of the five east European states, as soon as their revolutions made it clear that the peoples of Yugoslavia would have to reinvent their politics as well. Instead, all the other republics in former Yugoslavia preceded her, most recently Croatia, the other laggard. Even Albania, the weakest and most backward of European communist states, made its moves long ago.

The appeal of Vojislav Kostunica is not only that he promises to wrest the dead hand of Slobodan Milosevic from the tiller, but that he quite specifically vows to put Serbia back on the 1989 road which it ought never to have left. He does this, as a nationalist, without in any way agreeing that the main blame for the Yugoslav wars falls on Serbia. The blame, Kostunica would say, is certainly not all Serbia's and awaits, in any case, a neutral reckoning.

The priority is to get off a path which leads only to more isolation. Serbia must rejoin the east European story, which is one of transformation to a true multiparty state, the establishment of a market economy, and membership in European organisations leading on to a place within the European Union. This is a message Serbs are finally ready to hear. Indeed, the comparison between Serbia now and Serbia 10 years ago has been on everybody's lips.

The miners at Kolubara again and again, in talking to reporters, returned to the comparison between their lives 10 years ago, when they made a good living in a country at peace, and their parlous situation now. The young woman who told Maggie O'Kane that Milosevic had stolen 10 years of her life voiced a sentiment that has become widespread.

But it is not exact to say that Serbia missed the changes that 1989 brought to Russia and eastern Europe. Rather, as the Yugoslav state disintegrated, Serbia got the worst of those changes and missed the best. It lost an ideology that was already threadbare but acquired nothing to put in its place except a nationalism that became ever more atavistic. It got a multiparty state, but with a concealed single party still dominant and using the old methods of propaganda and media control to maintain that dominance.

It got the appropriation of state assets by the smartest and most ruthless members of the old apparatus which happened to one degree or another in most former communist states, but it did not get any genuine economic renovation. It did not get the rule of law but it did get, to an extreme extent, the criminalisation and mafia entrenchment that can also be seen in Russia.

The real tragedy of Serbia was that everywhere else in eastern Europe the often fierce nationalism which had survived under the thin mantle of international communist harmony worked with rather than against democratic change. That nationalism was mainly directed against the Russians, and provided a common ground between non-communists and those braver men and women among the communists who, everybody knew, had tried to protect national interests during the Moscow years. In addition, the ruthless ethnic rearrangments that followed the second world war had made most European states more homogenous.

But, in Yugoslavia there were no Russians, and nationalism rebounded off neighbours, not a distant superpower. In Serbia, especially, there was a culture of embattlement which saw 20th-century history as a series of threats to the very existence of the nation.

Dobrica Cosic, the intellectual whose theories embodied this fear, saw the Serbian essence as at the mercy of the big powers - whether malign like Nazi Germany, or uncaring like Britain and France - and as diminished by Tito's version of communism. With the changes of 1989, it was again threatened - by the economic power of the west and particularly the economic and political steamroller of the European Union, which he likened to a "huge multinational department store and travel agency."

This capitalist west did not care about Serbia, or about the Serbs abandoned as minorities in the new states of former Yugoslavia, seeing only industries to be taken over, markets to be exploited and small, weak governments to manipulate. What for other communist societies was a liberation was, for men like Cosic, to go from the frying pan to the fire. Out of such fears - not utterly without foundation - came the wars of the past 10 years, and because of such fears Serbia missed its appointment with revolution.

The 1989 revolutions were about embracing the future but also about the past, about lost time, lost possibilities, cruelties and idiocies that could have been avoided. Mark Frankland in his evocative book on the 1989 revolutions quotes Miklos Nemeth, the reformer who was Hungary's last communist prime minister, telling parliament that just as in times of trouble "our ancestors fled into the swamps and only the reed through which they breathed in air showed above the surface...we too have been submerged and threatening forces have pushed us under the water."

It has been Serbia's fate to stay beneath the water longer than any other ex-communist society, and to cause its own people and those of the rest of former Yugoslavia much pain because it could not or would not change. But it seems now that finally Serbia's moment has come.

fields.headline: If Trimble goes, it could be war
fields.standfirst:
His party should be cheering him, not plotting to unseat him

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: William Hague had a dose of it yesterday, just as Tony Blair had before him. Neither of them would have been surprised: after all, it has become the quasi-divine right of party leaders to be swamped in the ovations and adulations of their party conference. But one man will have no such luck.
fields.body:
William Hague had a dose of it yesterday, just as Tony Blair had before him. Neither of them would have been surprised: after all, it has become the quasi-divine right of party leaders to be swamped in the ovations and adulations of their party conference. But one man will have no such luck.

David Trimble will not be forced to adopt a pose of shy modesty, halting the rolling applause of delegates when he faces the Ulster Unionist conference tomorrow. On the contrary, he will face an audience at least half of which is plotting his downfall - scheduled for a special meeting of the party's ruling council at the end of the month. The plotters are the likes of William Thompson, one of Trimble's MPs who yesterday offered this comradely assessment of his leader's position: "He is on the skids and cannot survive."

Thompson and friends want Trimble to pull out of Northern Ireland's fledgling administration, thereby collapsing the institution. As the secretary of state, Peter Mandelson, warned yesterday, that's a fast track to putting 1998's Good Friday agreement in the deep freeze if not the morgue. The plotters' motives are a mix of conviction - they reckon the agreement has brought unionists too little and republicans too much - and self-interest: after the hardliners of Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists snatched the UUP stronghold of South Antrim in a byelection last month, they fear for their own political skins.

So Trimble has no shortage of reasons for walking away from the peace process: he wants to keep his job. Nor would he lack arguments. He could say the South Antrim result shows his community has lost faith in the accord. He could point to the early release of terrorist prisoners and the proposed name change of the Royal Ulster Constabulary as proof of how much unionists have been asked to give - and the lack of progress on decommissioning as proof of how little they have won in return. He could cite the loyalist civil war and yesterday's bomb alert on the Belfast-Dublin railway line, almost certainly the work of dissident republicans, as evidence that the peace process has brought plenty of process - but all too little peace.

For all that, he should not walk away from the peace table. First, he should remember that, when the unionist people had a chance to vote on the Good Friday agreement, they voted yes. That moral mandate remains - and with it a moral obligation not to destroy the accord. Only a no vote in a new referendum can remove that duty.

Second, he has a powerful response to those who say the agreement has brought unionists nothing. Trimble can boast - indeed should have spent two years boasting - that, thanks to the deal he negotiated, unionists have won enormous gains. For the first time, republicanism has accepted the partition of Ireland, confirmed by Sinn Fein's presence in the Belfast executive and assembly. What's more the Irish Republic has given up its historic claim to the north, rewording its constitution accordingly. No unionist leader ever won such a prize before.

But if these advances seem abstract, Trimble should ask unionists to look around. Yes, there is still violence - from the fratricidal feuding on the Shankill Road to the enduring menace of the Real IRA - but the once all-pervasive threat from the provisionals has been quieted. The IRA has made as clear as it can its resignation from warfare, opening up its once top-secret arsenals to outside inspection - unimaginable a decade ago. More concrete still, unionists can see the change the peace process has made - with foreign investment flowing in and business at last allowed to flourish.

If none of that prevails, Trimble should ask the nay-sayers what they would do in his place. Do they really think that ending self-rule in Northern Ireland would make decommissioning more likely - that if unionists say no, then republicans will say yes? What logic is it that makes the rejectionists believe they can refuse every compromise - keep the RUC as it is and share no power with nationalists -yet still expect the other side to keep giving? Mandelson is right: unless both sides give and take, there can be no accord.

That means nationalist flexibility on policing and republican movement on decommissioning, but it also requires a reciprocal approach from unionism. For peace processes have their own dynamic: if one side refuses to budge then the other does, too. The result is not always a return to the status quo ante, but something worse - a lurch back into all-out confrontation. If they doubt it, unionists need only look at that other stalled peace process -now spilling blood in Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza.

Those seeking the removal of David Trimble, unionism's most accomplished peacemaker, should think on that. The absence of peace is not a vacuum - it is war.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Mad Dog And Glory/Badlands/Les Diaboliques
fields.body:
Mad Dog And Glory

(John McNaughton, 1993)

9.30pm, 2.25am, Sky Cinema

Mad Dog is the ironic nickname of Robert De Niro's lonely, inhibited police photographer; Uma Thurman's Glory is the shopgirl "given" to him for a week as a reward for saving the life of mobster Milo (Bill Murray) during an armed raid. The intriguing set-up blends thriller, romance and comedy; the quality cast makes it surprisingly touching - as much in Mad Dog's affectionate relationship with Milo as his love for Glory.

Badlands

(Terrence Malick, 1973)

11.05am, TCM

Malick's brilliant debut paints a vivid picture of two alienated young Americans who become almost-innocent killers. Martin Sheen plays Kit, the garbageman who falls for Sissy Spacek's 15-year-old Holly; the union's sealed in blood when he murders her father (Warren Oates). Stark and unjudgmental, there are hints of Malick's mystical war film, The Thin Red Line: brutalities committed in stunning landscapes, here the Dakota Badlands; and the inner monologues of people locked in desperate situations, stumbling after some meaning.

Les Diaboliques

(Henri-Georges Clouzot, 1955)

2.15am, FilmFour

There was no more misanthropic and dark a practitioner of French noir than the bitter Clouzot, and this is a prime example. It's the story of a murder - ailing and bullied wife Vera Clouzot (the director's spouse) teaming up with spurned mistress Simone Signoret to kill her husband, vicious boarding school head Paul Meurisse. And then the body disappears. The subsequent investigation uncovers a heap of human misery and thwarted desire - so don't expect too many laughs.

fields.headline: Life in the fast lane
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Holby City/Modern Times: Affluenza
fields.body:
If ever there were a televisual equivalent of crack cocaine, it's Holby City (BBC1). While the experience may not be particularly pleasant, it's addictive and leaves you feeling as if you've just been run over by a van. Which is precisely what happened to half a dozen characters in the first few moments of the new series, as a convenient pile-up outside the hospital gates got the corpse count off to a flying start.

The next hour flashed by as if time itself had been telescoped. Holby City is played at such furious pace - there's a crash team or a "bleed" every 90 seconds or so - that one imagines the actors and production crew collapsing in a sweating heap at the end of the episode. The benefit to the audience of this frenetic approach is that there's never a dull moment; lust, hatred, pity and horror pile one up on the other. It makes Titus Andronicus look like The Good Life.

Lust inched ahead in the first half thanks largely to the new hunk on the block, cocky registrar Alex Adams (Jeremy Sheffield), who managed to flirt with a colleague over a bleeding roadkill. He even managed to deliver lines and look seductive in a surgical mask, always a challenge to the medical drama heart-throb. Meanwhile we longed to punch the screen every time silly, dippy Nina (Kelly Hunter) wittered on about her chakras. Things looked up when we learned that she had a dicky heart, but sadly she survived to witter another day.

More poignant was the tale of Alan and Greg (Peter Plycarpou and Gary Sefton), who had been innocently driving along in a van when implacable Fate caught up with them. As they took it in turns to collapse or go into spasm, we learned that Alan and Greg shared more than just a van; yes, they were lovers - which was news to Alan's wife. This triangle proved to be anything but eternal, as an aneurysm took Alan to his reward, leaving Greg and Mrs Alan sobbing over his remains. Astonishingly, this pulpy storyline contrived to be genuinely affecting, and to express something convincing about the fragility of life and the value of love - which, let's face it, is not what you expect from a BBC1 medical drama.

Far, far away in California's Silicon Valley, some unappealing rich people were discovering that money doesn't necessarily make you happy in Modern Times: Affluenza (BBC2). Poor dear Kathleen sold her hugely successful business and bought a huge house. Her husband is a CEO and earns a fortune; she has beautiful children and devoted staff; she even looks like Lauren Hutton - and yet Kathleen was not happy. Sensible British viewers would diagnose instantly that this was because she didn't know she was born; American experts, sensing a dollar, diagnosed "Sudden Wealth Syndrome" and invited Kathleen to get some therapy. Therapy is a guaranteed cure for Sudden Wealth Syndrome - it costs so much that money should no longer be a problem after about six months. And so Kathleen bleated about her empty life, about how she daren't leave the house lest the housekeeper steals the children's affection, and finally settled for a form of therapy that advised her to sit down and have a cup of tea quite a lot.

Other miserable rich people organised their children's lives with military precision, breeding another generation of loveless over-achievers, then went to therapy to complain about their own parents. One of the therapists made a strong bid for next year's Bafta for most irritating man by nodding, grinning and saying "thanks for sharing that" at every opportunity. The only sympathetic character in the show was Brian, who inherited $1m from his late girlfriend and is now chewed up by the traumatic change in his way of life. Sensibly, he decided not to blow it all on nasty Japanese "art" like Kathleen did. He also had the grace to look bemused by the therapists' psychobabble.

It's easy to get a laugh out of British audiences by parading a few foolish Americans on screen - and so, while Affluenza wasn't breaking any new ground, it hit its marks accurately enough. Nobody stood up and said "pull yourself together", although viewers across the land were presumably shouting those very words at their screens. Blow therapists: don't these people have mothers?
