The next hour flashed by as if time itself had been telescoped. Holby City is played at such furious pace - there's a crash team or a "bleed" every 90 seconds or so - that one imagines the actors and production crew collapsing in a sweating heap at the end of the episode. The benefit to the audience of this frenetic approach is that there's never a dull moment; lust, hatred, pity and horror pile one up on the other. It makes Titus Andronicus look like The Good Life. Lust inched ahead in the first half thanks largely to the new hunk on the block, cocky registrar Alex Adams (Jeremy Sheffield), who managed to flirt with a colleague over a bleeding roadkill. He even managed to deliver lines and look seductive in a surgical mask, always a challenge to the medical drama heart-throb. Meanwhile we longed to punch the screen every time silly, dippy Nina (Kelly Hunter) wittered on about her chakras. Things looked up when we learned that she had a dicky heart, but sadly she survived to witter another day. More poignant was the tale of Alan and Greg (Peter Plycarpou and Gary Sefton), who had been innocently driving along in a van when implacable Fate caught up with them. As they took it in turns to collapse or go into spasm, we learned that Alan and Greg shared more than just a van; yes, they were lovers - which was news to Alan's wife. This triangle proved to be anything but eternal, as an aneurysm took Alan to his reward, leaving Greg and Mrs Alan sobbing over his remains. Astonishingly, this pulpy storyline contrived to be genuinely affecting, and to express something convincing about the fragility of life and the value of love - which, let's face it, is not what you expect from a BBC1 medical drama. Far, far away in California's Silicon Valley, some unappealing rich people were discovering that money doesn't necessarily make you happy in Modern Times: Affluenza (BBC2). Poor dear Kathleen sold her hugely successful business and bought a huge house. Her husband is a CEO and earns a fortune; she has beautiful children and devoted staff; she even looks like Lauren Hutton - and yet Kathleen was not happy. Sensible British viewers would diagnose instantly that this was because she didn't know she was born; American experts, sensing a dollar, diagnosed "Sudden Wealth Syndrome" and invited Kathleen to get some therapy. Therapy is a guaranteed cure for Sudden Wealth Syndrome - it costs so much that money should no longer be a problem after about six months. And so Kathleen bleated about her empty life, about how she daren't leave the house lest the housekeeper steals the children's affection, and finally settled for a form of therapy that advised her to sit down and have a cup of tea quite a lot. Other miserable rich people organised their children's lives with military precision, breeding another generation of loveless over-achievers, then went to therapy to complain about their own parents. One of the therapists made a strong bid for next year's Bafta for most irritating man by nodding, grinning and saying "thanks for sharing that" at every opportunity. The only sympathetic character in the show was Brian, who inherited $1m from his late girlfriend and is now chewed up by the traumatic change in his way of life. Sensibly, he decided not to blow it all on nasty Japanese "art" like Kathleen did. He also had the grace to look bemused by the therapists' psychobabble. It's easy to get a laugh out of British audiences by parading a few foolish Americans on screen - and so, while Affluenza wasn't breaking any new ground, it hit its marks accurately enough. Nobody stood up and said "pull yourself together", although viewers across the land were presumably shouting those very words at their screens. Blow therapists: don't these people have mothers?

fields.headline: Spotlight on Gore the 'fabulist'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore may be leading George W Bush in the latest opinion polls, but the Democratic candidate for the White House is facing a renewed flurry of damaging accusations that he has made up and exaggerated a series of stories on the presidential campaign trail.
fields.body:
Al Gore may be leading George W Bush in the latest opinion polls, but the Democratic candidate for the White House is facing a renewed flurry of damaging accusations that he has made up and exaggerated a series of stories on the presidential campaign trail.

As he prepared to debate with the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, Joe Lieberman, in Kentucky last night, Mr Bush's Republican running mate, Dick Cheney, made an issue of Mr Gore's apparent tendency to embellish his own experiences and achievements.

Mr Cheney said he was "puzzled and saddened" by new examples of Mr Gore's supposed economy with the facts. Mr Bush's aides also spoke of "a troubling pattern" in Mr Gore's claims.

The allegations focus on a series of anecdotes he told in Tuesday's presidential debate.

At first he said that a Florida school had forced a student to stand during classes because she was the 36th student in a class originally intended for 24; it turned out that the classroom in Sarasota high school was being renovated to accommodate new laboratory equipment.

Later in the debate he told a story about a 79-year-old woman who "has to go out seven days a week" to collect cans for recycling to help pay for her medicines.

The woman, Winifred Skinner, had "come all the way from Iowa" with her poodle to tell her story, Mr Gore said.

But last night Republicans said that Ms Skinner was "a rather eccentric woman" who refused to accept financial support from her family and whose trip to the debate had in any case been paid for by the Gore campaign.

Mr Gore also described accompanying senior federal disaster-relief officials on a trip to Texas in 1998 to assess the damage caused by forest fires.

In fact he had been in Texas for a political fundraising event and met some relief officials when their paths crossed at Houston airport. "I got that wrong then," he confessed in a television interview.

An occasional slip of the tongue might be forgiven, but his opponents say Mr Gore has repeatedly "misspoken" about his life in ways which they believe add up to a flaw in a man who hopes to be president.

"I have learned over the years that if someone embellishes the resume in a job interview, don't hire them," Mr Cheney said before last night's clash with Mr Lieberman.

"This is another disturbing pattern, when under pressure the vice-president simply makes things up," Mr Bush's spokeswoman Karen Hughes said.

As this issue has long dogged his candidacy, Mr Gore is now fixed in some minds as a man perpetually given to overstating the facts: famously depicting himself as the inventor of the internet, for example.

Some of these tales are less Mr Gore's own inventions than the inventions of his political enemies. Mr Gore has never actually claimed to have invented the internet: he told CNN in a 1999 interview that he had taken the lead in creating it, which is true, since he drafted a bill in 1986 to extend computer networking to schools and libraries.

But it seems that he can also be his own worst enemy. Last month he claimed that his wife Tipper's mother had to pay more for her prescription drugs than he paid for his dog's arthritis drugs; aides later admitted that the story was a "composite" using numbers from various public reports.

And during September's alarm over oil prices, he said he had been involved politically with the management of US strategic petroleum reserves since they were first established. In fact, the reserve was set up more than two years before he was elected to Congress.

webTitle: Bodies found in hunt for family

fields.headline: Bodies found in hunt for mother and children
fields.trailText: Police investigating the disappearance of a woman and her four teenage children will this morning begin removing human remains from an isolated field six miles from a garden woodshed where three bodies were found yesterday.
fields.body:
Police investigating the disappearance of a woman and her four teenage children will this morning begin removing human remains from an isolated field six miles from a garden woodshed where three bodies were found yesterday.

A murder inquiry was launched after the first body was discovered beneath a pile of firewood in the shed in the west Cornwall hamlet of Carnkie early yesterday. Another two bodies were found later.

Investigators could not confirm the age or sex of the three bodies, which are believed to have lain there for up to four weeks.

The discovery has horrified friends and neighbours of Lesley Ford, 36, who disappeared more than a month ago with the four teenage children from her first marriage. Mrs Ford was not reported missing until last week when her brother, from Hampshire, raised the alarm.

Mrs Ford's husband Lee, 33, with whom she has two children, was interviewed about her disappearance after she was reported missing and told police his wife had left home after a family argument.

He is being questioned at Camborne police station on suspicion of murder.

The couple's children, Leanne, three, and Kieran, nine, are being looked after by relatives in Shropshire. Both are said to be safe and well.

Detectives, who began a thorough examination of the family bungalow two days ago, yesterday extended their search to a recently ploughed wheat field at Treluswell, near Penryn, after interviewing Mr Ford.

A large area around the field has been sealed off and a tent erected over the spot where two bodies are believed to have been buried. A spokesman for Devon and Cornwall police confirmed that human remains had been found at the site.

A pathologist is expected to visit the site this morning before the remains are removed.

The bodies are thought to have been buried deeply enough not to have been noticed by the farmer who owns the land, even though he has ploughed it since. He has told police he has never seen any suspicious activity in the area.

Mr Ford has not been taken to the scene. As forensic experts continued to carry out a fingertip search of the drab pebble-dashed bungalow which the Fords moved into only two years ago, neighbours were finding it difficult to come to terms with the horrific events that appeared to have taken place in their midst.

Jack Prowse, 70, who lives two doors away from the Fords, said his neighbours were "just an ordinary family" although Mr Ford, a ponytailed jobbing builder and roofer, was "a bit way out with his hairstyle".

The Fords moved into the £85,000 bungalow two years ago and sent the two youngest children to the Halwin junior and infant school at Porkellis just a mile or so down the road.

Three of Mrs Ford's teenage children Craig, 13, Stephen, 14, and Anne Marie, 16, were pupils at Helston school, while her eldest daughter, Sarah Jane, 17, who also went to the school, had a job at a nearby McDonald's restaurant. None of the children returned to Helston at the start of the new school year in September and it is understood that Mr Ford phoned staff to explain their absence.

Schoolfriends of the teenagers were yesterday being offered the support of educational psychologists as news of their absence from school be gan to take on more sinister overtones.

David Taylor, the school's deputy head, said pupils had ended the day "fearing the worst" for their schoolmates.

"We are all very worried about them. While the police are investigating their whereabouts it is clearly going to be a difficult time for their schoolfriends."

webTitle: Four-day week at fresh start school

fields.headline: Four-day week at fresh start school
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pupils are to go on to a four-day week at a government "fresh start" school because there are not enough staff to teach them.
fields.body:
Pupils are to go on to a four-day week at a government "fresh start" school because there are not enough staff to teach them.

Corby community college in Northamptonshire has been seven teachers short of its full complement of 52 staff since it opened at the start of term.

From Monday, each year group will have one day working from home each week, in yet another blow to education secretary David Blunkett's flagship scheme for turning round failing schools.

Among the vacancies waiting to be filled are three maths and one modern languages teaching jobs - both shortage subjects amid continued complaints from unions of a national recruitment crisis.

Corby college, produced from the merger of two failing schools, Beanfield and Queen Elizabeth, is not the only one in Mr Blunkett's troubled flagship scheme for turning round failing schools to have had problems attracting staff. Northamptonshire local education authority has launched an emergency recruitment campaign in Australia, the US and Canada, as well as Britain.

Headteacher Jenny James said: "We are not able to put enough teachers in front of pupils to continue with full-time education. We can only apologise for the problems this will cause. We will be working around the clock to solve the college's staffing problems. The harsh reality is that there is no other option at the moment."

In a letter to parents she explained there was "a national shortage of trained teachers".

Another school, Beechwood in Slough, Berkshire, went to a four-day week last month.

The crisis caused a spat last night between Northamptonshire county council and the Department for Education and Employment. A DfEE spokeswoman said: "The government is deeply disappointed that the LEA did not raise this with us at a point in time when national help could have resolved this matter earlier."

The county council said its area education officer, Andrew Wilkinson, had first warned officials in the fresh start unit at the department in the summer by phone that the college was having trouble attracting staff. But it admitted it had sent a letter by post to the DfEE warning of the four-day week plan on Monday, which would have reached it on Tuesday - 24 hours before parents were told. The school is in an education action zone.

The four-day week at the 792-strong school will last for at least a month. On Monday, year seven will be away from school, followed by year 11 on Tuesday, year 10 on Wednesday, year nine on Thursday and year eight on Friday. It is scheduled to continue until November 10, with a week's half-term holiday and two days' closure for staff training.

Pupils will be given study packs to work from home. But Debbie McFadden, whose 11-year-old son Karl is at the school, said: "I think the majority of pupils will see this study at home day as a holiday because parents will not be there to supervise them."

Gordon White, Northamptonshire spokesman for the National Union of Teachers, said: "The school was formed from two schools that were on special measures. They might have been failing but they never had to send the kids home."

Theresa May, shadow education secretary, said: "This shows the failure of David Blunkett's fresh start policy. How much damage to children's education does it take before he realises he has got it wrong?"

fields.headline: Government backs fluoride for all
fields.trailText: The government intends to press for fluoride to be added to the water supply throughout Britain after studies published today which show that the benefit to children's teeth and elderly people's bones outweigh the adverse effects.
fields.body:
The government intends to press for fluoride to be added to the water supply throughout Britain after studies published today which show that the benefit to children's teeth and elderly people's bones outweigh the adverse effects.

Health minister Lord Hunt drew support for the move from scientific papers published in today's British Medical Journal, but the anti-fluoride campaigners are unlikely to be convinced. Adding chemicals to the water supply is controversial. The government has left it to individual water boards to decide whether to fluoridate the water, and most decline to do so.

One of the papers published today, a review of the safety and efficacy of fluoridation in preventing dental caries, was intended to settle the question. But anti-fluoride campaigners have claimed it is biased.

But the review, commissioned by the government from the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination at the University of York, which analyses the findings of 214 studies on the effects of fluoridation, contains some mixed messages. Although Marion McDonagh and colleagues found that fluoride reduces dental caries in the local population, the reduction is smaller than previously reported. They also concluded that the quality of the research on fluoridation was poor.

A second paper in the BMJ found that women using fluoridated water had a higher bone mineral density at the hip and lower spine. They had a 31% reduced risk of hip fracture and a 27%reduced risk of vertebral fracture.

fields.headline: Wanadoo drive for custom costs
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: French internet service provider Wanadoo yesterday unveiled its first figures since its spin-off from France Telecom earlier this year.
fields.body:
French internet service provider Wanadoo yesterday unveiled its first figures since its spin-off from France Telecom earlier this year.

First half results showed Wanadoo made a loss of 66.9m euros (£40.2m) while sales amounted to 456.3m euros - at the bottom end of analysts' expectations.

The company expected turnover to grow sharply in the second half. "Bearing in mind the continued growth of internet activities and the seasonal nature of the directories business the group should be able to achieve second half turnover significantly above that of the first half," it said.

Shares in Wanadoo have fluctuated sharply this week, falling almost 10% on Wednesday and then recovering almost all the lost ground yesterday to close - before the figures were announced - at 16 euros. That is still 3 euros below the level at which the company was floated during the summer.

Investors will have the chance to deliver their verdict on the results when the French market opens this morning.

Wanadoo did not give figures for the first half of the previous year.

However, 1999 saw the company turn in an operating profit of 39.6m euros and sales of 810m euros.

First half results reflected higher investment spending as Wanadoo sought to boost its customer base.

It spent 110.1m euros - only 30m euros less than it spent in the whole of 1999. The end result was that the number of active users rose to 1.38m in June and had reached 1.5m by September.

Average revenue per user was €9.4 in September compared with an average of 8.4 euros for 1999.

Page views per month was also moving ahead over the three months between June and September underpinning the group's confidence that second half revenues will be ahead of the first six months.

webTitle: Comment: Polly Toynbee - Pity the poor Tories

fields.headline: Failure on both sides
fields.standfirst:
Pity the poor Tories, caught between feeling Michael Portillo's pain and Ann Widdecombe's lash

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
Special report: William Hague
fields.trailText: For the grand finale, which way would William Hague go? To zero tolerance or caring (but not sharing) conservatism? A dilemma since both soft Portillo and tough Widdecombe drew the audience to their Zimmer frames - none so far finding that crystal definition. But nor did Hague with his "Governing for  all the people."
fields.body:
For the grand finale, which way would William Hague go? To zero tolerance or caring (but not sharing) conservatism? A dilemma since both soft Portillo and tough Widdecombe drew the audience to their Zimmer frames - none so far finding that crystal definition. But nor did Hague with his "Governing for all the people."

The floor was already littered with the week's startling images. Squiffy good, spliffy bad. Fourteen pints makes a man, but a joint puts you in the slammer. No more short breaks to Amsterdam - a positive blood test at immigration within 10 days risks a £100 airport tax. Two and a half thousand more crazed cannabis smokers in jug, alongside the 78,000 asylum seekers to be locked up. Tally-ho for the party in favour of hunting burglars! But nothing, absolutely nothing to explain how they were going to spend more and tax less.

So away sail the Tories to never-never land, where Peter Pan Hague is eclipsed by the two big beasts fighting for his crown. Widdecombe Hook's law-and-order idyll wrestles with crocodile Portillo's penitential tears. The great culture war for the prow of the Marie Celeste is set to become Westminster's best pantomime. Michael wrings his hands and uses "I" and "me" 50 times in his grand audition, Ann stamps up and down proclaiming there's no such thing as "social tolerance". At last the fun is back in fundamentalism.

It's unlikely Mr Portillo has changed his scales. He may have taken a course in modernism, learning that the personal is political. Never mind the policy, feel my feelings. "I", "me", "my" politics is clammily involving, hot-breath intimate and above all confessional. Coming out as gay with an asylum-seeking father - what worse could a man own up to in that fearsome Bournemouth hall? A few sessions of hospital portering, touring Spain to rediscover his roots, searching his soul for the humility, truth and light that come after a great fall - here is heroic material for the making of a modern myth. (Did Max Clifford ever offer any advice?) It was a bravura performance.

But pause a moment to consider his versatility. Remember his last great theatrical conference role, where he used his defence brief for tub-thumping, intolerant Europhobia: "Britain is blessed with very brave soldiers, sailors and airmen, willing to give their lives - for Britain, not for Brussels. The European Commission might want to harmonise uniforms and cap badges, or even to metricate them. The European Court would probably want to stop our men fighting for more than 40 hours a week. They would probably have sent half of them home on paternity leave!" And the finishing war cry: "Around the world three letters send a chill down the spine of the enemy - SAS. And those letters spell out one clear message: don't mess with Britain. The SAS has a famous motto: Who Dares Wins. We will dare, we will win!" From Rambo in 1996 to Cliff Richard in 2000 - another year, another end-of-the-pier show.

So which way should William Hague turn? Towards Widdecombe's social whips and chains, old Portillo's union flag or new Portillo's I-feel-your-pain? Easy. Hague took it all in. But it was a remarkable dinosaur of a speech, a classic hour of political emptiness that would have any ordinary audience groaning in agony. Riffs of vacuous verbiage wove worn-out airy phrases in and out and back again to nowhere. "Making the most of being British", "I'm in it for you ... for the real people of this country ... who look to the Tories to give them back their country ... for all the people ... decent law-abiding families, hardworking families, with common sense values", over and over again, excruciating nothingness. Even his debating-society wit would have made a schoolboy wince: "Less PC and more PCs!"

Where in all this was the substance? More BSE than beef. And yet the dim outline of the coming election lurked within the leaden clouds. First law and order - "No government has ever been as tough on law and order as we will be." Then the real battleground: "No government has ever been as committed to cutting taxes as we will be." This is the crunch, the nugget in the dross. "Wanting to pay less tax isn't greedy" (a George W Bush line). Yet how will it be done? All week they have billowed out an extraordinary list of spending promises.

Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo seems to have been too busy practicing his lines in the mirror to rein in the profligacy of his comrades who have spent recklessly whenever they opened their mouths. More on pensions, whatever Labour offers. As much on schools and hospitals whatever Labour spends, unimaginable sums on locking in asylum seekers. A fortune on more police and yet more prison, stopping what Hague called "prisoners idling in their cells". Undisclosed sums knocking down tower blocks, petrol tax cut, more money for farmers and hauliers. (Hague did a good I-feel-your-pain about a hardworking trucker far from home.)

Where will it all come from? Three throwaway lines suggest a kind of answer. First there was a glancing reference to Gordon Brown's "surplus millions", money the Treasury denies exists unless the Tories plan to spend recklessly like Lawson and Lamont did in the good times, only to bust in the next down-turn. Then there was "cutting fraud", that old stand-by of phoney economics. Last and horribly plausible was the source that got just one brief sentence, a pledge to cut "worthless government schemes". That can only mean one thing, a slash and burn of all the programmes now rolling out, the ones that rarely catch the headlines.

No more to Sure Start for the poorest children, no more counsellors and clinics to cut teenage pregnancy, advisers to help the over-50s and single mothers back to work, the million new nursery, child care, after-school and homework club places - plus all the myriad other "worthless schemes" unrolling as yet too slowly to have earned public understanding and support. There are indeed billions to be slashed out there with few but the poor to notice their passing.

What can Labour learn from watching the Tories? Plenty. What matters is substance, there is nothing else. Less phrase-making, more intellectual rigour. Talk about hard practical things, admit failures, discuss problems, treat voters like grown-ups not like idiots. Let the next manifesto and annual report be nothing but Gradgrind fact, own up to disappointment, never over-promise, never over-claim. Modesty in success, honesty in failure. Above all no cheap tricks. The terrible leaked Gould memo did killer damage to Tony Blair's integrity. Never again louts-to-cash-point law-and-order lollipops: they convince no one. Leave tawdry opportunism to the enemy. Rein in Jack Straw; rise above, don't outbid Widdecombe. Leave emoting to Portillo. The public is canny, its cynicism often justified.

fields.headline: MediDesk targets 10,000 more doctors
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: MediDesk, an ehealth company that helps doctors make best use of the internet, has struck a sales and marketing agreement that will give it direct access to 10,000 extra GPs.
fields.body:
MediDesk, an ehealth company that helps doctors make best use of the internet, has struck a sales and marketing agreement that will give it direct access to 10,000 extra GPs.

The alliance with BDS Solutions, an NHS networking and messaging solutions provider, will enable MediDesk to sell products to primary health groups so that doctors can keep an audit trail on treatments and allow the electronic transfer of information such as patient records.

The deal comes in the middle of an £8m fundraising round, advised by Altium Corporate Finance, and is likely to lead to a £30m flotation or trade sale in the new year. MediDesk had planned to float for around £50m in the spring but the attempt was shelved when hi-tech stocks fell.

Chief executive Martin Leuw said the agreement with BDS would give it access to about one third of all GPs who are on-line. His aim is to become the market leader in providing desktop solutions to doctors and the wider health care community. "Doctors should have up to date medical information on every individual at their fingertips, so that you receive the best care no matter where in the country you are taken ill," he said.

Existing shareholders include venture capital groups 3i and Advent, the healthcare division of publisher Reed Elsevier, and drugs firms including Glaxo Wellcome, Pfizer and SmithKline Beecham.

fields.headline: Logica's £370m woos Germans
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Logica yesterday boosted its presence in Europe's largest IT market by paying £370m in cash for a privately owned German computer services company, Pdv Unternehmensberatung.
fields.body:
Logica yesterday boosted its presence in Europe's largest IT market by paying £370m in cash for a privately owned German computer services company, Pdv Unternehmensberatung.

The deal will be funded by a deeply discounted one for 10 rights issue at £11.50 per share to raise £458m. Logica shares slipped around 6% in early trading but rallied to close up 52p at £22.77.

"We have a good global spread of businesses in 24 countries but we have been too small in some," said Dr Martin Read, the chief executive. "Germany is Europe's biggest, fastest growing and most rapidly changing IT market and this deal gives us a serious presence through which we can sell the various Logica goodies."

Logica said it would also use the rights issue to fund two smaller acquisitions, one of which is an Australian firm called Utility Services Corp valued at £39m. The identity of the other remains secret.

Pdv recorded revenues of £73m in the year to December 31 1999 and has a client list including Volkswagen, Deutsche Telecom, Commerzbank and Lufthansa.

The company employs around 1,200 people; 14% of Logica's total workforce will be based in Germany following completion of the deal. It will be earnings enhancing by the end of next year.

Glyn Lloyd, a Lehman Brothers analyst who has a "buy" rating on the stock, said Log ica had got a good deal. "Pdv is the largest private IT company in Germany, and it was quite cheap compared to some others in the sector, because it was a private company. It is a quality business, with a strong management team that's apparently going to stay," he said.

Founder Wilfred Forster and his family owns 88% of the stock and Dr Read said it had taken four years to persuade him to sell.

"It's been a long courtship," Dr Read said. "Pdv is a successful company already operating in similar market sectors to Logica and I believe our products, services and expertise are ideally suited to the market."

Dr Read said the rights issue had been discounted to avoid the likelihood that shareholders would fail to take up their rights and eliminate the fees incurred when investment banks try to find buyers for the new equity.

The same tactic was employed when Pearson recently offered "cheap" shares to fund its £1.7bn acquisition of National Computer Systems, the US educational software company.

"If we had done a 'normal' rights issue it would have cost us 2%. This way it only costs us half a per cent," Dr Read said.

Dr Read said he saw Spain and the US as the markets where he would most like to boost the group's presence. The company is looking for markets where telecoms and utilities deregulation means new software systems and consultancy are required.

webTitle: Jury told LAPD witness is a murderer

fields.headline: Jury told LAPD witness is a murderer
fields.trailText: Potential jurors in the first trial arising from the biggest corruption scandal in the history of the Los Angeles police were told yesterday that an officer murdered two people and buried their bodies in a rubbish dump in Tijuana.
fields.body:
Potential jurors in the first trial arising from the biggest corruption scandal in the history of the Los Angeles police were told yesterday that an officer murdered two people and buried their bodies in a rubbish dump in Tijuana.

But the "police monster" who allegedly killed a young man and his mother because they did not come up with the drug money he demanded is not in the dock; he is the chief prosecution witness, former police officer Rafael Perez.

The suggestion that Perez, a corrupt officer who turned informer to escape a long sentence for stealing cocaine from a police locker, is also a murderer is the latest twist in a saga that has transfixed the city and seriously damaged police morale.

The trial of four police officers accused of corruption, which started this week, is the first opportunity for the full story of police shootings, drug dealing, bribery and planting of evidence to be told in court.

Perez's former girlfriend Sonia Flores claims that he has not told the whole story of his wrongdoing, although he has openly admitted taking part in the shooting of a gang member and planting drugs and weapons on criminals.

She says that she was present when Perez and another officer, David Mack, tried to extract money from the young man and his mother in central Los Angeles.

When the money was not forthcoming, Perez and Mack, who is serving a jail sentence for bank robbery, shot them, Ms Flores claims.

They allegedly wrapped the bodies in carpet and drove them south of the border where a corrupt Mexican officer helped to dump them in a tip.

A rubbish tip on a hillside outside Tijuana is due to be searched. If the bodies are found, it will seriously damage Perez's credibility, since he claims to have admitted all his crimes.

The four officers from the Rampart division - Edward Ortiz, Brian Liddy, Paul Harper and Michael Buchanan - are accused of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice, perjury, and filing false reports. They are alleged to have planted evidence on a suspect or given false evidence in a 1996 case.

The long process of selecting jurors for the trial has begun but the full opening statements will not be made until next week.

"He [Perez] was no more than a street thug in a police uniform, the likes of which this city has never seen before," Barry Levin, for the defence, told 120 potential jurors in the superior court.

"His coldness, his callousness, his evil knew no bounds," another defence lawyer, Harland Braun, told the jury panel.

The trial is the first of many of alleged corrupt officers. It is expected to expose the way in which one of the police divisions in the city routinely beat up, shot, framed and exchanged drugs with gang members.

Since Perez started making hisallegations, more than 100 criminal convictions have been overturned and more than 70 officers have been investigated. Millions of dollars have been paid out in compensation to those framed or wounded by police officers.

Perez made his deal for a five-year sentence after being caught stealing nearly $1m worth of cocaine.

With time served, he could be free by February, but the effects of his allegations will be felt for many years.

webTitle: Hole in ozone hits big city

fields.headline: Hole in ozone hits big city
fields.trailText: The hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica has expanded to expose a big city to high levels of ultra-violet radiation for the first time, scientists say.
fields.body:
The hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica has expanded to expose a big city to high levels of ultra-violet radiation for the first time, scientists say.

Previously, the hole had only opened over Antarctica and the surrounding ocean, but on September 9-10 it stretched over the southern Chilean city of Punta Arenas, exposing its 120,000-plus residents to radiation. Too much UV radiation can cause skin cancer and destroy tiny plants.

Citing data from Nasa, atmospheric research scientist Stephen Wood said that the hole had grown to three times the size of the US, a record.

Dr Dean Peterson, of the Antarctica New Zealand research group, said segments of the depleted layer breaking off from the hole could affect Argentina, South Africa, Australia or New Zealand.

"The hole won't grow to that size. But as it breaks apart, fingers of low ozone, or filaments as we call them, will go over major land-mass areas," he said.

Experts agree that the man-made chemicals contributing to ozone depletion are levelling off thanks to the 1987 Montreal protocol. But it could be 20 years before ozone levels recover noticeably.

fields.trailText: I applaud Yoko Ono's intervention to keep Mark Chapman in Attica State prison for a crime committed 20 years ago when he was clearly not in his right mind (Lennon's killer fails to win early release, October 4).
fields.body:
I applaud Yoko Ono's intervention to keep Mark Chapman in Attica State prison for a crime committed 20 years ago when he was clearly not in his right mind (Lennon's killer fails to win early release, October 4).

As John put it on the Some Time in New York City album: Free the prisoners, jail the judges/Free all prisoners everywhere/All they want is truth and justice/All they need is love and care/Attica State, Attica State, we're all mates with Attica State.
Andrew Rilstone
Bristol

fields.headline: Sudan aid
fields.trailText: Having recently returned from a visit to Sudan on behalf of aid agencies, I can confirm that there is a very real opportunity for peace (New Sudan rises from the ruins of war, October 4). But acute poverty, lack of infrastructure and war damage have left southern Sudan far behind.
fields.body:
Having recently returned from a visit to Sudan on behalf of aid agencies, I can confirm that there is a very real opportunity for peace (New Sudan rises from the ruins of war, October 4). But acute poverty, lack of infrastructure and war damage have left southern Sudan far behind.

Until now, the world used UN sanctions as the excuse of ignoring the needs of a "state within a state". Now that a settlement is plainly within reach, given the more active involvement of Egypt and the US, is it not time for Britain, with its historical and cultural links, to give the EU a lead and at the very least begin to support basic education, health and agriculture in areas where peace has already been restored?
Earl of Sandwich
House of Lords

fields.headline: Ends, means and genes
fields.trailText: • There are two things wrong with Leah Wild's defence of the parents who selected their child to be a bone marrow donor (Why the Nashes are good parents, G2, October 5). By discussing individual cases in moral terms, as she does, we always miss the social impacts of individual decisions and the social trends that are driving those decisions.

 There are two things wrong with Leah Wild's defence of the parents who selected their child to be a bone marrow donor (Why the Nashes are good parents, G2, October 5). By discussing individual cases in moral terms, as she does, we always miss the social impacts of individual decisions and the social trends that are driving those decisions.

What she fails to consider is the profound issues raised by producing children primarily to serve as a means for someone else's end. The very basis of human dignity, which in turn provides the foundation for human rights, is that we have to be treated as ends in ourselves. By using Adam in this way they have turned him into an object, that is wanted only conditionally, because he has the right genes. How will such a child feel about himself as he grows up? It is all part of a bigger trend, encouraged by technologies like pre-implantation diagnosis, of turning reproduction into just another consumer experience, where we are choosy about which product we acquire.

Imagine what it would be like if it became common practice for any of the thousands of children needing a bone marrow transplant. Once we get accustomed to using children this way, our concept of the value of human life will be profoundly damaged.
Dr David King
Editor, GenEthics News
cahge@globalnet.co.uk

 I am grateful to Walter Kaufmann for pointing out in his introduction to his translation of Martin Buber's I and Thou that Kant said we should always treat humanity as an end also and never only as a means. Omitting "also" and "only" can get us into all sorts of difficulties. These two words may be particularly useful in bringing balance to the Nash case.
Martin Earl
London
martinearl@onetel.net.uk

 James Meek asserts that, as our knowledge of human genetics increases, "it will become possible to predict most, if not all, diseases, and more, either before birth or before an embryo is implanted in a womb" (Now genetic ethics begins at home, October 4).

Surely very few diseases have a simple one- or few-gene link? In some cases complex multigene irregularities may indicate an increased susceptibility to particular types of disease, rather than saying one will definitely succumb to a particular illness. Our environment and lifestyle have a profound effect on disease - whether we smoke, over-eat, have a poor diet, encounter particular viruses and bacteria, drink too much, and so on.
Robert Ashby
Chair, Digestive Disorders Foundation
robert@humanism.org.uk

 There was no mention of the dilemma that the sister will confront (assuming she survives to breeding age) as the treatment she received makes no difference to her genetic make up and she is very likely to pass on her rare condition (Parents create baby to save sister, October 4). This raises the question as to whether so much effort should be put into rare, fatal abnormalities which, under natural conditions, would prevent their carrier from breeding and so die out.
Eliot Wright
Birmingham

 In less than a week, a professor of anthropology has been accused of starting a measles epidemic in Venezuela in the 1960s (October 4) and another doctor has been found with a stash of children's organs in personal storage (October 2). If these problems from years gone by are surfacing now, I dread to think what it will be like in years to come.
Jane Buckley
Oldham

fields.headline: More bald statements
fields.trailText: • It is likely that women in all jobs, not just doctors, will experience a drop in productivity if they take a career break to have children (Anger at slur on women doctors, October 5).
fields.body:
 It is likely that women in all jobs, not just doctors, will experience a drop in productivity if they take a career break to have children (Anger at slur on women doctors, October 5).

In which case, taking Phillip Hammond's views to their logical conclusion, why bother educating women at all, if all we do is selfishly interrupt our careers to take care of the next generation?
Katy Jones
(Hurrying back to the sink ...) Norwich

 If the Tories really want £100 off every cannabis user (Leader, October 5), why not just legalise the stuff and slap duty on it like they do with ciggies and beer?
Paul Whitehouse
London

Ann Widdecombe must be one of the few people in the country who fails to understand how problem drug users get their money.
T Todd
(Former drug squad officer) Abingdon, Oxon

 Don't worry, it's only going to antagonise floating voters.
Mark Rivlin
London

 Having reached no 86, Nagisa Oshima's Boy (G2, October 5), is there any danger whatsoever I might have heard of (let alone seen) at least one of Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies of the century?
Stephen Lucas
London

 Re David Yelland's defence of "bald prats" (Letters, October 5): the main reason William Hague is considered to be such a "prat" by everybody is because he bears such a distrubingly striking resemblance to the editor of the Sun.
Piers Morgan
Editor, The Mirror

David Yelland, editor of the Sun, leaps to the defence of injured and insulted minorities (Letters, October 5)? Pull the other one, baldy.
Jeremy Wallis
Ashwell, Herts

fields.headline: Watershed for news
fields.trailText: • The BBC's decision to move the main evening news has highlighted the need for it to be regulated by an independent communications authority (Why the BBC is gambling with news at 10, October 4).
fields.body:
 The BBC's decision to move the main evening news has highlighted the need for it to be regulated by an independent communications authority (Why the BBC is gambling with news at 10, October 4).

This is a piecemeal decision taken by the BBC, which largely regulates itself, and we now have the possibility of the BBC and ITN going head to head with their main evening news, thus limiting viewer choice. The anticipated communications white paper provides the government with an opportunity to include a vision and framework for public service broadcasting which will have as its focus the interest of consumers.
Anna Bradley
National Consumer Council

 When News At 10 moved, two reasons were given. The first was the concern by the ITV network that the 10.30 end of the news had become a natural "bedtime" and lost them a portion of their audience and, by extension, potential advertising revenue.

The other, similar problem was the fixed news slot impeded their ability to show after the watershed films without an incredibly irritating break for the news in the middle. In comparison, BBC had the ideal set up of news, then movie and then bed.

Why are they both moving heaven and earth to establish a news slot at 10pm?
Jon Harrison
London

 Why is the BBC's plan regarded as "dumbing down" when ITV was criticised for abandoning its "prime" slot at that time? And why can't ITV now simply retain the 6.30pm and 11pm slots, which it clearly prefers?
Peter McNiven
Rochdale

You can set your watch by BBC television news at 1pm, 6pm and 9pm. ITV's News at 10 would actually start up to five minutes later but always with the misleading tape of Big Ben striking 10. News at 10 or ads at 10? No contest.
Peter Caswell
Warrington

fields.headline: Israel's friends reply
fields.trailText: • Whenever there is a crisis in Israel, your paper turns into an anti-Zionist rag (Palestinians tell-tale wounds, October 5). You have made little effort to interview anyone who isn't vehemently opposed to Israel or Ehud Barak.
fields.body:
 Whenever there is a crisis in Israel, your paper turns into an anti-Zionist rag (Palestinians tell-tale wounds, October 5). You have made little effort to interview anyone who isn't vehemently opposed to Israel or Ehud Barak.

Like everyone on the left, I'm opposed to Sharon's provocative actions, but they didn't physically harm any Palestinians - who used this as an excuse to attack Israeli citizens at the Wailing Wall for the Jewish New Year and Israeli soldiers throughout the territories.

Israel's security forces have behaved like any others around the world ie excessive force to reduce harm to themselves or Israeli citizens. The British do the same in Northern Ireland. Barak has gone further than any other Israeli leader. Relinquishing control over its holiest site would be totally unacceptable to most Israelis, who are likely to re move Barak and replace him with Sharon (or Netanyahu) if he tried to offer this.
Syd Kaminsky
Manchester
s.kaminsky@leeds.ac.uk

 It is disingenuous of the pro-Arab lobby to maintain that Sharon's visit to the Temple Mount was the cause of a "spontaneous" uprising. The riots are the direct result of the major concessions made by Ehud Barak at Camp David, which took Arafat by surprise. It would have suited him if Israel had been shown to be the intransigent partner for peace. It would have reinforced the maximalist approach which allowed him to make unrealistic promises to his people. This approach is a cul-de-sac populated by dreams which have no hope of fulfilment.
Roger Radford
Ilford, Essex

fields.headline: PY's prize
fields.trailText: • Dome in "doesn't win an award it's not even nominated for" shock (Awards snub, October 5)! It's a shame the Guardian isn't interested in the awards the dome does win.
fields.body:
 Dome in "doesn't win an award it's not even nominated for" shock (Awards snub, October 5)! It's a shame the Guardian isn't interested in the awards the dome does win.

This week it won the Best New Leisure Attraction award in the Group Leisure Industry Awards 2000, the travel industry's premier event for excellence in group travel. Not to mention the dozens of engineering, design, architecture, accessibility and safety awards we've bagged.

The dome "stood forlorn yesterday?" I don't think so. With nearly 5m visitors, we're by far the UK's most popular pay-to-visit attraction. Our latest visitor survey, published on Tuesday and predictably not covered by a single national newspaper in England, shows that a record 88% of our visitors are satisfied with their day out. Surely this is the only accolade that matters?
PY Gerbeau
Chief executive, New Millennium Experience Company

 Knocking the dome is very fashionable and your news seems destined to feed the habit. However, one prize the dome did win outright was the 1999 MacRobert award for innovation in engineering, given by the Royal Academy of Engineering. This is the UK's premier prize for engineering, amounting to £50,000 and a gold medal. It went to a team of four engineers from Buro Happold, the consultants responsible for the design of the dome roof structure. As a feat of engineering, this was a remarkably conceived design for a still remarkable structure, whatever your views on the contents.
Keith Davis
Royal Academy of Engineering

fields.headline: Keeping peace alive
fields.trailText: The decision to waive extradition claims on certain Provos on the run is another painful, if necessary, part of the peace process, which, along with the premature release of paramilitary prisoners, is undoubtedly fuelling the climate of uncertainty and grievance amongst many law-abiding citizens throughout these islands.
fields.body:
The decision to waive extradition claims on certain Provos on the run is another painful, if necessary, part of the peace process, which, along with the premature release of paramilitary prisoners, is undoubtedly fuelling the climate of uncertainty and grievance amongst many law-abiding citizens throughout these islands.

One of the reasons for this is a perception that, although the British and Irish governments have delivered many confidence-building concessions to the supporters of both republican and loyalist groups, these organisations have been less than forthcoming. This in turn helps undermine the position of David Trimble, without whom, as you say, the agreement is in serious danger (Leader, October 4).

What are desperately needed now, not least before the meeting of the Ulster Unionist party this weekend, are reciprocal gestures from the main paramilitary groups. First of all, it would be highly useful if there were further inspections of IRA dumps that have not previously been examined and, if these dumps have remained intact, a clean bill of health from Messrs Ahtisaari and Ramaphosa. The second is a clear declaration from the paramilitary organisation that those who have been exiled from Ireland, for offending these groups in some way or another or because they were informers, will be ended. It would be entirely wrong if solutions for Provos on the run were not complemented by justice for those on the run from the Provos.
Harry Barnes MP
New Dialogue peace group

fields.headline: BT accused of depriving poor
fields.trailText: British Telecom is preventing some of its poorest customers from getting access to cheap telephone calls, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
British Telecom is preventing some of its poorest customers from getting access to cheap telephone calls, it emerged yesterday.

Low income families who have applied for the light user scheme, which cuts the cost of their line rental, can no longer make cheaper calls through rival telephone companies on their BT line.

When they try to do so - as some of the 2.3m users are discovering - a recorded BT announcement says: "There is not a fault. To regain access to indirect service providers you must cease membership of the light user scheme."

Members are charged the normal quarterly rental for their line but receive a rebate if call charges fall below £12.48. The maximum rebate if no calls are made is £14.49. The scheme, introduced in the 1990s, is administered through BT's so-called Age and Disability department.

A spokesperson for Age Concern said: "Telephone companies should be doing more for older people who don't use their phones much and watch their bills, and any moves which restrict older phone users' choice and access to calls are certainly not going to be welcomed by pensioners".

The provision of cut-price line rental is part of BT's licence obligation. But the number of people enjoying a dis count has been more than twice the company's original expectations.

BT, whose annual profits exceed £2.9bn, claims it has been forced to act because of an "abuse" of the service. It estimates that one in 10 light users are benefiting unfairly from reduced line fees.

It describes the cost to the company as "considerable", saying it "runs into millions of pounds". The call barring, which started in Northern Ireland in August, should be in place nationally by December.

A BT spokesman said: "This latest move is certainly not meant to be anti-competitive but is rather designed to police the system a bit better, to ensure that we're dealing with genuine cases only." Telecoms industry regulator Oftel says it has been discussing the issue with BT for some time, and admits that it is "unfortunate" that the very people the scheme was designed to help are the hardest hit.

However, a spokesman said that Oftel's "hands were tied" and BT's actions are consistent with its licence obligations.

"Given that the purpose of the scheme is to provide access of telephony services to those who would not otherwise be able to afford them, Oftel is content for BT to make the scheme ineligible to those who have alternative telephone services."

BT has made representations to the regulator claiming that other companies have been enlisting potential customers by saying that they are light telephone users, but then routing all calls through the new network.

A spokesman for NTLK, BT's biggest competitor, said: "Clearly we don't recommend that our customers do anything fraudulent. If we were to discover that any of them were suggesting abuse of such a scheme, we'd take immediate disciplinary action."

Conservative finance spokesman Michael Portillo has entered the dispute over BT's local exchanges. He said the company's power needed "to be looked at" in order to open up the market to other operators.

fields.headline: Trader who lost £6m escapes prosecution
fields.trailText: A trader who ran up £6m losses and caused the collapse of American and British companies will not be prosecuted.
fields.body:
A trader who ran up £6m losses and caused the collapse of American and British companies will not be prosecuted.

John Ho Park, 29, whose disastrous bet on the German futures market put more than 100 self-employed traders out of work, will not be charged by the Serious Fraud Office.

But the old Etonian may still face action by the Securities and Futures Authority, which has the power to fine and expel him from the trading register.

The news comes two days after another rogue trader, Stephen Humphries, was jailed for three years and nine months after running up £750,000 losses which destroyed the finance house, Sussex Futures.

He was prosecuted under the Companies Act.

Park had been a City high-flier in the mid-1990s, spending five years with Credit Suisse First Boston before branching out on his own in 1997. He set up Griffin Trading, a clearing agent for hundreds of independent traders.

But his gamble almost two years ago sparked the biggest financial scandal since Nick Leeson's losses brought Barings Bank to its knees in 1995.

The Cambridge university-educated trader left a trail of destruction after continuing to trade when the market had turned against him.

Just before Christmas 1998, Mr Park took a bet on the German futures market - which left a multimillion-pound hole in Griffin.

Traders at Griffin saw money they had deposited to cover their own dealings used to pay for Mr Park's disasterous punt.

The Securities and Futures Authority shut down the London branch of Griffin, while the Chicago-based parent filed for bankruptcy a day later.

When his actions were exposed Park fled his London home and went into hiding.

The news comes two days after another rogue trader, Stephen Humphries, was jailed for three years and nine months after running up £750,000 losses which destroyed the finance house, Sussex Futures. He was prosecuted under the Companies Act. Park had been a City high-flier in the mid-1990s, spending five years with Credit Suisse First Boston before branching out on his own in 1997. He set up Griffin Trading, a clearing agent for hundreds of independent traders. But his gamble almost two years ago sparked the biggest financial scandal since Nick Leeson's losses brought Barings Bank to its knees in 1995. The Cambridge university-educated trader left a trail of destruction after continuing to trade when the market had turned against him. Just before Christmas 1998, Mr Park took a bet on the German futures market - which left a multimillion-pound hole in Griffin. Traders at Griffin saw money they had deposited to cover their own dealings used to pay for Mr Park's disasterous punt. The Securities and Futures Authority shut down the London branch of Griffin, while the Chicago-based parent filed for bankruptcy a day later. When his actions were exposed Park fled his London home and went into hiding.

webTitle: Former Sotheby's chief admits price fixing scandal

fields.headline: Former Sotheby's chief admits price fixing scandal
fields.trailText: Diana Brooks, once the most powerful woman in the international art world, pleaded guilty in a Manhattan court room yesterday to charges relating to a price fixing scandal involving the world's two biggest art auction houses.
fields.body:
Diana Brooks, once the most powerful woman in the international art world, pleaded guilty in a Manhattan court room yesterday to charges relating to a price fixing scandal involving the world's two biggest art auction houses.

The former chief executive of Sotheby's appeared in court after reaching a plea-bargaining agreement with the US government's justice department after a three-year multimillion-dollar investigation into allegations that Sotheby's and Christie's colluded to fix prices for sellers of works of art. After a long line of defendants wearing regulation cell block outfits appeared before a New York judge yesterday, Ms Brooks stood up in a tailored black outfit and said: "I will be pleading guilty."

Her lawyers confirmed after the brief hearing that Ms Brooks has agreed to give details of her involvement in an anti-trust conspiracy which cost customers of both auction houses hundreds of millions of dollars.

Her plea could end in a three-year prison sentence and a heavy fine. The heaviest penalty could be $1bn, double the estimated losses suffered by the victims of the price fixing. The lowest penalty could be some $350,000 - or any amount Ms Brooks is found to have personally benefited from.

Her decision to co-operate with government investigators marks the end of eight months of negotiations after her resignation from Sotheby's in February as the price fixing allegations came to light.

Her agreement with the government could include her turning witness against her former boss, Alfred Taubman, the multimillionaire real estate developer who resigned as chairman of Sotheby's in Feb ruary. He has previously denied any wrongdoing.

Last month Christie's and Sotheby's agreed to pay a $512m civil settlement to aggrieved auction customers.

Mr Taubman, 75 - who is a significant shareholder of Sotheby's - has already agreed to pay $156m of this. He will also pay $30m to settle a legal action brought by Sotheby's shareholders.

In a separate deal yesterday, Sotheby's was also expected to plead guilty to anti-trust violations and to pay a fine of $45m.

The criminal case against Ms Brooks and Sotheby's could take some time to complete. Ms Brooks, 50, was granted bail with no travel restrictions yesterday.

She lives with her husband in New York and earned more than £1m with bonuses from Sotheby's last year.

Government prosecutors tightened the noose around senior executives at Sotheby's after Christopher Davidge provided documents to them after resigning from Christie's on Christmas Eve.

Christie's is understood to have received conditional amnesty from the criminal investigation as long as it continues to cooperate.

fields.headline: Surprise Lib-Lab coalition in Wales
fields.standfirst:
Special report: devolution in Wales
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats and Labour sprung a surprise last night by announcing they were forming a coalition government in Wales to match the similar partnership administration in Scotland.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats and Labour sprung a surprise last night by announcing they were forming a coalition government in Wales to match the similar partnership administration in Scotland.

The deal, announced yesterday, includes nearly 100 joint pledges and follows months of private negotiations between Rhodri Morgan, the Labour Welsh assembly leader, an advocate of coalition, and the Liberal Democrats. The deal was approved by Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy, who agreed it had no implications for closer cooperation at Westminster.

The deal, due to last until the next Welsh assembly elections in 2003, will give the Liberal Democrats two seats on the six strong Welsh executive. Labour has also conceded an inquiry into higher education funding in Wales, similar to the inquiry in Scotland which led to the replacement of tuition fees with a graduate tax.

As part of the annual budget due to be introduced in the assembly in the next few weeks, Labour has also agreed to free dental checks, free prescription charges for under 25s, and below-inflation council tax increases in the spring. Liberal Democrats claimed these as negotiating victories, but Labour claimed the measures had been made possible by a generous settlement in the spending review next summer.

Mr Morgan has also accepted a review to look at proportional representation for local government in Wales, which could end the sometimes damaging Labour monopoly in South Wales councils. Mr Morgan made clear his personal support for coalition government as soon as he took over the leadership from Alun Michael in the spring.

With Labour three short of an overall majority, Mr Morgan regarded coalition as the only way to end political instability and the repeated votes of no confidence which were undermining public support for devolution. The deal is subject to the agreement of the Welsh Liberal Democrat conference in a fortnight.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe's new biography by Nicholas Kochan enables readers to flesh out more fully someone who otherwise appears to be a loony rightwing caricature.
fields.body:
 Ann Widdecombe's new biography by Nicholas Kochan enables readers to flesh out more fully someone who otherwise appears to be a loony rightwing caricature. We coyly learn of her one and only boyfriend, and their holiday visit to a Portuguese cork factory ("not the most romantic of memories," says Kochan). But the book also traces the source of her Tory convictions: "Her family had disliked socialists since grandfather's bakery had been forced out of business by a Co-operative store which opened next door." (So much for market forces.)

That tallies with the family of Margaret Thatcher, whose grocer-father was politicised by the effects of the Co-op. Spooky...Thatcher and Widdecombe, all the fault of the Co-op! "Yes, we'll apologise for inflicting Margaret Thatcher and Ann Widdecombe on the country," said Martin Hudson, head of PR for the Co-op. And do you promise not to do it again? "We'll bear it in mind when we open a new store," says Martin. Thank you.

 Meanwhile there's an outbreak of political unity in Smith Square, home to Tory Central Office and the Ministry of Agriculture. Agricultural minister Nick Brown and his Tory shadow Tim Yeo both backed a weekly "farmers' market" in the square - giving hard-pressed sons and daughters of the soil a chance to flog veg to city folk. But Tory-controlled Westminster council has turned the plan down - apparently because it was worried about losing income from parking meters.

 There's nothing funny about bowel cancer, of course, but inspired by Prince Charles' declaration on Wednesday that the British are reluctant to talk about their bottoms, we ring No 10 to inquire about Tony Blair's bowels. Was Mr Tony going to take part in the fundraising day planned for November 3? "I could really say it's only October 5," replies an insolent young pup in the press office. So is Mr Tony reluctant to deal with bowels and bottoms? "Look, what part of the Guardian are you from?" Well, the Diary..."I see," she said primly. Getting back to bottoms... "Look, quite frankly I have much more important things to do right now than talk to you about this." Click, brrr. It seems Prince Charles is spot on about the reluctance, at least in Downing Street.

 Extraordinary stuff from the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. "Unique Dacre beasts saved for the nation," reads the news release. Steady on. Paul Dacre may be a unique rightwing beast of an editor of the Daily Mail, but he shouldn't go in the V&A.

 Howard Flight, the Tory MP for Arundel, has been lobbying other MPs to back Patrick Cormack for Speaker of the Commons, as replacement for Betty Boothroyd. But Howard has a very weird idea of supporting a candidate: "While some may accuse him of pomposity," writes Howard, "I feel he also has a dry sense of humour." Also? With friends like that, Patrick's a shoo-in.

 A frothtastic press release arrives about the world's most nutty professor, Kevin Warwick of Reading University (a man who has done for cybernetics what Slobodan Milosevic has done for democracy) and his barmy plan to insert a microchip into his and wife Irena's bodies. "Read your partner's mind with new microchip," says the headline. Wow - but hold on: "There are limits," it says lower down, "they will not be able to read each other's minds." For Kevin's sake let's hope the experiment is much more successful than his hilarious 1993 attempt to build a robot arm that mimicked a human one - but was unable to hold a teacup.

 Finally, to our readers in Ashkhabad, happy Turkmenistan Remembrance Day. Turkmenistan has more public holidays than any other country, including Horse Day, Carpet Day, and (of course) Melon Day.

fields.headline: Lea Parkinson
fields.trailText: Lea Parkinson, who has died in a fall aged 34, was a stunning dancer, a talented choreographer and an inspirational teacher, who came knocking on the door of the Lowry Centre when the project was in its infancy.
fields.body:
Lea Parkinson, who has died in a fall aged 34, was a stunning dancer, a talented choreographer and an inspirational teacher, who came knocking on the door of the Lowry Centre when the project, on Salford Quays, at the heart of Manchester's waterways, was in its infancy. His work embodied everything the Lowry stands for: artistic excellence made accessible to all.

Lea described himself as the Mancunian son of a boxer. He studied dance at Dartington College of Arts and Middlesex University, before becoming a founder member of the acclaimed CandoCo dance company, some of whose dancers perform in their wheelchairs. He was a pillar of the company - gentle, patient and an exceptional teacher, as Adam Benjamin, CandoCo's joint artistic director observed.

He continued to support CandoCo long after he left, bringing them to the Lowry for its opening season earlier this year. In 1992, he joined the V-TOL Dance Company, performing and teaching across Britain and Europe, which, once again, he continued to support long after he left.

Lea's career as a dancer, film-maker and, above all, talented educator, made him the ideal choice to head the Lowry's ALL arts team. He used dance not only to entertain conventional audiences but to bring freedom, beauty and creativity to the lives of some of society's most disadvantaged people. The Lowry's opening week ended with Paris Opera Ballet, but on its first three nights, To You, a work performed by professional dancers and large numbers of the local community, celebrated the centre as a place of hope and rebirth for inner-city Salford. To You was Lea's inspiration, and he was its driving force.

"To be a good teacher - and a good parent - you need a big imagination and a lot of love," he said. His talent lives on in the many Lowry projects he led. He was someone whom everybody loved. He leaves his partner, Maria, and three young children, Rosie, Ruby and Lilly.

 Lea Parkinson, dancer, choreographer and teacher, born March 1966; died October 1 2000

fields.headline: Francisco Madariaga
fields.standfirst: Poetic voice of Argentina's wild, sub-tropical northern lands
fields.trailText: The landscape of Argentina's sub-tropical northern state, Corrientes - the Iberá - became the source of the visionary poetry of Francisco Madariaga, who has died aged 73.
fields.body:
The landscape of Argentina's sub-tropical northern state, Corrientes - the Iberá - became the source of the visionary poetry of Francisco Madariaga, who has died aged 73.

He lived between noisy, booming Buenos Aires and a hut some 15km from Santa Rosa in Corrientes. All his poetry, with its flashes of tropical intensities, was written from that very urban city to ward off anguish.

Though born in the capital, Madariaga moved early to a Corrientes village, only returning to Buenos Aires when he was 15. Corrientes is Argentina's Mesopotamia; it lies between two vast rivers, the Paraná and the Uruguay, is dotted with shallow lakes, swamps, dunes and palm trees, and is populated by alligators, wild horses and snakes. It remains wild and backwards even today, with a history of violence and lawlessness, "a lush anachronism of colours and smells".

When I first met Madariaga in 1970, he offered me some cigars he had made, and invited me to visit him in the wilds. A reticent man, he spoke Spanish with a sing-song, and learnt Guarani, the regional Indian language, perfectly, sprinkling his poems with the odd Guarani words, while citing Rimbaud, DH Lawrence and Hölderlin. He blended peasant and sophisticate, linking him with writers of the American hinterlands, like Mexico's Juan Rulfo and Brazil's João Guimarães Rosa.

Madariaga once awkwardly identified himself in a poem as "beduin-gauchi-afro-hispano-guaraní" (Bedouin-Gaucho-Afro-Hispanic-Guarani). Tall, skinny and striking, with a delightful laugh, he refused to join respectable Buenos Aires literary life. On another time when we met, in 1977, he was a night porter. This deliberately marginal stance was reflected in his devotion to a kind of poetry that could be loosely described as ethically surrealist, in that he never betrayed his poetic values, nor watered down his work for easy reading.

He began publishing poems in 1943; his first collection, El pequeño patíbulo (Small Gallows), appeared in 1954, by which time his staccato and aphoristic constants were already evident. He followed this in 1960 with Las jaulas del sol (The Cages Of Sun), and in 1963 came El delito natal (Birth Crime). In 1973, there was, among others, Tembladerales de oro (Golden Quagmires), and he collected all his poems in El tren casi fluvial (The Almost Fluvial Train), which was published in Mexico and Argentina in 1987. His last book, in 1998, was Aroma de apariciones, (Aroma Of Appearances).

Although he published continuously, Madariaga's total output was small, and exclusively poetic. He never col lected the chronicles of his travels, by canoe and horseback, around his beloved backlands. On a postcard to me, he once described his work as "travel notes from canoes, trains and horses".

As well as celebrating the inaccessible Corrientes landscape, Madariaga evoked the way intense sensations - light, touch, smells, images - could be trapped in words without betraying them, a kind of sensual candour or erotic emotionalism. His short poem The Wood, translated by Anthony Edkins, captures this visionary energy:

A pot
boiling blood
in winter.
Region where
red fire-drinking
whores urinate.

Madariaga was a singer of love and women, and was anti-intellectual - or "anti-verbal", as he wrote in a poem. For him, the shock of direct experience with the world, when it matched his passionate imagination (or vice-versa), could not be analysed or controlled.

His 1954 poem, The True Land, opens with a question: "Is happiness elsewhere?" and closes with a mandate:

Virtuous drinker of the diamond's water, lie down
and rage at the giant globe of the idea.
This blood-drum is your land.

Madariaga adapted surrealism to his own purposes, but did join forces with poets Enrique Molina and Aldo Pellegrini in 1952 to found a surrealist cell, with a magazine, A partir de cero (Starting from Zero), which denounced the philistine, neo-fascist, cultural policies of the then ruling Peronists and the cosmopolitan nostalgia of writers grouped around Victoria Ocampo's magazine, Sur. It was a dotty, and stimulating assault on good taste.

He was a close friend of the wealthy avant-garde poet Oliverio Girondo, and his writer wife Norah Lange and their circle, and later promoted and protected countless younger poets and painters. Though he remained apolitical, he was admirably honest and eccentric.

By the late 1970s, Madariaga's poetry was officially recognised, was sung by folksinger Teresa Parodi, won prizes, and became included in most anthologies of Latin American poetry. In 1996, his work was chosen to launch the collection of outstanding Argentine poets published by the state-funded Fondo Nacional de las Artes.

He was twice married, with two children from his first wife, and a son with Elida Manselli, his second wife, also a poet.

 Francisco Madariaga, poet, born September 9 1927; died September 24 2000

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Balfour Beatty wins contracts
fields.body:
Balfour Beatty wins contracts

The American subsidiary of the construction and engineering corporation, Balfour Beatty, has been awarded three contracts totalling £123m.

The company has been given the $84m Sikorsky bridge contract by the Connecticut department of transportation, subject to final grant of permits.

The project is scheduled to begin in October and to last 54 months. It has also won an $80m contract in South Carolina for the widening of state highway 170, due to be completed in 2003, and a $15m contract in Texas to construct a four lane highway.

Profit boost for Kent brewer

Kent brewer Shepherd Neame's annual profits jumped 11.3% to £7.55m, despite competition in the south east from cut-price cross-Channel beer importers.

Chairman Bobby Neame said he thought the amount of alcohol coming across the Channel was levelling off, partly due to the abolition of duty free sales within the EU.

The company's top selling ales, Spitfire and Bishop's Finger, both showed steady growth and like for like sales at its 362 pubs rose 13%. A new pub in Frinton-on-Sea, the first to be opened in the seaside resort, is proving popular with weekly takings of more than £11,000.

Hopeful trials of eczema drug

fields.headline: Richard Mulligan
fields.standfirst: Brilliant comic actor behind crazy star of TV cult series, Soap
fields.trailText: The tall and rubber-faced Richard Mulligan, who has died aged 67, portrayed Burt Campell, the craziest of all the crazy characters in the spoof American TV soap opera, Soap, with brilliant comic timing and an ability to make his subject both real and sympathetic despite the circumstances.
fields.body:
The tall and rubber-faced Richard Mulligan, who has died aged 67, portrayed Burt Campell, the craziest of all the crazy characters in the spoof American TV soap opera, Soap, with brilliant comic timing and an ability to make his subject both real and sympathetic despite the circumstances. It was Mulligan's most celebrated role in an acting career that stretched from the late 1950s until only a few years ago, as he struggled against the cancer to which he finally succumbed.

Chronicling the lives of two very different families - the wealthy Tates and the struggling Campbells - made Soap a huge hit with audiences on both sides of the Atlantic from 1977 to 1981. In it, the bewildered, blue-collar Campbell tried to adjust to his new life as the second husband of bubble-headed Mary, with her two sons, one a mobster, the other a gay ventriloquist. At one point in the series, he was accused of his own son's murder, and was kidnapped and cloned by aliens.

Although he appeared in more than a dozen feature films, Mulligan found his true home in above-average TV sitcoms, such as Soap and the more conventional Empty Nest (1988-1995), for both of which he won Emmy awards. In the latter, he played Dr Henry Weston, a paediatrician widower living with three adult daughters and a large dog called Dreyfuss as confidant.

"He's certainly different from my role on Soap," Mulligan once remarked. "This guy's a good doctor who cares deeply about his patients. He's a good fellow trying to take care of his daughters. His wife died 18 months ago and he still can't take the ring off."

Mulligan himself was married and divorced four times, having had a son by his first wife. His second wife was the actress Joan Hackett, opposite whom he played a weak husband in The Group (1966), Sidney Lumet's uneasy cross between satire and soap opera. His last marriage (in 1992) to Serina Robinson, a 32-year-old former porn star, lasted only 10 months and ended bitterly, with Mulligan suing Robinson over her account of the break-up in a tabloid.

Born in the Bronx, the son of a New York Irish-Catholic policeman, Mulligan served in the US navy before studying to become a playwright at Columbia University. One day, while delivering a play to a community theatre, he was asked by the director to audition for the role of Andrew Mayo, a husky, down-to-earth farmer's son in the Eugene O'Neill drama, Beyond the Horizon.

"I thought, if I'm going to write for actors, maybe I should know better what it is that actors do," Mulligan explained later. "So I decided to do the audition. And I hated it. But they called, and told me that I was the guy. So I did the part again, in pursuit of knowing what it is actors do, and eventually got bit by the acting bug."

Mulligan got his first Broadway opportunity in 1960, in the Arthur Penn production of All the Way Home, going on a few times for Arthur Hill in the lead. Ten years later, Penn asked him to play a psychotic General Custer, demystifying the legend in his revisionist western, Little Big Man. Mulligan, who was superb in the part, had made his feature film debut in a small dramatic role in Love With The Proper Stranger (1963), directed by his seven-year-older brother, Robert Mulligan.

He seldom had a chance to be serious in films again. In the disaster spoof motive, The Big Bus (1976), he was a husband celebrating his divorce with his ex-wife, and in Teachers (1984), he played a nutty professor who dresses up as Custer and George Washington during history lessons, and turns out to be an escaped mental patient.

Mulligan was also in four of his friend Blake Edwards's strained farces, the best being the bile-filled satire S.O.B. (1981), where he bravely played a film director turning a disastrous family musical into a hit porn movie. In order to pull it off, he needs to convince his female lead and wife (Julie Andrews, Edwards's wife) to defy her wholesome squeaky-clean public image by baring her breasts.

Mulligan, who had just finished in Soap, thus consolidated his reputation for playing odd-ball characters.

 Richard Mulligan, actor, born November 13 1932; died September 26 2000
