fields.headline: No: 1735
fields.standfirst: Debbie Lancaster
fields.trailText: Debbie Lancaster
fields.body:
Can it be? Surely it's not? Oh baby baby, give me a sign, hit me Britney one more time. It isn't her.

But she has the same red PVC catsuit that makes her look like a beef tomato wrapped in clingfilm, the jailbait pop moppet school uniform, the same sultry moves and precocious poses. Are you sure it isn't her? Absolutely positive. Debbie Lancaster is a Britney lookylikey.

So she won the grand final of Stars in Their Eyes then. Well, I can't say I'm surprised. After the recent run of dead rockers and schmaltzy balladeers, it's about time someone with, um, breasts in skintight PVC won. Actually, Lancaster plans to pursue a career as a Britney impersonator without a leg-up from Matthew Kelly. In fact, her mimickry is being facilitated by your taxes.

I beg your pardon? As part of the government's New Deal employment training scheme, Lancaster - a 24-year-old mother of one from Hampshire - has already received some CDs and is expecting a microphone headset and a PA system to further her vocation pretending to be the pop princess.

You mean she has been given money by the government to abet her impersonation of a pop star? Not exactly money. She resigned from her last job - as a Debbie Gibson impersonator perhaps - so doesn't qualify for financial help. However, as part of her course, she has been given study packs about the music industry as well as some equipment.

Study packs about the music industry? What do they contain - a bag of cocaine and a booklet entitled How to Get Off With A Gallagher Brother? Cheeky. Actually, Lancaster is tipped for big things and has backing from her New Deal adviser.

I suppose he'll be in red PVC too? No, he turned down Lancaster's offer to become one of her dancers and is cheering from the sidelines. "She has a lot of talent," he said. Which is why she's not pretending to be one of Steps.

Not to be confused with: Debbie Gibson; Burt Lancaster; the real Britney Spears.

webTitle: How can I cope with my parents' anger after ending my marriage?

fields.headline: How can I cope with my parents' anger after ending my marriage?
fields.trailText: Private Lives: Next week... "My dilemma is that my friends are married with children."
fields.body:
I came from a hitherto close and loving family. In adult life I've enjoyed regular contact with my parents and two brothers and their families. However, 18 months ago, after 24 years of a dull and loveless marriage, with both children having left home, I left my husband.

It was the best decision I could have made. I feel content, my confidence has returned and all my relationships have improved; except those with my family. My parents have curtailed all social contact and regard me with utter contempt and disappointment. They believe me to be selfish and immature for not "sticking out" my marriage. My brothers' reactions are identical because my husband was a "decent guy who did nothing wrong".

I am indescribably hurt and feel terribly ashamed that at the age of 46 I can cry at being disapproved of and abandoned by my parents. Am I in the wrong? My judgment has been shot to pieces. How do I make amends?

Keep your door open

You have the same problem as my husband. His parents, too, are very loving to their children but firmly expect them still to be guided by their choices and values. This is deeply wrong. True love comes wrapped around with respect and support: respect that accepts you are the best person to decide what you do in your life, and support for when you make those decisions. Without these, your parents' love is cramping and controlling. But it is still love.

I suspect most of the letters on this page will be telling you to dump your parents. You don't have to. Clearly your family is important to you and losing them is causing you deep pain. Keep any doors open that you can. Try to stay on friendly terms with them. Write to them. See if they would engage in family counselling. Above all, don't compromise your position and never think in terms of making amends. You've done nothing wrong. Your parents and brothers have, by refusing their support.

Don't allow yourself to feel guilty. You did the right thing in leaving a loveless marriage and ultimately your parents may come to see that. Think about having counselling yourself to help your self-esteem which years of parental (and husband) control may have eroded. And enjoy your new life.
Name and address withheld

Carry on with your life

I divorced 10 years ago for similar reasons to your own, but my children were younger. My parents' reaction was identical. They raged, initially, then cut me off completely, opting to support my ex-husband emotionally, financially and in any other way they could think of (including visiting their solicitor in a bid to somehow remove my children from me by claiming that I was an "unfit mother").

I had no contact with them for two or three years until my mother became ill. This changed the situation somewhat. Suddenly I was needed. Like you, I had forged a happy, new life for myself. I had felt bitter towards my parents and had a struggle to overcome my feelings, but knew I would need to feel at ease with my conscience in the future, no matter what had happened, so my partner and I supported them through my mother's long illness and her death, three years ago.

I have no regrets at all about my marriage break-up and, like you, love my life now. We do not have arranged marriages in our culture, and do not have to live our adult lives according to our parents' wishes. Carry on with your life and turn to the people who have supported you and love you for yourself and respect your decisions whether they agree with you or not.

I wish you the very best of luck with your new life. You know you have done the right thing and that is what matters.
Name and address withheld

Continue to send gifts

Many people stay in unhappy marriages because they haven't got the guts to get out and start afresh, and I deeply admire your courage.

Don't take your parents' rejection so hard. Staying in a bad marriage for the sake of young children is fair enough, but doing so for the sake of elderly parents is plain silly. Their certitude of righteousness would be badly shaken if a close friend, or one of their precious sons, also got divorced, so wait and see what the future has in store. And as your parents become increasingly elderly, frail and dependent, they will realise that spurning a devoted and helpful daughter is a case of cutting off their noses to spite their faces.

So be patient. In the meantime, steadfastly send cards and small presents to every one of your relatives for every birthday and Christmas as a non-intrusive way of telling them that you care. If their intransigence does not permit them to phone and say thank you, then maybe they are not such a great loss after all. Tell yourself that the alternative would have been to remain in a miserable marriage until the day one of you died. Best of luck.
Claude Shields, Bucks

Don't be pushed around

It's time to grow up. Your parents and brothers don't approve. So what? Can they stop your pocket money? I'd avoid them all for six months. Don't give them a chance to bully you, because that's all it is, bullying. They rely on your coming back for more, like a little girl desperate for approval. Be very busy. If they do get a word in about your divorce, try a roll of the eyes, an "Are you still harping on about THAT?" and change the subject.

Your own family, your adult kids, are your most important relationship, and they love and support you, so you know you've done right. You've let your birth family push you around for long enough. (I expect you've endured plenty of criticism, from how you do your hair to how you spaced your babies, all humiliatingly discussed in front of you.) As for making amends, well, look forward a few years. Who's going to be infirm and needing care? And who'll be expected to provide it? You, the "girl". If your parents carry on driving you away they'll have a lot of humble pie to eat. Ditch that overdeveloped conscience and LIVE. They'll respect you for it in the long run.
Name and address withheld

It's the generation gap

You don't need to "make amends" for your courage in ending a loveless marriage. But you've shaken up the people closest to you and it's easier for them to punish you than think about why they are so uncomfortable. Your parents' attitude arises from a combination of social conditioning and possibly also religious belief, and as such is probably non-negotiable. In their generation, the misery of men and women trapped in regretted, misconceived or abusive marriages was (presumably) made more bearable by the belief that "sticking it out" was the right thing to do.

The harder (and much denied) truth you face is that love between parents and children is conditional after all - your parents can only accept a daughter they approve of, and that's no longer you. I hope you find the possibility always exists that they may grow to understand.

As for your brothers, you have challenged them (and more alarmingly, their wives) to examine their own marriages. Most women work a lot harder than most men to sustain and nurture love, and what you have done today, your sisters-in-law may do tomorrow. Perhaps your treatment is meant as a deterrent! But the rift with your family is hard for you. I hope you find peace of mind.
Name and address withheld

Next week

A year ago my boyfriend and I ended our four-year relationship. Although I decided to call it a day, we continue to be on good terms. On the whole I feel positive about being single. Since my relationship ended I have developed a new network of friends and I have joined several societies.

My dilemma is that many of my friends are married with children. I have found that if I wish to see them at the weekend, I have to make the arrangements. I appreciate that they are busy, but I wonder if it is worth inviting people round, who then never invite me back.

Recently some friends were invited to a wedding at which my ex-boyfriend was the best man. I had known the groom from university and seen him frequently over the last four years, yet I did not receive an invitation. I was upset that some people who were happy to meet up with me when I was part of a couple no longer want to include me in their activities.

I would like to meet more people of my own age (early 30s) who are single. My job involves working with people in their 40s and 50s, so I am unlikely to make friends through work. Have other readers had similar experiences, and if so, what would they recommend?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. I was upset that some people who were happy to meet up with me when I was part of a couple no longer want to include me in their activities. I would like to meet more people of my own age (early 30s) who are single. My job involves working with people in their 40s and 50s, so I am unlikely to make friends through work. Have other readers had similar experiences, and if so, what would they recommend?  Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. webTitle: Behind the screen Lucy Rouse's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: The suits of the international TV world aren't in London this week. Once again, they're enjoying a hooley in the South of France while the rest of us dig out woolly socks for the coming winter.
fields.body:
The suits of the international TV world aren't in London this week. Once again, they're enjoying a hooley in the South of France while the rest of us dig out woolly socks for the coming winter.

This week is the second of the annual TV markets in Cannes, where programme buyers from the various 'Stans (Kazakh; Uzbeki; Kyrgyz) meet sellers from every nation, including the BBC, to swap a small proportion of their gross national product for 50 episodes of Noel's House Party.

The champagne flows and everyone's happy... as long as they've got a deal, that is. Programme distributors desperate to make sure their show stands head and shoulders above the rest have been known to go to extreme measures. For example, the presenters of every country's version of Who Wants To Be a Millionare were gathered together for a photo shoot(pictured).

And, in time-honoured tradition, the way to really draw a crowd is by getting someone famous to fly down to the resort to plug their latest TV marathon.

Piece of cake? Celeb + Cannes + champagne = PR dream? Hardly.

A paradox arises when the celeb in question will only make an appearance on the understanding that it's a "select" do, with only invited guests and hacks, which won't draw the paparazzi combing the coastline for pictures of visiting alumni ( qv those pics of Robbie and Geri earlier this summer).

One distributor faced just such a dilemma when it invited an ageing rock star to puff its rock-mobilia series in Cannes this week. The star, who'll remain nameless (let's just say he gathers no moss), got a little bit antsy when all 2,500-plus companies attending were unwittingly alerted to his "select" dinner. Things were eventually smoothed over with the promise of extra security. Suffice to say, if you find yourself wandering the Croisette this week, if your name's not on the list...

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast.

webTitle: Gina Newson follows up Virgin Movies

fields.headline: Boys on film
fields.standfirst: Film-maker  Gina Newson followed two first-time film directors as they struggled to make their dreams materialise for the recent Channel 4 documentary Movie Virgins. But what has happened to the pair since?
fields.trailText: Film-maker Gina Newson followed two first-time film directors as they struggled to make their dreams materialise for the recent Channel 4 documentary Movie Virgins. But what has happened to the pair since?
fields.body:
"I want to make this film... I'm going to make this film... it's a big feature film. I want a cinema release in a year..." - Alex Jovy

"My friends said: how are you going to make a feature film? You can't even pay your phone bill. I don't know. I've got a great idea..." - Leon Herbert

That's how the first episode of our documentary series for Channel 4, Movie Virgins, started. And it ended four weeks later with the first-time directors at very different stages in their careers: Alex discovering that he'd landed a distribution deal and Leon still desperate for money to mix, dub and order a final print of his film. They're both in debt. In between, they underwent an extraordinary journey, trying to break into one of the world's toughest industries with no more than a couple of short films to their names.

Usually, interest in programmes like this dies away fast after they finish. But not with Movie Virgins. After the series ended, our phone didn't stop ringing. People are still asking us what happened to Alex and Leon, wanting to know when there will be an update. Both of them are stopped in the street, with people offering Leon cash and cheques, and sending scripts to Alex.

At first Leon was overwhelmed. From feeling rejected and despondent, he's gone to finding an army of people who want to help him. Alex also received a lot of sympathy for what he went through (anybody who saw him being snubbed by Jude Law in Cannes couldn't have helped but feel for him) but he also encountered hostility from people who thought he'd had it easier than Leon.

So where do they stand now?

Alex's film, Sorted, goes on general release today. His dream of being able to watch his film along with a paying audience has been realised. And I know what he'll be doing today - rushing from cinema to cinema checking out numbers, monitoring the response and trying to work out if cinemas are likely to continue the booking or drop it the following week. At the end of the day, the only thing the industry cares about is whether people want to see the film. The decision-makers don't really care that he sat in despair in his flat last summer when no one was returning his calls, with only six weeks to go before shooting. If the cinema chains sense an audience, they'll back it. If not... well it's only about £3m on the line.

For Leon, Movie Virgins has turned his world upside down. He's no longer just - as one critic put it - a legend in his own block of flats. Choice FM has started a fund-raising campaign, and he's planning a benefit concert before Christmas. And when (not if, he says) he gets funds to complete, he's going to distribute the film himself, booking cinemas and touring it round the country. He calls it an independent revolution. Oh yes, and he's starting three new companies - a distribution company, a web site and a music company (for the CD, of course).

The other day Leon spotted Tom and Mel from Big Brother having lunch together in Soho. He bounded up to them. Mel shook her head and insisted: "I'm just a lookalike". Undeterred, Leon told them, "I was on TV at the same time as Big Brother... in fact, one episode of the show was bumped because of Nasty Nick". Blank looks. "Anyway", Leon enthused, "did you watch Movie Virgins?" "No", chorused the none-too-bright "lookalikes", "we were stuck in the house, weren't we?"

On Wednesday night, Alex had his film's premiere and invited Leon. The press started calling out "Alex and Leon together", seemingly wanting a joint photo. It was strange because their stories never overlapped - in fact they met for the first time only recently when we all did a radio interview just after the series began.

Alex and Leon have both suggested we carry on filming, even though the programme may never be transmitted. So, for the moment, I will - partly because their stories intrigue me, and partly because I like open-ended documentaries. The foreplay may have happened but the ups and downs of the Virgins have yet to be played out.

Sorted is reviewed in the Friday Review.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Achavaneran
fields.body:
Achavaneran

The sighting of the latest carnivores in our acre paddock was on the last day in September when we watched a family of stoats hunting through the walls of the old dilapidated bothie. Two wood mice scampering around seemed to be the object of the chase, although at one stage one of the young stoats ran to a poultry feeder and ate some whole wheat.

We see more stoats in the paddock than any other carnivore - unlike most other species, they are active for periods by both day and night. On this last occasion the adult went towards some hens that cackled away; the stoat did not press the advantage and ran back to the old walls.

Most stoats we see leave the poultry well alone, but we did lose a couple of Indian runner ducks a few years ago to what I took to be a rogue animal. In the early days of keeping poultry we lost eggs, and I suspected a human until I saw a stoat pushing an egg out of a hutch with its nose. Earlier this year we also had a family of weasels in the garage, and they were very welcome because of the large numbers of mice they took.

A nocturnal carnivore visits the paddock almost every night - a badger, sometimes two. A bowl of whole maize, originally put out for the poultry, is the attraction.

We think the pine marten visits the paddock more than we think - when we have snow there are always tracks through the paddock, and a dropping I found on the day the stoats visited was full of the remains of rowan berries.

It's unusual get a red fox in the paddock, though. Perhaps they are more sensitive to the springer spaniel in an outside kennel, and run.

webTitle: EU court stubs out tobacco ad ban

fields.headline: EU court stubs out tobacco ad ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: The European court of justice in Luxembourg threw out the European commission's union-wide ban on tobacco advertising yesterday, ruling that the 1998 directive banning tobacco advertising and sponsorship from 2001 was illegal because it was outside the commission's powers.
fields.body:
The European court of justice in Luxembourg threw out the European commission's union-wide ban on tobacco advertising yesterday, ruling that the 1998 directive banning tobacco advertising and sponsorship from 2001 was illegal because it was outside the commission's powers.

The directive would have gradually have phased out almost all tobacco publicity and sponsorship by 2006.

It fell foul of the court because it was introduced as a single-market measure - which needs only a majority vote - rather than one which requires the unanimous backing of all 15 EU member states.

The tobacco companies and advertisers, which brought the case along with the German government, welcomed the ruling.

"It's a huge victory," said Volker Nickel of the German advertising association. "The court showed the EU institutions a red card."

But the British government promised to introduce its own legislation if a European ban proved impossible.

Governments and MEPs are debating proposals to tighten the limits on tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide in cigarettes and require stark new health warnings on cigarette packets. Moves are also afoot to phase out the EU's annual €1bn (£600m) in subsidies to tobacco growers.

The World Health Organisation in Geneva urged EU governments to draft a new ban on tobacco advertising.

fields.headline: British silence offends
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Madeleine Albright's office
Yasser Arafat's office
Ehud Barak's office
Israeli government
Palestinian National Authority
fields.trailText: Arab governments are becoming increasingly incensed at Britain's failure to condemn the Israeli government for the violence of the past week in which scores of people, mainly Palestinians, have died.
fields.body:
Arab governments are becoming increasingly incensed at Britain's failure to condemn the Israeli government for the violence of the past week in which scores of people, mainly Palestinians, have died.

Most of the anger is directed at the prime minister, Tony Blair, and Downing Street confirmed yesterday that Mr Blair had made no statement since the shooting began.

But there has also been criticism of the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and his deputy, Peter Hain, whose reactions to the killing have been muted in comparison with those of other European ministers..

Mr Cook, in his one statement, deplored the killing and said he was distressed at the suffering of the children, but he and Mr Hain have pointedly avoided criticising Israel and have failed to blame Ariel Sharon, the leader of the opposition Likud party, for sparking the rioting.

Mr Hain said yesterday: "The responsibility for the atrocities of the last few days is clear to everybody, but issuing public denunciations gets us nowhere in the urgent quest for peace. We remain very closely engaged in pressing all sides to end the violence and get the peace negotiations back on track."

Behind the scenes, Mr Cook has had talks with the Israeli foreign minister and the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, and yesterday Mr Hain saw the Israeli ambassador to London and the Palestinian chief negotiator.

But an Arab diplomat in London said yesterday that he had the impression that Downing Street was restraining the Foreign Office from making more robust comments.

webTitle: First cinema to rate Grade I listing

fields.headline: Grand design
fields.standfirst: First cinema to rate Grade I listing
fields.trailText: The Tooting Granada in south London yesterday became the first Grade I listed cinema. Its interior was summarised despairingly by cinema historian Richard Gray as "chunks of every European cathedral you've ever heard of with a bit of Moorish Chinese Venetian Shakespearean thrown in for good measure."
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The Tooting Granada in south London yesterday became the first Grade I listed cinema. Its interior was summarised despairingly by cinema historian Richard Gray as "chunks of every European cathedral you've ever heard of with a bit of Moorish Chinese Venetian Shakespearean thrown in for good measure."

Other English cinemas were listed for the first time or upgraded after a year long hunt to find the lost treasures of the golden ages of cinema building, between the wars and just before the first world war.

Despite the enormous recent rise in the popularity of cinemas, there are now an estimated 551 in England compared to 4,036 in 1946.

The appeal for nominations brought more than 450 suggestions to English Heritage, the government's conservation adviser. Some listings are just in time to save buildings which are now empty and decaying, or in use as warehouses and stores.

The 32 cinemas listed yesterday included some of the earliest, with the Electric Palace in Harwich, built in 1911, upgraded to Grade II*. The 1910 Picturedome in East Finchley, and the 1912 Empress Road, Manchester, now a paint store, were also listed. The grandest, the Tooting Granada, was built in 1931. The arts minister Alan Howarth yesterday took in its vast auditorium, with its cliff faces of Gothic tracery, medieval frescoes, stained glass, heraldic lions, griffins playing harps and foxes with trumpets, all under a Venetian coffered ceiling and said the picture palaces were part of everyone's heritage.

The cinema was built for Sidney Bernstein, who called his chain Granada in memory of a Spanish holiday, and insisted "people want architecture with marble columns, gilt and mirrors." His exotic interior designer, Theodore Komisarjevsky, a refugee White Russian prince, gave him all of those in spades.

"He really didn't know the meaning of the word excess," said Elain Harwood, English Heritage's expert on 20th century architecture.

webTitle: Castle's socialist ardour remains undimmed at 90

fields.headline: Castle's socialist ardour remains undimmed at 90
fields.standfirst:
It may be her birthday, but it is business as usual for the 'goddess of the Labour party', once tipped to be the first woman prime minister

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Barbara Castle, the irreducible core of the Labour movement, is 90 today. She will spend the day answering hundreds of pensioners' letters exhorting her to carry on her campaign to restore the link between pensions and earnings.
fields.body:
Barbara Castle, the irreducible core of the Labour movement, is 90 today. She will spend the day answering hundreds of pensioners' letters exhorting her to carry on her campaign to restore the link between pensions and earnings.

Politics has always been a crusade, and age, near-blindness and a little infirmity are no excuse for slacking off in a life devoted to what she once called "inching society towards civilised values".

At last week's party conference, the social security minister, Jeff Rooker, called her the "goddess of the Labour party". The chancellor, Gordon Brown, once ruefully remarked: "She is my mentor and my tormentor."

But she got an invitation to his wedding party last month, and tomorrow he will, among a hundred or so of her closest friends, troop out to her cottage in the Chiltern hills to pay homage. So will the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

In Brighton last week, the prime minister dropped in (with flowers) on her warm-up birthday party, organised by political friends from her long career: 35 years at Westminster, another 10 in Strasbourg.

And the home secretary, Jack Straw (who used to be her special adviser), made a warm and generous speech which went a long way to restoring relations fractured by his abrupt swerve to the right.

Lady Castle has become the icon of 20th century socialism, a full-colour original stepping out of the pages of history books. When Barbara Anne Betts was born in 1910 into a middle class household committed to socialism, the infant Labour party had just managed to increase its MPs from 30 to 40. She was eight before a woman MP took a seat in the Commons.

Her first political message was addressed to the soldiers still out in the Flanders trenches: "Vote for me, citizuns [sic], and I will give you houses," and she has remained unswervingly committed to the cause of the underdog ever since.

Slight and stylish, she has bulldozed her way into the history of the left with an integrity which infuriated many of her contemporaries but which now inspires a new generation. In her 20s, she helped to launch the leftwing weekly Tribune (her lover, the socialist writer and theoretician William Mellor, was its editor). She and the future Labour leader Michael Foot read Marx and Dickens shivering beside a gas fire, and she was a parliamentary aide to Sir Stafford Cripps in Clement Attlee's 1945 government. She was a leading Bevanite rebel, and finally, in 1964, she was promoted to the cabinet by her long-time political ally Harold Wilson.

Energy

Her commitment to socialism and the energy with which she pursued it did not always make her the easiest of colleagues. "If she wrote a note for the milkman she would bring socialism into it," one detractor observed.

But she has left an indelible footprint on the 20th century. She got equal pay past her reluctant male cabinet colleagues, she introduced the breathalyser, she brought in child benefit and the state earnings-related pension. And, of course, she linked the basic pension, by tying increases to earnings, with the nation's rising prosperity. She even built the Humber suspension bridge.

Many people (probably, very privately, including herself) thought she could be the first woman prime minister.

Newly arrived at the Department of Employment in 1968, she scandalised her officials after an early attempt at mediation in one of the endemic industrial disputes by having a whip-round for the families' hardship fund. Within six months her faith in the trade unions of the 1960s as an engine for reform was shattered.

Her subsequent attempt to introduce industrial relations legislation cost her any chance of leading the party. Typically, while Wilson as prime minister tried to bring the party into line by threatening an election, Barbara Castle told her colleagues that it was their right to oppose her and her right to resign (not that she ever did).

"Everywhere she went she made a difference," said the Labour peer Lord McCarthy last week. Critics say she was an activist before she was a socialist. But wherever she goes now, she meets people whose lives she has touched - not only pensioners but women who have won equal pay through her legislation, or trade unionists who will now admit she was right to try to change the law.

Above all, she still believes that if she argues long enough and hard enough her opponents will finally admit defeat. So not for her the demeaning tactics and trimming of daily political trade. Argument, the conflict between rival points of view, are her life blood, and if you cannot fight back, with facts, you are dismissed. "The greatest quality in politics," she once said, "is good nerves."


Labour's Mentor and Tormentor

 Born October 6 1910

 Educated Bradford girls' grammar school and St Hugh's College, Oxford

 Became a councillor in the borough of St Pancras, north London, 1937

 Administrative officer, Ministry of Food 1941-44

 Daily Mirror housing correspondent 1944-45

 Labour MP for Blackburn, 1945-79

 Labour party national executive member 1950-79.

 Minister for transport 1965-68

 Secretary of state for employment 1968-70 and for social services 1974-76, introducing Serps

 Has campaigned vociferously on behalf of pensioners and the movement to restore the link between the state pension and earnings

 She said recently at a meeting of Age Concern: "You must never whinge about getting old, but you can swear"

 Made a life peer in 1990

And the home secretary, Jack Straw (who used to be her special adviser), made a warm and generous speech which went a long way to restoring relations fractured by his abrupt swerve to the right. Lady Castle has become the icon of 20th century socialism, a full-colour original stepping out of the pages of history books. When Barbara Anne Betts was born in 1910 into a middle class household committed to socialism, the infant Labour party had just managed to increase its MPs from 30 to 40. She was eight before a woman MP took a seat in the Commons. Her first political message was addressed to the soldiers still out in the Flanders trenches: "Vote for me, citizuns [sic], and I will give you houses," and she has remained unswervingly committed to the cause of the underdog ever since. Slight and stylish, she has bulldozed her way into the history of the left with an integrity which infuriated many of her contemporaries but which now inspires a new generation. In her 20s, she helped to launch the leftwing weekly Tribune (her lover, the socialist writer and theoretician William Mellor, was its editor). She and the future Labour leader Michael Foot read Marx and Dickens shivering beside a gas fire, and she was a parliamentary aide to Sir Stafford Cripps in Clement Attlee's 1945 government. She was a leading Bevanite rebel, and finally, in 1964, she was promoted to the cabinet by her long-time political ally Harold Wilson. Energy Her commitment to socialism and the energy with which she pursued it did not always make her the easiest of colleagues. "If she wrote a note for the milkman she would bring socialism into it," one detractor observed. But she has left an indelible footprint on the 20th century. She got equal pay past her reluctant male cabinet colleagues, she introduced the breathalyser, she brought in child benefit and the state earnings-related pension. And, of course, she linked the basic pension, by tying increases to earnings, with the nation's rising prosperity. She even built the Humber suspension bridge. Many people (probably, very privately, including herself) thought she could be the first woman prime minister. Newly arrived at the Department of Employment in 1968, she scandalised her officials after an early attempt at mediation in one of the endemic industrial disputes by having a whip-round for the families' hardship fund. Within six months her faith in the trade unions of the 1960s as an engine for reform was shattered. Her subsequent attempt to introduce industrial relations legislation cost her any chance of leading the party. Typically, while Wilson as prime minister tried to bring the party into line by threatening an election, Barbara Castle told her colleagues that it was their right to oppose her and her right to resign (not that she ever did). "Everywhere she went she made a difference," said the Labour peer Lord McCarthy last week. Critics say she was an activist before she was a socialist. But wherever she goes now, she meets people whose lives she has touched - not only pensioners but women who have won equal pay through her legislation, or trade unionists who will now admit she was right to try to change the law. Above all, she still believes that if she argues long enough and hard enough her opponents will finally admit defeat. So not for her the demeaning tactics and trimming of daily political trade. Argument, the conflict between rival points of view, are her life blood, and if you cannot fight back, with facts, you are dismissed. "The greatest quality in politics," she once said, "is good nerves." fields.headline: Oasis profits hit by stiff competition
fields.trailText: Shares in fashion chain Oasis slumped to a record low yesterday as the store group issued a profits warning, blaming tough trading conditions on the high street and the fuel protest for its problems.
fields.body:
Shares in fashion chain Oasis slumped to a record low yesterday as the store group issued a profits warning, blaming tough trading conditions on the high street and the fuel protest for its problems.

The shares lost 16% of their value closing down 12.5p at 63.5p. Little more than 12 months ago the shares were changing hands at 275p and the company, now valued at just £33m, had a stock market capitalisation of £143m.

"The challenging high street trading conditions we experienced in the first half remain with us and it is unlikely that the company's profits in the second half of the year will significantly exceed those achieved in the same period last year," said a company spokesperson.

Last year the Oasis group -which also includes the Coast store brand aimed at over-30-year-olds - made £6m profit in the second half and full year profits of more than £11m. Analysts had been expecting around £12m this year, but yesterday trimmed back their expectations to around £10m.

The profit warning came as the company revealed first half profits of £2.9m, compared to £5m in 1999.

Oasis has 125 outlets in the UK, 17 in Germany and eight in Ireland. Like for like sales in the stores - which exclude the benefits of new trading space - were flat and in the first nine weeks of the second half are down 4%.

Chief executive Derek Lovelock said the market was "tough" and the disruption caused by the fuel protest had made matters worse.

The group's Coast customers, however, seem to have been among the lucky few to have had plenty of fuel in their tanks. Its like for like sales were up 16% in the first nine weeks. Nevertheless the Coast operation is still not profitable.

Some City analysts believe that Mr Lovelock wants to take Oasis into the private sector. "In reality Oasis might be better served by going private," said Rowan Morgan at Teather & Greenwood.

The recent departure of the group's finance director, Dominic Lavelle, to join department store group Allders has increased speculation that Oasis might abandon its public limited company status.

But yesterday Mr Lovelock said he had no such plans and that his finance chief's departure had "nothing to do with management buyouts". He added that he expected to appoint a replacement shortly.

webTitle: Mandelson jolts Unionists with Dublin spectre

fields.headline: Mandelson jolts Unionists with Dublin spectre
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson last night sparked new controversy when he warned Ulster Unionists that they faced a regime of joint authority involving the Irish government if devolution failed again and there was another return to direct rule.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson last night sparked new controversy when he warned Ulster Unionists that they faced a regime of joint authority involving the Irish government if devolution failed again and there was another return to direct rule.

Angry unionists saw his comments as inflammatory.

Mr Mandelson's move came as the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble was beginning a fresh fight for political survival after party dissidents demanded another meeting of the 860-strong ruling council. The outlook for the Good Friday agreement once more appears to be grim.

Mr Mandelson gave several interviews in an attempt to shore up Mr Trimble, who is seen as key to the survival of the 30-month accord.

He told Ulster Television that if the agreement fell, Ulster Unionists faced: "possibly not even just direct rule, but both governments interfering directly in the affairs of Northern Ireland."

Mr Trimble, who has been dismissive of the dissidents' move ahead of tomorrow's annual party conference, is expected to attempt to delay the council meeting until next month. He will then have a clearer picture of the government's plans on the policing bill, and will be able to determine tactics accordingly.

Dissidents want to force Ulster Unionists out of the province's power-sharing executive, where they sit with Sinn Fein, until the IRA begins to decommission its weapons.

The council meeting should take place three weeks after the 60 signatures demanding it were handed to party headquarters late on Wednesday.

But procedural wrangling is under way, the aim of which is to buy Mr Trimble a little more breathing space.

The Ulster Unionists' leader will test grassroots' opinion at tomorrow's conference. To once more unite the party and try to secure his position as leader, he may yet be forced to forward a motion himself at the subsequent council meeting to offer a timetable for withdrawal from the executive if there is no progress on IRA decommissioning.

Mr Trimble, who will also face a Democratic Unionist motion of no confidence in his performance as Northern Ireland's first minister in the assembly on Monday, criticised the dissidents' move, and allies labelled it self-indulgent.

He said that it was an attempt to upstage the party conference.

There is little doubt the mood among Ulster Unionists is swinging against Mr Trimble, particularly after the party's catastrophic defeat to the DUP in the south Antrim byelection last month.

His winning margin at successive ruling council meetings has narrowed, and is now in single figures.

Dissidents claimed their move was about policy. They insisted no leadership challenge was intended.

But Mr Trimble could hardly stay on if the hardliners forced a switch of his policies. The likely choice would then be between East Londonderry MP Willie Ross, as a stop-gap leader, or Jeffrey Donaldson, who represents Lagan Valley. Both men are strong opponents of the agreement.

Mr Ross said yesterday: "I believe many people in the party now accept this agreement has not delivered. Therefore a change in policy is necessary. The agreement has run its course."

Willie Thompson, MP for West Tyrone, and a long-time Trimble critic, said of his party leader: "He is on the skids. He cannot survive.

"This call for a council meeting is clearly another nail in David Trimble's coffin. Politics is about the art of survival, and no matter how altruistic your policy, you can only survive by getting votes.

"We just haven't been getting them and unless there is a change in policy we will be destroyed at the next election. David Trimble's position is untenable, and it's clear he is panicking."

webTitle: Indonesia seeks to try Suharto in his absence

fields.headline: Indonesia seeks to try Suharto in his absence
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The Indonesian attorney general's office lodged an appeal yesterday against last week's court ruling that former president Suharto is too ill to stand trial for corruption.
fields.body:
The Indonesian attorney general's office lodged an appeal yesterday against last week's court ruling that former president Suharto is too ill to stand trial for corruption.

Muchtar Arifin, a prosecutor, said the appeal was based on the fact that in such a case it should be possible to try the accused in his absence, an option which the judges rejected when they dismissed the charges against Gen Surharto.

Moreover, the judges did not take into account the widespread public demand for Gen Suharto to be brought to justice, he said.

A panel of five judges dismissed the case after hearing detailed evidence from 23 court-appointed independent doctors that the defendant was too sick to stand trial and would never be healthy enough to do so.

The decision sparked a day of violent running battles between protesters and the police in central Jakarta.

President Abdurrahman Wahid, who was abroad at the time, said the judges were corrupt and that he would demand a retrial with "clean" officials.

He also encouraged people to go to Gen Suharto's house and throw stones at the windows.

After lodging the appeal papers at the high court in Jakarta, Mr Arifin said: "A trial in absentia should be conducted because this is a special case.

"The presence of the defendant in court is not obligatory or an automatic right. It is a situation where he could appear to defend himself."

He added that the appeal also argued that it was in the national interest for the case to proceed.

Mr Wahid has made prosecuting his predecessor one of the planks of his reform agenda, but has promised to pardon him if he is convicted.

With his public support waning and demands for Gen Suharto to be imprisoned mounting, it is becoming increasingly uncertain whether the extremely unpredictable president will keep his word.

If the high court grants the appeal, a trail could begin very soon, according to Yushar Yahya, the attorney general's spokesman. "It all depends on the judges, but there's no reason for a delay."

Mr Suharto, 79, is charged with stealing about £400m from the state through seven charitable foundations he ran while president for 32 years until 1998.

His critics, including Mr Wahid, believe his true wealth is in the tens of billions of pounds.

The attorney general, Marzuki Darusman is also on the verge of imprisoning Mr Suharto's youngest son, Hutomo "Tommy" Mandala Putra, who earlier this week admitted his guilt in a corruption case but asked for a presidential pardon.

Mr Darusman said he would order Tommy's arrest as soon as Mr Wahid, who said on Wednesday that he would not grant the pardon, signed the necessary papers.

webTitle: CIA and drug firms out to get me, Mbeki says

fields.headline: CIA and drug firms out to get me, Mbeki says
fields.trailText: The South African president, Thabo Mbeki, claims that the CIA is working covertly with American drug companies to discredit him because he is challenging the world economic order and threatening profits by questioning the link between HIV and Aids.
fields.body:
The South African president, Thabo Mbeki, claims that the CIA is working covertly with American drug companies to discredit him because he is challenging the world economic order and threatening profits by questioning the link between HIV and Aids.

The Guardian's sister paper in Johannesburg, the Mail and Guardian, reports that Mr Mbeki painted a picture of an international plot against him to a meeting of 200 African National Congress cabinet ministers and MPs last week.

The president said that criticism of his Aids policy was a foretaste of foreign attempts to undermine his government to protect the existing balance of economic power. He called on MPs to resist the campaign.

Mr Mbeki said that his advisers were seeking to discover who was spreading the idea that he was "deranged", itself a part of the conspiracy against him.

On Wednesday the ANC's national executive committee alleged that press criticism of Mr Mbeki was part of "a massive propaganda onslaught against the ANC, its president and its government".

The government has begun a public relations offensive to deflect criticism of Mr Mbeki's Aids policy by focusing on his statement to parliament a fortnight ago that government policy was "based on the the sis that HIV causes Aids", and by admitting that he may have caused confusion.

But Mr Mbeki angered some of his own MPs by once again raising the issue in private. He told them that because big western drug firms stood to benefit from treating HIV infections it was in their interests to insist that the virus was the cause of Aids.

He then said that the CIA was actively promoting the belief that there was a link to protect the profits of companies making anti-retroviral drugs. But he said the CIA's campaign went further because it was also aimed at discrediting him as an effective voice for reform of a world economic order working at Washington's whim.

Mr Mbeki told MPs that there was a link between the struggle for a better economic deal for developing countries and the "propaganda" put out "covertly" by the CIA and drug companies.

But the Mail and Guardian quoted one ANC MP as pouring scorn on Mr Mbeki's address. "We have a president who is arguing against his own government's policy," the MP said. "And he talks like this after telling us he knows talking like this has caused confusion in the past and hurt the campaign against HIV-Aids."

To back his claims, the president said that a large drug company, which he did not name, had confessed to him that it had abandoned the search for an anti-Aids vaccine but would not admit it, fearing a collapse in its share price.

Mr Mbeki spoke approvingly of a conference of about 60 dissident scientists held in Uganda last month which said there was no scientific proof that HIV caused Aids. He also said that reports that Uganda had had significant success in the fight against Aids was untrue, despite its president, Yoweri Museveni, being praised for bringing down HIV infection rates.

webTitle: Power in prospect for Norwegian right

fields.headline: Power in prospect for Norwegian right
fields.standfirst: The Progress party under 'King Carl' Hagen is soaring in the polls. It wants a vote on halting all immigration
fields.trailText: For the first time since the second world war the far right is on the march in Norway, and real power is within its grasp.
fields.body:
For the first time since the second world war the far right is on the march in Norway, and real power is within its grasp.

According to opinion polls, the extreme right, anti-immigration, Progress party has outstripped the ruling Labour party to become the most popular political force with this affluent country's 4.5m people.

Its approval rating has soared as high as 35% and its charismatic leader, Carl Hagen - or "King Carl" - is being touted as the next prime minister.

With less than a year to go before parliamentary elections are held, alarm bells are ringing and Norway's reputation as a tolerant society is under threat.

The Progress party has won support by promising all things to all voters, and by promising to cut taxes and spend more of the country's oil revenue on improving the welfare state. It also wants to bundle the elderly off to Spain, where health care is cheaper.

As the party has become more popular, Mr Hagen has done his best to rein in some of its more outspoken members and play down its hardline immigration policies.

But his most radical ideas are unchanged. The party's manifesto advocates abolishing development aid to the third world because, it says, the money is spent on "arms and luxury goods" for the elite. Poverty, it argues, is a result of poor countries' inability to organise themselves.

Norway already operates a restrictive immigration policy but Mr Hagen would go further. A maximum of 1,000 immigrants a year would be allowed, and asylum seekers who broke Norwegian law would be repatriated.

The party also wants a national referendum on whether any more foreigners at all should be admitted - Norway has about 250,000 - and it is keen to test new arrivals for Aids.

The party is compared by some to Austria's far-right Freedom party and France's National Front, but it insists that it is not racist.

"We're a new political breed," says the silver-haired, rather portly, Mr Hagen, sitting in his smart office in the parliament building in Oslo.

"We combine the best from social democratic thinking and the best from conservative thinking."

Norwegian society is under attack, he warns, and too many immigrants will spark social unrest.

"Let's not be naive and blue-eyed. If you have too many immigrants you will get social conflict. You can like it or dislike it, but that's a fact."

And, he says, the problems have already begun, especially in eastern Oslo, known as Lit tle Karachi because it has so many Pakistanis.

"We have knives in schools, which we never had before, and we have gangs shooting at each other."

Asked if ordinary Norwegians feel as he does about newcomers, Mr Hagen is categorical. "Opinion polls for the last 10 years have shown that they agree with me."

Akhenaton de Leon, director of the Institution Against Public Discrimination, agrees that hostility against immigrants is widespread and says the rise of the Progress party is a symptom of this. "We have problems in paradise. Police harassment is rampant in this country, and racial discrimination in the housing and labour markets is widespread."

He says he has seen intolerance increase in the past few years. Clients have told housing agencies to let property to whites only, even the most menial jobs require unreasonably high language skills, and black people often find it difficult to get into to nightclubs and restaurants.

"Mr Hagen is a clever populist who is dangerous for society," Mr De Leon says. "If he enters into a coalition with the Conservative party it would be a disaster for the integration process in this country."

webTitle: Father demands justice for Omagh victims at son's inquest

fields.headline: Father demands justice for Omagh victims at son's inquest
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The surgeon who treated a 12-year-old boy after the Omagh bomb could have saved him if only he had been able to devote time to him earlier, the last inquest into the atrocity heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The surgeon who treated a 12-year-old boy after the Omagh bomb could have saved him if only he had been able to devote time to him earlier, the last inquest into the atrocity heard yesterday.

Dominic Pinto, the sole surgeon at the town's Tyrone county hospital, performed heroically on the Saturday afternoon of August 15 1998, when 240 injured arrived within 45 minutes of the blast.

James Barker, the 29th victim, lived for three hours after the blast, eventually dying of multiple internal injuries. His father Victor, a solicitor from Surrey, told Mr Pinto: "We don't criticise you in any way. You were operating under great stress."

In a powerful statement af ter the hearing at Omagh leisure centre, Mr Barker attacked the government for failing to deliver justice for the families, and lambasted the Sinn Fein leaders Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, who attended his son's funeral, for refusing to encourage republicans with evidence to pass it on to Gardai.

He also criticised Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, for declining to answer his letters promptly or adequately.

Mr Barker, who has reburied James's body close to the family's new home in England, told the coroner John Leckey his son was meant to caddy for him at a golf tournament that Saturday, but had decided at the last minute to go with Lucrecia Blasco Baselga, sister of Fernando, one of the Spaniards to die, on a trip to Omagh with another three dozen schoolchildren.

At a press conference, Mr Barker said: "No human being ought to be asked to endure the horror of that day, and to undertake the task which these men undertook voluntarily and without question. This, in itself, deserves the praise and gratitude of everyone, as much as the murderous acts of ruthless terrorists who perpetrated this outrage deserve worldwide condemnation."

He added: "I find it inexcusable that the government of Great Britain has only chosen to give us pieties about the hunt for the Omagh bombers, and has singularly failed to deliver any form of justice to the innocent victims, especially the many innocent children whose lives and bodies were shattered, including my son James."

fields.headline: Higher education dogged by class divide
fields.standfirst:
Drop-out rate far higher among students at 'non-elite' universities

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Students from poorer families are still far less likely to go to a top university or complete their degree, according to figures released today.
fields.byline: Will Woodward and Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Students from poorer families are still far less likely to go to a top university or complete their degree, according to figures released today.

Oxford University continues to take the smallest percentage of its students from state schools, but other elite universities, including St Andrews and University College London, also admit a disproportionate number of students from the independent sector.

Universities that have good records in attracting students from working-class backgrounds often have the highest drop-out rates. At the University of North London, 49% of undergraduates do not complete their courses, and 38% drop out of higher education altogether, more than double the national average.

In some areas, including Norwood, south London and Edgbaston, Birmingham, more than 80% of young people go on to higher education. At the other end of the scale, in Plumstead, south London, and King's Heath, Birmingham, less than 10% of young people go to university. Only 12% of students come from the poorest quartile of neighbourhoods.

Performance indicators released by the higher education funding council for England relate to the academic years 1997-98 and 1998-99 - before the summer furore over elitism in university admissions.

The tables cover the first year after the abolition of the student grant and the introduction of tuition fees, and appear to show an adverse effect on entry from disadvantaged areas, down 2,000, and the intake of mature students, down by 9,000 across the UK. In Scotland, where fees were not introduced, mature student entry hardly fell at all.

The funding council said the national dropout rate of about 17% was lower than in every major industrialised country except Japan. David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, said that did not take into account other countries where university places were available on demand. "I am concerned that after looking at the data last year you got so many leaders of institutions saying, 'It's serious, we must do something about it,' and so little has happened," he said.

Whereas at Oxbridge only 1% of students fail to complete a degree either there or elsewhere, in some universities around a third drop out, including the London Guildhall University and Bolton Institute of Higher Education.

Seven vice-chancellors of new universities in London last night said the tables underestimated the level of disadvantage in London and their success in widening access.

Half of all UK institutions take more than 90% of their students from state schools. About 85% of undergraduates come from state schools. But one in six universities takes more than 25% of students from independent schools.

The funding council measures actual performance against a "benchmark" figure: what, based on entry requirements and subject mix, it calculates each university should be achieving. Oxford takes 50% of students from the state sec tor, compared with a benchmark of 68%. The university that turned down the Tyneside state pupil Laura Spence this year says the proportion of state school pupils has gone up to 52% for 2000-01.

But St Andrews is furthest from its benchmark on state entry. Only 59% of its undergraduates come from a state school, 21 points under its benchmark. "It is inappropriate to make a direct comparison between St Andrews and institutions based in urban areas," a spokesperson said.

Little has changed from the year before, when - according to analysis by the educational philanthropist Peter Lampl - students from independent schools were 25 times more likely to go to an elite university than those from poorer backgrounds. Of the top 13 universities identified by Mr Lampl's Sutton Trust, nine take more than a third of their students from private schools and fail by more than 10 points to reach their benchmarks on state school applicants. Only three of them - York, Birmingham and Warwick, exceed the benchmark.

Lady Blackstone, higher education minister, said the government was spending £150m to improve working-class intake to university. "Every university which is below its benchmark for participation needs to consider what they could be do to widen access."

 Women graduates are convinced they are losing the battle for equality in the job market, the UK Graduate Careers Survey 2000, published yesterday, reveals.

In the survey of 10,000 students, women estimated that within five years of starting work they would be earning £28,900 a year, as against £35,400 expected by men.

fields.headline: GUS becomes fashionable buy
fields.trailText: Market professionals were yesterday piling into shares of Great Universal Stores in anticipation of an upbeat trading statement next weak.
fields.body:
Market professionals were yesterday piling into shares of Great Universal Stores in anticipation of an upbeat trading statement next weak.

Next Thursday GUS, Britain's biggest home shopping outfit, is expected to release a statement outlining its performance in the first six months of the fiscal year to March 2001.

While the performance of GUS's agency mail order business is expected to make gruesome reading, City analysts will be scrutinising the performance of Experian - its credit checking operation and the biggest contributor to group profits - and Burberry, once more a hot label in the fashion world.

Although the company gave few clues as to the performance of Experian at its annual shareholder's meeting in July, the omens look good.

Experian's US peers have been enjoying something of a renaissance. On Tuesday the share price of Equifax - a US rival - hit a 52-week high. Moreover, Experian makes 75% of its profits in north America and should benefit from the strength of the dollar.

The picture at Burberry is no less bright. If the glowing reviews in the world's fashion magazines are anything to go by then some meaty profit upgrades are likely to be in the pipeline.

Yesterday analysts at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney were said to have set a target price of 540p for GUS.

The shares last night closed 11.25p better at 443p.

News that domestic interest rates had been left on hold had little impact on London's blue chip index, which was caught in the grip of the so-called Vodafone affect.

The FTSE 100 ended 47.1 points better at 6,382, with the mobile telephone company delivering 37 points of the points gain. Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 gained 18.3 points to 6,679.2 and the Techmark fell 11.54 to 3730.02.

Vodafone gained 13.75p to 263.5p, as no less than five of the City's most influential brokers issued "buy" recommendations, the most important of which came from Deutsche Bank - the broker which has a virtual monopoly over trading in Vodafone shares.

Deutsche, which rates Vodafone a "strong buy", reckons the company is undervalued and in contrast with its European peers, well financed.

BT , a company many feel is not well financed, slipped 8p to 687p - a fresh closing low for the year. Dealers attributed the decline to Wednesday's disappointing figures from its mobile phone arm, Cellnet.

Bank of Scotland moved up 32p to 642p on a fresh bout of bid speculation. This time the name in the frame was National Australia Bank, owner of the Yorkshire and Clydesdale banks.

Cable group Telewest ended 0.75p higher at 138.5p after a lively session that saw one hapless trader buy 337.7m shares. The deal was subsequently cancelled - much to the trader's relief.

One strange trade that did stand was in discount retailer Matalan . After trading at 617p in the run-up to the controversial auction period, the shares ended at 650.5p, a gain of 55.5p. Dealers expect the stock to fall sharply this morning as the inflated closing price is unwound.

Lower down the market all sorts of silly takeover stories were doing the rounds.

Investment bank Close Brothers , up 52.5p to £13.07p, was the beneficiary of an odd tale that it had received an informal takeover approach from BNP Paribas.

Airport operator TBI closed 14.5p higher at 94.75p, on talk that a 115p a share bid would come this morning.

Elsewhere, petrol retailer Save Group closed 0.5p higher at 59.5p on news that the investment vehicle of property tycoon Jack Petchey has picked up another 750,000 shares - taking its holding to 19.75%.

IT company Sherwood International fell 67.5p to 625p after a number of directors sold shares.

fields.headline: Israeli Arabs enraged by underclass life
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Madeleine Albright's office
Yasser Arafat's office
Ehud Barak's office
Israeli government
Palestinian National Authority
fields.trailText: The protests by Israeli Arabs which have convulsed the Arab heartland, Galilee, and penetrated mixed areas of Tel Aviv and Haifa, led to the worst ethnic violence in Israel since the state was created in 1948.
fields.body:
Samar Zidan sobbed as she recalled her teenage daughter's screams. As she does most evenings, Sukina logged on to an internet chatroom earlier this week at her home in Haifa, only to discover that one of her friends was among 11 Israeli Arabs killed in the week's violent protests.

With a few key strokes the lives of mother and daughter were changed forever. "A 15-year-old suddenly realised we are two nations who hate each other, and that the other one can suddenly kill her friend," Mrs Zidan said yesterday.

The protests by Israeli Arabs which have convulsed the Arab heartland, Galilee, and penetrated mixed areas of Tel Aviv and Haifa, led to the worst ethnic violence in Israel since the state was created in 1948.

Perhaps no death captures the feelings of betrayal and despair that have engulfed Israelis - Arabs and Jews - more than that of Sukina's chatroom friend, Asil Asleh.

For an Arab teenager Asleh, 17, had an unheard-of circle of Jewish friends, whom she met through Seeds of Peace, an American summer camp for Jewish and Arab teenagers.

His father, who described his death yesterday to a hushed crowd of Israeli Arab activists trying to make sense of these bloody days, says he was first beaten by soldiers and then shot in the neck.

His audience, professionals mainly, Hebrew speakers and veterans of peace and human rights organisations, have had their dream of co-existence between Israeli Arabs and Jews destroyed by the security forces' killing of Asleh and 10 others.

It is also raising uncomfortable questions about the effectiveness of decades of peaceful efforts to secure equal rights for Israel's Arab minority.

"Something very urgent has happened in relation with the state of Israel and our Arab citizens of Israel," said Mohammed Zidan, who heads a human rights organisation in Nazareth.

"Even if there will be an agreement in the West Bank and Gaza, if there is no solution dealing with the Palestinians in Israel there will never be a real peace. The situation is ready to explode."

The soul-searching has its mirror image among Israeli Jews. But their conclusions are profoundly, and disturbingly, different. Across the political spectrum, few Israeli Jews doubt that the army had any choice but to open fire on Israeli Arab protesters, and they believe that Arab members of parliament played a huge part in provoking the violence.

Israeli Arabs see this week's violence as an explosion by a community torn between sympathy for its Palestinian cousins and its situation in Israel. Palestinians who chose citizenship rather than exile when Israel was created, and their descendants, make up 18% of Israel's population.

Although they are far better off economically than those in Palestinian-controlled areas they suffer systematic discrimination in jobs, schools, housing and social services.

Since 1948 no new Arab town has been built in Israel, and until this year Arabs were legally barred from buying land and building homes in much of Israel. Their towns are crowded and dirty. Much of their traditional landhas been confiscated by the army and kibbutzim and for the controversial road now being built which will slice through the centre of Israel.

In Galilee the frustration was brought to the boil earlier this year when a speeding Arab motorist was shot and wounded by an Israeli police chief. Arabs say the police chief is racist; the Israeli authorities have refused to transfer him.

Such nuances are lost on most Israeli Jews, who see this week's explosion as sheer treachery, and criticise the prime minister Ehud Barak's attempt to bring reconciliation as pandering to an uppity minority.

The liberal newspaper Ha'aretz said in a commentary yesterday: "What is taking place in the streets of Arab towns and neighbourhoods is - why should we continue to deny the fact - a revolt. A revolt against the Jewish majority in whose midst they live, and a revolt against the very democracy in which they are citizens."

The divide is an accurate expression of the way the two peoples live. Few Jews have Arab friends; there are only two or three experimental schools where the children of both communities study together. In their segregated neighbourhoods in such cities as Haifa and Accre, the two communities live separate existences.

Still, many thought they were making progress. At last year's elections many Israeli Arabs voted Mr Barak. They believed he was sympathetic towards the campaign for equality, which has been gaining momentum for the past five years.

Many thought the Israeli-Palestinian peace process had put the days of confrontation behind them, and that the growing prosperity from Israel's hi-tech boom would gently erase the other frictions.

"I never voted. I never demonstrated. I did not want to raise my kids with this stupidity: should you be an Israeli, or should you be an Arab," Mrs Zidan said. . "I thought I could put the whole question in a drawer."

This protests have shaken that belief. So did her conversations with Jewish acquaintances, which convinced her that a wall had gone up between them.

"I thought that this week was the maximum, that things could get no worse," shesaid. "But now I really think Israelis have a psychological problem of denial. I live in a Jewish neighbourhood, and they just do not see me." She corrected herself: "They don't see us, and we don't see them."

Burden of inequality

The law

Israel grants automatic citizenship and residency to Jews under the law of return, but not to non-Jews

The Jewish National Fund, which owns or administers most of the land, bars its sale or lease to non-Jews

Housing

No Arab town has been built since Israel was proclaimed in 1948. So far this year Israel has refused 22,000 building permits for Arab citizens

Arabs are ineligible for 62.4% of housing ministry grants for buying flats, and ineligible for 68.7% of the budget for rent aid. In 1995, 2.3% of Arab applicants were granted mortgages

Social spending

Arab poverty and infant mortality rates are double those of the Jewish population

Per capita expenditure on Arab towns is one-seventh of that for Jewish towns

Jobs

The unemployment rate is 14% for Arabs, 9.5% for Jews. The average hourly wage is 33%higher for Jewish men than for Arab men

Arabs do not serve in the army, so lack security clearance to work in companies with defence contracts and many areas of hi-tech industry

About 2,800 of the government's 50,000 employees are Arabs, and 25 of its 2,400 senior staff

Education

In 1998, 40 of the 5,000 university professorships were held by Arabs

About 10% of Arab graduates work as drivers, waiters or unskilled labourers compared with 3% of Jews

fields.headline: Rover's market share falls
fields.standfirst: Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: The problems facing the new owners of Rover, Britain's last indigenous volume car-maker, intensified yesterday when new figures showed it sold just 13,005 cars last month - a market share of 3.7%.
fields.body:
The problems facing the new owners of Rover, Britain's last indigenous volume car-maker, intensified yesterday when new figures showed it sold just 13,005 cars last month - a market share of 3.7%.

This compares with sales of 23,369 in September 1999, a 6% share.

Rover's difficulties were thrown into sharp relief by the performance of its previous owners, BMW, whose 3 series model leaped into seventh place in September on the back of a cut in price from £21,195 to £20,130. The company is on course to make record profits this year.

MG Rover, pointing out that its overall sales in the first nine months of 2000 had dipped only slightly to a 4.7% market share compared with 5% last year, said it was quite happy with the situation. "Our sales are viable and profitable," a spokesman said.

The loss-making company, sold to the Phoenix consortium by BMW for £10, said its sales had been affected by the switch from the old 200 and 400 series to the R25 and R45 and pointed to a trebling of Mini sales. The last of 5.4m Minis was built this week.

Overall, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, new car sales fell 8.7% last month - when the X reg plates were introduced - to 353,494. The SMMT blamed the fuel crisis and price realignments.

It said this year's new car market, with sales for the first nine months down just 1.2% to 1,797,755, was "healthy" and should top the 1999 level of 2.2m at 2.25m. Private buyers last month bought more cars but overall sales were dented by fleet managers' uncertainty about prices.

Sales of Renault, Nissan and Jaguar models fell last month while those of manufacturers such as Citroën, Land Rover and Porsche rose. The market leader remains Ford, with 16.9% so far this year, followed by Vauxhall (13.4%), Peugeot (8.5%), Renault (7.2%) and Volkswagen (6.7%).

fields.headline: Nycomed on the slide
fields.trailText: Healthcare firm Nycomed Amersham's shares are on the slide. Since closing at 700p in early July the shares have lost 10%. Yesterday they fell another 14p to close at 629p after CSFB said they should be trading nearer 429p.
fields.body:
Healthcare firm Nycomed Amersham's shares are on the slide. Since closing at 700p in early July the shares have lost 10%. Yesterday they fell another 14p to close at 629p after CSFB said they should be trading nearer 429p.

The problem is the next year's Nasdaq listing of a 10% stake in APBiotech, its life sciences venture with Pharmacia of the US.

Earlier this week Nycomed filed registration documents for the float with the US regulators that forced it to disclose the previously unavailable divisional profitability of APB. After inspection of the documents CSFB has concluded that APB is significantly less profitable than its closest rival, Applied Biosystems.

CSFB reckons Nycomed's 45% stake in APB is worth no more than 242p. Combined with the rest of Nycomed operations, CSFB finds it hard to justify a share price higher than 443p, and is advising its clients to sell.

fields.headline: Goa targets 'drug culture' market
fields.standfirst: India's hippy paradise falls victim to a puritanical state's drive for upmarket tourism
fields.trailText: Twenty-five years ago Anjuna Beach was at the heart of Goa, one of the world's great hippy capitals, up there with Katmandu, Bali and Ibiza. And when western travellers in Goa finally ran out of money, as they invariably did, it was to Anjuna's celebrated flea market they would turn to sell their guitars and well-thumbed copies of Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance so they could carry on partying.
fields.body:
Twenty-five years ago Anjuna Beach was at the heart of Goa, one of the world's great hippy capitals, up there with Katmandu, Bali and Ibiza. And when western travellers in Goa finally ran out of money, as they invariably did, it was to Anjuna's celebrated flea market they would turn to sell their guitars and well-thumbed copies of Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance so they could carry on partying.

Eventually all the hippies went home. But their entrepreneurial spirit lived on and the market continued to flourish - until last week, when Goa's newly puritanical authorities decided to close it down.

The state's chief minister, Francisco Sardinha, announced that the market in north Goa, where vendors sell Indian kitsch, Tibetan brassware, old motorcycles and techno music tapes, was a haven for drugs and earning the former Portuguese colony a bad name.

"I won't tolerate drugs. I don't want to start that culture here," he said last night.

"I want things to be more organised."

The decision came hard on the heels of an earlier order banning the playing of loud music after 10pm. Goa's traditional rave scene - full moon and acid parties up and down the coast - was badly hit. Some tourist managers have reported a falling off of visitors.

Mr Sardinha, who took over as chief minister a year ago, is unrepentant. "I understand the needs of tourism, but the local population cannot be disturbed either," he said yesterday.

But the weekly market, set in a secluded palm grove metres from the beach, has won a temporary reprieve. Last Wednesday, while the chief minister was in Delhi, there was a standoff between the traders and police officers sent in to shut down the stalls. Eventually, after a delegation rushed to see the minister's deputy, the police were withdrawn.

But, Mr Sardinha warned: "If the drug problem persists I will not hesitate to close it down. After it is closed it will be closed for ever."

Yesterday the deputy, Dayanand Narvekar, struck a more conciliatory note. Allowing loud music until 11.30pm was being considered, he said. But he added that he was unhappy about the large number of charter tourists who visited Goa without spending money locally.

"We have found a lot of nurses come from the UK to Goa in December. They don't contribute much. Back in London they would have to heat their places because of the snowfall," he said. Wealthier tourists would be more welcome, he added.

The market was started on Valentine's Day 1975 by an American hippie called Eddie Mazmaniam.

Originally a small affair, a matter of hippies trading portable cassette players and other modest possessions, it has grown into a huge moneyspinner, visited by middle-class tourists and fresh-faced backpackers alike.

Performing monkeys, snake charmers, fortune-telling bulls, vermilion-smeared elephants and a German bakery add to the mix.

Most of the stallholders these days are Indian or Tibetan, though a few more unusual traders can still be seen selling leatherware and old novels.
